headline: DANA REJECTS ARVINMERITOR'S $2.2 BILLION TAKEOVER BID
abstract: dana rejects arvinmerit

headline: U.S. Economy Grew 3.3 Percent in Quarter
abstract: Commerce Department reports that US economy grew at annual rate of 3.3 percent in second quarter, lifted by incease in consumer, corporate and government spending; spending rose at annual pace of 3.8 percent for consumers, 7.3 percent for businesses and 8.5 percent for government; University of Michigan consumer confidence index fell to 87.7 in September from 89.3 in August; economy grew at 1.4 percent annual pace in first quarter; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC., Rochester Hills, Mich., a maker of solar panels and batteries for electric cars, said it would delay reporting its yearly results because it needed more time to determine the purchase price of its acquisition of stakes in United Solar Ovonic and United Solar Ovonic.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Sales Fall
abstract: Fiat, Italy's largest manufacturer, loses ground to its competitors in Italian car market in June; sales of Fiat, Lancia and Alfa Romeo brand cars are 48,501 units, down 4.6 percent from figure in June 2002; photo (S)

headline: Singapore Goes for Biotech
abstract: Singapore government is throwing its administrative might--and at least $2.3 billion in investments, grants and other incentives--behind effort to become integrated biotechnology hub; biotechnology initiative has attracted big-name manufacturers and research talent, but local start-ups are struggling, and economists say biotechnology investment is unlikely to yield jobs on scale that electronics did; JTC Corp is building new $286 million Biopolis biomedical research and development complex; photo (M)

headline: Recession Is Over; Jobs Aren't Trickling Down
abstract: National Bureau of Economic Research says recession that began in March 2001 ended in November 2001; economists say announcement is not surprise, and politicians say it offers little comfort to millions of Americans without jobs; Rep Pete Stark says we have declared victory over recession, and we are still laying off couple hundred thousand workers each month; Joint Congressional Economic Committee says jobs have not followed economic growth, because of increases in workers' productivity; Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Banc of America Capital Management, says unemployment rate is unlikely to fall until economy expands at annual rate of 3.5 percent or 4 percent, sort of pace attained in only two quarters since recovery supposedly began; J P Morgan Chase economist James E Glassman says economy has been largely stagnant because of series of shocks, including bursting of stock market bubble; graphs (M)

headline: Court Orders Accountant To Name Shelter Investors
abstract: Federal appeals court orders BDO Seidman to give names of tax shelter investors to Internal Revenue Service, which will then know whose returns to audit; ruling is blow to accountants' ability to protect identity of clients (M)

headline: Flying Less and Enjoying It More
abstract: Article on some odds and ends as business-travel season begins with imminent end of summer: Enterprise Rent-a-Car says more business travelers are driving rather than flying; Air Transport Association says passenger traffic was down all summer on most major airlines; Delta Air Lines says its airport Crown Room Clubs are beginning 30-day test of selling meals, much like meals being sold on airlines that have cut back food service in coach cabins (M)

headline: From Wall Street to Mean Street
abstract: Interview with Peter Jaquith, formerly rich Wall Street investment banker, on his plunge into crack cocaine addiction and homelessness and his recovery; he says journey has brought him new emotional strength; chronology of events; photos (M)

headline: Calpers Accuses AOL of Inflating Revenue
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System (Calpers) files suit against AOL Time Warner over $250 million in lost investments; accuses AOL of inflating revenue by $1.7 billion through illegal accounting practices; Calpers owns 18.4 billion shares of stock (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Brother Of Qaeda Operative Held
abstract: Pakistan's Interior Ministry spokesman reports arrest of Rusman Gunawan, brother of Riduan Isamuddin, who is alleged terrorist link between Al Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiyah (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Research In Motion Raises Forecasts
abstract: Research in Motion Ltd, maker of BlackBerry pagers, says second-quarter sales and profit will be higher than prior forecasts because of increased subscribers (S)

headline: ABC Names New Top Producer for 'World News Tonight'
abstract: ABC News appoints Jon Banner executive producer of World News Tonight With Peter Jennings; will succeed Paul Slavin, who was named senior vice president in news division in May; Banner produces This Week with George Stephanopoulos; photo (M)

headline: AVERY DENNISON REDUCES THIRD-QUARTER PROFIT FORECAST
abstract: Avery Dennison reduces third-quarter earnings estimate (S)

headline: Swiss Airline Talks With Rivals About Deal
abstract: Swiss International Air Lines says it is holding talks with rivals about closer ties that include possible merger; Lufthansa has reportedly offered to buy it (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Changes to Pension Bill Spur a Political Dispute  More than a dozen Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee -- infuriated by last-minute changes to a pension bill -- left a hearing and holed up in an adjacent library, prompting the committee's Republican chairman, Bill Thomas, to summon the police.    At issue was a bill that would make changes to federal pension laws, including increasing the amount workers can contribute to their retirement accounts. [Page A1.]

headline: Executive Life; New Kind of Snooping Arrives at the Office
abstract: Employers are increasing surveillance of workers' computer use, with new specialty known as human resource forensics devoted to monitoring employees' web site visits, downloaded data and deleted files; legal experts hold that spying on employees is damaging to morale and pushes boundaries of what is ethnical or legal; Arthur G Tisi, chief executive of technology company atthought.com, says companies should very careful about monitoring employees; photo (M)

headline: Bulgari Builds on Brand in Many Ways
abstract: Profile of Bulgari, Italian jeweler; chief executive Francesco Trapani discusses expansion plans, interview; sales and earnings graph; photo (M)

headline: ABC News Executive Leaves for CBS
abstract: Victor Neufeld, longtime producer and executive at ABC News, is leaving division to become producer of The Early Show on CBS; Neufeld comments (M)

headline: MASTERCARD PROFIT FALLS 11% AS EXPENSES RISE
abstract: MaterCard Inc says second-quarter profit fell 11 percent; net income dropped to $32 million from $36 million; revenue climbed 24 percent, to $557 million; operating expenses rose 28 percent, to $507 million (S)

headline: Columbia Business School Dean for 14 Years Will Resign
abstract: Meyer Feldberg plans to leave as Columbia Business School dean at end of academic year; will have served for 15 years, unusually long tenure; discusses challenges facing school, which has gained stature under his leadership, interview; photo (M)

headline: Company Says It Mapped Genes of Virus in One Day
abstract: 454 Life Sciences says it has determined entire genetic code of virus in single day; says it is first time that entire genome of organism has been sequenced using unconventional technique and demonstrated feasibility of its technology, which it says might eventually allow gene sequencing to be done faster and less expensively; Richard Gibbs, director of genome-sequencing center at Baylor College of Medicine, lauds breakthrough; other scientists are more skeptical, saying that sequencing virus is trivial and that there are aspects of technology that might make it difficult to do more complex organisms (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: London: Security Report Criticizes Police
abstract: British authorities, responding to investigation launched after infamous party crasher Aaron Barschak gained entry to private birthday party for Prince William at Windsor Castle, announce Army and undercover agents may begin protecting members of royal family (S)

headline: Business Tax Shelters a Drain on States' Finances, Study Says
abstract: Multistate Tax Commission finds US states lost as much as $12.4 billion because of tax sheltering in 2001 fiscal year; says in 1980's, 9 percent of corporate profits were paid to states; says this declined to less than 6 percent by 2001; concludes corporate tax shelters are reducing ability of states to provide basic needs and are undermining equity and integrity of state tax systems; graph (M)

headline: Executive at WPP Takes Agency Job
abstract: Jon Steel, who has been worldwide account planning consultant at WPP Group, becomes vice chairman at WPP's Berlin Cameron/Red Cell ad agency (S)

headline: Blair Denies Misleading M.P.'s, Saying 'We Did the Right Thing'
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair firmly denies manipulating intelligence data or misleading Parliament to got to war in Iraq; tells House of Commons panel he stands by Iraq decision and believes analysts gave correct information at the time; panel absolves Blair of doctoring intelligence but says government did present unsubstantiated information (S)

headline: Formula Receives Credit As Us Weekly Picks Editor
abstract: Wenner Media names Janice Min editor of US Weekly; had formerly credited editor Bonnie Fuller, who left abruptly last month, with magazine's success, but now credits formula that mixes coverage of celebrities with intense focus on fashions of famous; photos (M)

headline: ROYAL NUMICO SELLS REXALL SUNDOWN FOR $250 MILLION
abstract: Royal Numico sells Rexall Sundown vitamin unit to NBTY Inc for $250 million (S)

headline: Cellphone Companies Agree to Set of Consumer Guidelines
abstract: Cellular phone companies Verizon Wireless, Cingular, Sprint PCS, Nextel and AT&T are set to announce voluntary seal-of-approval program in hopes of staving off more restrictive consumer legislation; agree to adhere to 10-part code of behavior that is intended to make it easier for consumers to compare prices and plans; Richard L Brodsky, assemblyman from Westchester County, NY, who is chairman of State Assembly's Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, applauds effort by companies; describes it as only first step to improving protections for customers who face confusing array of choices and no easy way to compare them (M)

headline: 2 Cameras Seek Bliss As a Couple
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column reviews Samsung's DuoCam SCD5000, single device that is both camera and camcorder; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Study Finds Drug Costs Are Soaring for Elderly
abstract: Study by Families USA finds that prices of 50 drugs most prescribed for elderly increased average of 6 percent last year, compared with rise of 1.8 percent in Consumer Price Index; study is met with sharp criticism from pharmaceutical industry, which argues that many elderly people are able to buy drugs at discounted prices; group's director Ron Pollack comments (M)

headline: CINTAS PROMOTES OPERATING OFFICER TO CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Cintas Corp promotes chief operating officer Scott D Farmer to chief executive, succeeding Robert J Kohlhepp, who is named vice chairman; Farmer will retain position of president (S)

headline: Forget F-Stops: These Cameras Have Area Codes
abstract: Hybrid camera phones are quickly gaining popularity, with 42 million expected to be sold this year and huge increases forecast in coming years; gadgets are potentially powerful as witnesses to news events, but some people fear they can be used for prying or voyeurism because they are small and look innocuous; Howard Rheingold, author of Smart Mobs: The Next Social Revolution, predicts technology will change news landscape, as more users document events; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Muslim Reports Threats
abstract: A Muslim woman who recanted her testimony that Hindu neighbors burned members of her family said threats from Hindu nationalist politicians in Gujarat caused her and her family to change their testimony, an allegation denied by those accused. The woman, Zahira Sheikh, 20, was the key witness in a trial of 21 Hindus accused of burning 14 people alive in March 2002 during riots that killed 1,000 people, most of them Muslims. After the recantations, all 21 were acquitted.   Hari Kumar (NYT)

headline: Nokia Names An American To a Top Post In an Overhaul
abstract: Nokia announces first management restructuring in five years, with chief financial officer Pekka Kallasvuo to run mobile phones unit and mobile phones head Matti Alahuhta to become chief strategy officer; Rick Simonson, formerly with Bank of America, is named chief financial officer and becomes first American to hold senior management position at company; moves prompt speculation that chief executive officer Jorma Ollila, whose contract expires in 2006, is preparing s uccessor; company also announces estimated 36 percent of market while main rival, Motorola, holds about consolidation of its business units to concentrate on mobile phones, multimedia, networks and enterprise solutions; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Cuts Operations
abstract: German utility RWE abandoned plans to buy power plants in United States; will shut US trading operations (S)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON DISCLOSES INVESTIGATION OF DRUG UNIT
abstract: Johnson & Johnson says US attorney's office in New Jersey is investigating marketing practices at company's Centocor unit, which makes rheumatoid arthritis drug Remicade (S)

headline: Investing; As Interest Rates Climb, Must Bank Stocks Fall?
abstract: Outlook for investing in bank shares discussed in light of sudden rebound in long-term interest rates; returns on bank stocks have correlated strongly for decades with yields on government bonds, falling as yields rise; stocks have pulled back in response to current rise, but decline has not been severe; graphs of bank stock prices and bond yields; photos (M)a

headline: Khieu Ponnary, 83, First Wife Of Pol Pot, Cambodian Despot
abstract: Khieu Ponnary, quiet Cambodian intellectual who was first wife of Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot and prominent member of movement in its early days, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline: 2 in Dynegy Case Return to Court
abstract: Former Dynegy Inc employees Gene S Foster and Helen C Sharkey, accused of helping company disguise loans as cash flow, will be re-arraigned, federal court (S)

headline: Instilling the Pride Of Ownership
abstract: Essence Communications c

headline: Business; In Computer Security, a Bigger Reason to Squirm
abstract: Computer security professionals acknowledge grudging admiration for author of SoBig-F, virus that has deluged e-mail; warn that even experts can be careless about opening Internet attachments; photo (M)

headline: No Survivors Found in Wreckage of Russian Copter
abstract: Wreckage of helicopter carrying Igor P Farkhutdinov, governor of Sakhalin region in Russia's Far East, is found on mountainside on Kamchatka Peninsula, with no survivors among 20 passengers and crew members (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Ubi Soft International's United States division gives its advertising account to Kirschenbaum Bond & Partners (S)

headline: Swiss Carrier and British Air Reach Accord for Partnership
abstract: Swiss International Air Lines announces partnership with British Airways, and says it will join OneWorld Alliance (M)

headline: Investing; Making Its Mark in the 911 Phone Market
abstract: Outlook for investing in Intrado, company that supplies most of database systems used in 911 emergency calls discussed; shares have jumped 78 percent this year; company dominates wire-based 911 market and says it has some 60 percent of current cellphone market; stock price graph; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Troops Hit Gaza; Palestinian Forces Battle Hamas
abstract: Israeli Army stages its largest raid into Gaza Strip since its partial withdrawal in June, sweeping into central refugee camp and killing Hamas militant in firefight; later, Palestinian security forces clash with Hamas gunmen in dispute that demonstrates turbulence in Palestinian politics; senior Palestinian official says Hamas members burned down police station and threw grenades; Palestinian Interior Ministry issues statement saying Hamas kidnapped security official and that security forces then arrested seven Hamas men to interrogate them; Muhammad Dahlan, who controls Interior Ministry, was appointed by former Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas; Hamas denies starting fight to test Dahlan's resolve; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Spiked Magazine Articles Find a New Life and Readers in 'Killed' Anthology
abstract: Nations Books to publish Killed: True Stories You Weve Never Meant to Read, anthology of unpublished articles written for magazines; David Wallis, founder of syndication service for independent writers, collected articles (M)

headline: DataBank; Indexes Climb as a Season Winds Down
abstract: Stock market limps to end of summer last week with third-lowest five-day volume of year; but main market gauges gain; profile of some stocks in the news (M)

headline: Warning on Artery Stent Cites Some Cases of Clots
abstract: Johnson & Johnson sends letter to doctors advising them about rare cases of life-threatening blood clots linked to its new drug-coated Cypher stent, fast-selling device used to keep blood flowing through arteries; Food and Drug Administration says it has received 47 reports of blood-clotting, or thrombosis, that occurred at time company's stent was implanted or within few days; adds five patients have died; more than 50,000 patients have received stent since it was approved in April; FDA says it is reviewing report and working with company to determine what is causing blood clots; Johnson & Johnson spokesman Martin E Schildhouse says some of problems are caused by doctors improperly using stent and not by device itself; Dr Lawrence A Reduto says overall incidence of thrombosis with Cypher stent appears to be no greater than associated with stents that have not been coated with drug; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Stocks Climb, but Where's the Confidence?
abstract: Week's stock market and corporate reports reviewed; graphs

headline: WILLIAMS TO SETTLE CHARGES OF INDEX MANIPULATION
abstract: Williams Cos, natural gas pipelines operator, to pay $20 million civil penalty to settle Commodity Futures Trading Commission charges that company and its Williams Energy Marketing and Trading unit tried to manipulate natural gas price indexes from Jan through June 2002 by reporting false trading data to companies that compile indexes (S)

headline: Wholesale Inventories Fell 0.3% In May, Commerce Dept. Reports
abstract: Commerce Department reports wholesale inventories fell 0.3 percent in May, to $289.34 billion; wholesale sales fell 0.5 percent after dropping 2.5 percent; inventories of durable goods fell 0.3 percent after falling 0.2 percent in April; durable goods sales declined 0.4 percent after falling 0.5 percent (M)

headline: Jostling for the Wi-Fi Lead in a Crowded Field
abstract: Wayport chief executive Dave Vucina discusses how pioneer in installing high-speed Internet access in hotels and airports hopes to exploit lead now that many telecommunications companies are rushing into Wi-Fi wireless world; company aggressively resells its service to cellular carriers and corporate access providers, increasingly relies on Wi-Fi hot spots and is ramping up to sell its service in new places; photo (M)

headline: Putin Portrays Yukos Inquiries As an Isolated Criminal Matter
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin portrays probes involving Yukos Oil as isolated criminal matter that do not signal wholesale review of 1990's privatization of state assets, interview with American journalists; denies Kremlin involvement or political interference; at least eight probes of Yukos, Russia's richest company, have begun since July arrest of Platon Lebedev, close associate of Yukos chairman Mikhail B Khodorkovsky and chaiman of Menatep, which owns 61 percent of Yukos (M)

headline: Blair Aides Are Said to Doubt Finding Weapons
abstract: British news organizations report that senior officials in Prime Min Tony Blair's government are saying privately that they no longer believe unconventional weapons will be uncovered in Iraq; say they contend that weapons had existed but were dismantled or hidden beyond discovery before allied troops entered Iraq in March; Blair's official spokesman rebuts reports and denies that government is backing off from its previous insistence that what justified going to war was threat of weapons; failure to discover them has undermined Blair's credibility, dented his public support and turned majority of Britons against war they once supported (M)

headline: Pact to Help Poor Nations Obtain Drugs Is Delayed
abstract: World Trade Organization comes close to approving agreement to help poor nations buy lifesaving generic medicines through new exemptions from trade rules, only to postpone final decision; several countries ask for further clarifications, and meeting is adjourned at organization's headquarters in Geneva to permit more time; US this week reversed its earlier opposition and agreed to support measure (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Announces New Technologies
abstract: Intel introduces number of new chip technologies and reinforces its view that wireless and computing industries are converging to produce new class of electronic devices; one product is hald-held device that can automatically switch between Wi-Fi and cellular networks (S)

headline: Old Kremlin, New Kremlin: It's Still a Big Secret
abstract: Prosecution involving Yukos Oil, Russia's richest and most powerful company, stirs speculation about who really wields power under Pres Vladimir V Putin; clues about waxing or waning influence are even skimpier than in days of Soviet Union, with those who surround Putin rarely even appearing in public with him; Kremlinologists speculate prosecution was favor to one of company's rivals; some cite chief executive Mikhail B Khodorkovsky's contributions to opposition political parties; others see personal motive behind effort; no more is known about motives and Putin's role in probe than when it started two months ago; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Telecom Acquisition
abstract: America Movil, wireless telephone company controlled by Mexican billionaire Carlo Slim Helu, to acquire Brazil's BCP wireless company for $625 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.E.C. Seeks to Keep Ban on Old Advisers' New Role in Bankruptcies
abstract: Wall Street firms' efforts to persuade Congress to let them earn fees advising same companies in bankruptcy that they counseled in better days have met with opposition from Securities and Exchange Commission; SEC chairman William H Donaldson has written letter expressing his agency's opposition to proposed change in bankruptcy law approved in House in March; provision would allow investment bankers that have done business with copmany to advise it even after company has filed for bankruptcy, removing restriction thath as been in bankruptcy code for decades; SEC's objections to provision may doom its chances of inclusion in bankruptcy bill before Senate (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Bad Boy Executive Gives P. Diddy A New Name: 'Doll'
abstract: Francesca Spero, senior vice president at Bad Boy Entertainment and producer of soundtrack from Baby Boys II, credits Sean (P Diddy) Combs as mentor; album has sold more than 500,000 copies since mid-July; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Murray Dudgeon, executive vice president and worldwide operations director at Universal McCann Worldwide, is named to new post of chief operating officer; David Hills is named to new post of president for media solutions at 24/7 Real Media; Stacy Kallan is named to new post of partner and director for broadcast operations at Gotham; Maureen Phillips is named managing partner and director for broadcast production, assuming some duties that had been handled by chief creative officer Lynn Giordano; Robert Fox is named to head Posner Advertising's new office in Boca Raton, Fla (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Shell Oil Co names Initiative Media to handle media planning and buying on accounts of Pennzoil Motor Oil and Quaker State Motor Oil (S)

headline: Agents Search Marketing Firm
abstract: Advanced Marketing Services, which provides services to book industry, says federal authorities holding search warrant and subpoena arrived at its San Diego headquarters seeking records regarding its advertising services; denies wrongdoing and says it cooperates fully (S)

headline: E-Mail Stock Tip Tests Limits of Securities Laws
abstract: SEC lawsuit against Frank Porter Stansberry and Agora Inc, his employer, is first to test whether securities laws can be used against commentary about company in which authors have no financial stake; Stansberry sent e-mail to thousands of newsletter subscribers claiming to have inside information that would send a certain company's stock price up 100 percent and promising to identify company to anyone paying $1,000; information proved to be premature, and shares of company failed to perform as promised; defendants say allowing suit to proceed would expose all forms of communication about investment opportunities to civil liability for publication of any allegedly false statement; SEC says that defendants lied about product they sold and that that lie amounts to securities fraud because it concerns a security; company touted, USEC Inc, is not defendant; graph (M)

headline: Indonesia Bans Foreign Aid Workers From Embattled Province
abstract: Officials of United Nations and other organizations say Indonesian government refuses to give their aid workers permits to be in Aceh province, where estimated 100,000 people have been displaced as result of fighting; government justifies ban by saying that foreigners are in danger of being kidnapped by separatist rebels; insists that it is capable of distributing food and health supplies to civilians who have fled their homes (M)

headline: In Glare of Politics, Bush Weighs Fate Of Tariffs on Steel
abstract: Bush Administration is studying two key reports as it decides future of protective steel tariffs imposed in 2002; one report casts doubt on validity of complaint from many steel-consuming manufacturers that rising steel costs have reduced profitability and caused layoffs; report notes that employment declines were greater prior to tariff implementation than after, and concludes that many companies are unable to distinguish effects of tariffs from other changes in market conditions; majority of companies do not see continuation or cessation of tariffs as critical determinant of future economic health; graph; photo (M)

headline: Diana Charity Halts Grants, Citing Lawsuit
abstract: The charity set up in honor of Diana, the Princess of Wales, said today that it was cutting off all grants because of a financial crisis brought on by a lawsuit filed by the Franklin Mint, the company that specializes in commemorative dolls, dishes and baubles featuring celebrities, living and dead.    The suit will not affect the availability of porcelain ''Diana, Princess of Culture'' dolls at $195, or heart-shaped diamond ''Diana, England's Rose'' pendants at $135. Both items, and 35 others carrying the likeness of Diana, are still available from the Franklin Mint, payable in five monthly installments.

headline: Drawing Stares and the Police but Not Many Buyers
abstract: Sales of Segway Human Transporter electric vehicles have fallen short of Segway LLC's hopes, despite laws in 45 states that allow Segways on public sidewalks; analysts say high selling price of $5,000 has limited Segway's appeal to consumers, while travel experts question its viability as alternative form of transportation; photo (M)

headline: Clash, Then Synthesis: Joys of a Laptop Jam
abstract: Laptop music is new trend; Manhattan's Openair club offers jam sessions every Sunday where performers share their creations, composed or improvised; photos (M)

headline: Europe's Deficit Cap Becomes Rule Often Broken
abstract: Germany's announcement that it would move up sweeping tax cut to recharge its economy is that country's almost certain violation of treaty-imposed ceiling on budget deficits for third consecutive year; chronic violation of rules by Germany, which has Europe's biggest economy and insists its neighbors cap their deficits as precondition of adopting single European currency--could effectively vitiate agreement known as Stability and Growth Pact; France this year will also breach deficit ceiling, which is set at 3 percent of gross domestic product, while Italy and Portugal are skirting the edge; all told, countries representing 71 percent of total economic output of euro zone no longer comply with its fiscal rules; experts say fact that larger countries ignore deficit ceiling with impunity will encourage smaller countries to do same; photo (M)

headline: 3rd Season for 'Osbournes'
abstract: Rock star Ozzy Osbourne and his family agree to return for third season of TV program The Osbournes; MTV will broadcast 20 new episodes of show starting early next year (S)

headline: U.S. Moves to Halt Import Of Drugs From Canada
abstract: Justice Department moves to close Canadian drugstore chain Rx Depot, signaling that federal regulators are cracking down on import of cheaper drugs from abroad; Rx Depot president Carl Moore says company is not going to stop and will fight for right of senior citizens to buy affordable medicines (M)

headline: U.S. Pact Lifts South Africa Car Exports
abstract: More than 80 percent of cars made at BMW South Africa's plant in Rosslyn are for export; half of those, estimated 25,000 in 2003, will be shipped to US; cars will enter duty-free, under preferential trade agreement intended to stimulate African economies; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Volkswagen Strike; VENEZUELA: Talks With World Bank;.

headline: Personal Business; Ready to Renovate? Keep an Eye on Taxes
abstract: Advice on impact of home improvements on property tax bills; making major improvement can spur almost immediate reassessment, as can many projects that requires building permit; homeowners can usually repair walks and make other outside improvements without raising assessments; photo (M)i

headline: F.T.C. APPROVES LIBERTY MEDIA'S PURCHASE OF QVC STAKE
abstract: Federal Trade Commission approves Liberty Media Corp's $7.9 billion purchase of Comcast Corp's 57 percent stake in home shopping network QVC; acquisition still awaits approval from European regulators and Federal Communications Commission (S)

headline: Wi-Fi Technology Moves From Storeroom to Store
abstract: Fast-dropping price of Wi-Fi and its ability to convey large volume of digital data wirelessly over short distances have enabled variety of businesses to improve sales and profits, while better serving customers face to face; standardized Wi-Fi systems are far cheaper and are more reliable than proprietary wireless technology long used to track inventory and speed shipping; photos (M)

headline: China Allows Sale of Animal Tied to SARS
abstract: Chinese agriculture officials in Beijing are allowing farms to resume selling masked palm civets, species related to mongoose that may have been source of SARS virus; Chinese provinces retain discretion to bar human consumption of animals (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: FileNet Reduces Earnings Forecast
abstract: FileNet Corp reduces its second-quarter earnings outlook, citing deferral of several large sales (S)

headline: Universal rolls out 'Seabiscuit' with plans to run a marathon, not a sprint.
abstract: Universal Pictures's carefully calibrated $35 million marketing plan for film Seabiscuit seeks to spur steady stream of moviegoers in coming weeks; is betting that character-driven story aimed at adults will have staying power (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices fall; natural gas for Sept delivery falls 24.4 cents, or 5 percent, to $4.63 per million BTUs; graphs; table (S)

headline: Media Grow, but They Can't Hide
abstract: NBC's plan to acquire Vivendi Universal's entertainment businesses, latest episode in media business merger boom, could also signal final stages of boom; five companies, Viacom, AOL Time Warner, Walt Disney, News Corp and General Electric, have carved up almost entire broadcast and cable audience; mergers have helped companies expand profits by lowering costs in face of slowing or negligible growth in demand; recent events suggest mergers may not be solution to industry's problems; photo (M)

headline: Court Deals Setback to Buffett's Clayton Homes Purchase
abstract: Tennessee appeals court blocks Berkshire Hathaway's acquisition of Clayton Homes; Berkshire Hathaway, headed by Warren E Buffett, had offered $1.7 billion, which Clayton Homes had accepted; court halts acquisition pending judicial review of deal (M)

headline: Six Flags Picks New Ad Agency
abstract: Six Flags Picks.

headline: Closing His Eyes, He Sees a Path
abstract: closing his eyes, he sees a path**8

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDONESIA: Troops Battle Aceh Rebels; PAKISTAN: Freed Detainees Return; PAKISTAN: Ex-Taliban Commander Killed;.

headline: Colombians Travel More Freely as Leader's Policies Pay Off
abstract: Programs introduced by Pres Alvaro Uribe of Colombia have given people in his country glimmer of hope after years of political and criminal violence; country is still violence-racked nation, but increasingly Uribe's policies--sending more troops into field to install civilian intelligence networks, creating war tax to pay for military buildup--appear to be working; kidnappings dropped 26 percent in last six months and homicides fell by 23 percent; vast fields of coco, plant used to make cocaine, have decreased by 15 percent, prompting Pres Bush and Secretary of State Colin L Powell to shower him with praise while promising more aid; human rights groups say he has failed to cut ties between army and paramilitary death squads, and they worry that antiterrorism legislation he proposes could lead to rights abuses; photo; map (M)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: List of Americans newly confirmed dead in Iraq

headline: Sun Plans Licensing Strategy To Ease Sales and Upgrades
abstract: Sun Microsystems is set to simplify way it sells, maintains and upgrades software it licenses to corporations and cut prices; will also unveil version of Linux operating system for personal computers that features innovative user interface; both projects are seen as crucial to Sun's efforts to maintain its shrinking position in network computing market (M)

headline: Newspaper Ad Sales Edge Up in Quarter
abstract: Newspaper Association of America's preliminary estimate shows advertising spending in newspapers increased 1.6 percent in second quarter, to $11.1 billion, compared with year earlier; estimate represents slight slowdown from growth rate in first quarter, when spending increased 1.8 percent, to $9.9 billion; ad spending in newspapers totaled $20.9 billion for first half of year, up 1.7 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai Strike Ends
abstract: The signs hanging from windows of the union office at Hyundai Motor in Ulsan proclaim, ''Win a 40-hour week'' and ''Give the union a place in management.'' Those goals that had seemed all but impossible when the company's 39,000 workers walked off the job for two hours on June 20, the first day of an off-again, on-again strike that ended early yesterday with an agreement in which the union achieved both goals. As workers returned to their jobs after hearing a three-hour explanation of the agreement, a union leader, Chang Kyu Ho, said, ''We got what we wanted.'' The company estimated that the strike had been one of the costliest in its history. The union leader said he was confident that workers would accept the agreement when it goes to members for a vote tomorrow.     Don Kirk (NYT)

headline: A Sports Guy's Credo
abstract: The Boss column on ING Group chief Ewald Kist on his upbringing in Netherlands during and after World War II; comments on work-life balance and favorites sports; photo (M)

headline: From Uzbek to Klingon, the Machine Cracks the Code
abstract: Statistical machine translation, in which computers learn new languages on their own instead of being taught by bilingual human programmers, gives scientists facility to develop translation systems for wide number of obscure languages; traditional machine translation is painstaking process that requires programmers to enter vocabulary and syntax rules, but researchers at IBM developed, in early 1990's, new system in which computer compares new language with English and essentially learns new language; researchers are refining quality and accuracy; technology has led to explosion of translated texts in far-flung languages; drawing (M)

headline: Virus Aside, Gates Says Reliability Is Greater
abstract: Interview with Bill Gates, Microsoft's chaiman and chief sofware architect, on issue of computer security, and what company is doing to keep hackers at bay (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: EchoStar Profit Triples On New Subscribers
abstract: EchoStar Communications Corp says second-quarter profit more than tripled after company signed up additional subscribers for its Dish Network service; net income rose to $128.8 million from $37 million year earlier; revenue rose 21 percent, to $1.41 billion (S)

headline: Report Says Freddie Mac Misled Investors
abstract: Report for Freddie Mac board by outside investigators holds big mortgage financier used grab bag of accounting techniques to mislead investors since 2000, reducing reported profits and creating reserve of earnings for future years; says new chief executive Gregory Parseghian knew of some of tactics; report underscores complexity of accounting used by firm and underlines how easily financial companies can manipulate earnings reports; chairman Shaun F O'Malley expresses confidence in Parseghian; Baker Botts lawyer James Doty led probe; photos (M)

headline: Combos For Mutt And Jeff
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column reviews two new combination cellphone-palmtops by Samsung; one runs on Palm operating system and other on Microsoft Pocket PC system; drawing; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WELLS FARGO & CO., San Francisco, said it increased its dividend from 30 cents a share to 45 cents a share, payable Sept. 1 to stockholders of record on Aug. 8.    GANNETT CO., McLean, Va., the newspaper publisher, said it extended the employment agreement for Douglas McCorkindale, the chairman, through July 2006. Mr. McCorkindale's previous agreement would have ended in June 2004, when he will be 65 years old.

headline: Philippines Tries to Help Its Currency
abstract: Philippines central bank heeds call by Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo to 'crack the whip' against currency speculators and raises crucial interest rates as concerns grow about political instability that sends country's currency to new lows; central bank governor Rafael Buenaventura says move is intended to stave off potential inflationary effects of peso's decline; inflation has been hovering at annual rate of about 3 percent, well below government's target of 4.5 percent to 5.5 percent; some analysts believe peso is falling because of political security concerns; mutiny late last month by members of armed forces and accusations of corruption against Arroyo's husband are part of what investors fear presages period of increasing political turmoil ahead of presidential elections next year (M)

headline: Some in Poland Have Concerns About Nation's Expanding Role as a U.S. Ally
abstract: Poland, now America's unrivaled best friend in Europe, is also sharply divided between political class that almost unanimously supports helping with Iraq occupation and ordinary people worried about 2,500 troops there; leaders say Poland is also threatened by terrorism and sees participation as boon to national prestige and test of its military (M)

headline: Troubles Plague Plans for a Pipeline to Australia
abstract: Pipeline, estimated to cost $3.5 billion, to carry gas from Papua New Guinea's rugged southern highlands as far south as Brisbane, Australia, nearly 2,000 miles away, has been put off until at least 2007 because Exxon Mobil and its partners have failed to sign up enough customers to make it worthwhile; gas rests from populated areas that need it; since 1996, group of companies, led first by ChevronTexaco and now Exxon Mobil, has been planning to build pipeline; map (M)

headline: British Home Builder Acquires a Rival
abstract: British home builder Taylor Woodrow agrees to buy Wilson Connolly Holdings for 480 million pounds ($758 million) in cash and stock to become country's second-biggest provider of new houses; Taylor plans to cut 300 jobs after takeover, saving 25 million pounds each year (S)

headline: Blair Aide Apologizes for Comment About Dead Arms Scientist
abstract: Tom Kelly, spokesman for Prime Min Tony Blair, issues unusual public apology for likening late weapons scientist David Kelly to Walter Mitty, fictional character who leads humdrum life but dreams of heroic deeds; latest dispute stemming from accuracy of intelligence data erupts day before funeral of Kelly, who apparently committed suicide after testifying at inquiry about reasons for going to war in Iraq (M),

headline: U.S. Suspends Aid to 35 Countries Over New International Court
abstract: Bush administration suspends all American military assistance to 35 countries that have refused to pledge to give immunity before International Criminal Court to US citizens serving within countries' borders; nations include Colombia, Ecuador and Croatia; 22 other countries that have signed but not ratified immunity agreements get waivers; US cites possibility of politically inspired charges against Americans (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Russian Out On Bail
abstract: Kremlin critic and businessman Vladimir Gusinsky is released on $108,000 bail from Greek prison pending court ruling on his extradition to Russia; claims charges of money laundering and fraud are politically motivated (S)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: Defense Department identifies another American soldier killed in Iraq

headline: Radio Ad Revenue On the Rise Again
abstract: Adverti

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Reduces Employee Options
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp reduces number of stock optiosn for employees and will study how it pays its executives (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE NETHERLANDS: Baby Food Cuts; RUSSIA: Oil Profit Rises; FINLAND: Paper Outlook; BLOOD TEST SETTLEMENT;.

headline: MERCK SETS DATE FOR SPINOFF OF MEDCO HEALTH SOLUTIONS
abstract: Merck & Co says it will spin off Medco Health Solutions, pharmacy-benefits manager unit, Aug 19 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: New Wrapping For Stalin's Gift
abstract: Polish newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reports that Warsaw's tourist authority intends to wrap city's Palace of Culture in gold fabric to celebrate Poland's entry in European Union scheduled for next May; covering building, which was given as gift by Josef Stalin and is universally recognized as eyesore, will cost estimated $1.9 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tire Company Cuts Outlook
abstract: Bridgestone Corp cuts full-year profit goal by 2 billion yen ($18 million) because of fire that destroyed factory in Japan; sales forecast unchanged (S)

headline: Personal Business; Yachts to Call Your Own (If Only for a Vacation)
abstract: Yacht charters are no longer for the rich and famous; charters have gained popularity as people seek creative ways to customize their vacations; experts offer advice on arranging charter; list of charter companies; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Dendrite Will Cut 300 Jobs and Close 10 Plants
abstract: Dendrite International will close 10 plants and eliminate about 300 jobs as result of its acquisition in May of Synavant; Dendrite says second-quarter net income rose 29 percent to $$5.92 million from $4.60 million year earlier; revenue climbed to $69.5 million from $57.6 million year ago (S)

headline: Helping Amateurs Move Beyond Point-and-Shoot
abstract: Canon unveils EOS Digital Rebel, which combines automatic features with attractive price; photo (M)

headline: Auto Unit Overhaul Cited as Fiat Cuts Losses
abstract: Fiat group reports better-than-expected results in second quarter for its global activities; says operating profit was 25 million euros ($28 million), down sharply from loss of 127 million euros a year earlier; revenue is 12.46 billion euros ($14 billion); photo (M)

headline: Trust Says Company Owes Rent on 24 Hotels
abstract: Hospitality Properties Trust says Prime Hospitality Corp failed to pay $1.98 million rent due on July 1 for 24 AmeriSuites hotels that Prime Hospitality manages for it (S)

headline: A Hand-Held Portal To Musical Delights
abstract: Concert Companion is hand-held device meant to enhance appreciation of classical music performance; displays program notes during concert, explaining what is being heard; Roland Valliere, former director of Kansas City Symphony and developer of device, hopes orchestras will rent devices to patrons interested in expanding experience of performance; some in music world are concerned that device will distract audience's attention; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Luxury Goods Rebound
abstract: Gucci Group chief executive Domenico De Sole sees improving demand for luxury goods in Asian markets; photo (S)

headline: Market Place; G.M. Profit Gets Lift From Pension Deal
abstract: General Motors Corp says it will contribute most of proceeds from $13.1 billion bond issue to its retirement plans later this year; GM will end up with gain--small oen for 2003--because pension contribution will be close to end of year; transactions will increase GM's profits by about $200 million before taxes in 2004, compared with net income of $1.7 billion last year (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon Extends Sales Pact With Target
abstract: Amazon extends its five-year Internet-sales agreement with Target Corp until August 2008 (S)

headline: A German Union Takes Stock
abstract: Leaders of Germany's most formidable labor union IG Metall gather in Frankfurt to sift through wreckage of aborted strike in June in eastern Germany; meeting may end up being not just battle for future of union, but milestone in history of organized labor in Germany; at issue is whether IG Metall's vice chairman Jurgen Peters misled his fellow board members about bare-knuckle tactics he planned to use to push for shorter workweek in eastern Germany; German labor experts say IG will have to confront sobering reality: its militant style has less and less place in country with high unemployment, chronically sick economy and population no longer tolerant of old remedies for problems; IG Metall's campaign in eastern Germany was supposed to force manufacturers, through brief strikes, to shorten workweek to 35 hours from 38 in line with factories in western Germany; union's departing chairman Klaus Zwickel accused Peters of deceiving executive board by scheduling longer strikes that were calculated to disrupt assembly lines in western Germany; Peters, who is expected to succeed Zwickel this fall, has absorbed most of blame for four-week strike, which was called off June 28 after union acknowledged that it had alienated many Germans; photos (M)

headline: A Climb to Riches, One Merger at a Time
abstract: Market Place column on Sanford I Weill's decision to step down as chief executive of Citigroup focuses on how Weill through long series of mergers and acquisitions created global financial giant called Citigroup; says Weill took public Commercial Credit in 1986 and that company acquired others and went through names of Primerica and Travelers Group before merging with bank then called Citicorp; investor who put $10,000 at Commercial Credit's initial public offering, and who reinvested all dividends and distributions over years, would have had stock worth $334,349 at Citigroup's closing price on July 16 (M)

headline: Fewer Iraqi Men: Dead or Undercounted?
abstract: Newly released data from most recent Iraqi census show unusually high portion of Iraq's men seemingly disappeared between 1987 and 1997; data, which Saddam Hussein sealed as state secret, reveal previously unseen population scars left by years of war and repression; 1987 census takers recorded 106 men for every 100 women; decade later count was 99 men for every 100 women; lowest reported male-female ratios were clustered in southern third of country, where Hussein persecuted Shiite Muslims after their uprising in 1991; United Nations and United States demographers caution against assuming great accuracy in counts; map (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Necessities, not luxuries, are driving Americans into debt, a new book says.
abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column on book The Two-Income Trap by Elizabeth Warren and Amelia Warren Tyagi that contends Americans are being driven into debt by spending on necessities not superficial luxury spending; authors contend many middle two-income families are having trouble making ends meet, despite boom of 1990's, not just poor and working poor; chart (M)

headline: Chirac's Words: Sovereignty Must Shift
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Jacques Chirac of France. The interview was done in French and translated by The New York Times. The full transcript is at nytimes.com/world.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Production Rose In July
abstract: British trade group Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply says its British manufacturing activity index rose to 50.9 in July, up from 49.5 in June; survey also shows export orders dropped in July, with gauge falling to 49.1 from 50.2; graph (S)

headline: U.S. Cuts Off Financing for AIDS Program, Provoking Furor
abstract: State Department cuts off aid to small but well-regarded AIDS program for African and Asian refugees, holding Marie Stopes International, one of groups involved in project, supports forced abortions and involuntary sterilizations in China; admits it has no evidence that group is involved in such programs; says it acts because group is partner in China with United Nations Population Fund, which is barred from getting United States funds; denies move is ideologically motivated; move raises furor among AIDS and refugee groups; US, which gave $1 million to cover first year of project, offered to fund six other relief groups involved if program ended ties to Marie Stopes; groups refused (M)

headline: Chief of Norway Oil Company Holds Job but Faces Inquiry
abstract: Board of Statoil, Norway's government-controlled oil company, lets chief executive Olav Fjell keep his job after sharply questioning him about $15.5 million consulting contract with Horton Investment intended to improve Statoil's access to Iranian oil fields; Norwegian police question Fjell; probe whether pact involved illegal influencing of foreign officials; Fjell admits contract was misstep that called into question company's commitment to ethical business practices, interview; says he is unsure of financial ties between Horton and Mehdi Hashemi Rafsanjani, influential son of former Iranian Pres Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani (M)

headline: A German Court Accepts Teacher's Head Scarf
abstract: Germany's highest court rules that Muslim teacher cannot be forbidden to wear head scarf in public school; decision ends protracted legal battle involving Fereshta Ludin, Afghan-born woman who was barred from teaching at school in Stuttgart because she refused to shed her scarf; ruling may do little to resolve what has become anguished, murky debate in Germany, France and other European countries over how much freedom to give their growing Islamic minorities to express religious identity in schools and other secular institutions; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: ITALY: No SchrÖDer? What A Calamity!; VATICAN CITY: Pope Begins 2-Month Retreat; CYPRUS: Mixed Marriages To Be Allowed;.

headline: Cool in the Midst of Battle
abstract: Nyko's Air Flo controllers contain small fans in grips that blow air into computer game player's palms during heat of combat; photo (M)

headline: Heineken Pokes Fun At Big Blackout
abstract: Heineken USA is introducing TV ads that poke fund at blackout of Aug 14; spot, in Spanish, is aimed particularly at viewers with roots in Dominican Republic, where power failures are more common; ad was created by Vidal Partnership (S)

headline: Franks Sees Decision Soon on Rotation System for G.I.'s
abstract: Gen Tommy R Franks says Pentagon is near decision on policy to regularly rotate thousands of Army forces through Iraq for months and years to come; defense officials are deciding what mix of Army and allied forces will replace 20,000 soldiers of Army's Third Infantry Division, and when; Army has hired Halliburton's Kellogg Brown & Root subsidiary to feed and house up to 100,000 troops in Iraq; Army spokesman says $200 million project could include construction of semipermanent wooden buildings; taken together, new troop policy and housing contract represent most concrete examples of Pentagon's long-term commitment to Iraq and acknowledgment that rebuilding country will take years and large numbers of American forces (M)

headline: Formula One:a way of fine-tuning an image
abstract: MOGYOROD, Hungary—  The first time the hills outside this village northeast of Budapest echoed with the roar of the world's fastest racing cars, Soviet tanks were parked on the crests, soldiers with Kalashnikovs walked the streets and the wealthier locals drove to the race in tin-can-like Trabant cars.

headline: In Europe, Profits Are Painfully Low For Auto Industry
abstract: DaimlerChrysler of Germany and Peugeot of France report sharply lower profits, while investors brace for bleak earnings report expected from Volkswagen; DaimlerChrysler, hobbled by $1.1 billion operating loss at its Chrysler division, reports profits fell 90 percent in second quarter from year-earlier period; Peugeot reports 12 percent decline in its net income; Renault manages to post increase in profits, thanks to buoyant results at Nissan Motor, in which it has 44 percent stake; fact that France's second-largest carmaker depends on its Japanese partner to salvage its numbers underscores ills affecting Europe's auto industry; earnings detailed (M)

headline: Singapore Says It Has Confirmed a New Case of SARS
abstract: Singapore said today that it had confirmed a new case of SARS in a researcher who worked in the city's medical laboratories.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ETHAN ALLEN INTERIORS INC., Danbury, Conn., the furniture maker and retailer, increased its quarterly dividend from 7 cents a share to 10 cents a share, payable on Oct. 27 to shareholders of record as of Oct. 10.    SUN LIFE FINANCIAL INC., Toronto, Canada's largest life insurer by assets, said that second-quarter profit rose to about $264 million, or 60 cents a share, from about $51 million, or 14 cents a share, a year ago.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: $72 Million Deal For Datamark
abstract: ECollege.com agrees to buy Datamark Inc for about $72 million from Leeds Weld & Co (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Hughes And Cooperative Settle DirecTV Dispute
abstract: Hughes Electronics Corp says National Rural Telecommunications Cooperative will give up its rights to distribute Hughes's DirecTV service by end of June 2011, under terms of settlement; DirecTV will continue to pursue $50 million lawsuit claiming Pegasus Communications Corp, which markets DirecTV on behalf of cooperative, breached marketing agreement; graph (M)

headline: One Realtor Wearing Many Hats
abstract: Many times real estate agents must also be investigators, psychiatrists, decorators, financial consultants and sympathetic listeners.

headline: Internet Chat Seen as Tool To Teach Theft Of Credit Cards
abstract: Internet security experts say chat groups, particular those using format called Internet relay chat, or IRC, play important and growing role in online credit card fraud; say IRC channels and affilated Web sites make it possible for large groups of people to share tactics for criminal activity and allow access to programs users have placed there that automate task of credit card fraud, like checking stolen card number's validity or systematically searching for Web sites that have credit information and are vulnerable to attack (M)

headline: Bush Defends War, Sidestepping Issue of Faulty Intelligence
abstract: President Bush today brushed aside the controversy over his use of faulty pre-war intelligence that said Iraq had tried to buy uranium from Africa.

headline: Judge Rules Against Simon in Mall Suit
abstract: Federal Judge Paul A Magnuson orders that Simon Property Group be stripped of its control of Mall of America in Minnesota, saying company breached its fiduciary duty to Canadian partner Triple Five by secretly arranging to gain ownership interest in mall; orders Simon to sell 27.5 percent stake in mall to Triple Five, owned by brothers Raphael, Nader, Bahman and Eskander Ghermezian for $81.4 million; also orders Triple Five to replace Simon as managing general partner of mall; increases Ghermezians' share of management fees to 80 percent from 20 percent; ruling calls for special master to determine how much Simon owes Triple Five, including net profits resulting from its ownership interest in mall since 1999, and those from sale to Ikea of 15-acre site north of mall; Simon Property says company believes that court's order is legally and factually wrong; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: CHILE: Court Bars Pinochet Rights Trial; ARGENTINA: Belgium Questions Bomb Suspect;.

headline: Humvee Is Bombed on a Baghdad Street, Killing a Soldier
abstract: American soldier is killed and three are wounded in daylight bombing in Baghdad, latest in string of deadly ambushes against occupation forces; military officials say four soldiers were riding in Humvee when bomb was thrown from overpass; Iraqi policeman at scene reports witnesses saw man running from overpass, indicating bomb had been detonated by remote control; latest death illustrates relative sophistication of attacks against Americans; American forces hunting for loyalists to Saddam Hussein's ousted government conduct 29 raids and arrest 241 people; effort is sowing frustration among Iraqis who had little to do with old government; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: RF Micro Lifts Revenue And Sales Forecast
abstract: RF Micro Devices, maker of computer chips for mobile telephones, raises its revenue and sales forecasts for fiscal second quarter and says it will break even or have profit; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Election Set
abstract: First Rwandan presidential election since 1994 mass ethnic killings is set for August 25; current transitional President Paul Kagame, who is Tutsi leader of Rwandan Patriotic Front, is expected to face Faustin Twagiramungu, moderate Hutu, who has served as Prime Minister (S)

headline: Debt Issue Schedule For Coming Week
abstract: This week's schedule of Treasury auctions includes the sale of new three-  and six-month bills today and a four-week bill tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.93 percent; the rate on the six-month issue was 1.01 percent; and, the rate on the four-week bill was 0.88 percent.

headline: Making Plants Comfortable While Traveling
abstract: If you thought vacationing with infants was a pain, try traveling with plants.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Energy Company's Profit Falls
abstract: norwr

headline: Paris Journal; A Thin Blue Line Rolls Where Peugeots Roam
abstract: Streets of Paris are being patrolled by team of 38 policemen wearing in-line skates; roller brigade is meant to give police hipper, friendlier face in country where police are widely resented and often despised; photo (M)

headline: With Emphasis On Slavery, A Softer Tone
abstract: Pres Bush elevates effort to halt human trafficking to near top of his agenda at United Nations, apparently trying to put softer face on American foreign policy and emphasize his stance to domestic coalition that includes religious right (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper prices rise at inventories fall to two-year low, partly because of increased demand in China; September contract increases 1.8 cents, or 2.3 percent, to 79.8 cents per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: 86% Rise In Profit For Hyundai In Quarter
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co reports 86 percent increase in second-quarter profit, despite strike that began third week of June and declining sales in domestic market; net income was record 571 billion won ($482.8 million), up from 307 billion won year earlier; sales rose 7.6 percent, to 436,000 vehicles (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: OPEC to Cut Oil Output In Effort to Keep Prices Up  The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries unexpectedly agreed to cut oil production on Nov. 1, just as most of the developed world will be heading toward winter.    Though the United States has been increasing imports, oil prices have fallen recently. Commercial inventories of heating oil are healthy and government stockpiles are robust, but the sharp rise in oil prices after the announcement could translate into higher prices for heating oil and gasoline. [Page A1.]

headline: Lawsuits Filed on Music Sharing
abstract: The action is expected to help define legal boundaries for millions of people in the U.S. who use file-sharing networks.

headline: Chávez Urges Deference for Electoral Board
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez, in new air of conciliation, urges Venezuelans to respect newly named electoral board that has authority to organize recall referendum that might end his presidency, radio speech; holds board is main arbiter in political stalemate and should not be pressured (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merrill Reaches Settlement With U.S. Over Enron Role  Merrill Lynch, in an agreement with prosecutors that let it avoid criminal charges over its role in the Enron debacle, promised not to engage in business deals that help companies mislead investors about their financial condition. The firm also agreed to allow the government to monitor portions of its business for the next 18 months.    Federal prosecutors said that they hoped the Merrill settlement would be seen by other companies as a model for appropriate behavior in the financial world. [Page A1.]

headline: CNBC Disclosure Stirs Ethics Debate In Business Media
abstract: Unusual disclosure by CNBC stock-market reporter Maria Bartiromo, made at start of indepth interview with Citigroup chief executive Sanford I Weill, that she owns Citigroup shares highlights issue that has divided financial journalism; many business news organizations bar reporters from covering companies in which they have investments; others say disclosure usually solves problem of apparent conflict of interest; neither Bartiromo nor her supervisors saw her Citigroup stake disqualifying her from questioning Weill; photo (M)

headline: GOLDMAN BUYS CALIFORNIA CONTRACT FROM ALLEGHENY
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group agrees to pay $405 million for electricity supply contract that Allegheny Energy signed with California during state's energy crisis in 2000 and 2001 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda Profit Slips
abstract: Japanese automaker Honda Motor Co reports profits fell 54 percent in Apr-to-June quarter, to 102 billion yen ($850 million); raises full-year profit target (S)

headline: Yahoo's Earnings Double As Revenue Sets a Record
abstract: Profits more than doubled at Yahoo in second quarter; earned $50.8 million, up 137 percent; advertising revenue increased 44 percent, to $219 million; chief executive Terry Semel comments (M)

headline: The Laptop as Recorder, Remote Control Included
abstract: Toshiba introduces new laptop that allows television programs to be recorded directly to its hard drive for scheduled viewing; can also play DVD's; photo (M)

headline: Returning From Iraq War Not So Simple for Soldiers
abstract: American soldiers returning from Iraq war find homecoming far more complicated, even conflicted, than they expected; Army, having trained soldiers to fight, is now undertaking its greatest effort ever to ease their return to 'civilian' life; returning soldiers are screened for symptoms of combat stress, and those with signs of it are referred to psychologists for further evaluation; soldiers are required to attend sessions in which they are encouraged to air their feelings after months of keeping them in check; purpose is to reassure soldiers that strains they are experienceing--from paying bills to re-establishing relationships with spouses and children--are not unusual; sessions are sobering outgrowth of wave of murders and suicides last year involving soldiers returning from war in Afghanistan; wives attend similar sessions before soldiers return; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Joint Operation Against Taliban
abstract: Zabul, Afghanistan, Governor Hafizullah Khan reports joint operation between American ground troops and Afghan forces against suspected Taliban forces in southeastern Afghan mountains resulted in 14 anti-coalition casualties (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Technology Investment
abstract: Siemens plans to invest more than $110 million in research and development for mobile phone technology in Brazil within next five years (S)

headline: Actor From Reebok Ad Doesn't Make Ballot
abstract: Among 112 would-be candidates for governor of California whose documents were rejected by county and state authorities is Lester Speight, actor who plays Terry Tate character in series of commercials for Reebok International (S)

headline: Judge Releases Audit of Barnes Foundation
abstract: Montgomery County, Pa, Orphans Court Judge Stanley R Ott orders release of highly critical audit of Barnes Foundation, which is seeking to move its art collection valued at $6 billion from suburban Merion to downtown location; details of audit, covering 1990's, are not available; audit has been previously reported to show spending irregularities by former Barnes president Richard H Glanton, who has since left (S)

headline: U.N. Assembly Calls for Israel To Drop Threat Against Arafat
abstract: United Nations General Assembly emergency sessions approves resolution demanding that Israel rescind threat to deport Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; minor changes to resolution, vetoed by United States in Security Council, are enough to win support of Germany and Britain, who abstained in council vote; Israel, United States, Micronesia and Marshall Islands vote against measure; main change puts more stress on condemning suicide bombings by Palestinians than extrajudicial killings by Israelis; new resolution also notes Palestianians' obligation to end violence and terror; Pres Bush declares current peace effort 'stalled;' Israeli Amb Dan Gillerman scores what he calls Arafat's corrupt leadership (M)

headline: Bush's Remarks Draw Skepticism
abstract: Pres Bush's urging that all nations support reconstruction and political transformation of Iraq meets with largely skeptical response, laced with some general expressions of approval, in both General Assembly and in capitals around the world; most diplomats and scholars focus on Bush's unapologetic tone; delegates applaud him far less than they do Pres Jacques Chirac of France, his chief rival for hearts and minds of arena of international diplomacy; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Telecom Italia Profit Increases
abstract: Telecom Italia, in what will be its last earnings report before merging with Olivetti, its parent company, says first-half operating profit advanced 7.8 percent, to 3.95 billion euros ($4.53 billion); sales declined 1.1 percent, to 14.82 billion euros (S)

headline: Just East of the West, Unity Has Its Costs
abstract: Benefits of membership in European Union outweigh costs for most of 75 million people in 10 countries that will join European Union in May, but for Gyor, Hungary, and other commercial hubs on western frontier of new Europe, integration could be prove to be trick passage; while labor costs remain lower in Hungary than in Western Europe, gap is closing; wages in Hungary rose average of 18 percent last year, with salaries in some sectors jumping 50 percent; lower-cost cities in eastern Hungary, not to mention even cheaper ones in Romania and Bulgaria, are beckoning; many foreign investors are asking whether there is enough skilled labor in Gyor or would they better be off going someplace else; Gyor's struggle to attract and retain foreign investment is being replicated across Hungary; while country was one of stars of Central Europe through 1990's, it has lost some of its luster because of its rapidly rising wages, slower growth and ballooning state budget deficit; Audi of Germany, which has plant is Gyor, is seeing tax breaks it receives there vanish as Hungary prepares to join European Union; Gyor has embarked on arduous talks with Audi over what taxes it will pay; map; graph; photo (M)

headline: Dell Decides to Diversify Into Consumer Electronics
abstract: Dell Inc will begin selling consumer electronics and offering online music service; Dell Music Store is in talks with record labels to make their music available on Dell site (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Oil Executive Resigns
abstract: Statoil chairman Leif Terje Loeddesoel resigns as pressure increases on top managers in connection with 11-year, $15.5 million consulting contract that Norwegian police are investigating as possible attempt to buy influence in Iran; chief executive Olav Fjell is expected to face more questions from board about June 2002 contract with Horton Investment (S)

headline: REAL ESTATE DEVELOPER SOLD FOR $990 MILLION
abstract: Lennar Corp and LNR Property Corp to buy Newhall Land and Farming Co, real estate developer, for about $990 million, plus debt (S)

headline: U.S. DENIES SBC ON LONG-DISTANCE REQUEST
abstract: SBC Communications fails to win Justice Department support for its bids to enter $7 billion market for long-distance service in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Wisconsin; department says that SBC issued inaccurate bills to carriers who buy wholesale local services on its network (S)

headline: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY SOLD FIRST DATA AND BOUGHT HCA
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway Inc reduced its stockholdings in First Data Corp, Duke Energy Corp and Iron Mountain Inc during second quarter; says it owned 16.6 million shares of HCA Inc as of June 30, stake worth about $532 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: An Interest Rate Cut
abstract: South Africa's central bank reduces its benchmark lending rate by one percentage point, after surge in value of currency pushed manufacturing into recession and economy slid to its slowest growth rate in nearly five years; cut follows 1.5 percentage-point reduction in June, and 1 percentage-point cut in August (S)

headline: Foreign Automakers Unleash a New Wave of Luxury
abstract: Opening of new Lexus assembly plant in Ontario, Canada, underscores determination of foreign manufacturers to continue dominance of US luxury vehicle market; luxury segment is among few with growing sales and profits, led by luxury sport utility vehicles; building SUV's in US and Canada allows foreign makers to concentrate their foreign production on cars, which have higher overseas sales than light trucks; other advantages of local production include ability to respond more rapidly to consumer tastes, protection against currency fluctuation and defense against charges of undermining American jobs; photo (M)

headline: FENWAY PARTNERS BUYS SPORTS APPAREL MANUFACTURER
abstract: Fenway Partners Inc acquires Riddell Sports Group, maker of football helmets and athletic uniforms, from Lincolnshire Management Inc for about $100 million (S)

headline: Alcan Posts $89 Million Loss As It Continues Bid for Rival
abstract: alcan posts $89 million loss as it continues bid for rival**h

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Gets Deadline Extension
abstract: Elan Corp receives one-week deadline extension from its creditors for filing its 2002 annual report with Securities and Exchange Commission; deadline allows Elan to avoid declaring bankruptcy on its $2 billion in debt; is being investigated by SEC for its off-balance-sheet accounting (S)

headline: Shots fired across DMZ by 2 Koreas
abstract: SEOUL:—  North and South Korean troops exchanged machine-gun fire inside the demilitarized zone on Thursday, raising tension as diplomatic efforts to persuade North Korea to engage in talks on its nuclear weapons program intensified. No casualties were reported in the incident, which was the first exchange of fire across the zone since 2001.

headline: Business People; A Designer Ponders A Show on Clothes, On and Off the Models
abstract: Fashion dï

headline: Are the Baby Boomers Prepared for Retirement?
abstract: Brent Green letter notes that many baby boomers have been unable to build comfortable retirement portfolios because of economic factors beyond their control

headline: An Exchange Says a Rival Botched Options Trading
abstract: International Securities Exchange charges in letter to Securities and Exchange Commission that rival American Stock Exchange has had serious operational problems with its new options trading system called Intermarket Linkage Program; system was designed to allow traders to buy and sell options at best possible price on any of five main exchanges; International Securities Exchange claims that options orders sent to American Stock Exchange have not been executed as intended and that its customers have been harmed as result (M)

headline: A Jog in Baghdad Offers Lessons About Life in a War Zone
abstract: First-person account by reporter Dexter Filkins of life in Baghdad; says city has grown menacing and bleak; says bombings of recent days have given life heavy feel; says that, added to heat and haze, make it unhappy time for American soldiers stationed there; says he has taken to jogging at night, to amazement of onlooking Iraqis; photo (M)

headline: The Bits Are Willing, but the Batteries Are Weak
abstract: Blackout of Aug 14 deprives Internet addicts of digitized information that permeates their lives, from work-related records to Google searches to e-mail love letters, and punctures their cherished illusion that cyberspace is separate universe, immune from real-world physics; adds to sense of vulnerability created by Blaster worm; experts on Internet infrastructure say it is increasingly important to strengthen link between dual grids of electricity and information that power economy; photo (M)

headline: Roughing It, but Not Quite Getting Away From It All
abstract: Campgrounds, which have traditionally offered such amenities as laundry rooms and firewood, now include Internet access; list of campgrounds can be found at modemfriendly.com and koakonnect.com; photo (M)

headline: 27 Israeli Reserve Pilots Say They Refuse to Bomb Civilians
abstract: Twenty-seven reserve pilots in Israeli Air Force present signed petition to air force head Maj Gen Dan Halutz, saying they will not take part in 'illegal and immoral' strikes in Palestinian areas of West Bank and Gaza Strip; some Palestinian civilians have been killed during airstrikes aimed at Hamas militants; Halutz says members of military should not take political positions; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Reports Arrest Of Al Qaeda Chief For Southeast Asia
abstract: Riduan Isamuddin, 39, an Indonesian better known as Hambali, who is thought to be Al Qaeda's main organizer in Southeast Asia and to have led the deadly bombing in Bali last year, has been captured, the White House said yesterday.    Hambali, a veteran of the war between Afghanistan and the Soviet Union, and one of the few non-Arabs in Osama bin Laden's inner circle, has been connected to some of Al Qaeda's most notorious terrorist acts, among them a plot in 1994 to blow up airliners over the Pacific, the suicide attack in October 2000 on the American destroyer Cole and the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Merrill Reaches Deal With U.S. In Enron Affair
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co reaches agreement with prosecutors that lets it avoid criminal charges over its role in Enron debacle; promises not to enage in business deals that it believes might be used to mislead investors about a company's financial condition; also agrees to allow government to monitor portions of its business for next 18 months; settlement involves deals late in 1999 that let Enron increase its reported profits when its business was falling short of Wall St's expectations; Merrill acknowledges that government has evidence that some of its employees might have committed crimes in transactions, and it accepts responsibility for those employees' actions; three former senior executives charged in connection with their roles in one deal, Daniel Bayly, Robert S Furst and James A Brown, all plead not guilty; prosecutors hope Merrill settlement will be seen by other companies as model for appropriate behavior in financial world; details of negotiations and settlement described; photos (L)

headline: ABC Mourning Star of Series That Was Key To Its Lineup
abstract: Death of television star John Ritter poses quandary for ABC executives who are discussing whether to continue producing show 8 Simple Rules for Dating My Teenage Daughter that stars Ritter; series, which is network's most popular comedy, is expected to continue; ABC had hoped that show would serve as anchor for several new 'family-friendly' sitcoms, and its cancellation would cause major disruption to fall schedule; three new episodes were completed prior to Ritter's death, with first to air Sept 23 (M)

headline: Sleeves in His Heart, Thread in His Veins
