abstract: GAV chief executive Andrew Grossman, son of suit maker and grandson of pocket maker, will head production of Calvin Klein women's sportswear line for Phillips-Van Heusen; Grossman's wife Robin Howe is chief designer and his partner Alexander Vreeland is handling sales and marketing (M)

headline: Renovation of Pabst Brewery Aims to Revitalize Downtown Milwaukee
abstract: Developers Ferchill Group and Wispark LLC, division of Wisconsin Energy Corp, have teamed up to purchase and renovate sprawling historic but long-vacant Pabst brewery complex in Milwaukee into entertainment and residential complex; project--called Pabst City--is expected to provide city with downtown entertainment district featuring kind of national dining and entertainment chains--like ESPN Zone and House of Blues--that have increasingly come to dominate many center-city revitalization efforts; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Attributes Explosion at Iraqi Mosque to Bomb-Making Activity
abstract: United States Central Command in Iraq says explosion at mosque in Falluja that killed at least six people, including mosque's imam, resulted from presence of bomb-making class inside; American commander says that unless troops are fired on from mosque, he will continue to adhere to policy of not searching them because it might risk further alienating Muslim population already seething at American-led occupation; members of Falluja mosque insist explosion was caused by American missile fired from helicopter or airplane; their version of events gains currency on streets of Falluja and beyond, prompting vows of revenge; neighbors of mosque say they heard no aircraft before explosion but they did hear that explosives were being stored at mosque; photo; map (M)

headline: Ex-Official Captured in Iraq
abstract: American officials in Baghdad announced that the former interior minister had been captured. In Basra, British troops struggled to quell rioting over shortages. Page 10.

headline: U.S. Envoy in Indonesia Warns Americans of Future Attacks
abstract: At a meeting of American residents in Jakarta today, the American ambassador warned that future terrorist attacks, like the one at the J. W. Marriott Hotel last week, were likely.

headline: Harry Potter and the Internet Pirates
abstract: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix is being downloaded in pirated online versions; some fans are assisting in cumbersome process of scanning and typing in book, which its author, J K Rowling, has not authorized for publication in any of existing commercial e-book formats; English-language copies are available on all major file-sharing networks in variety of formats; portions unofficially translated into German and Czech appeared on Web, only to be removed after owners of those rights threatened legal action; piracy may be perverse sign that public is finally acquiring taste for e-books; file-sharing software may be most powerful force in shaping online distribution of books; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Gilead Sales Surge On Aids Drug
abstract: Gilead Sciences says revenue was $236 million to $239 million in second quarter as doctors wrote more prescriptions for its Viread AIDS drug; graph (S)

headline: Big Fine Over Trader's Mutual-Fund Moves
abstract: New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer says his office has uncovered widespread illegal trading by hedge funds and mutual fund companies; Spitzer, in announcing settlement with Edward J Stern and his hedge fund Canary Capital Partners, says it is just first step in broad-based probe of how mutual fund companies conduct their trading operations; accuses fund companies of favoring short-term interests of institutional clients over individuals who invest for long term; Stern and Canary Capital Partners agree to pay $40 million in fines and restitution to settle New York State case without admitting wrongdoing; Spitzer contends Canary entered into quid pro quo agreement with Bank of America's fund business that allowed Canary to buy and sell fund shares after market closed and then trade them next day for substantial profit; state and federal securities law prohibit investors to buy or sell mutual fund shares--at that day's price--after market has closed and then profit by trading them next day; Bank of America's funds allegedly received hundreds of millions in investments from Stern as well as commissions; Spitzer says other mutual funds engaged in similar practices with Canary; photo (M)

headline: Orangemen On Parade Peacefully
abstract: Annual parade by Protestant Orange Order passes without incident for first time since 1995 in countryside outside Portadown, Northern Ireland; marchers are prevented for sixth consecutive year from walking their traditional route through Roman Catholic neighborhood; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Search Service From I.B.M.
abstract: IBM is introducing service that combines World Wide Web searching with text analysis and database queries; service, called WebFountain, represents combined effort of 300 IBM scientists, who have collected more than 100 patents on this research since it began in late 1990's; project is collecting and indexing 25 million Web pages per day, about 4 billion pages this year, half of them stored in IBM databases; IBM vice president Robert Carlson says technology goes well beyond text searches and popularity of Google; service is partnership with Factiva, company backed by Dow Jones and Reuters (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Dress Code Debate
abstract: Kenyan Parliament changes rule and allows legislators to wear African dress after speaker Francis ole Kaparo expelled three men last week, but debate continues on current suit and tie dress code (S)

headline: Smithfield Makes $364 Million Bid for a Rival Pork Processor
abstract: Smithfield Foods, nation's largest pork producer and processor, offers to buy pork processor Farmland Foods for $363.5 million in cash; deal would strengthen Smithfield's position as nation's biggest pork processor and further consolidate nation's meat-processing industry, which is dominated by Tyson Foods, Excel, unit of Cargill, Swift and Smithfield (M)

headline: Acquitted Man Says Virus Put Pornography On Computer
abstract: Legal experts say British case in which Julian Green was acquitted of child pornography charges after arguing that material on his computer was gathered without his knowledge by computer virus raises concerns both that actual child pornographers could use defense and that Web surfers could be charged with possessing illegal material that virus program acquired; Green, his solicitor and computer security expert who found so-called Trojan Horse programs on Green's computer comment; photo (M)

headline: JUDGE APPROVES SETTLEMENT OF DRUG INSURANCE SUIT
abstract: Merck & Co's Medco Health Solutions unit says federal judge gave premilinary approval to $42.5 million settlement of class-action suit charging plaintiffs did not get maximum savings they had been promised through Medco; accord requires changes in way Medco notifies subscribers of coverage (S)

headline: AES RECEIVES $890 MILLION IN FINANCING FOR POWER PLANT
abstract: Electric power supplier AES Corp completes $890 million financing for new 1,200-megawatt plant in Cartagena, Spain (S)

headline: For Many Chinese, America's Allure Is Fading
abstract: Chinese are having second thoughts about paying up to $60,000 to be smuggled to America; tales of hard, miserable existence deters many, especially in Fujian province; there are more options at home now with jobs available in small business, manufacturing or construction; while many people have at least one relative in US, Golden Venture, decrepit freighter packed with illegal immigrants that ran aground 10 years ago in New York City, killing 10 people, became shorthand for cruel world of exploitation; maps; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; More Losers in Funds Seek Equity in Court
abstract: Market Place article on small but growing number of investor suits against mutual funds and other investment funds; factors include rise in number of investors, stock price plunge and quest by plaintiffs' lawyers for deep pockets; suits against fund administrators are moving through courts even as Congress weighs regulatory changes (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Convictions In Killing Of Missionary Family
abstract: Orissa State (India) court convicts 13 men for 1999 murder of Australian missionary Graham Staines, who was burned alive in car along with his two sons (S)

headline: 78% of Bush's Postwar Spending Plan Is for Military
abstract: Pres Bush's $87 billion request for postwar costs is heavily weighted to maintaining military operations, with $65.5 billion directed to armed forces, $15 billion toward rebuilding Iraq, $5 billion toward building its security forces, and $800 million to new spending for civilian programs in Afghanistan; combined with earlier $79 billion approved by Congress to conduct war and pay initial postwar expenses, it would bring cost to United States of deposing Saddam Hussein and stabilizing Iraq and Afghanistan this year and next to $166 billion; Bush administration officials say their main financial goal is to squeeze donations from other countries to help pay for physical reconstruction of Iraq; total cost of reconstruction has been put at $50 billion to $75 billion; photo; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: ABN Profit Rises 46%
abstract: Banking company ABN Amro Holding says that its second-quarter profit rose 46 percent, to 782 million euros ($887.3 million) (S)

headline: $8 Billion in Cash in Bronfman Bid
abstract: Group led by Edgar Bronfman Jr that is bidding for entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal has made offer that includes about $8 billion in cash; amount of cash being proposed is higher than what NBC is said to be offering (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Murder Inquiry Faulted
abstract: European Court of Human Rights rules that Britain failed to provide an adaquate investigation into 1989 death of Patrick Finucane;, prominent Catholic lawyer in Belfast was shot to death by Protestant gunmen, allegedly in collusion with Royal Ulster Constabulary; court orders payment of legal costs to his widow; photo (S)

headline: On Iraq and Bush's Speech, a Sampling of the Public Pulse Finds Varying Beats
abstract: Pres Bush's speech on Iraq seems to have changed few minds among people in and around Atlanta, Ga; Democrats by and large remain impatient for American effort in Iraq to end, while Republicans generally say they still back administration's policy; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Talks On Control Of Steel
abstract: Polish government says it will hold exclusive talks for control of about 70 percent of Poland's steel industry with LNM Holdings, British-Dutch steelmaker largely owned by Indian-born billionaire Lakshmi N Mittal; rejects rival bid from US Steel; government cancels expected $600 million sale of oil refiner Lotos to Poland's largest energy company PKN Orlen and British-investment group Rotch Energy; Treasury ministry says it will merge Lotos with three ailing, government-owned refineries in Southern Poland (S)

headline: Personal Business; The Unemployed Lose More Than a Paycheck
abstract: Corpor

headline: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Cooperation Agreement
abstract: European Union and Japan agree to cooperate more closely in field of competition regulation; will exchange general information about antitrust and merger probes and will work closer to stem rise in international cartels (S)

headline: Power Shift Between Argentina and the I.M.F.
abstract: August promises to be interesting month in Argentina; in perceptible shift in balance of power, somewhat feisty Argentina will be meeting less imperious International Monetary Fund to hammer out new three-year accord; for both sides, much rides on deal to replace current eight-month emergency agreement that expires Aug 31; Argentina owes $14.3 billion to IMF, more than 500 percent of country's statutory IMF quota; photo of Argentine Pres Nestor Kirchner with Pres Bush in Washington (M)

headline: JetBlue Target Of Inquiries By 2 Agencies
abstract: Homeland Security Department and Federal Trade Commission open investigations into JetBlue Airways in response to airline's admission that it provided travel records of 1.1 million passengers in 2001 and 2002 to Army contractor Torch Concepts, violating its own privacy rules; moves come at JetBlue dicloses it has hired Deloitte & Touche to review company's privacy policies and determine if they needed to be revamped; airline apologized to customers last week after disclosing it provided Torch Concepts with more than five million computer files, reflecting travel records of 1.1 million passengers; Torch Concepts matched JetBlue records against other database to determine passengers' Social Security numbers, occupations and family size in effort to identify potential terrorists; Homeland Security Department chief privacy officer Nuala O'Connor Kelly is conducting inquiry; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 93,000 Jobs Lost in August; Jobless Rate Falls to 6.1%  The Labor Department announced that 93,000 jobs were lost in August, countering expectations that employment would begin to expand and extending to 22 months an economic recovery that has failed to halt job losses.    The unemployment rate declined to 6.1 percent from 6.2 percent in July, but economists said that was apparently because of a surge in the number of people who, having lost jobs, listed themselves as self-employed rather than unemployed. [Page A1.]

headline: Charter to Sell Junk Bonds
abstract: Charter Communications Inc will sell about $1.7 billion of junk bonds, gaining cash to buy back some convertible notes and more time to pay debt (S)

headline: Bali Blast Defendant Gets Death Sentence
abstract: An Indonesian court sentenced a suspected member of the militant group Jemaah Islamiyah to death after convicting him for plotting the Bali nightclub bombing that killed 202 people in October.     Immediately after the verdict, the defendant, who is known as Amrozi, swiveled in his chair and with both hands gave thumbs-up signs to spectators in the courtroom, including survivors of the bombing and families of the victims. After his trial began, in mid-May, Amrozi indicated that he wanted to become a martyr, and he mounted little defense during the proceedings.

headline: Nokia Forecast Worries Skeptical Investors
abstract: Nokia left investors unimpressed today with a forecast that it would earn less from handset sales despite third-quarter profits at the high end of its forecasts.

headline: In Ruined Capital, Liberians Fear for Shaky Peace
abstract: Buildings housing Liberia's Senate, House of Representatives and Supreme Court are in shambles, smashed and looted by army of Pres Charles G Taylor, and officials examining them express grave doubts about prospects for power-sharing agreement signed on Aug 18 between country's rulers and rebels; rebels and handful of ruling party leaders left behind by Taylor say they will not claim top four posts for next two years, yielding jobs of chairman, vice-chairman, Senate president and House speaker to civilian noncombatants; election once scheduled for October is reset for October 2005; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FOG CUTTER CAPITAL GROUP INC., Portland, Ore., an investment firm, said that it had acquired Magic Johnson's majority stake in Fatburger Holdings Inc., a chain of 49 hamburger restaurants, for a $6 million investment and financing package.    CASCADES INC., Kingsey Falls, Quebec, a maker of paper towels, napkins and tissue paper, said that it had bid about $14.3 million for an idle plant in Memphis owned by the bankrupt American Tissue Inc., Hauppauge, N.Y., whose assets are being auctioned off.

headline: Survey Finds Fraud's Reach In Big Business
abstract: Companies surveyed by accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers and law firm of Wilmer Cutler & Pickering shows fraud and other kinds of economic crime have victimized more than third of companies surveyed; about 36 percent of companies whose executives responded to survey say they have been victims of asset misappropriation--usually theft or embezzlement--or some other kind of economic crime in last two years; study also finds . that while executives feared that financial misrepresentation--tampering with balance sheets or earnings reports--is rampant, only two of surveyed companies said they suffered from such manipulation (M)

headline: Sad to See Summer End? Travel Industry Is, Too
abstract: Long lines at airports, car-rental counters and hotel registration desks this Labor Day weekend are of little consolation to weary travel industry, which is looking past them to expectations of another difficult fall; analysts and executives fear that travel industry's problems will return; officials across travel industry note that leisure and business travelers are waiting far longer than they did in past to book trips, making demand difficult to forecast and creating some optimism that things might turn out better than expected; Air Transport Association managing director John P Heimlich says spurt of business this summer was partly result of pent-up demand by travelers who put off winter and spring trips because of concerns over war in Iraq and SARS; says there is no imminent rebound in business travel, which is off 15 percent from 2000; graph; photo (M)

headline: China's Leader Gives No Sign of Changes to Come
abstract: Pres Hu Jintao says in major address that 'foremost political duty' of China's leaders is to carry out ideological theories of former Pres Jiang Zemin; tells meeting on Communist Party's 82nd anniversary that members must rededicate themselves to helping urban and rural poor; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Companies are trying once again to find ways to turn penny-ante charges for Web viewing into profits.
abstract: Start-up Internet companies are again trying to create effective online micropayment systems for very low-priced items that would let customers pay pennies for digital content and help online merchants collect small fees; BitPass and Peppercoin have rolled out test verisons of their services, attracting attention from investors, merchants and some customers; photo (M)

headline: For Mixed-Race South Africans, Equity Is Elusive
abstract: Mixed-race people in South Africa are still denied status as first-class citizens; one mixed-race South African says that under apartheid, they were not white enough, and that now they are not black enough; many mixed-race people of Cape Flats, where poverty and unemployment help push young men into violent street gangs and where life seems to have gotten harder since apartheid's end, say they feel there is no place for them in new South Africa; photos; map (M)

headline: Shell to Avoid Oil Drilling At Sites Listed By Unesco
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell promises to avoid oil exploring or drilling on sites that carry United Nation's World Heritage designation; it is first energy company to make such a promise; Shell's decision comes week after International Council on Mining and Metals, group of world's 15 largest mining companies, said it would stop exploring or mining on World Heritage sites (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lord Archer Is Freed
abstract: Jeffrey Archer, millionaire novelist and House of Lords member, is released from prison after serving half his four-year sentence for perjury and obstruction of justice stemming from his 1987 libel trial against London newspaper that reported that Archer had paid hush money to prostitute; photo (S)

headline: SureBeam Hires Accountants for a Review
abstract: SureBeam Corp, which has fired two auditors this year and faces possible delisting from Nasdaq, says it is still looking for auditor; says it found accounting firm identified as McGladrey & Pullen to conduct 'independent review of issues raised by Deloitte & Touche,' last auditor that was fired; company fired Deloitte after it discharged KPMG (S)

headline: Times Co. Says Profit Will Not Meet Estimates
abstract: New York Times Company says its earnings for third quarter will probably be lower than analysts have forecast because of weaker-than-expected advertising demand; ad revenue at Times Co's newspaper group has risen 1.7 percent, to $1.2 billion so far this year from $1.18 billion year ago; senior vice president Leonard P Forman says weak ad environment in July continued throughout August; International Herald Tribune, which has been owned by Times Co since January, says it will no longer accept advertising for escort services; decision is in part response to reports that suspected prostitution ring, now subject of trial in France, used such ads to communicate with clients (M)

headline: France Makes Major Changes in Pension Law
abstract: France's Senate and National Assembly approve groundbreaking law that would force French to work longer before becoming eligible to retire on full pension; vote seen as victory for center-right government of Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin, architect of reform of country's expensive and generous pension plan; law states that public sector workers, more than one-fourth of French work force, must follow same general formula as private sector by 2008, and must contribute to state pension system for 40 years instead of 37 and half (M)

headline: TENET SELLS FOUR ARKANSAS HOSPITALS TO TRIAD
abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp sells four hospitals in Arkansas to Triad Hospitals Inc for $134 million to reduce debts; assumes $8 million of Tenet's debt (S)

headline: British Yellow Pages' Owner Revives Stock Offering Plan
abstract: Yell Group, which publishes British yellow pages, says it will try again to go public in 850 million pound ($1.4 billion) stock offering that, if successful, would be world's largest this year; Yell Group, which is 90 percent owned by Hicks, Muse, Tate and Furst and Apax Partners, plans to list on London Stock Exchange about July 9; estimates that its shares will trade at 250 to 300 pence ($4.16 to $4.99); company cancelled initial offering last July few days before offering date, citing deterioration in market for new stocks; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Displays Bodies of Hussein's 2 Sons
abstract: American officials displayed the bodies of Uday and Qusay Hussein today and said they had reconstructed their faces with putty and repaired wounds the men had sustained in the shoot-out on Tuesday.

headline: Patents; Verifying people's identities by using their hands, eyes or voices.
abstract: Recently patented identification devices include method developed by Stephen Marksteiner for verifying that fingerprints are from 'living human skin,' iris scanning device designed by Takahiro Oda that gauges whether physical reaction of eye is appropriate, all-in-one biometric sensor embedded in stylus or pen that can be used with electronic and computer systems designed by Gerald Black and Vahe Kaladjian's design for jewelry with person's fingerprints cast into its surface (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Expanding Gas Production
abstract: French-Belgian oil and chemicals group Total plans to expand its gas exploration operations and increase production amid continued high gas prices; estimates that by 2007, exploration and production will account for 60 percent of capital employed, compared with 48 percent last year (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Debt Relief
abstract: Korea Asset Management Corp will buy another 3 trillion won of nonperforming loans from country's nine credit card companies (S)

headline: Indonesians Answer Critics Of Trial Verdict
abstract: Indonesians blame United States for withholding evidence that would have helped convict militant Islamic cleric Abu Bakar Bashir; instead, Bashir was acquitted of role in Bali nightclub bombing because no connection was made between him and Jamaah Islamiyah terror group (M)

headline: Meeting of Moguls, if Not of Minds
abstract: Media moguls gather in Sun Valley, Idaho, for annual summer camp organized by investment banker Herbert Allen, and conversation tends to turn on who may soon be acquiring whom and particularly on auction of Vivendi Universal's film and television studios, cable channels and theme parks; Vivendi deal is seen as catalyst for more to come; some executives doubt wisdom of FCC's recent loosening of restraints on media ownership and further industry consolidation; photos (M)

headline: In Portugal, Cork Makers Just Say No To Screwcap
abstract: Growing use of non-cork bottle stoppers by global wine industry is sharply opposed in Portugal, origin of more than half of $2 billion in corks produced annually; industry is centered in Alentejo region in country's south-central area; cork is produced by stripping bark from mature oak trees, with average tree yielding sufficient material to cork 4,000 bottles each harvest; each tree may be stripped once every nine years during its expected 200-year lifespan (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Expects To Meet Forecast
abstract: The EMC Corporation, one of the largest makers of computer data-storage systems, said yesterday that it expected to meet its third-quarter forecast for profit to rise to 4 cents a share, on an estimated sales increase to $1.45 billion to $1.5 billion. Second-half sales will increase by an unspecified percentage in the ''midteens,'' and gross margin, the share of sales left after production costs are paid, will widen to 48 percent by the end of 2004, EMC said. The company held its annual analyst meeting in New York yesterday. The chief executive, Joseph M. Tucci, is rebuilding profit after losses in 2002 and 2001. Last year, EMC had third-quarter net income of $21.3 million, or 1 cent a share, on sales of $1.26 billion.

headline: Better Off Without E-Mail?
abstract: You already know that individuals and businesses worldwide are struggling to fix e-mail. The spam, the viruses, the irrelevant forwarding, the insipid joke mailing lists...whatever productivity gains e-mail once offered are rapidly being offset by the time we spend weeding through the chaff.

headline: After Decades, Russia Narrows Grounds for Abortions
abstract: Russia increases its restrictions on abortion for first time in nearly half a century, reflecting first stirrings of wider debate over morality of abortion as well as effect abortions are having on women's health and country's declining population trend; regulations remain permissive, with no limits on abortions in first 12 weeks of pregnancy; collapse of Soviet Union and increased availability of contraceptives have already caused abortions to decline from high of 4.6 million in 1988 to 1.7 million in 2002; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Charges Ernst & Young Ex-Partner In Audit Case
abstract: Thomas Trauger, former partner with Ernst & Young, is arrested and charged with destroying and altering audit work papers related to federal probe of bank subsidiary of NextCard Inc, consumer loan company that is being liquidated; Securities and Exchange Commission records show Trauger was assisted in effort by Ernst & Young former senior manager Oliver Flanagan and former audit manager Michael Mullen; Mullen is not charged in criminal case; Flanagan entered guilty plea in August but plea remained under seal until Sept 25 (M)

headline: Fishing for Information? Try Better Bait
abstract: New book Google Hacks: 100 Industrial-Strength Tips and Tools by Tara Calishain and Rael Cornfest is latest resource in growing industry to help people become better online searchers; tips for using truncation devices and other shortcuts noted; drawing (M)

headline: Deutsch to Handle Monster's U.S. Work
abstract: Monster, job search engine, names Deutsch to handle creative duties on its US account (S)

headline: JUDGE APPROVES SALE OF ALTERRA HEALTHCARE TO EMERITUS
abstract: Federal bankruptcy Judge Mary F Walrath approves Emeritus Corp's acquisition of Alterra Healthcare, nursing home operator, for $76 million (S)

headline: China Ousts 4 Over Korea Refugee Issue
abstract: China deports two South Korean reporters and two Japanese who have been held for three weeks in connection with attempt to smuggle nine North Korean refugees out of China; fate of refugees is unknown (S)

headline: PRESIDENT ORDERS TROOP DEPLOYMENT TO LIBERIAN COAST
abstract: Pres Bush orders naval amphibious force that includes 2,300 marines to sail from Mediterranean and nearby waters to position off Liberia's coast; leaves force's mission vague; says conditions in Liberia are deteriorating rapidly; holds Pres Charles Taylor must leave country; announcement catches Pentagon officials off guard, sending them scrambling to explain that three ships carrying marines could be off Liberian coast within week or so; decision falls far short of actually sending American troops ashore; United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan hails decision; photo (M)

headline: SONOCO PRODUCTS TO CUT 340 JOBS AND CLOSE 20 PLANTS
abstract: Sunoco Products Co, maker of boxes, plastic bags and food cans, will eliminate 340 jobs and close 20 plants to reduce expenses because of declining sales and prices, and higher costs (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Presses Return Of Refugees
abstract: Chechen administration head Akhmad Kadyrov, after meeting with Russian President Vladimir V Putin, announces all refugees living in Ingushetia must return to Chechnya by September; presidential elections in Chechnya are set for October 5 (S)

headline: Ford Says New S.U.V.'s Less Fuel-Efficient Than Old Ones
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's sport utility vehicles will be less fuel-efficient in the 2003 model year than the previous year, the company said in a new report.

headline: NATO Takes Over Peacekeeping Force in Afghanistan
abstract: In its first mission beyond Europe's frontiers, NATO took formal control of Afghanistan's peacekeeping force today.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Volkswagen Wage Cuts
abstract: Senior management and other nonunion workers at Mexican plant of Volkswagen will take 8 percent wage cut after union agrees to shorter workweek to maintain profit as world demand for its cards drops; company's 9,800 unionized workers have already accepted reduced four-day workweek to prevent 2,000 job losses as plant's production of new Beetles and Jettas has fallen 11.2 percent so far this year on fewer exports to US, its main market (S)

headline: DataBank; Technology Stocks Keep the Markets Happy
abstract: Graphs and charts on week in stock market

headline: London Journal; What's in a Name? In This Case, Fancy Sandwiches
abstract: Family of Britain's 11th Earl of Sandwich has set up sandwich-selling business; Lord Sandwich is one of few hereditary peers who won right to keep their seats in House of Lords after most were evicted by government in 1999; idea for sandwich company was born in 1992 when Lord Sandwich's second son, Orlando Montagu, stumbled on snack bar that called itself Earl of Sandwich and used family as its theme; photo (M)

headline: ROCHE BARRED FROM SELLING SOME INSULIN PUMPS IN U.S.
abstract: FDA bars Roche Holding from selling insulin pumps in US made by recently acquired Disetronic Holding until manufacturing violations are resolved; discovered quality flaws while inspecting plant in Burgdorf, Switzerland (S)

headline: Cisco Reports Higher Profit on Lower Revenue
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc reports net income of $982 million for firscal fourth quarter, up from $772 million in year-earlier period; sales were $4.7 billion, down 2.6 percent from year ago, but up from previous quarter's $4.6 billion; president and chief executive John Chambers is only cautiously optimistic about outlook, disappointing analysts (M)

headline: Jury Acquits Pilot Who Questioned Liability for Income Tax
abstract: Federal jury in Memphis acquits FedEx pilot Vernice Kuglin on six counts of tax evasion after she testifies that she wrote letters asking Internal Revenue Service what law required her to pay taxes but never received response; verdict brings into question IRS practice of ignoring such questions, which it regards as frivolous because first words of IRS code are 'a tax is hereby imposed'; Kuglin filed withholding statement on Dec 30, 1995, directing that no taxes be withheld from her pay; she earned $920,000 from 1996 through 2001 but no taxes were withheld; normal taxes for period would have been about $250,000; acquittal does not relieve Kuglin of obligation to pay taxes; photo (M)

headline: The Winner Is: Las Vegas
abstract: Maritz Travel reports Las Vegas is again top

headline: Stewart Loses in Attempt to Affect Sentencing
abstract: A federal judge has refused to grant Martha Stewart's request to have the federal sentencing guidelines declared unconstitutional.

headline: Alstom to Issue $692 Million In New Shares
abstract: Alstom SA's shareholders approve sale of as much as 600 million euros ($692 million) in stock, move seen as vital for struggling power and transportation company (M)

headline: Information On-Ramp Crosses a Digital Divide
abstract: Private-public partnership in Winston-Salem, NC, is rolling out WinstonNet, one of most advanced networks in nation offering computer resources, training and high-speed Internet access to those without home computers; program will allow any resident with library card to have e-mail account, transact business with city and store homework or other documents on central server so they can be easily retireved from any site on network; map; photos (M)

headline: Fine-Tuning the Sound in Your Own Cinema
abstract: Setting up speaker system for home theater can be fraught with problems; new products and technologies can help achieve cinematic sound regardless of how acoustically imperfect room may be; drawing (M)

headline: Everything for the Pointy-Pencil Crowd
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column surveys Web sites with back-to-school supplies; drawing (M)

headline: Rebels Move Fighting Into Burundi's Capital
abstract: Hutu rebels in Burundi, who for last few years have limited their fighting to rugged rural areas of country, are making bold incursions into heart of capital, Bujumbura; city's predominantly Tutsi residents are suddenly forced to confront fierce ethnic divisions that they thought were resolved by peace accord; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: New President Pledges Corruption Fight
abstract: Nicanor Duarte Frutos, vowing to stop widespread corruption in Paraguay, is sworn in as president; predecessor Luis Gonzalez Macchi is forbidden to leave country until investigation into alleged corruption, including $16 million bank transfer, is complete (S)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: List of Americans newly confirmed dead in Iraq; 307 members of US military have died there since start of war

headline: FORD TO USE LOW FINANCING AS DRAW FOR F-150 PICKUP
abstract: Ford Motor Co will offer financing on its redesigned F-150 pickup truck at rates as low as 2.9 percent but will not offer rebates (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless Settles Lawsuit
abstract: AT&T Wireless and eight former TeleCorp PCS executives agree to pay $47.5 million to settle suit charging mobile-phone company secretly paid TeleCorp executives $140 million to win their support for its $4.6 billion 2002 purchase of TeleCorp; settlement with Telecorp investors comes as AT&T Wireless completes buyback of $540.4 million in high-interest debt it assumed in acquisition of TeleCorp and another company (S)

headline: Verizon and Unions Agree on Tentative 5-Year Contract
abstract: Verizon Communications and its unions announce agreement on tentative contrat that includes one-year wage freeze and retains strong job security protections that company had sought to weaken; Verizon's two main unions boast that they achieved major victories on job security and health insurance, having beaten back Verizon's efforts to make its unionized workers pay significantly more toward their health coverage; unions agree that new hires will not be covered by job security provisions; Communications Workers of America president Morton Bahr comments; specifics of contract detailed (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Posts Profit
abstract: Allianz, German insurance and banking group, posts net profit of 622 million euros ($704 million) in second quarter after four quarters of losses (S)

headline: Pursuing Hussein, U.S. Captures 175 In Dozens of Raids
abstract: American soldiers in Iraq conduct dozens of raids and seize more than 175 suspected Saddam Hussein loyalists in his hometown of Tikrit, in what military calls accelerating drive to flush him out of hiding; forces conduct 58 raids in 24 hours, garnering clues to Hussein's whereabouts; hunt coincides with new audiotape, apparently by Hussein, referring to deaths of sons Uday and Qusay; Iraqis seized include Hussein bodyguard Adnan Abdullah Abid al-Musslit and Tikrit security chief Daher Ziana; photo; map; Gen Richard B Myers warns Tikrit-Baghdad area is still 'war zone'; former Baghdad University dean Dr Muhammad Abdullah Falah Alrawi is shot to death in apparent revenge for his close links to Hussein; Iraqi Governing Council announces rotating chairmanship (M)

headline: Body of Man Believed to Be British Arms Expert Is Found
abstract: The body of a man believed to be the arms expert at the center of a high-profile dispute over the validity of government weapons intelligence was found today.

headline: E-Mail Etiquette Redux
abstract: I’m incredibly proud of you, the Circuits newsletter readership -- or maybe I should say writership. Not only were your 2,000 responses to my July 10 “E-mail Etiquette” column thoughtful, funny, articulate and persuasive, but not a single one was abusive and mean.

headline: Arafat's Security Adviser Calls for Cease-Fire
abstract: Yasir Arafat's security adviser called for a Mideast cease-fire, but Israel immediately dismissed the plan as inadequate without Palestinian action to break up violent factions.

headline: Forsaking Pixel Power for Shutter Speed
abstract: Nikon's latest professional digital camera is built around new type of imaging sensor; new chip promises sharp reduction in shutter lag that frustrates many consumers; reflects shift in emphasis to pixel power; photo (M)

headline: Strong Dollar, Weak Dollar: Anyone Have A Scorecard?
abstract: Whether China and Japan will move to weaken dollar remains unclear three days after Group of 7 suggested that they adopt 'flexible exchange rates'; dollar, after plunging to three-year low against Japanese yen on Sept 22, climbs; anxiety about continued strength of dollar against most Asian currencies is running high in US and Europe; American manufacturers have complained for years that strength of dollar has devastated their competitive position by making foreign imports cheap and their own exports expensive; Bush administration has abandoned strong-dollar policy of Clinton administration and pressured Asian countries to let their currencies appreciate against it; European leaders are almost equally anxious; euro has soared against dollar as well as Asian currencies over last two years; graphs (M)

headline: Tests Show a Decline In Workplace Drug Use
abstract: Drug test maker Quest Diagnostics reports that use of drugs in workplace declined in 2002 to lowest level since 1988; 4.4 percent of those tested were positive, down from 4.6 percent in 2001 and 13.6 percent in 1988 (S)

headline: WorldCom and Dissident Creditors Settle on Payment Plan
abstract: The agreement should help remove a major impediment to WorldCom's emergence from bankruptcy protection.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Hostage Holders Seek Contact
abstract: Algerian kidnappers holding 14 Europeans hostage in Mali are reported to have called German officials in attempt to deal directly with them on ransom demands (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.75       Federal funds   1.00   0.97   1.68       3-month Libor   1.14   1.14   1.83       3-month T-bills   0.94   0.94   1.64       6-month T-bills   1.01   1.01   1.63       10-yr. T-infl.   2.17   2.24   2.24       10-yr. T-note   4.18   4.28   3.84       30-yr.
