headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hilton And I.B.M. To Develop Hotel Kiosks
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp will work with IBM to develop kiosks that Hilton plans to install in hotel lobbies; terms undisclosed; Hilton plans to begin testing kiosks, which allow guests faster ways to check in and out of their rooms, in Hilton New York and Hilton Chicago hotels in fourth quarter (S)

headline: A Top Iraqi Captured
abstract: Ali Hassan al-Majid, a cousin and adviser of Saddam Hussein, has been captured, the American military said. He ordered the use of poison gas against Kurds in 1988, earning the nickname Chemical Ali.    Article, Page A12.

headline: A Media Rule By the F.C.C. Is in Jeopardy In the House
abstract: House, in stunning political development, seems poised to support reversal of new Federal Communications Commission rule that lets nation's biggest TV networks grow even larger; debates measure that would bar FCC from spending any money to permit transfer of broadcast license to any company that can reach 35 percent of nation's viewers; growing political movement to reverse eased media ownership rules is remarkable at time when Washington's major political institutions and federal courts have been dominated by deregulatory thinkers; House had been expected to block any efforts to change new rules (M)

headline: The Awkward Rite of Summer: Hear the One About the Intern. . .
abstract: Summer internship offers opportunity for young people to acquaint themselves with acceptable office deportment; egregious gaffes of several summer interns noted; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bids For Bank
abstract: South Korea's Kookmin Bank joins with Asia Financial Holdings in bid to acquire Bank Internasional Indonesia; United Overseas Bank of Singapore makes separate bid to acquire Bank Internasional, which is also being sought by Panin Bank of Indonesia (S)

headline: U.S. ABANDONS IDEA OF BIGGER U.N. ROLE IN IRAQ OCCUPATION
abstract: Bush administration abandons idea of giving United Nations larger role in occupation of Iraq as sought by France, India and other countries as condition for their participation in peacekeeping there; says it prefers not to involve UN or countries that opposed war and are now eager to exercise influence in postwar Iraq; says United States will widen effort to enlist other countries to assist occupation forces in Iraq; currently there are 139,000 US troops there, 11,000 British troops and 10,000 troops from 17 other countries; administration's position could complicate its hopes of bringing large number of American troops home in short order; on separate front, United States moves at Security Council to get resolution passed that would welcome establishment of 25-member Governing Council set up by US and Britain in Iraq; Security Council is expected to pass resolution, but measure of its misgivings is evident in last-minute decision to change wording, saying Security Council 'welcomes' Iraqi group rather than 'endorses' it (M)

headline: With U.S. in Neighborhood, Syria Eases Its Grip
abstract: Argument that Syrian government would ease grip with US in neighboring Iraq comes up against more complicated reality suggesting that future may hold something less than democratic contagion; Pres Bashar al-Assad has ordered Baath Party to stay out of day-to-day bureaucracy and decreed other changes, including amnesty that led to dropping of charges against Haitham Maleh, longtime rights campaigner; government's tolerance for political cartoons of Ali Firzat ends, on the other hand, as he gives up printing paper; cartoon (M)

headline: Israeli Strike, Missing Target, Kills 1 and Wounds 20
abstract: It was the third such Israeli attack in a week, since a Hamas suicide bomber killed 21 people aboard a city bus.

headline: French Aide Warns Militant Mosques and Radical Muslims
abstract: The interior minister threatened today to close any mosque that is considered extremist and expel radical Muslim prayer leaders.

headline: INTEL TO OPEN A RESEARCH OPERATION IN SOUTH KOREA
abstract: Intel Corp will open research center in South Korea this year to develop semiconductors for mobile telephones and electronics (S)

headline: Telecom Role In Decline, JDS Uniphase Gets New Boss
abstract: JDS Uniphase says founder Jozef Straus is retiring as chief executive and co-chairman and will be replaced by Kevin Kennedy, formerly chief operating officer of Openwave Systems Inc; chief operating officer Syrus Madavi resigns; company's shares rise 31 cents, or nearly 10 percent, to $3.50; stock traded above $146 in March 2000 (M)

headline: Hotel bombings tied to Basque separatists : Two blasts wound 13 in Spain
abstract: MADRID:—  Two bombs planted in beachfront hotels on Spain's Mediterranean coast exploded Tuesday, wounding 13 people, including foreign students, tourists and police officers.

headline: U.S. WANTS IRAQIS TO JUDGE HUSSEIN
abstract: United States plans to create special tribunal of Iraqi judges to try Saddam Hussein for crimes against humanity if he is captured; State Dept official says administration has ruled out seeking broad-based international tribunal or United Nations-led effort to try Hussein, thinking that there should be Iraqi-led process, that ownership of these matters should be in hands of Iraqi people; military officials are sounding more optimistic that increasing number of tips from Iraqis will help locate Hussein; Judge Gilbert S Merritt of US Court of Appeals for Sixth Circuit recently returned from several weeks in Iraq advising American and Iraqi authorities about establishing war-crimes court and other legal issues; he says officials want to create tribunal that would have stature to be seen as free of American control; says Iraqi judges and lawyers argue that allowing them to try Hussein would be seen as 'vote of confidence' in Iraqi judiciary (M)

headline: LEADER OF LIBERIA SURRENDERS POWER AND ENTERS EXILE
abstract: Charles G Taylor resigns from presidency of Liberia and leaves country for exile in Nigeria; before departing, in address to crowd assembled at Executive Mansion, he calls himself 'sacrificial lamb' and says 'history will be kind to me'; he blames international forces for his downfall and challenges United States in particular to step in, now that he has done his part; Pres Bush had made Taylor's exit condition for any American involvement in peacekeeping there; Taylor hands over presidency to Vice Pres Moses Blah, who will steer country until new transitional government takes over in mid-October; Taylor is accused of spreading conflict across region, and has been under United Nations arms embargo and been charged with playing role in civil war in neighboring Sierra Leone; his departure prompts Pres John Kufuor of Ghana, current leader of regional block Economic Community of West African States, to proclaim 'the war in Liberia has ended'; it is not clear when Americans, or West African peacekeepers already on ground, would secure vital Free Port of Monrovia to open lifeline for food and fuel to rest of city; photos (M)

headline: Suggestions for the New Version of Microsoft Office
abstract: This fall, the world will be treated to yet another version of Microsoft Office, the software suite that towers over the world like the Jolly Green Giant.

headline: Intel Says It Is Ready to Sell 2 New Chips in Itanium Line
abstract: Intel will offer two new versions of its Itanium 2 processor, as it tries to gain wider acceptance of its high-performance server chips; seeks to cut cost of server using chip to under $7,000; second, low-voltage version will use less power (M)

headline: Verizon Talks Are Halted
abstract: Verizon Communications Inc and unions representing 78,000 employees in Northeast halt contract talks until Sept 2 (S)

headline: For Newer Microsoft Employees, a Sense of Redress
abstract: Microsoft Corp's decision to replace stock options with grants of stock itself, even if they will come in small quantities, goes long way in lifting morale; under stock award plan, employees will still be able to make money on their stock-based pay even if company shares are not rising; Microsoft executives say they hope move will create fairer compensation system and help attract and retain talented employees who might otherwise be drawn to start-up companies; several employees say they believe company's strategy will work; employees Francois Ajenstat and David A Pritchard comment; photos (M)

headline: Bill Asks More of Fund Families
abstract: House committee approves bill to require mutual fund companies to disclose more about fees and management compensation (S)

headline: Flow of Saudis' Cash to Hamas Is Scrutinized
abstract: Saudis are under fresh scrutiny by American and European investigators in Saudi Arabia and Israel for their political and financial support of Hamas, militant Palestinian group whose suicide bombings have spurred deterioration of Israeli-Palestinian relations; American and Israeli officials say at least 50 percent of Hamas's current $10 million annual operating budget comes from people in Saudi Arabia; Saudi portion grew larger after Sept 11, 2001, as donations from United States, Europe and other Persian Gulf nations dried up; is very small part of hundreds of millions of dollars that flow into Saudi charities each year; most of donations are in cash, making them hard to track; Saudi officials deny government money goes to Hamas, although Hamas document shows senior leader Khalid Mishaal met with Crown Prince Abdullah at fund-raising conference in Riyadh and thanked him for aid; say their government support for Palestinians, some $80 million or more a year, goes solely to Palestinian Authority (M)

headline: Kodak Reports Lower Profits And May Cut 6,000 Workers
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co, scrambling to keep costs in line with shrinking film revenue, says it will cut up to 6,000 jobs; posts second-quarter income of $112 million, compared with $284 million in 2002 period; sales are flat at $3.35 billion; predicts income in second half will fall sharply from 2002 period (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Blast Kills 7
abstract: Pilgrims en route to Hindu temple in Jammu and Kashmir are caught in twin bomb blasts that kill 7 people and injure 38 others (S)

headline: Bush Stresses Policy Plans With Powell, Not the Future
abstract: President Bush stood at the side of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell today and proclaimed that ''this guy has done a fabulous job,'' but he left open the question of whether Mr. Powell would serve in a second Bush administration.    ''We'll deal with it at the right time,'' Mr. Bush said, as he and Mr. Powell stood outside the Coffee Station, Crawford's combination restaurant and gas station, in a six-minute question-and-answer session with reporters. It was the first time the two had appeared in public together since The Washington Post reported on Monday that Mr. Powell and his deputy, Richard L. Armitage, would not serve a second term. The White House vehemently denied the article's assertions, and Mr. Bush's show of support for Mr. Powell today appeared intended to put the assertions to rest.

headline: How The Office Becomes a Classroom
abstract: Readers share anecdotes about classes on the job; drawing (M)

headline: Disney Wins Summer Race At Box Office With 2 Big Hits
abstract: Walt Disney Co is clear winner in summer movie season, distributing blockbuster Finding Nemo, which grossed $330 million, and producing hit Pirates of the Caribbean, which took in $261 million; Revolution Studios produced two of summer's least-watched films, Hollywood Homicide, which grossed $30 million, and Gigli, which made only $6 million; Hollywood studios trying to draw lessons from summer can conclude that big-budget sequels are vulnerable, and that more modest fare aimed at general audiences is more likely to prevail; overall, domestic summer box office receipts are up 2 percent to $3.59 billion; photos; graphs (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Buyout Firms Pull Millions in Cash From Holdings
abstract: Market Place column on moves by leveraged buyout firms to take tens of millions of dollars in profits from companies they own in form of special dividends, mostly financed by junk bonds and loans; profit-taking could help firms raise capital to make new acquisitions at time when it is hard for them to sell companies they own; photo (M)

headline: Judge Says Seattle Papers Must Stay Linked
abstract: Seattle State Judge Greg Canova rules that Seattle Times has not lost money for long enough time to justify end to 22-year-old joint operating agreement with Seattle Post-Intelligence; ruling preserves Seattle Times is considering appeal (M)

headline: Stock Offerings Planned
abstract: The following equity offerings are expected this week:

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Luxury Profits Rise
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton says net profit rose 24 percent, to 265 million euros ($297 million); operating income rose 4 percent, to 874 million euros ($980 million); chief executive Bernard Arnault comments; photo (S)

headline: Russia Allows Merger of 2 Giant Oil Companies
abstract: Russia approves merger of two of its largest oil companies, Yukos and Sibneft, clearing way for creation of world's fifth-largest publicly traded oil company; acts despite widening criminal investigation into Yukos, already Russia's largest oil producer; Yukos will pay $13 billion in cash and stock to buy Sibneft, Russia's fifth-largest oil company; photo (M)

headline: Tax Cut May Add New Meaning to Stock Buybacks
abstract: Analysis of corporate stock repurchases notes that new tax legislation, by equalizing treatment of dividends and capital gains, may increase usefulness of share repurchases as indication of company's underlying value; companies in past have rewarded shareholders with repurchases rather than dividends, which have been taxed at higher rates; graph (M)

headline: Nigeria Readies Peace Force for Liberia; Battles Go On
abstract: Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) announces that it could send as many as 1,300 Nigerian peacekeeping troops to Liberia within two weeks; decision comes after intense lobbying by United Nations Secretary Gen Kofi Annan; UN officials are hopeful that arrival of Nigerian vanguard could begin sequence of events that would end with departure of Pres Charles G Taylor and firm US commitment of peacekeeping troops; Washington has not yet committed to sending troops; Bush administration has insisted that Ecowas take lead (M)

headline: People
abstract: Lance Smith is named to new post of president and chief operating officer at Cossette Post; chairman Frank Sampagna, creative director Steve Crane and media services director Richard Lefkowitz are named managing partners; Foote Cone & Belding executive vice president Chris Becker is named chief creative director, succeeding Rich Russo, who is leaving (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: New Bid For Toy Retailer; ITALY: Fiat'S Sales Fall;.

headline: A Rebound for the Dollar, but Maybe Not for Long
abstract: Dollar bounces back against euro, climbing 9 percent since May 29; gain comes as data show America's economy rebounding and Europe's remaining weak; analysts predict that dollar's rebound will not last; chart shows net foreign purchases of US stocks and bonds (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Contract Ban May Cut WorldCom Profit
abstract: WorldCom Inc says its earnings might be reduced by $250 million through 2005 by federal government's plan to bar company from new phone and data contracts; federal government is WorldCom's biggest customer, generating about $1 billion in annual sales, or 6.3 percent of total revenue (S)

headline: Mixed View of a Pact for Generic Drugs
abstract: Prospect of trade agreement that would help give poor nations access to cheap generic drugs is criticized by activists but welcomed as progress by some health officials in developing countriews; representatives of many nongovernment health organizations working in developing world are highly critical of deal, saying it made too many concessions to Western drug companies and set too many conditions for poor nations; other say that while deal might seem to offer new opportunities on paper, few countries that produce generic drugs would likely be willing to risk wrath of US by repeatedly breaking patents to help their neighbors; photo (M)

headline: Chief Is Selected at ADC
abstract: ADC Telecommunications Inc names Robert Switz chief executive, succeeding Richard Roscitt (S)

headline: Patents; Hoping to wear pantyhose with sandals, a woman visited a seamstress and came away with a patent.
abstract: Karyn Cortani comments on her patent for panty hose woven into mitten shape at foot so that it can be worn with thong-type sandals; has begun offering hose on her Web site; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Weak Bond Auction; RUSSIA: Oil Shipments Start; SOUTH KOREA: Questions About Sk; JAPAN: Communications Venture; SINGAPORE: Airline Cuts Salaries;.

headline: WHX Agrees to Settle Pension Lawsuit
abstract: WHX Corp agrees to settle lawsuit involving pensions for workers at Wheeling-Pittsburgh steel division; agreement, between WHX, United Steelworkers of America and Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp ends lawsuit with federal agency; also ends pension agency's attempt to become trustee of pension plan of steel unit (S)

headline: CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY BACK SOME DEBT
abstract: Charter Communications Inc will buy back $609 million of its convertible notes in privately negotiated transactions (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jewish Museum A Target
abstract: Suspected terrorist Shadi Mohd Mustafa Abdellah states during his Dusseldorf trial that he was part of four person group planning attacks on Jewish targets in Dusseldorf and on Jewish Museum in Berlin (Germany); Palestinian from Jordan, he trained with Al Qaeda, but contends he was working with Al Tawhid, terrorist group (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Taubman Centers Wins Big Round in Takeover Fight  The Michigan Senate passed legislation that would change the state's takeover laws and would allow the Taubman family to block a hostile takeover of its shopping mall empire, voiding a federal court decision that prevented it from taking such action.    The legislation, backed by an intense lobbying campaign by the Taubman family and passed by a vote of 24 to 14, would make moot the $1.74 billion bid for Taubman Centers from the mall owners Simon Property Group and Westfield America Trust. [Page C4.]

headline: Kmart Chooses Grey Global Units
abstract: Kmart Corp names units of Grey Global Group to handle several major advertising and marketing assignments; total billings estimated at $200 million to $250 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle Bid For PeopleSoft Delayed
abstract: Oracle Corp's executive vice president Chuck Phillips says $7.25 billion hostile offer made by Oracle to acquire PeopleSoft Inc might not clear antitrust investigation by Justice Department until November (S)

headline: U.S. Penalizes 6 Asian Firms For Helping Iran Arm Itself
abstract: Bush administration imposes economic sanctions on five Chinese firms and North Korean company for assisting Iran's weapons program; does not specify shipments; State Department says action is not linked to visit by Chinese Deputy Min Wang Yi, who will urge US to meet again with North Korea on its nuclear program (M)

headline: Tenet Reports New Investigation of Its Deals With Doctors
abstract: Tenet Healthcare receives subpoenas from US attorney's office in Los Angeles seeking information about physician relocation agreements related to seven hospitals in South California, mainly in Los Angeles area, and also for more general information about physician-relocation agreements at all of Tenet's 114 hospitals; grand jury continues to investigate Tenet's Alvarado Hospital Medical Center in San Diego; Tenet expects hospital, and possibly company itself, to be indicted later this week; Alvarado chief executive Barry Weinbaum was indicted last month on charges of making illegal payments to doctors to induce them to refer patients to hospital; photo (M)

headline: Want to Stop the Conversation? Just Mention Your Finances
abstract: Abby Ellin column on money as taboo subject of conversation, whether its salaries, savings or debt; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Deutsche Telekom Seeks Polish Stake
abstract: Deutsche Telekom offers to pay 1 billion euros ($1.1 billion) to Elektrim and Vivendi Universal for 51 percent of Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa, Central Europe's biggest mobile phone company, that it does not already own (S)

headline: Global Crossing founder objects to cards bearing his likeness : An executive order:Cut the deck
abstract: Some people, it seems, just don't have a sense of humor. Take the lawyers representing Gary Winnick, the embattled founder of Global Crossing. Winnick started the world-spanning network company in 1997, only to ride it into bankruptcy five years later when it filed the sixth-largest Chapter 11 case in U.S. history in January 2002.

headline: Traffic crackdown starts to show results : Italy's drivers swerve toward the slow lane
abstract: MILAN:—  Midsummer is usually a nightmare for the Italian traffic police as millions of families pack their cars with bags and bambini and jam the highways.

headline: Europeans Warn Iran on Nuclear Inspections
abstract: Javier Solana, foreign policy chief of for European Union, presses Iran to sign protocol that would allow more aggressive inspections of its nuclear sites; warns of 'bad news for Iran' if it refuses to sign additional protocol (M)

headline: Administration Joins Outcry Against China Trade Policies
abstract: Bush administration singles out China for criticism over trade practices; Commerce Sec Donald L Evans announces plans for task force to investigate unfair trade restrictions, accusing China of backsliding on promises to ease restrictions on foreign companies, dismantle old trade barriers and clamp down on piracy; Democratic opponents of Pres Bush quickly denounce Evans's tough language on China as inadequate response to loss of American manufacturing jobs (M)

headline: Ex-Mayor of Toulouse, France, Is Clear in Murder Inquiry
abstract: The former mayor of Toulouse, Dominique Baudis, was allegedly involved in a sadomasochistic ring that purportedly led to the murder of at least one prostitute.

headline: Leading Shiite Cleric in Iraq Is Hurt in Deadly Bomb Attack
abstract: Senior religious officials were quick to blame the attack, which killed three, on members of the deposed Baath Party.

headline: Taking a Temperature By Squeezing The Trigger
abstract: MiniTempFS thermometer developed by Jacques Torres and his team at Raytek has become a hit in food industry because it gives precise surface reading of temperature of food or kitchen equipment without any direct contact; photos (M)

headline: Sharon Heading to Britain and U.S. for Talks on 'Road Map'
abstract: In the latest round of talks, the Palestinian security chief demanded the release of more than 5,000 prisoners held by Israel.

headline: Bond Sales Are Set For Coming Week
abstract: This week's schedule of Treasury auctions includes the sale of new three- and six-month bills today.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.93 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 1.01 percent.

headline: I.B.M. Explores Shift of Some Jobs Overseas
abstract: Top International Business Machines Corp employee relations executives recently told corporate colleagues around world in conference call that IBM must accelerate its efforts to move software design and other white collar jobs to India and other low-wage nations from United States to remain competitive; said shift was needed even though it risked backlash among politicians and IBM workers; IBM worker gave recording of call to Washington Alliance of Technology Workers; many politicians, including some in Bush administration, have begun voicing concerns about shift abroad of jobs in slumping information technology industry (M)

headline: Easy Does It for a Giant of Gyms
abstract: Profile of Gary Heavin, founder of Curves International fitness-center chain, which has become fastest-growing franchise in America by focusing on very people who are most likely to steer clear of health clubs: overweight middle-aged women who tire easily; he devised simple, 30-minute workout, barred men from the clubs and eliminated mirrors; photo (M)

headline: Tarbaek Journal; Fury, God and the Pastor's Disbelief
abstract: Thorkild Grosboll, popular Lutheran pastor in Danish village of Tarbaek, has been suspended as village pastor after saying in newspaper interview that he does not believe in a physical God; his remarks and suspension set off wave of theological discourse across Denmark, where religion is almost never defining political or personal issue; Bishop Lise-Lotte Rebel, who oversees Grosboll's parish, says that for man of God not to believe in God is unacceptable; in Tarbaek, Grosboll is hero; ultimate decision to defrock him rests with Tove Fergo, minister for ecclesiastical affairs, who has so far sided with Rebel; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FAIR ISAAC, San Rafael, Calif., a provider of marketing and database management services, said it had bought Diversified HealthCare Services, San Ramon, Calif., a provider of medical bill review products and services to insurers. Terms were not disclosed.    PANAMSAT, Wilton, Conn., the operator of commercial satellites, said it had agreed to buy Esatel Communications, Alexandria, Va., a provider of voice, data and Internet access to government agencies. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Marvel Posts Sharp Increase in Earnings
abstract: Marvel Enterprises Inc says second-quarter net income rose to $32.8 million from $8.38 million year earlier; sales increased 27 percent, to $90 million (S)û

headline: Business; Detroit Discovers That Women Like Power, Too
abstract: Automakers report that while women still want safety, security and reliability in cars they buy, they are increasingly drawn to power, speed and hot looks as well; photo (M)

headline: SHAREHOLDERS IN MIRANT GAIN VOICE IN REORGANIZATION
abstract: Justice Department lawyer charged with overseeing Mirant Corp's bankruptcy proceedings names committee to represent shareholders in company's reorganization (S)

headline: Axis Capital Shares Rise on Public Offering
abstract: Shares of Axis Capital Holdings rise 16 percent after it raises $473 million in this year's biggest initial public offering by insurance company; sells 21.5 million shares at $22; stock closes at $25.55 (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Dept of Defense releases names of four Americans confirmed dead in Iraq (S)

headline: Reality TV Rivets Africa, to the Churches' Dismay
abstract: Estimated 30 million Africans are watching Big Brother Africa, latest incarnation of reality television show that started in Europe; show throws together strangers as housemates and then lets viewers watch their every move; in African show, dozen young professionals are plucked from countries all across vast, diverse continent and moved into house in Johannesburg with oversize Jacuzzi; some African politicians and clergy criticize program; photos (M)

headline: U.S. and Russia Enter Meat and Poultry Deal
abstract: Bush administration announces trade agreement with Russia that could increase American poultry and meat exports to Russia as well as remove some obstacles blocking Russia's entry into World Trade Organization; senior US trade negotiator Robert B Zoellick announces agreement; photo (M)

headline: Mighty Brew for the Do-It-Yourselfer
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on Web search for assertive coffee beans used to make Cuban-style coffee; drawing (M)

headline: Jury Rules Against Microsoft in Patent Case
abstract: Federal jury in San Francisco awards former University of California researcher Michael Doyle $521 million in lawsuit against Microsoft that asserted its Explorer Web browser infringed patent for sending software applications over Internet; lawsuit, which was filed in 1999 by Doyle, now Chicago businessman and founder of Eolas Technologies Inc, and university, sought $1.2 billion; plaintiffs asserted that invention had been crucial in permitting Microsoft to compete against Netscape Navigator Web browser, now owned by AOL Time Warner Inc; Microsoft spokesman Jim Desler says company will appeal (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: British Defense Chief Testifies Arms Expert Supported Iraq War
abstract: British Defense Sec Geoff Hoon says Dr David Kelly, weapons expert cited as source of BBC report casting doubt on Britain's reasons for going to war, told him he supported government's position on Iraq; defends himself against charges that he brought excessive pressure to bear on Kelly; Kelly is thought to have killed himself three days after his publicly televised grilling before House of Commons foreign affairs committee (M)

headline: ADIDAS SAYS NORTH AMERICAN SALES DOWN AT LEAST 10%
abstract: Adidas Says Nort

headline: Media Rule Appears In Jeopardy in House
abstract: Article noted on House debate over reversing FCC's loosening of limits on media ownership

headline: Taliban Are Killing Clerics Who Dispute Holy War Call
abstract: Senior Muslim clerics in Afghanistan are being killed by Taliban for resisting call for holy war; Kandahar's 15-member clerics' council and its branches in districts have been vocal suporters of Pres Hamid Karzai and have welcomed presence of foreign troops in Afghanistan; although council members are clearly allied with government, they are also keepers of city's most hallowed shrines and are among most senior tribal and religous figures; council issued religious edict denouncing Taliban's call for jihad, and since then three clerics have been killed by Taliban assassins, others narrowly escaped death and many others have been wounded; clerics concede that Taliban have continuing influence in districts; photo; map (M)

headline: Arthur Helton, 54, Refugee Advocate, Dies
abstract: Arthur C Helton, lawyer and human rights activist, dies at age 54; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Satisfies Australia on Possible Terror Trial
abstract: Australia's Justice Min Chris Ellison says his government is satisfied with fairness of procedures that United States would use if it tries David Hicks, Australian citizen, on terrorism charges before military tribunal; says he has been assured that Hicks would not be prosecuted on any offense that carries death penalty; conditions he outlines are nearly identical to those American officials negotiated earlier in week with British government concerning two of its subjects; Hicks is being detained at US naval base in Guantanamo Bay (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Fireworks Blast Kills 29
abstract: Chinese fireworks factory near Tianjin explodes killing 29 people and injuring 141; manufacture of fireworks remains one of China's most dangerous industries (S)

headline: Argentine Prosecutor Turns Focus to New War Crimes Court
abstract: Luis Moreno Ocampo of Argentina talks about his first three months as chief prosecutor of first permanent International Criminal Court in The Hague; new court does not answer to United Nations Security Council but to 92 countries that have agreed to take part in it since its creation in 1998; it can deal only with crimes that occurred after July 1, 2002; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONS.

headline: T. Rowe Price Joins Clients Leaving Bates
abstract: T Rowe Price Group joins list of clients shifting their ad accounts from Bates Worldwide after acquisition of Bates parent Cordiant Communications Group by WPP Group; T Rowe Price names J Walter Thompson, part of WPP, as agency of record on its mutual fund account, with billings estimated at $35 million (S)

headline: Oh, if Only the G.I.'s Would Come Marching In
abstract: Comment on craving of Liberians for US intervention to end warfare; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MCI Names New President
abstract: WorldCom, which changed its name to MCI, names Richard R Roscitt president and chief operating officer; photo (S)

headline: For the Gadget-Packed Home, A Souped-Up Cable Signal
abstract: Terk Technologies makes amplifier that boosts incoming UHF, VHF, FM and HDTV signals in homes where signals must supply several computers and Internet connection; photo (M)

headline: W.H.O. Finds Use of Antibiotics in Animal Feed Can Be Reduced
abstract: World Health Orgn says Denmark has proved that pork and poultry industries can thrive without using antibiotics to promote animal growth; report bolsters WHO's longstanding position that use of drugs in healthy animals should be curtailed; antibiotics are routinely added to feed in United States and many other countries even when animals are not sick; practice can breed drug-resistant bacteria, which may infect people who eat contaminated meat or food or water tainted by animals' droppings (M)

headline: You Call This A Midlife Crisis?
abstract: Bill Gates and Steven A Ballmer, after tricky transition, appear to have settled into their new roles at Microsoft Corp: Ballmer as chief executive and Gates as in-house technology guru; they insist that company is not entering mature phase, resigned to reduced growth and diminished expectations, but is prepared for new cycle of opportunity and growth that is arriving as people depend more and more on digital devices to work, play and communicate; say only Microsoft has skills, money and focus to put software pieces together, which they call 'integrated innovation,' to deliver promise of digital world; photos; graphs (L)

headline: France to Continue Bailouts Despite Criticism by Europe
abstract: French Finance Min Francis Mer meets with Europe's competition commissioner Mario Monti in Brussels to explain why France will not abandon its 300 million-euro bailout of Alstom, nearly bankrupt French industrial group; also defends his government's decision to intervene on behalf of French computer company Bull; European Commission had ordered France to recover 450 million euros ($500 million) of government aid that Bull received last year; Monti threatened to take France to European Court of Justice if it did not collect money by end of September (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Bank Stake Acquired; SOUTH KOREA: Growth Forecast Cut;.

headline: Army Is Devising Ways To Reorganize Its Forces
abstract: Army, stretched by commitments in Iraq and stretching to prove it can be as nimble as other service branches, undertakes dramatic changes in organization and deployment of troops in combat; Gen John M Keane explains that soldiers from different units with different specialties will be mixed and matched under one commander (M)

headline: Guilty Pleas Expected in Homestore Case
abstract: Homestore Inc former executives Thomas Vo, Sailesh Patel and Jessica McLellan will plead guilty to criminal charges they made fraudulent transactions to inflate Homestore's advertising revenue; Securities and Exchange Commission also says it has settled lawsuits against five former executives at company and two former executives at Homestore business partner; SEC has accused 11 people of participating in scheme to falsify financial statements at Homestore (S)

headline: 3 Student Leaders Seized by Vigilantes in Iran
abstract: Three student leaders in Iran are arrested by armed vigilantes after holding news conference in Tehran to announce cancellation of planned protests to mark anniversary of 1999 student protests; authorities say they arrested 4,000 people during 10 days of protests last month; hard-line prosecutor's office has jailed scores of pro-democracy demonstrators; government has banned any demonstrations to commemorate unrest of 1999, in which one student was killed (M)

headline: U.P.S. Plans a New Route
abstract: United Parcel Service plans to start direct cargo service to Europe from Hong Kong rather than Philippines to save time and money (S)

headline: Procter & Gamble Buys Time on Super Bowl
abstract: Advertising:

headline: Former Medi-Hut Executives Plead Guilty in Fraud
abstract: Medi-Hut Co's former chief executive Joseph Sanpietro, former chief financial officer Laurence Simon and former vice president Lawrence Marasco plead guilty to conspiracy to inflate revenue and earnings at drug wholesaler and lying to investigators; former chief operating officer Vincent Sanpietro pleads guilty to obstruction of justice; former executives also reach civil settlement with Securities and Exchange Commission barring them from serving as officers or directors of public company; Medi-Hut plans to pay $400,000 in cash and issue 861,990 shares to settle investor class-action lawsuits in connection with accusations (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Airline Posts Loss
abstract: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines reports quarterly loss of 54 million euros ($619 million), down from profit of 11 million euros year ago; graph (S)

headline: People
abstract: Ben Langdon is leaving as McCann-Erickson Worldwide regional director and chairman of London office; David Warden will assume his regional duties (S)

headline: Market Place; Ohio Utility Cited in Blackout Has Had a Troubled Summer
abstract: Massive blackout is latest of FirstEnergy Corp's problems this summer, Market Place column; company acknowledges that alarm system had not been working at time of blackout, but it tries to deflect blame for widespread power failure, saying there were problems in other parts of nation's electrical system before its lines began to fail; North American Electric Reliability Council, group created by utilities to set standards for reducing risks of disruption, was first to call public attention to FirstEnergy's problems, but it agrees with company that problem is more complicated than just one utility; Richard H Marsh, FirstEnergy's chief financial officer, cites company's other problems this summer: blackouts in coastal New Jersey communities over July 4 weekend, federal judge's ruling that company violated Clean Air Act, delays in getting nuclear power plant in Ohio back in operation and decision by its auditors to require it to restate profits over last three years; photos; graph (M)

headline: Shares Advance as Retailers Raise Forecasts for Quarter
abstract: Stocks advance as Wal-Mart Stores and Best Buy say quarterly earnings would exceed forecasts; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index adds 7.04 points, to 974.12; Dow Jones industrial average rises 64.71 points, to 9,126.45; Nasdaq composite index slips 0.5 point, to 1,652.18; graph; table; Treasury prices rise; yield on 10-year note rises to 4.37 percent; 30-year bond gains 13/32, to 102 13/32; yield falls to 5.22 percent (M)

headline: Security Council Supports a Liberia Force
abstract: UN Security Council approves US resolution for multinational force to quell violence in Liberia and keep peace until new government is formed; UN would send own peacekeeping troops by Oct 1 (S)

headline: In Annans Words: Fork in the Road
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23 — Following is transcript from a speech today at the General Assembly by Secretary General Kofi Annan as supplied by the United Nations.

headline: Poll: Risk Is for the Rough
abstract: American Century Group survey of golfers finds more than half describe themselves as 'aggressive' on golf course, but only one-quarter use term to describe their investment strategy; drawing (S)

headline: Bush Defends Tax Cuts
abstract: In response to the unexpectedly bad employment report, President Bush defended his reliance on tax cuts as a remedy for the nation's economic troubles.      Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Senators Assail 2 Officials For Lack of Postwar Details
abstract: Senators from both parties assail Joshua B Bolten, Pres Bush's budget director, and Deputy Sec Paul Wolfowitz for refusing to spell out how much postwar effort in Iraq will cost and how many US troops will be needed; photo; Bolten tells contentious hearing of Senate Foreign Relations Committee that total reconstruction costs this year will be about $7.3 billion; senators warn that public support hinges on candid information, suggesting vagueness masks drifting policy; pepper Wolfowitz with questions about continuing American deaths (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bid For Property Fund Raised
abstract: Investa, Australian listed property trust, raises its bid for Principal Office Fund, Principal Group associate that controls 12 major office Australian office buildings, to 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.3 billion) from 1.8 billion and pushes back extended date to Aug 4; says it has raised its stake to 21 percent of fund (S)

headline: Argentina Defaults on $3 Billion I.M.F. Debt
abstract: Argentina defaults on $3 billion loan payment to International Monetary Fund rather than dip into its foreign reserves to pay debt; refuses to make concessions to seal three-year aid package from IMF that would allow $12.5 billion in multilateral debt to be rolled over; photo of demonstrators protesting IMF policies (M)

headline: They're Just a Bunch of Regular Media Moguls
abstract: Profile of Providence Equity Partners, rapidly growing media and telecommunications empire; firm and its president, Jonathan M Nelson, have been little noticed despite company's role in number of big media deals; Nelson cites value of low profile, interview; table of recent investments; photos (M)

headline: Israel Reportedly Willing to Delay Portions of Barrier
abstract: Israel agrees not to construct segments of West Bank barrier it is building until it reaches compromise with Bush administration over matter; senior Israeli official says Bush administration does not object in principle to barrier but does have 'great deal of concern' about very limited portions, particularly planned branch to encompass large Israeli settlement of Ariel; Palestinians call barrier Israeli land grab and attempt to create political border; Secretary of State Colin L Powell, in recent interview in Israeli newspaper Maariv, appears to suggest that Israel is using barrier to appropriate land; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Hospital 'Spy Ring'
abstract: Belfast (Northern Ireland) Chief Constable Hugh Orde announces arrest of five men believed to be part of Real IRA Royal Victoria Hospital spy ring, which used medical records to single out politicians and police (S)

headline: Lopez Said to Be Near Settlement
abstract: Jennifer Lopez, pop diva and actress, is close to reaching settlement with former manager Benny Medina, whom she has accused of misappropriating money and inappropriately making deals on her behalf (M)

headline: 3 Iraqis Killed as G.I.'s Set Up Raid in Hunt for Hussein
abstract: American soldiers fire on Toyota passenger car in upscale Baghdad neighborhood, killing at least three Iraqis, as American Special Operations team prepares to raid nearby house in what Iraqi policeman later describes as unsuccessful attempt to capture Saddam Hussein; owner of home that is raided claims he has not seen Hussein for more than year; shootings outrage local residents, who say Americans did not offer adequate warnings before firing on car; photo (M)

headline: The Fourth Wife
abstract: The deposed dictator's turbulent family life: Only last year Saddam Hussein married a woman of German origin.

headline: US Airways Swings to Profit in Quarter
abstract: US Airways Group, which exited bankruptcy proceedings in April, says it had second-quarter net income of $13 million, helped by lower costs and government payment for some security expenses (S)

headline: Request by Stewart Lawyers Is Rejected
abstract: Federal Judge Miriam G Cedarbaum rejects request for inquiry into whether information about grand jury that indicted Martha Stewart was released before June 4 indictment; Cedarbaum writes that she asked prosecutors from US attorney's office to submit minutes from instructions to grand jury on avoiding news reports about Stewart and her former stockbroker Peter E Bacanovic, who was indicted along with her (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: BMC To Cut Jobs
abstract: BMC Software says it will cut 13 percent of its staff and that it had its first loss in five quarters as customers cancel purchases; fiscal first-quarter net loss is $6.1 million, as compared to year-earlier net income of 5.2 million (S)

headline: Bush Officials Weigh Offer to North Korea
abstract: The Bush administration is considering conciliatory steps toward North Korea. In return, the government of Kim Jong Il would have to fully disclose its weapons or allow inspectors into the country.    Possible concessions include some form of written assurance that the United States has no intention of attacking North Korea, and some steps that would help North Korea economically. According to a Bush administration official, however, ''There's no such thing as you-do-this and suddenly Ed McMahon shows up with a check for $10 billion.''

headline: Business; Can Manchester United Make Shareholders Cheer?
abstract: Manchester United PLC, owner of championship soccer team Manchester United, has compiled winning record on London Stock Exchange; shares have year-to-date return of 61.5 percent, far more than overall British stock market or most of other publicly traded European soccer teams; photo; graph shows stock prices, 2000 to 2003 (M)

headline: Wilfred Thesiger, 93, Dies; Explored Arabia
abstract: Sir Wilfred Thesiger, who first foreigner to cross Empty Quarter of Saudi Arabia twice, when that vast desert was one of last unmapped regions of earth, dies at age 93; photos (M)

headline: China Names 2 New Hong Kong Aides
abstract: China's state council, or cabinet, appointed a new security chief and financial secretary in Hong Kong today.

headline: MOODY'S CUTS RATING ON KODAK DEBT
abstract: Moody's Investors Service cuts rating on $3 billion of debt of Eastman Kodak Co to lowest investment grade (S)

headline: Some Dow Jones Workers To Avoid TV Appearances
abstract: Independent Association of Publishers' Employees, which represents 1,700 editorial and other employees at Dow Jones & Co, says that, as result of contract dispute, its members will refuse to appear for at least month on televised segments arranged by Dow Jones and broadcast on CNBC, financial news channel (M)

headline: French Prime Minister Exercises a Gift for the Political Faux Pas
abstract: Jean-Pierre Raffarin's verbal blunders — as well as his sweet and sometimes meaningless aphorisms — are so numerous that there is a name for them: "Raffarinades."

headline: Market Place; Lucent's Chief Offers Bad News, and Optimism
abstract: Lucent Technologies reports losing 7 cents a share in fiscal third quarter ended June 30; reports revenue of $1.96 billion, down from $2.4 billion in previous quarter and $2.95 billion in year-earlier period; chief executive Patricia F Russo assures investors Lucent is making strides toward becoming profitable in 2004, despite revenue shortfall, conference call; earnings graph; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: SARS Patient Released
abstract: Singapore medical researcher infected with mild case of SARS is released from hospital, but will remain in quarantine at home for two weeks; World Health Organization reports that SARS diagnosis was confirmed by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Atlanta) (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction: Sept 7 Market Watch colu

headline: Violence Spreads Through Afghanistan, Killing Dozens
abstract: The most violent day in Afghanistan in nearly a year comes two days after NATO assumed control of the peacekeeping force.

headline: DVD's Meant for Buying but Not for Keeping
abstract: Buena Vista Entertainment, Walt Disney Co's home video division, plans to test-market new type of movie DVD that will be priced about same as rental but never needs to be returned because it stops working after fixed period of time; experiment will be closely watched in Hollywood, where home video market provides nearly 59 percent of film industry's $17.38 billion in North American revenues; late fees are lucrative source of added income for rental companies, but provide little or no revenue for studios; graph of movie industry revenues; photo (M)

headline: A Popular Idea: Give Oil Money to the People Rather Than the Despots
abstract: Liberal foreign aid experts, conservative economists and diverse group of political leaders in United States and Iraq favor giving some of nation's oil revenues directly to people, perhaps through annual payments; idea has mass appeal in Iraq; American officials say properly functioning oil industry would generate enough to give every Iraqi adult some $1,000, half annual salary of middle-class worker; photos (M)

headline: Webdenda
abstract: Adient , Wayne, N.J., hired three employees and promoted one. Chris Gruno was named imaging specialist; he had worked for Adient on a freelance basis. Kevin A. Ledwith was named senior vice president and management supervisor; he had been group account director at the Hal Lewis Group, Philadelphia. Linda Sadler was named executive vice president and managing director; she had been executive vice president and client service director at Sudler & Hennessey, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group. And Matthew Gotimer , traffic coordinator, was named assistant account executive. Adient is part of the CommonHealth division of the WPP Group. Rebecca Altman was named senior account executive at SFGT Advertising , Philadelphia. She had been senior account executive at Grey Worldwide, New York, part of the Grey Global Group. William Bellenger , staff art director at Quinn Fable Advertising , New York, was named studio operations manager. Jennifer Bolt was named media director at the Tracy Locke Partnership , Dallas, succeeding Lora Funderburk, who left, the agency. Ms. Bolt had been vice president for media at the Integer Group, Denver. Tracy Locke and Integer are units of the Omnicom Group. Adam Feldman was named to the new post of vice president and general manager at Performance Media , Wilton, Conn. Mr. Feldman had been senior vice president for account service at Momentum Worldwide , New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Performance Media is part of Marketing Drive Worldwide, part of the FCB Group division of Interpublic. Donna Sanders Felix was named to the new post of vice president and management supervisor on the account of Dell Computer at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos . Ms. Felix had been senior account manager at Bam Advertising, Austin. She will be based at the Austin headquarters of T3 (The Think Tank), which shares with Hill, Holliday the direct-marketing and catalog duties for efforts aimed at small and medium-sized businesses. Hill, Holliday is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Thomas Ferguson Associates , Parsippany, N.J., part of CommonHealth, promoted nine employees. Stephanie Albinson , art director, was named senior art director. Anita Caruso , senior art director, was named group art director. Julia Faraldo , account executive, was named senior account executive. Larry Hannon , copywriter, was named senior copywriter. Angela Hawk and Stephen Sullivan , assistant account executives, were named account executives. Lisa Melone , assistant art director, was named art director. Beth Tansey Peller , vice president and group copy supervisor, was named associate creative director. And Renee Wentworth , senior copywriter, was named copy supervisor. CommonHealth is part of the WPP Group. Gary J. Gatyas Jr. was named to the vacant post of vice president and director for public relations at Dudnyk Advertising and Public Relations , Horsham, Pa., part of CommCor. He had been managing supervisor at Gibbs & Soell Public Relations, New York. Health Learning Systems , Parsippany, N.J., part of CommonHealth, promoted four employees. Laura Nolan , vice president for meetings management, was named vice president for meetings management and data services, succeeding Cynthia DaRin , who was named senior vice president for operations. Anthia Mandarakas , director for program planning and development, was named senior director. And Ramana Yalamanchili , vice president and director for medical affairs, was named senior vice president. CommonHealth is part of the WPP Group. Jim Hunt , former governor of North Carolina, was named co-chairman for the Advisory Committee on Public Issues at the Advertising Council , New York, succeeding Vernon Jordan, managing director at Lazard Frères. The advisory committee guides the direction of the council's public service campaigns. Rainer Jenss , associate publisher at National Geographic Kids magazine, New York, was named to the new post of publisher. National Geographic Kids is part of National Geographic Magazines, a unit of the National Geographic Society. Jaci Kotzum was named assistant account executive at L.C. Williams & Associates , Chicago. She had been an intern at Golin/Harris International, Chicago, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Bari R. Love was named managing director at the Atlanta office of Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide , succeeding Genna Keller, who left, the agency said. Ms. Love had been executive vice president at Fletcher Martin Ewing Advertising, Atlanta. Ogilvy is part of the WPP Group. John R. McCarthy was named senior vice president for sales and account management at HotJobs , New York, part of Yahoo. He had been executive officer in charge of sales and operations at StorageApps, Bridgewater, N.J., part of Hewlett-Packard. Millward Brown , Warwick, England, a market research unit of the WPP Group, acquired Centrum voor Marketing Analyses , Amsterdam, which will be renamed Millward Brown/Centrum. Terms were not disclosed. In May, Millward Brown acquired Sadek Wynberg Research, London. Staci Nicks , media buyer at NKHW&W , Kansas City, Mo., was named senior media buyer. Don Scales , executive vice president and chief operating officer at Agency.com , New York, was named to the new post of president. He continues to work from the Dallas office.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Credit Card Losses; PHILIPPINES: Bank Suspensions Challenged;.

headline: PROCTER & GAMBLE'S EARNINGS INCREASE 4.9%
abstract: Procter & Gamble says that fourth-quarter profit rose 4.9 percent, to $955 million; sales rise 7.4 percent, to $10.9 million (S)

headline: Election Race? First, Check Out This Bike
abstract: WaveCrest Laboratories is developing new kind of electric motor that does not require gears or transmission, but uses computer algorithms to maximize torque and efficiency; hopes to put motors into hybrid cars someday, but is currently focused on bikes and claims that two-wheeler can go 30 mph with hardly any pedaling; Gen Wesley K Clark, chairman of WaveCrest, says bike would be asset to military, as it is light and simple; photos (M)

headline: Music Industry Ponders Costs Of Steep Cut in Prices of CD's
abstract: Universal Music Group's decision to lower prices of its compact discs leaves rest of music industry scrambling to respond, with some arguing that long-term effects could hurt struggling specialty chains and independent music stores and favor discounters like Wal-Mart; other side of Universal's price cut is simultaneous cutback in payments company makes to retailers for shared advertising and in-store promotions; executives at rival labels say those cuts will hurt small stores, which rely on payments, more than major chains, which have lower costs and more bargaining power; music industry executives say companies like Universal typically offer stores about $1.20 in promotional subsidies for each CD sold to retailers for $12; Universal will keep $1.20, but lower wholesale price to $9, instead of $12; representatives of other major industry players say they will defer judgment on Universal's pricing plan; Warner Music spokeswoman Dawn Bridges says company has no specific plans to do something about its pricing policy; EMI and music division of Sony Corp decline comment (M)

headline: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES TO DELAY DELIVERY OF NEW JETS
abstract: Continental Airlines is deferring deliveries of 36 Boeing 737 jets it scheduled to accept in 2005, 2006 and 2007; will not take deliveries until 2008 and beyond; Continental chief executive Gordon Bethune says carrier is not going to invest in aircraft that it cannot profitably fly in current marketplace (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: The Ancient Art Of Monopoly
abstract: Al Gumhoria, state newspaper, reports Egyptian Labor Minister Ahmed al Amawi has canceled work permits for foreign belly dancers working in Egypt; foreign dancers generally work for lower wages and local dancers have campaigned for stricter regulations to protect their jobs (S)

headline: Ex-Officer of 2 Citigroup Funds Is Indicted
abstract: Former Citigroup employee Paul David is indicted on charges that he embezzled almost $73,000 from two Citigroup Global Markets investment funds where he was director; Securities and Exchange Commission sues David, accusing him of violating year-old federal statute known as Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which requires chief executives and chief financial officers to disclose any fraud occurring in their companies (S)

headline: DEUTSCHE BANK OUSTED FOR PROVIDING CONFLICTING ADVICE
abstract: Auto parts maker Dana Corp dismisses Deutsche Bank as advisor in its efforts to avert hostile takeover by ArvinMeritor Inc; action follows disclosure by Deutsche Bank that it earlier had recommended to ArvinMentor that it pursue Dana takeover (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Rail Strike Ends; SOUTH KOREA: Foreign Investment Falls;.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; New Impetus for Even More Retailing in Paramus
abstract: Retail real estate market in Paramus, NJ, discussed in light of opening of large new Ikea home furnishings store; map; photo (M)

headline: Saying He's Hussein, Speaker on Tape Tells Iraqis to Resist
abstract: Another audiotape surfaced today in which a speaker purporting to be Saddam Hussein, and sounding almost desperate, urged Iraqis not to cooperate with Americans.

headline: G.I.'s Have X-Ray Vision. Of Course.
abstract: As an American soldier peered out of a passing tank, a young engineering student and a retired accountant contemplated one of the more common questions on the streets of Baghdad: Did the soldier's wraparound sunglasses give him X-ray vision?     ''With those glasses, he can definitely see through women's clothes,'' said the engineering student, Samer Hamid. ''It makes me angry. We are afraid to take our families out on the street.''

headline: ENRON WORKERS SUE OVER BONUSES PAID TO EXECUTIVES
abstract: Panel representing Enron employees in company's bankruptcy case sues 292 former employees, officers and executives for return of $72 million in bonuses paid them in days surrounding company's collapse (S)

headline: Business People; The Stars Are Aligned For a Cause, or Two
abstract: Several celebrities are auctioning their Emmy outfits on eBay to raise money for Cure Autism Now, research and advocacy group, and for Union of Concerned Scientists (S)

headline: For Motorola, Chief's Ouster Seen Bringing Strategy Shift
abstract: John Pepper Jr, Motorola director leading search for successor to ousted chairman and chief executive Christopher B Galvin, cites company's progress under Galvin's leadership and restructuring efforts; says Galvin's dispute with board involves current stage of turnaround, not past (M)

headline: The Haves and Have-Nots Reside On Both Sides of Liberian Capital
abstract: Sides of Monrovia held by Liberian government and by rebel forces are divided by bridges, composing bleak landscape of haves and have-nots; photos; Pres Charles Taylor's side has little food or fuel but sufficient supply of drugs and doctors dispatched by international aid agencies; rebel side holds port and has plenty of food and fuel, but no drugs or doctors; commander of what is to be West African 'interposition force' visits rebel zone, where leaders say they will not release port until Taylor leaves country; individual soldiers on both sides and ordinary people rejoice in streets at prospect of peace (M)

headline: U.S. Troops in Liberia Not 'Peacekeepers,' Pentagon Says
abstract: The Pentagon said today that 200 more U.S. troops could go ashore, but said that their mission was not peacekeeping.

headline: Greenspan Says Fed Shouldn't Be Restricted by Formal Targets
abstract: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan today fended off critics who say the nation's monetary policy has become too personalized and idiosyncratic.

headline: The High Value Targets Game
abstract: For the U.S. military, the raid on Saddam Husseins sons served as a symbolically important rallying cry.

headline: DataBank; Investors Turn Jittery as Interest Rates Rise
abstract: Stock market performance for the week reviewed; graphs; charts (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Investment Cap Eased
abstract: China's banking regulator Liu Mingkang confirms government plans to lift ceiling on foreign bank ownership of local banks to 25 percent from 15 percent in bid to improve performance of midsize institutions; says China should encourage foreign banks to become strategic investors in its midsize banks; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Sars All-Clear; MEXICO: Ex-Minister Questioned In '71 Massacre;.

headline: 33 Are Killed in Stampede at a Hindu Festival
abstract: Thirty-three people die and 74 others are injured in stampede at Hindu festival in Nasik, India, where tens of thousands of pilgrims try to bathe in holy waters of Godavari River in single day; government officials say crowds rushed forward too quickly after fence was opened to allow devotees to go for holy bath; stampedes have occurred at festivals in past, although last two passed without major incidents; Hindu nationalist politicians call for investigation into what went wrong; map (M)

headline: Buenos Aires Journal; A Street Battle Rages in Argentina's 150 Years War
abstract: Descendants of two adversaries in Argentina's history carry on battle in conflict over naming of street in Buenos Aires; Juan Manuel de Rosas, who dominated country for much of first half of 19th century, met defeat on battlefield and went into exile; his adversary, Domingo Sarmiento, became president; now City Council proposes to put Rosa's name on three-block section of thoroughfare long designated Avenida Sarmiento; photos (M)

headline: Bush Presses South Africa to Step Up Efforts to Fight AIDS
abstract: AIDS was one of two issues that President Bush and President Thabo Mbeki discussed. The other was Zimbabwe, which is becoming unstable.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Pro-Aristide Gang Leader Found Dead
abstract: Haitian gang leader Amiot Metayer, longtime supporter of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is found dead in St Marc; known for his group's violent attacks on political opponents of Aristide, he was shot in heart and in each eye (S)

headline: China Moves To Tighten Bank Credit
abstract: China's central bank, in sign that policy makers fear country's rapid economic growth may e too fast in some areas, raises level of deposits that commercial banks and other lenders must keep at central bank; commercial banks and most other deposit-taking financial institutions must raise their compulsory deposit reserves by 1 percentage point, to 7 percent of total deposits, effective Sept 21; financial administrator Ma Kai warns that rapidly expanding credit threatens China's financial health (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Downgraded
abstract: Standard & Poor's downgrades credit rating of Fujitsu to level below investment grade; cites impact of price cutting on profitability (S)

headline: SHARON AND ABBAS STAND SIDE BY SIDE, THEN BEGIN TALKS
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon and Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas appear side by side at meeting in Jerusalem, declaring mutual respect and hopes for peace as Israeli forces prepare to withdraw from Bethlehem; photo; map; Sharon envisions 'future of hope' and Abbas says it is time to put the past behind and end suffering and death; two hold fourth meeting, first without US or other foreign leader, in spirit of apparent warmth; Abbas says struggle is political, to be ended through diplomacy; Sharon says Yasir Arafat may leave Ramallah only to go one way to Gaza, but indicates new flexibility on release of 5,000 Palestinian prisoners (M)

headline: A Dissent on the Digital Divide
abstract: University of Maryland sociologist Steven P Martin says government's most recent report on Americans' Internet use was flawed in its conclusion that digital divide is closing; insists truth is actually the opposite, and that it may take 20 years for lowest-income groups to catch up to wealthier households when it comes to computer ownership and Internet use (M)

headline: J.P. Morgan and Citigroup Settle Inquiries on Enron's Fraud
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup agreed today to pay a total of more than $300 million for their roles in Enron's manipulation of its financial statements.

headline: World Business Breifing
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: Ads against drunken driving are aimed at a specific group and a specific weekend.
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is trying to curb nation's backsliding drunken driving problem with advertising and enforcement campaign that takes aim at Fourth of July weekend, historically one of worst periods of alcohol-related accidents; agency has coordinated many law enforcement efforts to single out troublesome times of year, but it has never had financing to simultaneously conduct paid advertising campaign; Congress approved $11 million for ads aimed at young male drivers, who are most likely to drink and drive; half of money will go to 13 states, including several with either highest alcohol-related fatality rates or highest number of fatalities; ad campaign was developed by GMMB, part of Fleishman-Hillard unit of Omnicom Group; photo (M)

headline: Learning to Eat on the Cheap in Tokyo
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on ways to can eat well and cheaply in Tokyo, city business travelers often consider exasperatingly expensive; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Trial Ordered In Serial Killing Case; COLOMBIA: Unionist Killed;.

headline: Hearst Names New Editor in Chief for Seventeen Magazine
abstract: Atoosa Rubenstein, who had been editor in chief of CosmoGirl, will become editor in chief of Seventeen magazine.

headline: Time's Up, Young Gamer: Mom's Stand-In Cuts Off the Juice
abstract: Card Access will introduce device that tracks and controls time that child uses anything plugged into electrical outlet; device locks into power outlet of video game or other equipment and enables parent to program length of time it receives power; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Backs Head Scarves
abstract: Germany's highest court rules that Muslim woman cannot be fired for wearing Islamic head scarf at work (S)

headline: Hong Kong Drops Unpopular Internal-Security Bill
abstract: Hong Kong's chief executive is withdrawing internal-security legislation that had provoked protests in July.

headline: July Spending By Consumers Shows a Rise
abstract: Commerce Department reports consumer spending rose 0.8 percent, to $7.7 trillion at annual rate in July, after revised 0.6 percent increase in July; says pretax income rose 0.2 percent; reports economy grew at 3.1 percent annual rate from April through June; National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago's factory index increased to 58.9 in August from 55.9 in July; employment index increased to 51.2 from 46 in July; University of Michigan's August consumer sentiment index fell to 89.3 from preliminary 90.2 reading earlier in month; graph on personal income (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: CHECHNYA: Groups Decide Against Observers; SWEDEN: Assassination Suspect Identified; BELGIUM: One In 10 Tries Suicide, Survey Finds; GERMANY HEALTH PACKAGE APPROVED; BRITAIN: Serving God And Mammon;.

headline: Rape (and Silence About It) Haunts Baghdad
abstract: Iraqi women grow increasingly afraid of being abducted and raped in Baghdad since end of war and outbreak of anarchy on streets; physicians, law enforcement and families say such crimes have increased in society where shame of rape is so strong that many families blame victims; sister of nine-year-old girl named Sanariya says parents and brothers have beaten child daily since she was raped by stranger seven weeks ago, and morgue gets corpses of women killed by relatives; many women and girls are too frightened to go to work or school and victims are ignored or humiliated when they try to report crimes; US police adviser Bernard B Kerik tells of firing precinct chief for failing to search for missing teenager; photos (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Despite the recovery in stocks, some of the forces behind the Internet bust are still lurking.
abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene article on some forces behind Internet bust that are still lurking despite recovery in stocks; cites recent post-mortem on dot-com boom by New York University Profs Eli Ofek and Matthew Richardson in article published in June 2003 issue of Journal of Finance; authors contend constraints on short-selling still exist, so market is still suspectible to irrational exuberance on part of small investors; holds individual investors are buying most of speculative stocks while institutional investors are sitting on sidelines, pattern that does not bode well for current technology recovery (M)

headline: When It Comes to Child Custody, Who Pays for Yale?
abstract: Personal Business column on obligations of divorced parents to pay for college educations (M)

headline: BIG FLORIDA CONCRETE MAKER BUYS A NEW UNIT
abstract: Florida Rock Industries Inc, leading maker of concrete products in Southeast, agrees to buy Lafarge Florida Inc unit of Lafarge SA for about $122 million in stock to supplement its operations in Fla (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Adidas Sells Bonds
abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: Adidas Sells

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Carreker Stock Surges On Profit News
abstract: Carreker Corp reports net income of $3.9 million in fiscal second quarter ended July 31, 51 percent decline from $7.9 million year earlier; revenue fell 17 percent, to $36.2 million from $43.5 million; chief financial officer Frank W Tilley says company will have profitable year and positive cash flow (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: XM Satellite Says It Has 692,000 Subscribers
abstract: XM Satellite Radio Holdings ends second quarter with more than 692,000 subscribers, much ahead of Wall Street's projected growth (S)

headline: Swedes Arrest Suspect in Assassination of Minister
abstract: Swedish police arrest unidentified man suspected of stabbing Min Anna Lindh to death while she shopped in Stockholm store (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Firearms In Europe
abstract: Graduate Institute of International Studies (Geneva, Switzerland) survey on firearm ownership estimates there are 17 guns per 100 people and total of 67 million guns in European Union countries; France and Germany have highest average with 30 guns per 100 people; United States averages 83 to 96 guns per 100 people (S)

headline: Patents; 'Funky A.T.M.' is designed to let you pay cash for that purchase made online.
abstract: Carl Amos patents way to pay for online transactions with currency rather than credit or banking cards; patent covers modified ATM that not only dispenses money but also accepts cash, which can be used to transfer money from person to person or pay for online purchases; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bigger Loss For Airline
abstract: All Nippon Airways Co says its loss in April-to-June quarter grew 55 percent because severe acute respiratory syndrome limited overseas travel; loses 18.3 billion yen ($151.7 million) in quarter (S)

headline: Liberians Surge by Barricades in Capital as Food Aid Arrives
abstract: Tens of thousands of Liberians poured over the bridge that had separated warring forces and reunited a broken city today.

headline: AES Corp. To Hand Over Power Plant To Creditors
abstract: The AES Corporation said today that it was walking away from Britain's largest plant and the roughly $3 billion it paid for it in 1999 after creditors refused to accept a plan to buy back some debt.    In doing so, AES made good on an ultimatum to creditors, who are owed about £1.3 billion, to leave the plant, known as AES Drax Holdings, in creditors' hands. After 10 months of talks, AES, which is based in Arlington, Va., gave creditors until midnight Tuesday to accept a £60 million plan to buy back some senior debt.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Shorter Workweek Approved
abstract: Volkswagen's Mexico unit reaches agreement with unionized workers for shorter workweek that will save 2,000 jobs; union agrees to accept four-day workweek and overall temporary pay cut for 20 percent of workers with least seniority; other 80 percent will lose pay just for day not worked (S)

headline: A Pep Talk for Women to End All Pep Talks
abstract: Nearly 200 executive women gathered in Midtown Manhattan to learn to talk themselves up in a way that engages the listener and feels natural.

headline: Indonesia Sentences Defiant Islamic Militant to Death for the Bali Nightclub Bombing
abstract: Indonesian court sentences Imam Samudra to death after convicting him of playing major role in Bali nightclub attack that killed 202 people last year, including 88 tourists from Australia; Samudra, militant who has shown belligerent demeanor throughout trial, shouts 'America, Australia, go to hell!; Indonesian investigators say he trained at camps run by Al Qaeda in Afghanistan; reaction to death sentence among Indonesia's moderate Muslim leaders, who represent vast majority of Muslims there, is supportive of court's reasoning; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Staff Recommends Tighter Limits Of Hedge Funds
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission staff recommends tighter regulation of growing hedge fund industry, including registration of funds and greater disclosure of way they operate; proposal would have effect of raising eligibility requirements for smaller investors in such funds by $500,000, to $1.5 million, in many circustances; officials say changes would force funds to provide more accurate valuations of their assets; would also apply to any foreign fund that has at least 14 American investors (M)

headline: Iraqi Informants' Tips Grow After Brothers' Deaths
abstract: Military officers in Iraq say informants have produced stream of new tips, some of which have led to major raids, in three days since American soldiers killed Saddam Hussein's sons Qusay and Uday; say American forces raided house south of Tikrit, caturing nearly dozen people suspected of being Hussein's personal bodyguards; say soldiers seized over 45,000 sticks of dynamite in second raid; Maj Gen Raymond T Odierno says number of Iraqi informants had been growing in last two to three weeks, even before death of Hussein's sons; map; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 'Do Not Call' List Challenged
abstract: American Teleservices Assn asks federal court to overturn Do Not Call Registry (S)

headline: One Music Label or Several? Pearl Jam Weighs Options
abstract: Pearl Jam, which has fulfilled its contract with Sony Music's Epic Records, is considering various options as way of striking balance of distribution, artistic freedom and commercial control; possibilities include signing with major music labels in some countries, aligning with independents in others and releasing albums on their own in America; other artists, managers and music label executives are eager to see how it plays out; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PLAINS ALL AMERICAN PIPELINE, Houston, which transports and stores oil in the U.S. and Canada, said it completed three pipeline and gas-storage acquisitions during the second quarter that had a combined cost of $29 million.    APACHE CORP., Houston, an independent oil and gas driller, announced a large wildcat discovery, a gas field in Egypt's western desert.

headline: TO MOLLIFY IRAQIS, U.S. PLANS TO EASE SCOPE OF ITS RAIDS
abstract: The American military, in a major revision of strategy, has decided to limit the scope of its raids in Iraq after receiving warnings from Iraqi leaders that the raids were alienating the public, the top allied commander said today.    In its search for Baath Party operatives and other friends of the former government, the American military has carried out large sweeps, some of which have rounded up hundreds of Iraqis.

headline: Arab League Nations Agree to Grant Seat To Iraq's Council
abstract: Al Jazeera reports that Arab foreign ministers have agreed to grant Iraq's seat in Arab League to American-appointed Iraqi Governing Council; says Governing Council will hold seat in 22-member league until election of new government and drafting of constitution (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Digital Cameras Help Olympus
abstract: Olympus Optical reports profits in April-to-June quarter jumped 86 percent, to 9.1 billion yen ($76 million) (S)

headline: SONOCO TO CLOSE NEW YORK PLANT WITH 130 WORKERS
abstract: Sonoco Products Co, which makes boxes, plastic bags and food cans, will close plant in Fulton, NY, that has 130 employees as part of plan to reduce costs amid falling sales and prices; plant will close by end of March 2004 (S)

headline: Afghan Prison to Reopen Despite Memories of Its Brutal Past
abstract: afghan prison to reopen despite me8

headline: Adelphia Creditors Sue Banks Over Loans to Rigas Family
abstract: Adelphia Communications creditors sue dozens of banks that made loans to company and its founding family, charging banks helped Rigas family loot over $3 billion from Adelphia; hold banks, including Citigroup and J P Morgan, knowingly created complex loans that let family use company assets as collateral for billions of dollars in loans it could not repay; suit seeks $5 billion (M)

headline: HOME DEPOT IS PLANNING SECOND STORE IN MANHATTAN
abstract: Home Depot Inc plans to open store on Third Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets in mid-2004 (S)

headline: Powell Backs U.S. Role to Aid Liberia
