abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell voices strong support for United States interceding in Liberia, interview in Washington Times; stresses that Bush administration will accept mission of only limited 'scope and duration' and that American involvement will be primarily on humanitarian basis; expresses regret that administration has failed to agree quickly on strategy with Liberia's neighbors to stabilize country (S)

headline: Tenet Healthcare Says U.S. Inquiry Is Intensifying
abstract: Tenet Healthcare says it is being formally investigated by Securities and Exchange Commission, adding growing list of investigations and lawsuits company is facing; receives subpoena for documents dating to May 31, 1997, related to certain payments made from Medicare and insurance companies as well as to company's financial disclosures; Tenet's stock has dropped steeply since last fall, when it said that much of its rapid profit growth in last couple of years came from 'outlier' payments, which Medicare makes for treatment of especially costly cases; SEC is apparently looking at whether Tenet executives misled investors by not informing them well enough that company's growth was closely tied to those payments, which some analysts have characterized as Medicare loophole (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bhopal Extradition Sought
abstract: India asks US government to extradite Warren M Anderson, who was chairman of Union Carbide during toxic gas leak at company's factory in Bhopal in December 1984; warrant has been pending against Anderson since April 1992 in criminal case in which he is charged with culpable homicide; more than 3,000 people were killed when deadly gas was released from storage tank at plant; thousands more died later from aftereffects; case is being pressed by organizations representing survivors (M)

headline: World-Class Chip, but a Fragile Business
abstract: Surprisingly large second-quarter loss by IBM's semiconductor business raises questions about whether IBM can achieve its hybrid strategy of producing microprocessors for its mainframes and server computers, while also profitably making custom chips for outside companies; internal demand consumes only about third of IBM's plant capacity; IBM's approach to contract business varies from that of other chip makers; stresses close ties with limited number of customers that want advanced chips; graph of IBM sales and income; photos (M)

headline: Temporary Workers: A Barometer Of Recovery
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Greg Cappelli, business and professional services analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, on prospects for companies that place temporary employees; photo (M)

headline: Two U.S. Soldiers Killed as Iraqi Resistance Persists
abstract: Also today, Iraqi police officers in Falluja staged a protest and demanded that U.S. soldiers leave town.

headline: Sweet Taste of Start-Up Success
abstract: Profile of David A Hammond and Linda HammondØ

headline: Critics Say Guatemalan Ex-Dictator Is Mob Manipulator
abstract: Peasant mobs that have rampaged through exclusive neighborhoods in Guatemala City are well organized by party of Efrain Rios Montt, former general and dictator whose iron-fisted rule devastated peasant communities in early 1980's and who is now running for president; photos; Rios Montt, whose candidacy is being debated in court, is evangelical Christian who preaches helping the poor, but is also target of human rights groups that want him prosecuted for massacres while he was in power (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: 'Honor Killings' Law Blocked
abstract: Jordan's Parliament, supporting conservative and Islamist views, votes against stricter penalties for men who commit honor killings, in which fathers or brothers kill women who have had sex outside of marriage (S)

headline: Stocks Bounce Back . . .. . . Across the Board
abstract: Charts show second-quarter gains for Nasdaq composite index, Standard & Poor's 500 index and Dow Jones industrial average and gains in specific sectors of Standard & Poor's 500-stock index

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Effort To Free Hostages Shifts To Mali
abstract: German State Secretary Jurgen Chronbog meets with Mali President Amadou Toumani Toure in hopes of securing some answers as to fate of 15 European tourists kidnapped in Algeria; tourists, missing since February, are now thought to be held in Mali (S)

headline: Iran 'Willing to Cooperate' and Still Talking
abstract: Iranian government says it is still negotiating with Dr Mohamed ElBaradei, director of United Nations' nuclear agency, before deciding whether to allow tougher inspections; ElBaradei has met with Foreign Min Kamal Kharrazi, Pres Mohammad Khatami and Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, director of Iran's nuclear agency, to press for more rigorous inspections (M)

headline: Latest Tape Is Evidence Hussein Is Alive, C.I.A. Says
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency spokesman says tape recording broadcast on Al Jazeera television network on July 4 was probably of Saddam Hussein, giving strongest evidence yet that he is alive and calling for resistance to American military occupation; 20-minute audiotape was transmitted by telephone to Al Jazeera on July 3; CIA says exact date of recording has not been determined, but American intelligence officials say its references make it appear likely that tape was made within last month (M)

headline: Japan Is Spending Heavily to Pursue a Weak-Yen Policy
abstract: Japanese government is defying logic of foreign exchange market by keeping yen from rising sharply in value against dollar; Japan has himited yen's rise against dollar to no more than 2.3 percent this year by spending trillions of yen to buy dollars in foreign exchange market; yen is up 1.3 percent against dollar; Japan's success in keeping yen from gaining significant strength against dollar is helping country's economy rebound by keeping its exports more competitive abroad; is drag on American economic growth and is making it more difficult for US to reduce its troublesome current account deficit, which is over $500 billion; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Chrétien Has A Successor
abstract: Former Canadian Finance Minister Paul Martin, defeating Heritage Minister Sheila Copps, wins 90% of Liberal Party delegates to national party convention in November; will succeed Prime Minister Jean Chretien early next year and then face election (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: E.T.A. Bombers Sentenced
abstract: Spanish court sentences ETA members Santiago Arrospide and Caride Simon to several life terms in prison for their participation in 1987 Barcelona supermarket bombing that killed 21 people and injured 44; bombing is most deadly in 35-year-old Basque insurgency (S)

headline: Growing S.E.C. Role In Big Board Reform
abstract: Management crisis at New York Stock Exchange has raised long-dormant questions about whether exchange can continue to be regulator and presents major challenge for Securities and Exchange Commission; broad change is beginning to seem inevitable with H Carl McCall calling for division of regulatory and commercial functions when announcing his resignation from exchange's board; that change will test regulatory mettle of commission's new leader William H Donaldson, who helped topple Richard A Grasso and anoint his interim successor; Donaldson is moving gingerly in debate over exchange's future; commission and exchange officials expect Donaldson to be consulted before exchange discloses plan to overhaul how it is governed and structured; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: COPPER GAINS. Copper prices rose after an increase in durable-goods orders for June signaled stronger demand. In New York, copper for September delivery rose 0.45 cent, or 0.6 percent, to 79.8 cents a pound.

headline: World Briefing | Australia: Insect Thought Extinct Begins To Breed
abstract: Rare Lord Howe Island stick insect pair in Melbourne (Australia) Zoo propagates species as first of estimated 100 eggs hatch; insect was thought to be extinct since 1918, but was rediscovered in 2001 (S)

headline: IRAQIS WILL JOIN GOVERNING COUNCIL U.S. IS SETTING UP
abstract: Main Iraqi political groups that supported United States and Britain in toppling Saddam Hussein say they would join first postwar interim government later this month and press for greater powers under occupation authority; groups' decision marks final stage of two-month-long exercise in brinkmanship between former Iraqi opposition leaders and American administrator L Paul Bremer 3d over how much power and authority Iraqi leadership body will be given; Bremer sweeps aside plans made by his predecessor Jay Garner to turn over significant powers to Iraqi provisional government; Shiite Muslim tribes meet for first time to discuss how they, as country's religious majority, could help create united Iraqi nation; several prominent members of former opposition forces say they are urging US military commanders to allow creation of Iraqi national security force to help thwart attacks that are destabilizing country; say they have support for force from Gen John P Abizaid, who is taking over US Central Command from Gen Tommy R Franks, and from Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz; proponents say force would be paramilitary army trained and equipped by US on crash basis to confront remnants of Hussein's Baathist government, which are believed to be responsible for killing 29 American soldiers since May 1; photo; map (M)

headline: ABC News Is Close to Signing a Top CNN Correspondent
abstract: Kate Snow, a CNN congressional correspondent, would become a White House correspondent for "Good Morning America."

headline: Senators on Both Sides See Need for More Troops in Iraq
abstract: Senior senators of both parties also said that many billions more dollars were needed to stabilize and rebuild Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Plan to Rebuild Iraq Gains Some Backing on Capitol Hill
abstract: The Bush administration got some support on Capitol Hill today as it continued to defend its Iraq-reconstruction program.

headline: Israel Authorizes Removal of Arafat, but Puts Off Action
abstract: The Israeli government today authorized actions in the future to exile, jail or possibly kill Yasir Arafat.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle May Seek Other Deals
abstract: Oracle, a leading business software company, may make other acquisitions as it pursues a hostile bid for PeopleSoft, Oracle's executive vice president, Charles Phillips, said yesterday. The Justice Department's antitrust investigation into Oracle's offer should be completed in September to November, Mr. Phillips said at the CIBC World Markets Enterprise Software Conference in New York, in remarks broadcast on the Internet. ''We may be working on the PeopleSoft one now,'' he said, ''but that doesn't stop us from looking at others.'' He would not say what other purchases Oracle, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., might consider.

headline: Crackdown on Tycoon Shakes Up Moscow
abstract: A noisy political brawl between President Vladimir V. Putin and Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the country's richest man, is rewriting the rules of Russian politics.

headline: CIT GROUP NAMES PEEK AS ITS NEW PRESIDENT
abstract: CIT Group names Jeffrey Peek, Credit Suisse First Boston official, president and chief operating officer; says he probably will succeed chairman and chief executive Albert Gamper (S)

headline: Homesick at Camp
abstract: Michael J Hildenbrandt letter deplores using technology for young campers to keep in close touch with parents, saying it defeats purpose of fostering independence (Jul 31 article)

headline: AK STEEL SAYS TOP 2 EXECUTIVES HAVE RESIGNED
abstract: AK Steel Holding's chairman-chief executive Richard M Waldrop and president John G Hritz resign; chief financial officer James L Wainscott will run company until replacements are found (S)

headline: Rumsfeld Strikes Back at Critics of U.S. Effort on Terror
abstract: In a first, the defense secretary today suggested that critics might unwittingly be aiding the terrorist cause.

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Annan Asks For New Rwanda Prosecutor
abstract: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan recommends separate prosecutors for war crimes in former Yugoslavia and Rwanda; Security Council agreement would make Carla Del Ponte prosecutor only in former Yugoslavia; some feel Del Ponte has been political target of Rwandan government therefore limiting her effectiveness to prosecute (S)

headline: Brazilian Court Lifts Ban on Genetically Modified Soybeans
abstract: A Brazilian federal tribunal said today it decided to lift a longstanding ban on the sale of Monsanto's genetically modified Roundup Ready soybeans in the world's No. 2 soy producer.

headline: Sudan's 2 Sides Take Big Step Toward Peace: A Security Pact
abstract: Government of Sudan agrees to withdraw most of its troops from rebel-held south of country and begin integrating its soldiers with those of rebels in unified army; one of Africa's longest-running and deadliest wars has taken major turn toward peace; two million people, mostly civilians, have died from bullets and bombs as well as war-induced disease and famine; still unresolved is how to apportion political power between government and rebels; photo (M)

headline: Sharon Aide Says Israel Is Considering Killing Arafat
abstract: Vice Prime Min Ehud Olmert of Israel says killing Yasir Arafat is one of several options now under government consideration; says other options include expulsion or confinement to his office in Ramallah, but cut off from world by severing communications and barring visitors; Olmert's remarks are most explicit descrition of options Israel is considering for dealing with Arafat since Prime Min Ariel Sharon's government decided 'in principle' to remove him; that decision is facing widespread international opposition, including objections from United States, Israel's strongest ally; Arafat's complex has taken on rollicking carnival atmosphere, with ordinary Palestinians filling square outside his office to protect him; photo (M)

headline: Bush, at U.N., Defends Policy Over Iraq
abstract: President Bush was vigorous in his defense of the war even as he sought the financial assistance of a still cautious world in rebuilding Iraq.

headline: Brown-Forman Profit Falls
abstract: Brown-Forman Corp says profit dropped 14 percent in its fiscal first quarter ended July 31; net income fell to $31.1 million from $36.1 million; sales rose 11 percent, to $532.6 million (S)

headline: U.S. Civilian Killed in Blast Near Tikrit
abstract: American civilian working in Iraq for Halliburton subsidiary KBR is killed when he drives mail truck over homemade bomb north of Tikrit; US forces carry out 25 raids and detain 141 people in hunt for Saddam Hussein (S)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: TYPHOON BATTERS SOUTHEAST ASIA; JAPAN: U.S. Marine Pleads Guilty To Rape;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Western Digital Shares Soar On Acquisition News
abstract: Western Digital's shares rise $1.98, or 21 percent, to $11.48 after company says buying Read-Rite Corp last month will increase profitability (S)

headline: S.E.C. Demands Documents From Former Enron Chief
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission asks federal judge to compel production of certain documents from Enron Corp's former chairman Kenneth L Lay in response to subpoena issued in agency's probe into company's collapse; dispute centers on two folders filled with records that Lay, through his lawyers, has said do not have to be produced because they are covvered by Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination; SEC lawyers contend documents are corporate records and thus not covered by Fifth Amendment; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway TV's To Double As PC Monitors
abstract: Gateway Inc introduces line of televisions that can serve as computer monitors as company expands sales beyond personal computers; is selling 17-inch LCD television for $799 and 18-inch model for $899 (S)

headline: STATE CHECKING INTO REPORT OF MICROSOFT IMPROPRIETY
abstract: Massachusetts, only state still challenging Microsoft's antitrust settlement with Bush administration, is investigating whether company retaliated against computer maker promoting rival operating system; state says Microsoft 'retaliated' against unnamed company for promoting Linux operating system; Microsoft spokesman Jim Desler denies company violated agreement (S)

headline: Weak Earnings Dent Optimism in Japan
abstract: Japanese economic outlook dims on reports of weak quarterly results by leading technology companies Toshiba Corp and Matsushita Electric Industrial and report that industrial output unexpectedly fell 1.2 percent in June; Toshiba, semiconductor maker, reports loss of 36.8 billion yen ($307 million) in Apr-June quarter, compared with year-earlier loss of 18.8 billion yen; Matsushita reports profits fell 22 percent to 2.7 billion yen ($22.5 million); companies's shares fall on news, spurring 201-point drop in Nikkei 225 index, to 9,632; photo (M)

headline: Doubts Expressed As Bush Presses Asia on Currency
abstract: Publicly berating China and Japan over their exchange rates is winning Bush administration praise from American manufacturers, but is not playing so well among economists; pushing China to let its currency rise against dollar, as Treas Sec John W Snow has been doing, would help American producers by making Chinese imports more expensive and American exports cheaper; growing number of experts, including some with close ties to Bush administration, warn that effort could create more problems than it solves; China and other Asian countries have helped to finance repidly expanding federal budget deficit with huge purchases of Treasury securities over last year; China and Japan could reverse course and start selling Treasury securities, which could drive up interest rates (M)

headline: Blast in Iraq Kills a Leading Shiite Cleric
abstract: A top Shiite leader and more than 90 other people were killed today in a car bomb explosion outside a mosque in Najaf soon after Friday prayers.

headline: Bush Seems to Favor Sending a Modest Force to Liberia
abstract: Pres Bush gives his strongest indication yet that he will send small force of American troops into Liberia to help enforce cease-fire there; says that he is waiting for further information from military teams in region before deciding and that peacekeeping operation would ultimately be taken over by United Nations; makes statement after White House meeting with UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan; says any American military involvement would be limited in scope and duration and would be conditional on Pres Charles Taylor stepping aside; says any American troops sent to Liberia would support those coming from other African countries under umbrella of Economic Community of West African States; photo (M)

headline: 45 Dead in Bombay After Twin Blasts in Crowded Area
abstract: No one has taken responsibility for the blasts, which Pakistan quickly condemned as "acts of terrorism."

headline: I.B.M. WINS CONTRACT TO RUN ABB'S INFORMATION SYSTEMS
abstract: IBM wins 10-year contract worth $1.1 billion to manage systems of ABB Ltd, Europe's largest electrical engineering company (S)

headline: MEDICAL PRODUCTS MAKER ISSUES A WARNING ON PROFIT
abstract: Vital Signs Inc says third-quarter profit from continuing operations will be below its estimates because of legal and accounting costs; is being sued by its former chief financial officer for 'fraudulent accounting' (S)

headline: Investing; In Developing Countries, Prices May Be Right
abstract: Many portfolio managers are optimistic about prospects for emerging markets, despite already strong performance thus far in 2003; governments in developing countries have been forced to implement policies to address widespread currency crises of late 1990's, when returns on equity in emerging markets were fraction of those in US; Asia is seen as most attractive target for investment, particularly India and South Korea; graph; photo (M)

headline: Business; On His Shoulders, A Graying Japan
abstract: Profile of Noboru Terada, executive investment officer of world's largest pension fund, Japan's government pension fund; he is charged with raising investment returns to keep national pension system, hurt by years of rising payouts, near-zero interest rates and falling stock prices, from collapsing; politicians, fearful of addressing problem of wave of baby boomers nearing retirement, have merely trimmed benefits and nudged premiums higher; Terada has imported new investment techniques, like indexing, and broken with local custom by rewarding better-performing, not better-connected, investment managers; hopes modernizing system will increase returns and reassure public; graphs of fund holdings; photo (M)

headline: Diller Finishes Buying Expedia
abstract: InterActiveCorp, run by Barry Diller, completes acquisitions of Expedia Inc and LendingTree Inc; InterActiveCorp is issuing shares worth $4.63 billion for Expedia stock it does not already own; is giving stock worth $732.4 million to Lending Treee shareholders (S)

headline: Peace and Reason Amid Chaos, a Balm for Pain
abstract: Profile of Roman Catholic Abp Michael Kpakala Francis of Liberia, who spoke out against nation's ousted warlord president, Charles G Taylor, despite constant death threats; Amb John W Blaney credits him with keeping hope alive; photo (M)

headline: Economy Shows Unexpected Strength
abstract: Commerce Department reports economy grew at revised annual rate of 3.1 percent in second quarter and unexpected strength leads economists to raise their forecasts for rest of year; among positive signs are continued strength of consumer spending, rebound of capital investment by businesses, leanness of business inventories, which fell, and increase in corporate profits; inflation was at annual rate of only 0.7 percent; total nominal Gross Domestic Product rose to $10.794 trillion in second quarter; personal consumption expenditures, adjusted for inflation, rose 3.8 percent, up from increase of 2 percent in first quarter and initial second-quarter estimate of 3.3 percent; spending on business equipment and software rose 8.2 percent; private inventories fell $20.9 billion; after-tax corporate profits rose 15.9 percent, to $670.7 billion; Labor Department reports initial unemployment claims rose slightly more than expected, to 394,000 last week; graphs (M)

headline: Murder now seen in Italian banker's 1982 death
abstract: MILAN:—  Rome prosecutors, looking into the death of Roberto Calvi, the Italian banker found hanging from Blackfriars Bridge in London 21 years ago, have concluded that Calvi was murdered.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Key Rate Holds
abstract: Bank of England votes to hold its key interest rate at 3.5 percent (S)

headline: Chile's Wound, 30 Years Later, Is Still Inflamed
abstract: Many on Chile's left have reached nuanced view of Salvador Allende, leftist president overthrown 30 years ago; many Socialists now argue he erred by failing to drift toward center to woo Christian Democrats; Allende's Communist allies and others on hard left still do not accept view, clinging to his image and programs and thus implying ruling Socialists have abandoned their principles; photos (M)

headline: 69,000 Died or Disappeared in Peru Conflict, Panel Reports
abstract: A Maoist rebel group was responsible for the greatest number of deaths, a panel said after a two-year inquiry.

headline: The Surge in Rates Won't Short-Circuit a Recovery
abstract: Recent increases in interest rates are seen posing little threat to US economic recovery; despite sell-off in Treasury market, rates remain very modest by historical standards; home sales are expected to decline as result in increases in mortgage rates, but may be offset by increases in business and consumer spending; graph (M)

headline: Toronto Turns On Rock to Drown Out SARS Fears
abstract: Huge rock concert is held in Toronto, Ontario, organized in part by government with goal of proving to world that SARS no longer poses threat to those wanting to visit; when World Health Orgn issued travel advisories for Toronto, it prompted massive cancellations of conventions, concerts and vacations; more than 430,000 people crush into stadium to hear Rolling Stones, Rush and AC/DC perform; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CLOROX CO., Oakland, Calif., the household bleach maker, said it would raise its quarterly dividend to 27 cents from 22 cents a share, a 23 percent increase, and may repurchase $700 million of its shares to help raise the stock's price.    LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., the military contractor, said it had received a $100 million award from the Air Force to modify 10 C-130 transport planes to be used for combat search-and-rescue missions.

headline: In Silicon Valley, Pressure for Stock Grants in Lieu of Options
abstract: Silicon Valley companies feel increased pressure to alter their compensation packages after Microsoft Corp decides to change way it pays its 50,000 employees; Mel Croner, chairman of Croner Group, which surveys and advises Silicon Valley companies on compensation, says large number of companies are already exploring whether to book expenses for their options (M)

headline: In Search for Baath Loyalists, U.S. Finds Itself in Gray Area
abstract: US efforts to 'de-Baathify' Iraqi government excludes from public employment all party members of 'group' rank or above, including many who had no political roles but were party members to keep jobs; Ahmad Saleh Al-Wan recalls coming back from Iranian prison to printing job with rank that increased his pay; Baath Party, like Nazis, played central role in disseminating propaganda, stifling dissent and encouraging informing; excluding members, as was done in Germany, is easier to announce than to apply; they include unrepentant members like Ibrahim al-Najim, university professor who admits informing, and school principal Fawzia Habib Hassan; Baathists also worked closely with vast security apparatus, some acquiring wealth from victims that could help them in new free-market economy, all of which has to be sorted out for sone sense of justice to prevail; millions of minds shaped by party's culture also have to be retooled; culture of informing and accusations is documented in notebooks that fill maze of rooms beneath party headquarters; photos (L)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sabotage Of Illusionist Charged
abstract: British police arrest man for trying to cut water line and other cables connected to large plexiglass box housing American illusionist David Blaine; many Britons have hurled insults at Blaine, critical of his attempt to remain in box suspended near London's Tower Bridge without food for 44 days (S)

headline: Laos Releases 2 European Journalists and Aide
abstract: Three men were released today after being sentenced to prison during a trial that one of them called "a mockery of justice."

headline: Where the Jobs Went As Productivity Grew
abstract: Jim Hazy letter on Sept 14 article h

headline: Heralded Investigation of Abuses In Mexico Said to Achieve Little
abstract: Human Rights Watch report says special office created by Pres Vincente Fox to investigate most brutal periods of Mexico's past could end in failure; says rather than uncovering new evidence, office has accomplished little more than compile oral and written testimony already gathered by victims' associations; notes high-profile interrogations flopped when witnesses invoked their constitutional protections against self-incrimination, and that Fox himself has suggested that some of crimes cannot be prosecuted because of statutory limitations (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: President Quits Party
abstract: South Korean President Roh Moo Hyun discontinues his membership in Millennium Democratic Party shortly after 37 lawmakers leave party to form new People's Participatory United New Party (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DUKE ENERGY CORP., Charlotte, N.C., agreed to sell a 25 percent stake in a power plant in Vermillion County, Ind., to Wabash Valley Power Association Inc., Indianapolis, for $44.4 million.    MENU FOODS INCOME FUND, Mississauga, Canada, a producer of pet food, agreed to buy a plant in South Dakota from the Procter & Gamble Co., Cincinnati, and become the exclusive supplier of Procter's Iams pet food in the United States and Canada. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: The Road to the Panel's Final Report
abstract: Article recalls protracted, occasionally bumpy and often secret investigation into intelligence failings that led finally to release of Congressional report on Sept 11 attacks (S)

headline: G.E. Bid for Instrumentarium Receives European Approval
abstract: European Commission approves General Electric's planned $2.2 billion acquisition of Finnish medical devices maker Instrumentarium, on condition that GE sell Spacelabs, US-based maker of patient monitors bought by Instrumentarium last year, and promises not to shut out competitors in European market combined companies will dominate (M)

headline: Pakistan Criticized as India Bombing Toll Rises to 52
abstract: Death toll from two Bombay bombings rises to 52; blasts threaten to derail fragile reconciliation between India and Pakistan; Deputy Prime Min Lal Krishna Advani, on visit to blast sites and hospital, scores Pakistan; blames Lashkar-el-Toiba and Students Islamic Movement of India; opposition leader Sonia Gandhi also goes to Bombay, officially known as Mumbai; city is now back to normal in many ways (S)

headline: ADVENT PAYS $40 MILLION FOR MAJORITY STAKE IN TERAPIA
abstract: Advent International Corp pays $40 million for majority stake in Terapia SA, Romania's 4th-largest drug maker (S)

headline: Finance Chief Is Resigning at Troubled Advertising Company
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies' chief financial officer Sean F Orr will resign, effective at end of August; chief operating officer Christopher J Coughlin will assume Orr's title and duties (M)

headline: People
abstract: Financial Dynamics names Declan Kelly, president for its North American operations, to added new post of chief executive; company's main North American agency, FD Morgen-Walke is being rebranded as Financial Dynamics; Public Agenda, research organization, names Ruth Wooden president, succeeding Deborah Wadsworth (S)

headline: Pension Fund Presses Banks on Standards
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System will ask 90 investment banks and brokers that trade on its behalf to tighten rules intended to prevent conficts of interest (S)

headline: F.C.C. Vows to Enforce Do-Not-Call List for Telemarketers
abstract: The list faces more court challenges, even as President Bush signed a bill today that was meant to counter one of them.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Greece: Coke Executive Resigns
abstract: Coca-Cola HBC (Greece) chief executive Irial Finan resigns; to be succeeded by former chief financial officer Doros Constantinou, who is returning to company after three-year hiatus (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Dalai Lama Visit Barred
abstract: Russia's Foreign Ministry, citing international commitments that include agreements with China, refuses to grant visa to Dalai Lama for proposed visit to southern republic of Kalmykia (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airwaves Sale Advances
abstract: Cingular Wireless's planned $1.4 billion purchase of airwaves from bankrupt NextWave Telecom moves closer to completion after other cellphone providers decide not to submit bids by Sept 15 deadline (S)

headline: A New Way to Bring Plastic to the People
abstract: Prepaid, or 'stored value,' work much like standard gift cards, but often have Visa or MasterCard logos, allowing them to be used wherever those brands are accepted; banks predict that this and other payment options will become more commonplace over next few years (S)

headline: Iraqi Family Ties Complicate American Efforts for Change
abstract: Nearly half of all marriages in Iraq are between first or second cousins, creating strong family bonds that complicate change Americans are trying to institute; world is divided into kin and strangers and people know that whoever is in power will give important positions to relatives, just as Saddam Hussein did; people tend to live in large family groups and do not understand American propensity for independence; while cousin marriage has become rare in West, it has persisted in Middle East and makes nation-building frustrating because it tends to negate central power and makes people suspicious of outsiders; photos (L)

headline: KOCH NAMED LIKELY BUYER OF DUPONT UNIT
abstract: DuPont Co, which last winter put its textile-related businesses into stand-alone unit that it said it would sell or spin off, identifies Koch Industries as probable buyer (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Kingfisher Profit Rises
abstract: British home-improvement retailer Kingfisher says first-half profit before interest and tax increased 29 percent; earnings for six months ended Aug 2 rose to 335 million pounds ($539 million) from 259 million pounds ($416 million) year earlier; sales rose 15 percent, to 3.9 billion pounds ($6.2 billion); graph (S)

headline: STOCK IN SONUS NETWORKS RISES ON VERIZON DEAL
abstract: Shares of Sonus Networks Inc rise by 24 percent after company announces deal under which it will supply software for Verizon Communications' voice and data networks (S)

headline: Wolfowitz Sees Challenges, And Vindication, in Iraq
abstract: Deputy Sec Paul Wolfowitz visits Mosul and sees newly elected, multi-ethnic local council as fruit of long personal mission to oust Saddam Hussein; roadside bomb explodes near US convoy, killing soldier and Iraqi interpreter; Wolfowitz's five-day trip includes visits to mass grave site and notorious prison, vindicating his warnings dating to 1979; he underscores Hussein's bruality, virtually ignoring issue of weapons of mass destruction that were Pres Bush's main reason for war; says conditions are better than he thought but notes crucial need to capture Hussein to end state of fear; photo of Shiites demonstrating against US in Baghdad (M)

headline: Nanotechnology Group to Address Safety Concerns
abstract: NanoBusiness Alliance, trade group for businesses at work on nanotechnology, is forming task force to address health and environmental concerns that could be associated with microscopic nano-scale products; many nano-scale materials exist naturally with no known negative health or environmental consequences, but there has been little research on impact of making large amounts of new nanomaterials (M)

headline: A List of Candidate Web Sites
abstract: Here are candidates (and a governor's wife) who have established campaign blogs in the California recall vote, along with the Web addresses:

headline: New Law Raises Obstacles to Israeli-Palestinian Marriages
abstract: Israeli Parliament votes to block Palestinians who marry Israelis from becoming Israeli citizens or residents, erecting new legal barrier as Israel finishes first section of new physical barrier against West Bank Palestinians; supporters of bill call it necessary bulwark against infiltration by terrorists, as well as way to preserve Israel's Jewish majority; opponents call it racist measure that threatens to divide thousands of families or force them out of Israel; Israel's 1.2 million Arab citizens are far more likely than Israeli Jews to marry Palestinians; Israel solicits construction bids to build 22 new homes in settlement in Gaza Strip, even though new peace plan calls on Israel to freeze settlement construction; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies Lobby to Shift Part of Drug Costs to U.S.  The bills to provide drug benefits through Medicare that were passed by the House and the Senate last week offer some of the country's largest employers a long-sought prize: shifting at least some of their burden of soaring drug costs to the federal government.    With billions of dollars at stake, those companies are lobbying hard to make sure that those gains survive in the final version of the law. [Page A1.]

headline: Reality TV as Sitcom: 'Green Acres, We Are There'
abstract: New wave of reality programs, which will be well represented on both broadcast and cable television in coming months, will seek to generate laughter associated with situation comedies; new variation on genre builds comedy into concept; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Profit Lower Than Expected
abstract: Deutsche Bank returns to profit in second quarter but posts lower-than-expected net profit of 572 million euros ($642 million) because of tax charges (S)

headline: Sears to Sell Card Portfolio To Citigroup For $3 Billion
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co sells its credit card portfolio to Citigroup for $3 billion in cash; portfolio includes Sears private-lable cards and co-branded MasterCards; sale is strategic shift for Sears as it repositions itself as stand-alone retailer without buffer of credit card operation that has provided hedge against unpredictability of retail business for so many years; credit card business provides about 60 percent of Sears's annual profits, or about $1.5 billion, far more than at any other retailer; Citigroup will continue to operate business under Sears name; photo (M)

headline: New Yorkers meet the neighbors in impromptu block parties : No lights, big city:the next day
abstract: NEW YORK:—  Although power returned to large sections of New York on Friday, the city was still largely off-kilter, with subways closed, cash machines down and tens of thousands of people happy to simply sit outside and chat about the Great Blackout of 2003.

headline: When Work Is Everything
abstract: Alan Goldstein letter on work addiction (Aug 17 Preludes column)

headline: BBC Says Arms Expert Who Died Was Source for Contested Report
abstract: The announcement cast doubt on the network's credibility since the arms expert said two days before his death that he did not provide the report's central contention.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Phone Shares Sold
abstract: Dutch government sells 300 million shares in telecommunications firm Royal KPN to Citigroup Global Markets for $2.2 billion; sale represents 12 percent of KPN, and reduces government's holding to 19.3 percent; graph (S)

headline: Kenya Starts Crackdown On Fake Charity Groups
abstract: Across Africa, fake AIDS charities are springing up as more and more money arrives from overseas to combat the disease; Kenya's AIDS oversight body recently stopped financing four such groups, including one supposedly intended to help AIDS orphans, although none of organizers have been apprehended; another 10 groups are under investigation; experts say bad apples represent only small percentage of 680 AIDS-related nongovernmental oganizations in Kenya and of hundreds of other community-based organizations working to combat AIDS (M)

headline: MediaTalk; After 'Gigli,' Less of J. Lo Is Seen as a Good Thing
abstract: Miramax Films, following poor box office and critical reception of Ben Affleck-Jennifer Lopez film Gigli, has begun highlighting fact that Lopez barely appears in Jersey Girl, her next film with fiance Affleck; director Kevin Smith cut Lopez's part even before Gigli bombed, over objections of Miramax, which wanted to take advantage of couple's star appeal (M)

headline: QUALITY DISTRIBUTION PLANS INITIAL OFFERING TO PAY DEBT
abstract: Chemical transportation company Quality Distribution plans to raise as much as $132.3 million in initial public offering to pay debt (S)

headline: An Ancient Game With Fresh Appeal
abstract: Mah-jongg is getting new digital life, appealing to stereotypical grandmothers and young Asian players alike; Internet has sown some confusion, as there are more than 12 styles played across Asia and in North America, and many players are unaware that several versions exist; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Police Take Over Security for Bethlehem
abstract: Israel, however, maintained its military cordon around the town, continuing to barricade Palestinians inside.

headline: Bush, in Africa, Promises Aid but Offers No Troops for Liberia
abstract: Pres Bush opens five-country tour of Africa with promise in Senegal to work more closely to help African countries build for future; does not commit to sending US troops to help keep peace in Liberia and repeats demand that Pres Charles Taylor step aside; goes with Senegal Pres Abdoulaye Wade to Goree Island, where slaves were sent on journey across ocean; photo; Bush does not apologize for role of US but condemns slavery in unflinching, religious terms; Sec Colin Powell and security adviser Condoleezza Rice tour island with Bush (M)

headline: Boeing Tests Effort to Curb Volatility In Fuel Tanks
abstract: Boeing tests protective system it hopes to install on airplanes to prevent type of fuel tank explosion that destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800 in 1996; system adds nitrogen to empty space in fuel tank to dilute oxygen content to level that will not support fire or explosion; Federal Aviation Administration head Marion C Blakey hails fuel-tank inerting as safety advance, but is not sure whether agency will require airlines to install costly system; diagram (M)

headline: Labor Adopts New Strategy
abstract: Labor unions, among burst of maj

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Ex-Mayor Cleared In Sadomasochism Case; AZERBAIJAN: Putin Backs Young Leader;.

headline: Yen Surges On Statement By Ministers
abstract: Japanese yen rises to 33-month high after finance ministers and central bankers from Group of 7 nations urge Japan to limit its role in foreign exchange markets; dollar falls as low as 11.37 yen, nearly 4-yen move from Sept 19 (M)

headline: Antiglobization Woodstock Attracts Thousands in France
abstract: Among the stars of the show was José Bové, the 50-year old sheep farmer, union leader and national hero for his refusal to bow to globalization.

headline: Sale of Stock Is Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Restrained
abstract: Canada's annual inflation rate fell to 2 percent in August, slowest pace in 13 months, suggesting that central bank will keep interest rates unchanged this year; consumer price index rose 0.2 percent from July (S)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Westchester County; Old Insurance Building Steps Into a Familiar Role
abstract: USI, inf

headline: A Jolt of Caffeine For the Sluggish PC
abstract: Background applets are tiny utilities that can slow PC's processing speed while contributing to spontaneous lockups; they are routinely installed by drivers and adapters for software or peripherals to make applications run more quickly and smoothly; process of uninstalling unnecessary applets described; several tools and utilities for doing job noted; drawing (M)

headline: Speculation on Weaker Dollar Leads to Gains for Euro and Yen
abstract: US dollar tumbles against euro and yen in New York trading on speculation that US officials might seek weaker currency to bolster corporate profits and extend recovery; dollar weakens to $1.1589 for euro from $1.1474; falls to 110.91 yen from 111.91; graph (M)

headline: Extension of Stay in Iraq Takes Toll on Morale of G.I.'s
abstract: Morale within Army's Third Infantry Division suffers blow when soldiers are informed that their tours of duty have been extended indefinitely; soldiers have been in Persian Guf region since November and were originally scheduled to be home by early June; are tired of patrolling hostile Iraqi towns in punishing heat, on guard for invisible enemy, and some are skeptical about peacekeeping work they have been asked to do; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of two Americans in Iraq (S)

headline: Europe to Require Labels on Modified Foods
abstract: The European Parliament approved legislation today to require labels for food made with genetically altered ingredients.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 10 article about financial disclosure at InterActiveCorp, and of shorter, related article about deal that created Vivendi Universal Entertainment

headline: Bush, at U.N., Defends Policy Over Iraq
abstract: Pres Bush vigorously defends Iraq war and rebuffs calls from France and Germany for rapid transfer of sovereignty to Iraqi Governing Council, speech to United Nations General Assembly; holds self-government for Iraq must come through 'orderly' process that should not be hurried or delayed; implies weapons of mass destruction, or at least programs behind them, will still be revealed; seeks financial in building Iraq's 'young democracy'; offers very limited description of expanded role he envisions for UN in Iraq; gets cool response; Sec Gen Kofi Annan seems in his speech to accuse United Sates of endangering world peace with policy of pre-emptive force; French Pres Jacques Chirac, who led opposition to war, offers stinging counterpoint to Bush; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Economy Maintains Growth
abstract: China's industrial production rose 16.5 percent in July from year earlier to 341 billion yuan ($41.2 billion); total exports for January-July period rose by about one-third to $228 billion (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Poor Outlook For Steelmaker
abstract: British steelmaker Corus Group lost 125 million pounds in first half of year compared with 237 million pounds year earlier; graph (S)

headline: Big Investors Urged to Unite For Reforms
abstract: New York State Comptroller Alan G Hevesi proposes that big investors work together to try to prevent more corporate scandals like those that hurt shareholders and employees of Enron and WorldCom, annual meeting of Council of Institutional Investors; calls for creation of National Coalition for Corporate Reform, which would try to influence behavior of companies through proxy voting, litigation and lobbying (M)

headline: Exercising Self-Awareness
abstract: University of Vermont Asst Prof Sara Solnick letter on David Leonhardt's July 6 Economic View article on study by economists Stefano Dela Vigna and Ulrike Malmendier that shows consumers are increasingly losing income by miscalculating utility of future-oriented purchases such as health club memberships

headline: A U.N. Official to Visit Iran Over Nuclear Sites
abstract: Dr Mohamed ElBaradei, who heads International Atomic Energy Agency, will visit Iran, which is under mounting international pressure to open up its nuclear program (S)

headline: Awards Ceremony For Family Shows
abstract: Fifth annual Family Television Awards are presented by coalition of advertisers interested in stimulating production of prime-time television programs meant to appeal to multigenerational audiences (S)

headline: Truck Bomb Explodes Outside Baghdad Police Headquarters
abstract: The bomb went off near the office of the Baghdad police chief, missing him but killing one officer and wounding 26 others.

headline: Diverging Estimates Of the Costs of Spam
abstract: Spam has become the bane of the Internet because it is so cheap and easy to send that many businesses and individuals do so. Spammers these days pay as little as 0.025 of a cent to send an e-mail message. The computing costs for the recipients, or their Internet providers, to process each message are similarly tiny.

headline: Bar Association's Guidelines On Client Secrets Are Eased
abstract: American Bar Association approves changes to its model code of conduct, allowing lawyers greater discretion to reveal clients' confidences; proposed change would allow--but not require--lawyers to disclose confidences to prevent or rectify crime or fraud causing financial injury, when lawyer's services were used to help perpetrate crime; critics of proposed change argue that if states were to adopt it, it would weaken privilege that protects client confidences and undermine lawyers' relationships with clients; supporters argue that it is necessary to make it clear that under certain circumstances lawyers could disclose confidences without violating rule; bar association president Alfred P Carlton Jr reports to House of Delegates, which determines policy for association, won partial victory in lawsuit it filed against Federal Trade Commission; lawsuit challenged whether 1999 law requiring disclosure of policies on protection of clients' privacy was applicable to lawyers (M)

headline: Nasdaq Posts $49 Million Loss for Quarter
abstract: Nasdaq Stock Market reports $49 million second-quarter loss, compared with year-earlier profit of $8.8 million; revenue fell 26 percent, to $151.4 million (S)

headline: In the Lecture Hall, A Geek Chorus
abstract: Proliferation of wireless networks allows people to communicate with each other during meetings, lectures and other gatherings, adding new dimension for attendees; practice adds 'back-channel' of conversation during which comments may be exchanged along with Web sites relevant to topic; some people, of course, ignore speakers by surfing Web or checking e-mail, but others are genuinely interested and want to talk concurrently about what is being said; some speakers find practice annoying (M)

headline: In 2 Bombings, Arab Attackers Kill 13 in Israel
abstract: Two Palestinian suicide bombers kill at least 13 people in separate attacks, striking Jerusalem cafe and bus stop crowded with soldiers in Tsrifin; bombings come amid rising anger and despair on both sides, as Bush administration's Mideast peace plan founders; Israeli military kills two suspected Hamas terrorist leaders in Hebron; boy, 12, is hit by shrapnel and reportedly dies later; Israeli troops shoot Palestinian at boundary fence with Israel in Gaza; Ahmed Qurei, nominated by Yasir Arafat as Palestinian prime minister, expresses regret for loss of innocent lives in violence; calls for end to Israeli military operations; map; photo (M)

headline: Russian Oil Man Arrested; Allies Blame Politics
abstract: Russian authorities arrest Platon Lebedev, chairman of Menatep, company that owns 61 percent of giant Yukos Oil Co, on charges of embezzling money from state company in 1994; arrest, at hospital where Lebedev was convalescing, is first of major tycoon since Vladimor Gusinsky in 2000, as Pres Vladimir Putin consolidated power; arrest may be blunt message to Yukos chief executive Mikhail B Khodorkovsky to stop involving himself in opposition politics (M)

headline: Johnson & Johnson to Sell Cancer Drug From Millennium Overseas
abstract: Johnson & Johnson wins right to sell cancer drug Velcade, made by Millennium Pharmaceuticals, outside US; Ortho Biotech Products, unit of Johnson & Johnson, will pay Millennium $15 million up front and as much as $520 million later if Velcade wins approval in various countries for treating multiple myeloma and other types of cancers and if it achieves sales goals; Johnson & Johnson will also pay double-digit royalty and at least 40 percent of costs of clinical trials for drug (M)

headline: Unions See More Delay in Talks With Verizon
abstract: Two main unions at Verizon Communications say there will be delays in reaching settlement because of new proposals that company made on job security; but Verizon immediately counters that unions are unnecessarily stretching out talks to win concessions (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Deflation Worsens; SOUTH KOREA: Possible Bank Stake Sale; SOUTH KOREA: Bank'S Profit Falls; HONG KONG: Kerry Shareholders Reject Bid; SOUTH KOREA: Drop For Electronics Maker;.

headline: Governor of Russian Pacific Region and Aides on Missing Copter
abstract: Helicopter carrying Gov Igor P Farkhutdinov and other senior officials of Sakhalin Island disappears while flying toward Kurile Islands; airborne search for helicopter is suspended at nightfall, dimming hopes that helicopter and those aboard would be found safe; spokeswoman for Russia's Emergency Situations Ministry says as many as 18 passengers and 3 crew members are thought to have been on board when helicopter took off from airport on Kamchatka Peninsula; map (M)

headline: The wrath of the conquered
abstract: America's GIs feel like living targets on Baghdad's streets, while the subjects of the accursed dictator Saddam Hussein complain more and more vocally about the arrogance and incompetence of their conquerors. The star of Gulf war champion George W. Bush is also beginning to fall at home.

headline: HEALTH INSURER AGREES TO SETTLE LAWSUIT BY DOCTORS
abstract: Health insurer Cigna Corp agrees to pay $85 million to settle accusations that it routinely underpaid doctors; also agrees to to make changes to its billing processes and business practices that may bring value of settlement to more than $700 million (S)

headline: The Geography Factor in Nursing Home Bills
abstract: Nursing home care remains a major financial burden for families, but it may be harder for some because of where they happen to live, a recent survey shows.

headline: Finally, It's Official: the Recession Ended 20 Months Ago
abstract: The recession that began in March 2001 ended eight months later, the National Bureau of Economic Research reported today.

headline: 2 Blair Aides Again Deny Misleading Britons on War
abstract: Two senior members of Prime Minister Tony Blair's today resisted vigorous attempts by lawyers to shake their earlier testimony.

headline: Efforts to Bring Down Arafat Seem Only to Prop Him Up
abstract: Yasir Arafat re-emerges to claim support among Palestinians despite months of efforts by United States and Israel to sideline him; their threats and epithets count as pluses for him among Palestinians in Gaza and West Bank; many of them see him as lofted back onto center stage by very people who most seek his eclipse--Pres Bush and Prime Min Ariel Sharon; Arafat's current surge of popularity could fizzle out if he is seen to be moving against those who take responsibility for suicide bombings; they are regarded by some Palestinians as their only effective response to Israel's overwhelming military force; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates

headline: People
abstract: Claire Ferguson is named operation director for new British division of DVC Experimental Marketing (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Equipment Maker Posts Loss
abstract: ASML Holding, one of world's largest makers of semiconductor equipment, will eliminate 550 jobs as it announces second-quarter loss that is worse than expected; reports net loss of 64 million euros ($71.6 million) compared with profit of 9.5 million euros in year-ago quarter; sales dropped to 329 million euros from 609 million euros year earlier (S)

headline: Powell Begins Push for Increasing U.N. Security Role in Iraq
abstract: The move came as the White House faced intense pressure to defray the mounting human and financial costs of the occupation.

headline: European Parliament Votes To Limit Software Patents
abstract: European Parliament Vo

headline: Big Board Faces Pressure to Demutualise
abstract: Demutualizing the New York Stock Exchange would end its role as a regulator, a step some members say is needed.

headline: African Nations Press for an End to Cotton Subsidies in the West
abstract: World Trade Orgn's director general Supachai Panitchpakdi says he will intervene to address grievances of four poor African nations whose cotton farmers have been hurt by rich nations' farm subsidies; says there is merit in complaint of leaders of Benin, Mali, Chad and Burkina Faso; in United States, where cotton farmers receive $3 billion a year, vast bulk of cotton is exported; this has prompted accusations from African and South American countries that subsidies amount to unfair trading practice; Europe gives nearly $1 billion in subsidies to cotton farmers, mostly in Greece and Spain (M)

headline: Group to Honor 7 Executives
abstract: American Advertising Federation will induct seven people into its Hall of Achievement, which honors executives in marketing and media who are 40 and younger; inductees are Kathy Delaney (Deutsch), David Droga (Publicis Worldwide), Susan Mboya (Procter & Gamble Co), John Osborn (BBDO North America), Stephen Pasierb (Partnership for a Drug-Free America), Michael Sands (Snapple Beverage Group) and Christopher Schroeder (Washington Post Co) (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Federal Customer Service
abstract: Federal government is creating customer service program to consolidate and disseminate information from all federal agencies; program, called USA Services, seeks to provide responses to all inquiries via World Wide Web (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shipbuilding Dispute
abstract: South Korea, accused by European Union of unfairly subsidizing its shipbuilding industry, reponds by charging that European countries are ones subsidizing shipbuilders; files complaint with World Trade Organization denying that it unfairly subsidized ship builders and accusing European Union members of providing such subsidies; South Korean complaint is based on European Union decision that enables member countries to assist their shipbuilders in face of South Korean competition; South Korean companies, led by Hyundai Heavy Industries, hold global market share of 36 percent, while European shipbuilders account for only 8 percent of sales worldwide (S)

headline: Air Force Lease With Boeing Seen Adding Billions to Cost
abstract: Congressional Budget Office criticizes proposed $20 billion plan by Air Force to lease 100 Boeing 767 air refueling tankers as being far more costly than expected and for failing to meet government rules on operating leases; report concludes leasing deal will cost $5.7 billion more than having Air Force buy planes outright; says plan does not qualify as operating lease and that program's full costs should be reflected in federal budget--something Air Force has wanted to avoid; Air Force had hoped to gain support for tanker program through lease arrangements that would lower initial costs, pushing most of expense into future; Taxpayers for Common Sense vice president Keith Ashdown; photo of Bob Gower of Boeing with House Speaker J Dennis Hastert and Rep Todd Tiahrt at Boeing plant in Wichita (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Car Sales Fall At Hyundai
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co says off-again-on-again strike by workers led to steep drop in sales in July; sold 40,208 vehicles, 42 percent less than year earlier, and shipped 57,732 vehicles to foreign markets, down 40 percent; all Korean carmakers sold 247,339 vehicles in July, down from 276,269 year ago (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.75       Federal funds   1.06   1.03   1.85       3-month Libor   1.16   1.14   1.81       3-month T-bills   0.94   0.92   1.54       6-month T-bills   1.02   0.99   1.47       10-yr.
