headline: For Music Industry, U.S. Is Only the Tip Of a Piracy Iceberg
abstract: Recording industry's problems with illegal online distribution of music in United States pale beside rampant piracy that goes on overseas; in many countries, line between legitimate and pirated music has all but vanished; factories in Taiwan and Eastern Europe churn out counterfeit CD's to teenagers in Scandinavia and Singapore who download songs from Internet and 'burn' them on to blank discs; music executives abroad doubt that American industry's legal campaign against people who share files on Internet would work in their countries, given relative weakness of laws protecting copyrights and ubiquity of activity; industry's biggest hurdle may be cultural; swapping files and burning tracks on CD's are viewed in United States and most other countries as routine, not renegade, behavior; KaZaA, most popular file-sharing software, was dreamed up by Swede and written by three young Estonians; photo (M)

headline: AVERY DENNISON AND BEMIS RECEIVE SUBPOENAS FROM U.S.
abstract: Avery Dennison Corp, world's largest label maker, and competitor Bemis Co receive subpoenas from Justice Department related to investigation of competitive practices in label industry (S)

headline: U.S. Will Ask U.N. for Move to Widen the Force in Iraq
abstract: The Bush administration is preparing a Security Council resolution that would urge other nations to send troops and aid.

headline: Top Orthopedic Implant Maker In Europe Is Down to U.S. Bidder
abstract: Zimmer Holdings emerged today as the top bidder for Centerpulse A.G., Europe's top maker of orthopedic implants, after Smith & Nephew said that it would not raise its bid for Centerpulse.    The announcement by Smith & Nephew of Britain ended a four-month battle over Centerpulse, which is based in Switzerland. In buying Centerpulse, Zimmer, from Indiana, would gain a strong European presence in the fast-growing segment of spinal implants. Its cash and stock bid was valued at 4.2 billion Swiss francs ($3.15 billion).

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Jobless Rate Rises
abstract: Australia's unemployment rate rises to 6.1 percent in June from 6 percent in May, with loss of 27,900 jobs (S)

headline: Arafat's Choice Sets Conditions For Acceptance
abstract: Ahmed Qurei, nominated to be next Palestinian prime minister, says he will not accept post unless Bush administration presses Israel to restrain its military and stop isolating Yasir Arafat; Qurei, an accomplished politician, seems eager to reassure Palestinians of his loyalty to Arafat, who is regarded by Israel as terrorist; his fervently emphasized allegiance underscores standing paradox of Bush administration's policy: it wants whoever becomes prime minister to undermine Arafat, very man from whom he derives authority; Qurei, speaker of Palestinian parliament, would succeed Mahmoud Abbas, who never became popular domestically, in part because he was seen as American and Israeli weapon against Arafat--view that Arafat is said to have encouraged; Abbas was careful to emphasize his loyalty to Arafat and blamed Israel for his failure, but also told Palestinian legislators that Arafat had not backed him; some diplomats expect White House to take more calibrated approach to Qurei than it did to Abbas, if only to avoid stamping him as 'made in America'; photo (M)

headline: A New DVD, Straight From the Camcorder
abstract: The shift away from videotape may pick up speed with the release of three new camcorders from Sony that will record directly to three-inch DVD-R and DVD-RW discs capable of holding up to 60 minutes of video or thousands of still images.      The discs recorded by the three Sony Handycam models, the DCR-DVD100, 200 and 300, are said to be compatible with any DVD player that plays DVD-R discs, including the Sony PlayStation 2.

headline: Quick: What's The Boss Making?
abstract: Ouster of New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso over his big, complex pay package is being felt in corporate boardrooms across America; compensation experts say scandal may cause directors to simplify pay plans for chief executives and will force them to produce more detailed explanations of how plans are constructed; graphs of top executives' pay packages; photos (M)

headline: Rosy Earnings Reports for 3 Big Banks
abstract: Earnings at Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers more than doubled for three months ended Aug 31; Goldman Sachs Group says third-quarter profit rose 30 percent; Morgan Stanley says net income rose to $1.27 billion, up 108 percent from $611 million year earlier; net revenue rose 13 percent, to $5.25 billion from $4.64 billion; chairman-chief executive Philip J Purcell and president-chief operating officer Robert G Scott comment; Lehman Brothers reports net income of $480 million, up 147 percent from $194 million year ago; net revenue rose 74 percent, to $2.35 billion from $1.35 billion; Goldman Sachs' net income rose to $677 million compared with $522 million year earlier; net revenue rose 4 percent, to $3.8 billion from $3.65 billion (M)

headline: New Top General Tells Legislators U.S. Will Probably Need a Larger Army
abstract: Gen Peter J Schoomaker, former Special Operations commander called from retirement to be Army chief of staff, says Army will likely need more troops to meet worldwide commitments; photo at Senate Armed Services Committee confirmation hearing with Lt Gen Bryan D Brown, nominated to head Special Operations Command (M)

headline: Blair Says He Would Have Quit If BBC Iraq Report Had Been True
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair says he would have resigned had there been any truth to BBC report that his government embellished intelligence dossier on Iraq with dubious information; holds that BBC's report went beyond area of permissible dissent to attack his integrity; BBC report claimed that Blair's aides 'sexed up' dossier on Iraqi arms, that they knew claims to be false and forced it into document over objections of intelligence chiefs; Blair makes his remarks testifying at judicial inquiry into death of weapons expert Dr David Kelly, who was identified as source of BBC report and who is thought to have committed suicide shortly thereafter; Blair says BBC has refused to admit error in its report; Gavyn Davies, BBC chairman, testifies at inquiry that network believes it was right to put source's comments into public arena even if his charges were not 'intrinsically true'; photo (M)

headline: Iraqi Leaders to Press Congress For Control Over Rebuilding
abstract: Leaders from Iraqi Governing Council say they will go to Congress to argue that American taxpayers could save billions of dollars on Iraq's reconstruction by granting sovereignty more rapidly to council; Iraqi leaders, discussing their planned end run around American and British occupation authorities, say they plan to tell Congress that Americans are spending two or three times more money to secure themselves than they are spending to secure Iraqi people; council's maneuver to bypass American administrator Paul Bremer seems bound to irritate and embarrass him; Bremer was not told in advance of council's plan to send members to Washington (M)

headline: Armed With Pencils, Army of Census Workers Fans Out Into Afghan Outback
abstract: Census takers from Afghanistan's Central Statistics Office fan out in effort to take nation's first census in 23 years; census is occurring simultaneously with consultations on new constitution; Ghulam Hazrat, controller of project, say no one really knows how many people live in nation, or where they live; his office estimates population of 23 million; map; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 13 article on science underlying new skin care treatments: main ingredient in some products sold by dermatologists is human growth factor, not human growth hormone

headline: Scientist Was the 'Bane of Proliferators'
abstract: Dr David Kelly, British microbiologist who committed suicide while caught up in dispute about whether British government doctored intelligence repors on Iraq's weapons programs, played central role in uncovering Iraq's biological weapons program in 1995; he was Britain's leading specialist in biological weapons, and also played key role in Western efforts to uncover biological warfare programs in former Soviet Union (M)

headline: 3 Iraqis Killed as G.I.'s Set Up Raid in Hunt for Hussein
abstract: A Special Operations team raided a house in what an Iraqi police officer later said was a failed attempt to capture Saddam Hussein.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNITED STATES EXPLORATION INC., Denver, a producer of oil and natural gas, said it had agreed to be acquired by DGL Acquisition Corp., a company formed by Steven D. Durrett for this acquisition, for $53.3 million.    CONOCOPHILLIPS, Houston, said a unit based in Canada had hired Tristone Capital Inc., Calgary, Canada, an investment bank, to help sell three groupings of oil and natural gas properties in Alberta.

headline: A Final Push for the Bedeviled, Beloved Osprey
abstract: US Marine Corps, along with contractors Boeing and Bell Helicopter, are making final push to gain Defense Dept approval of V-22 Osprey hybrid aircraft, half helicopter and half airplane; Osprey has been in development for two decades, at cost of more than $12 billion thus far; craft, which takes off like helicopter and flies like plane, is twice as fast and has five times range of Marines' current helicopters; critics hold that Osprey's design is overly complicated, too expensive and has not been adequately tested; photo (M)

headline: Bush to Defend Iraq War at U.N.; Chirac Urges a Transfer of Power
abstract: Pres Bush, in upcoming speech to United Nations General Assembly, will say he was right to order invasion of Iraq even without UN's explicit approval, and will urge new focus on countering nuclear proliferation as only way to avoid similar confrontations; will acknowledge no mistakes in planning for postwar security and reconstruction in Iraq, although administration officials acknowledge privately that Pentagon was unprepared for scope and duration of continuing guerrilla-style attacks against American-led alliance and newly appointed Iraqi Governing Council; Bush, in his speech, will repeat his call for nations--including those that opposed Iraq action--to contribute to rebuilding country; he will offer no concessions to French demands that major authority for running country be turned over immediately to Iraqis; following speech, Bush is scheduled to hold meetings with leaders of France, Germany, Pakistan, India and Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: Big Merger In Aluminum Is Approved
abstract: Alcan Inc receives

headline: After Tour, Senators Warn U.S. Is Spread Thin in Iraq
abstract: Bipartisan group of nine US senators returns from three-day trip to Iraq, warning that US forces are stretched thin as they face continuing attacks from disparate but increasingly organized guerrillas; senators also say US faces nation-building effort that will take years, cost billions of dollars and require tens of thousands of troops; they differ, at news conference, on whether Pentagon needs more troops now; Republicans play down that issue (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association is adding two categories to its annual Effie Awards competition, which honors effectiveness in advertising. The new categories are for ads aimed at African-American consumers and Hispanic consumers. The two categories will be part of the 2004 awards ceremony, to be held on June 8.

headline: HealthSouth Looks Deeper Into Its Books
abstract: Internal investigation by HealthSouth produces evidence of possible fraudulent accounting; company reported as assets debts it was owed but for which it did not expect to receive payment; revelation raises possibility that Ernst & Young, HealthSouth's accounting firm, may have knowingly participated in the false accounting (M)

headline: REVLON LOSES MONEY FOR THE 19TH CONSECUTIVE QUARTER
abstract: Revlon Inc, cosmetics maker, says second-quarter loss narrowed to $37.8 million; it is 19th straight quarterly loss for Revlon (S)

headline: Annan Is Said to Want New Prosecutor for Rwanda War Crimes
abstract: Secretary Gen Kofi Annan has reportedly decided to recommend that Carla Del Ponte, chief prosecutor for war crimes tribunals for Yugoslavia and Rwanda, be relieved of her Rwanda responsibilities when Security Council votes on renewing her contract; has agreed to wait while Del Ponte lobbies Security Council members for chance to renew contract for both courts; some critics have charged that Rwanda court has taken back seat to Balkan tribunal during her four-year term; United States and Britain said to favor idea of splitting prosecutors' jobs for two courts, while other Council members, including Germany and Spain, are sympathetic to Del Pointe's view that changing proseuctor in Rwanda so late in investigation would seriously undermine court's work (M)

headline: Uneasy Calm in Basra as British Stand Ready for New Unrest
abstract: Some officials said today there could be more unrest if the supply of fuel and electricity does not improve quickly.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB Sales To Go On
abstract: ABB Ltd says it will push ahead with plan to sell units and will not be hindered by agreement to delay its $1.3 billion settlement of asbestos claims (S)

headline: White House Tries to Dismiss Iraq Claim as Campaign Issue
abstract: White House mounts aggressive campaign to contain what several Republicans say is potentially worrisome dispute over Pres Bush's use of suspect information in pressing for war on Iraq; Bush's aides for first time describe chronology that they say mitigated his citation of unsubstantiated British intelligence in his State of Union address that Iraq tried to buy uranium from Africa; Bush personally addresses issue for fourth time in six days, claiming questions about evidence he used do not undercut his overall case for war; his political advisers are pushing back against Democratic presidential contenders who have in recent days acccused him of losing credibility on what has been seen as his strong suit, foreign affairs; photo (M)

headline: Bushs Remarks Draw Skepticism
abstract: President Bushs speech met with a largely skeptical response, laced with some general expressions of approval.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Connecticut; An Interstate Begets a Home Improvement Center
abstract: Lowe's Home Improvement Centers is planning $80 million, 14-million-square-foot distribution center on 200-acre site in Plainfield, Conn, off Interstate 395 to serve its stores in Northeast; map (M)

headline: 'Raymond' Actor Reaches Deal With CBS
abstract: CBS and Brad Garrett, star of network's hit comedy Everybody Loves Raymond, settle their salary dispute; Garrett, who has been boycotting show, will return to work; no salary terms are announced (S)

headline: People
abstract: Michael Haje is named senior partner and director in charge of Diageo account, overseeing brands like Smirnoff vodka, at J Walter Thompson; assumes duties handled by Peter Grossman, who is named global business director on account of Cadbury nonchocolate confections; Harris Brandt is named to new post of vice president and executive creative director at Quinn Fable Advertising (S)

headline: Personal E-Mail at Work
abstract: Howard Ungar letter suggests using Web-based e-mail account at work for greater portability and flexibility to ensure privacy from possible eavesdropping by network administrator (June 26 article)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Banks To Recover Tax
abstract: Tokyo government will probably repay 30 of Japan's largest banks 234.4 billion yen ($2 billion) in taxes collected over two years; banks had been paying less tax because they were declaring losses; 15 of banks successfully sued city (S)

headline: Rates Curb Refinancings
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Association of America's index of mortgage applications dropped 10.7 percent to 736.7 last week, lowest since week ended July 12, 2002, from 824.6; refinancing index fell 14.9 percent to 2,756.8 (S)

headline: Antiterrorism Experts Warn More Attacks May Be Coming
abstract: The bombing in Jakarta fit reports indicating the possibility of more attacks overseas, and possibly inside the U.S.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit Grows At Steel Maker
abstract: Pohang Iron and Steel posts profit of 550 billion won ($471 million) in second quarter, compared with 169 billion won the year earlier (S)

headline: J.P. MORGAN UNIT TO RESUME LEASING CARS IN RHODE ISLAND
abstract: J P Morgan Chase & Co will lease cars again in Rhode Island because governor is scheduled to sign law limiting liability for auto-leasing companies; leases will be offered to dealers and residents whose lease terms do not exceed 39 months through its Chase Manhattan Automotive Finance unit; J P Morgan stopped writing leases in Rhode Island last October after court awarded $28 million against bank (S)

headline: Warnaco Posts Narrower 2nd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Warnaco Group Inc says second-quarter loss narrowed to $8.46 million from $32 million year earlier; sales fell 12 percent, to $335.8 million; company is closing plants in Thomasville, Ga, and Commerce, Calif, and laying off about 430 (S)

headline: Large Gain in Factory Output; Consumer Prices Rise Slightly
abstract: Federal Reserve reports industrial production rose 0.5 percent in July, more than expected and most since January; production of consumer durable goods rose 2.3 percent after increasing 1 percent previous month; proportion of nation's factory capacity in use rose to 74.5 percent from 74.2 percent in June; Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 percent in July, same as in June; graphs (M)

headline: Business People; A Little Magic, A Lot of Music And an Online Coup
abstract: Rob Glaser, the chief executive of RealNetworks Inc., was rummaging through the bins of a used-record store in downtown Seattle last weekend, looking for Rolling Stones music. His company was about to announce that its Internet music service, Rhapsody, would be the first to offer Rolling Stones tunes online, with subscribers permitted to record their music on CD's for 79 cents a song.     Mr. Glaser, 41, knew he would be meeting with the news media on Monday to discuss the deal, and he wanted to cram. While he had the Rolling Stones in his music collection, he was looking for older stuff, like original album covers or 45's. ''I kind of believe in the gestalt of what I'm doing,'' he said.

headline: Statement by the New York Stock Exchange
abstract: Following is the text of a statement released by the New York Stock Exchange after the resignation of Richard A. Grasso, its chairman and chief executive:

headline: Gillette Moves in Court on Schick Razor
abstract: Gillette Co takes more actions to try to pre-empt competition from four-bladed Quattro razor that Schick-Wilkinson Sword plans to introduce in few weeks; Gillette, which on Aug 12 filed patent infringement suit against Schick's parent Energizer Holdings, files motion requesting preliminary injunction against Schick; also announces new television campaign for its Mach3 Turbo razor that stresses Gillette's 'advanced technology' and 57 patents, and that offers money-back guarantee to anyone who concludes that any other razor gives closer shave (S)

headline: Mutal Funds Report; At Last, a Quarter When It's Safe to Look
abstract: THE stock market ended June with its best quarterly gain since the end of 1998, but the historical comparisons for mutual funds were even more impressive.    With the exception of one fund group -- bear funds, which bet that stock prices will fall -- every category tracked by Morningstar Inc. and Lipper posted double-digit gains in the second quarter.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BELGIUM: Accord On Government Near; AZERBAIJAN: Leader Hospitalized; ICELAND: Accusations Of Sex Trafficking; ITALY: Dioxin-Tainted Cattle Seized; RUSSIA: Bomb Toll Rises To 14;.

headline: Farnborough Journal; There's a Bug in My Seat Cushion
abstract: Company called QinetiQ, two-thirds owned by British defense ministry and one-third by American investors, is developing high-tech commercial airliner seat with sensors that cabin staff can read for clues about passengers and their potential threat; heavily guarded plant is former military facility in Farnborough; photos; map (M)

headline: 5 Palestinians and 1 Israeli Are Killed in Overnight Raids
abstract: Israeli troops raided militants in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in the bloodiest day of fighting in more than two weeks.

headline: Correction: Stocks in the News
abstract: The text with a chart last Sunday in Stocks in the News carried incorrect information about the reason for the rise in Igen International's shares the previous week.    Igen International  NNM: IGEN  Roche agreed to aquire Igen International for $1.26 billion, then give nearly the whole company back to Igen's shareholders in exchange for a license to use Igen's amino acid-based technology without paying royalties. Igen will also  receive a working-capital payment from Roche, raising the value of the deal to about $1.4 billion.  CLOSE (JULY 25): $59.25  WEEKS CHANGE: +74.83%  EST. '03 P/E: --

headline: Cargill Challenges Pork Giant With Rival Bid for Farmland Foods
abstract: Cargill Inc bids $385 million to acquire pork processor Farmland Foods, unit of Farmland Inc, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings; bid tops earlier offer of $363.5 million by Smithfield Foods (M)

headline: Tramping Immigrant Byways With a Whisper in Your Ear
abstract: Cellphone walking tour of New York's Lower East Side, developed by Candide Media, can be downloaded from www.talkingstreet.com; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Accounting Rules Approved
abstract: European Commission approves rules that would require all publicly traded companies in European Union to adopt common accounting standards by 2005, though it leaves out regulations that are being revised after opposition from banks; Frits Bolkestein, union's single market commissioner, comments; photo (S)

headline: Coming Soon To a Hand Near You
abstract: Palm-size portable video players, which play compressed files on small screen, are beginning to change how people watch videos and are designed to be less expensive and more convenient than portable DVD players; Archos and Hasbro have both released players; industry experts warn that providing legal content for devices is and will continue to be major obstacle; game company Nintendo is hastening development of players, calculating that they will appeal to young people who are already used to small, relatively low resolution screen; photos (M)

headline: Hollywood Reporter's New Ads Poke Fun at Readers
abstract: Hollywood Reporter, trade newspaper, plans $300,000 advertising campaign, its first in over decade; drive will poke fun at lifestyle of its readers; editor in chief and publisher Robert J Dowling comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: Webdenda
abstract: Budget Living magazine, New York, hired an employee and promoted another. Jacob Hill was named to the new post of senior vice president for business development. He had been group publisher at Advanstar Communications, Boston, part of Advanstar Inc. And Scott Willett , associate publisher, was promoted to executive vice president. Budget Living is published by Budget Living Media. Eric Bruggemann was named an editor at the Blue Rock Editing Company , New York, which handles post-production work for the advertising, music and film industries. He had been editor at the New York office of Final Cut. Draft , Chicago, hired two employees. Michael Davis was named to the new post of vice president and director for emerging media. He had been executive creative director at TVproduction.com, Chicago. And Eric M. Edge was named manager for corporate communications, assuming duties that had been handled by Stacey K. Cohen, who left, the agency said. Mr. Edge had been senior staff representative for the onboard service division at United Airlines, Elk Grove Village, Ill., part of the UAL Corporation. Draft is part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Euro RSCG Worldwide , New York, part of Havas, is continuing a reorganization that began with its American operations in May 2002 by forming divisions of Euro RSCG Partners in Britain, where it combined eight agencies, and the Netherlands, where three agencies are being combined. The reorganization has also been extended to France and Spain, and it is scheduled to be completed by the end of next year. Fallon Worldwide , Minneapolis, promoted three employees. Adrian Ho , group planning director, was named director for account planning, assuming duties that had been handled on a temporary basis by Rob White, president, since Anne Bologna was named president at the Fallon New York office in January. Ullrich Appelbaum and Dan Sutton , group planning directors, were named worldwide planning directors. Mr. Appelbaum continues to work on the account of Nestle Purina, and Mr. Sutton continues to work on the account of Citibank, part of Citigroup. Fallon is part of the Publicis Groupe. The High Museum of Art , Atlanta, named Huey/Paprocki Advertising , Atlanta, as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by the Atlanta office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, largely on a pro-bono basis. Billings were not disclosed. The High Museum is part of the Woodruff Arts Center. Zachary Hastings Hooper , senior account executive at the Rosen Group , New York, was named a vice president. Jack Hough Associates , Norwalk, Conn., merged with the Inergy Group , Wilton, Conn., to form Inergy Group/Jack Hough Associates, based in Wilton. Terms were not disclosed. Independent Public Relations Alliance , Washington, was formed by 60 public relations executives with small practices to encourage cooperation on accounts and business development. Kathryn Kercher was named to the new post of director for marketing for the women's group at Rodale , based in the New York office. She had been managing director for the College Marketing Network at Barnes & Noble, New York. Kiplinger's Personal Finance magazine, Washington, named Richards, McLaughlin & Company , Atlanta and Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., to handle advertising sales in the Southeast, which had been handled by Quenzer International, Duluth, Ga. Kiplinger's is part of the Kiplinger Washington Editors. The NBC Agency , Burbank, Calif., hired two employees. Jodi Flicker was named to the new post of senior marketing director; she had been management supervisor at Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, part of the Publicis Groupe. Sharon Merle-Lieberman was named marketing services director, succeeding Mishel Brownlee, who left. Ms. Merle-Lieberman had been vice president for marketing and product development at GetMusic, New York, part of Vivendi Universal. The NBC Agency, which is responsible for promoting NBC programming, is part of the NBC unit of the General Electric Company. The Neiman Group , Harrisburg, Pa., hired one employee and promoted another. Kimberly Allen was named to the new post of vice president and head of the consumer public relations practice. She had been vice president at the Los Angeles office of Rogers & Cowan, part of the Weber Shandwick unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. And Buffy McCoy Kelly , associate creative director, was promoted to group creative director. John Noble Jr. was named to the new post of senior vice president and director for broadcast production at Element 79 Partners , Chicago, part of the Omnicom Group. Mr. Noble had most recently been senior vice president and director for broadcast production at the Martin Agency, Richmond, Va., part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The Promotion Marketing Association , New York, named new officers for 2003-4. Mickey Jardon , executive vice president and managing director at DVC Co-Marketing, part of DVC Worldwide, was named chairman and chief executive; he had been chairman-elect. Mr. Jardon succeeds William M. Miltenberger, chief executive at USAChefs, who becomes chairman emeritus. Rick Murray , senior director for strategic marketing at the Country Music Association, was named chairman-elect, in line to become chairman for 2004-5. Mr. Murray had been vice chairman. And Sabrina Ironside , vice president for worldwide promotions at the NewsCorp One unit of the News Corporation, was named vice chairwoman and vice president for membership and marketing. Barbara Rosenthal was named senior account executive at the New York office of Cballero TV and Cable Sales . She had worked as a New York consultant to Radio Disney, part of the Walt Disney Company. Jeffrey B. Ross was named associate creative director at Euro RSCG Tatham Partners , Chicago. He had been freelancing and before that had worked at agencies like the San Francisco office of Leagas Delaney and GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group. Euro RSCG Tatham Partners is part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Patricia Santangelo was named account executive at Biography magazine, New York. She had been chief executive at Patricia Santangelo & Associates, New York. Biography is published by A&E Television Networks, a joint venture of the ABC Inc. unit of the Walt Disney Company; NBC, part of the General Electric Company, and the Hearst Corporation. Mark Sitley was named to the new post of executive creative director for production at Euro RSCG MVBMS , New York. Mr. Sitley had been director for production for North America at Fallon Worldwide, Minneapolis, where he worked on BMW Films, the online commercial series produced for the North American division of BMW. Euro RSCG MVBMS is part of Euro RSCG Partners, a unit of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Fallon is part of the Publicis Groupe. Steve Wehrenberg , executive vice president and group management supervisor at Campbell Mithun , Minneapolis, was named to the new post of director for strategic planning and integration. Campbell Mithun is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Fasten Seat Belt. Start Engine. Deflate Ego.
abstract: John Carr, manager of Carr's Driving School in Point Pleasant Beach, NJ, comments on his experiences with various driving students through the years; photo (M) (My Job column)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: No Extradition For Argentines
abstract: Argentine government decides not to seek extradition of 39 former military officers and one civilian charged with variety of human rights crimes committed during military dictatorship (S)

headline: A Protest or Just Time Off; Zahn's Colleagues Wonder
abstract: Paula Zahn's colleagues are still trying to figure out, two weeks after her return to CNN's live programming, what led to her six-week absence; CNN executives and Zahn deny her absence was to protest plans for her show American Evening, interviews; say she wanted break and was unhappy with show, but worked on developing program during break; photo (M)

headline: Face Recognition: Readers React
abstract: Last week in this newsletter, I described a fast, effective ID-card mechanism that a cruise line employs to speed up the boarding process. I wondered if it could be considered a tiny trial of the national security card that's been proposed.

headline: It's Not Exactly a Theater, But PC Viewing Has Its Perks
abstract: Win DVD Platinum 5 by InterVideo is software program designed to enhance watching movies on PC; photo (M)

headline: Mutal Funds Report; Greatest Investing Hits (By the Stock Gurus)
abstract: Edward Wyatt reviews investment how-to book What Do I Do With My Money Now, featuring essays by financial experts including Warren Buffett, Peter Lynch and John Bogle (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Response To U.S. On Military Budget
abstract: China's official press accuses American military analysts of overstating amount China spends on armament and defense (S)

headline: Gadgets to Go: A Little Something for the Road
abstract: Article on various types of electronic gadgets for business traveler to take on road during tiring business trips; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Power Plant Bidding
abstract: Independent board of directors of Drax, London's largest coal plant, will decide whether to accept buyout offer from International Power or Goldman Sachs; International Power offered to buy plant for 130 million pounds ($205 million); Goldman is offering one pence less on pound for debt, but offer does not include 2.5 million per year management fee that International Power plans to charge (S)

headline: Priceline Plans $100 Million Note Sale
abstract: Priceline.com, an Internet seller of discount travel services, plans to raise as much as $100 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fire Cuts Steel Output
abstract: Nippon Steel Corp says fire at its factory in Nagoya, Japan, might reduce company's profit by 42 percent, or 30 billion yen ($255 million); may have to cut crude steel production by 500,000 metric tons because of fire; fire breaks out at third largest of Bridgestone Corp's nine factories in Japan (S)

headline: Two Boys Thrilled by Jobs, and Paychecks
abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column on her two young sons who have their first jobs this summer; says they are developing new perspective on money, and are beginning to appreciate that work can be difficult as well as rewarding; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Is Back, but Is It Here to Stay?
abstract: After glancing at the top-performing technology and Internet funds, investors may be forgiven for wondering if they have somehow gone back to 1999.

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: ARGENTINA: Iranian Sought In Bombing Held In Britain; ARGENTINA: Military Amnesties Repealed;.

headline: Betting the Ranch, a Really Big One
abstract: King Ranch Inc is betting its future on areas unrelated to cattle, from leasing land to quail hunters to lending ranch's name to line of luxurious pickup trucks; challenges facing ranch include claim by descendants of Maj William W Chapman, business partner of Richard King when ranch was formed in 1850's, to 7,500 key acres at ranch's core; another pressing issue is how to keep ranch's large cattle herd relevant in age of skepticism about beef eating; photos (M)

headline: Monitor Sheds Some Buttons In Favor of Savvy Software
abstract: Samsung's new SyncMaster LCD computer monitor is managed solely through mouse clicks with software called Magic Tune; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Militants Strike Kashmir
abstract: Al Mansoorin, Islamic separatist group, claims responsibility for bombing in crowded market in Kashmir town of Bandipore (India); two civilians and one policeman are killed and 39 others are wounded (S)

headline: AIR PRODUCTS TO PURCHASE ASHLAND UNIT FOR $300 MILLION
abstract: Air Prod

headline: BURGER KING TO SELL LOW-FAT CHICKEN SANDWICHES
abstract: Burger King will introduce line of low-fat chicken sandwiches that will sell for $2.89 (S)

headline: Europe Accuses Microsoft of Continuing Antitrust Abuses
abstract: The E.U. accused Microsoft of trying to monopolize markets and gave the company a last chance to defend itself.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Police Used Excessive Force on Israeli Arabs, Panel Says
abstract: An Israeli commission today accused the police of using excessive force three years ago to combat riots that it said had resulted from simmering, overlooked anger.

headline: Failed Magazine May Be Revived
abstract: Oxford American editor Marc Smirnoff resolves to revive magazine only hours after announcing it would suspend publication (S)

headline: Dispute on Iraq Weapons Clouds Blair's Trip to U.S.
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair travels to Washington on Thursday on a mission to underline Britain's relationship with the U.S.

headline: Management Shuffle at Nokia, With Perhaps More on Way
abstract: Nokia announced changes in its top management today, spurring speculation that it may be preparing to change its chief executive.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: ZIMBABWE: Newspaper'S Equipment Seized; NIGERIA: Taylor Warned On Liberia;.

headline: A China Odyssey Sheds Light on a Murky Past, and Hints at the Future
abstract: David W Chen article on return to father's hometown of Chen Dong in Fujian Province, China, for ceremony honoring his grandparents; photo; map; looks back on twenty generations of Chens who are chronicled in local genealogy, and describes lives of relatives today (M)

headline: Oil Company In Norway Under Cloud
abstract: Directors of Statoil, Norway's state-controlled oil company, are weighing fate of company's chief executive Olav Fjell after relevations about $15.5 million consulting contract said to involve Mehdi Hashemi Rafsanjani, son of Iran's former president Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani; Norwegian police are investigating contract, to see if it involved 'illegal influencing of foreign government officials'; Dagens Naeringsliv newspaper says Statoil engaged Horton Investment registered in tax haven of Turks and Caicos to provide advice on gaining oil concessions in Iran; Horton is owned by Abbas Yazdi; younger Rafsanjani is executive in subsidiary of National Iranian Oil Co, which is partner with Statoil in offshore gas filed in Persian Gulf; Rafsanjani denies involvement in consulting deal; newspaper says auditors failed to persude Fjell and Statoil chairman Leif Terje Loeddesoel to cancel contract on ethical grounds (M)

headline: Aetna Profits Are Up 28% As Health Insurers Prosper
abstract: Aetna, health insurer, reports second-quarter net income rose 28 percent, to $138.4 million, up from $108.2 million in 2002 period; operating profits rose to $203.9 million from $91.8 million; chief executive Dr Jack W Rowe comments, interview (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about the new careers of onetime dot-com employees misidentified the business school of the University of North Carolina, where an associate professor, Daniel Cable, described how such workers had to unlearn their old work habits. It is the Kenan-Flagler Business School, not Keenan Flagler.

headline: AOL Seeks a Separation in Name Only
abstract: AOL Internet service is pushing to delete its name from AOL Time Warner two and half years after it imposed AOL name on biggest media company in world; when AOL acquired Time Warner, its executives insisted on putting AOL at front of name; company's chairman Richard D Parsons and chief executive Jon Miller, in written proposal, asked to drop letters AOL, apparently to protect brand from stigma of larger company's problems; biggest obstacle to change may be Stephen M Case, former chief executive of AOL and former chairman of AOL Time Warner who remains company director; Case devised merger, and two executives who worked closely with him say he might view deletion as repudiation of its rationale or erasure of his accomplishment; Miller's petition is likely to succeed; photo (M)

headline: Advisory Panel Endorses More Uses for Stimulant
abstract: Food and Drug Administration advisory panel endorses new uses for Cephalon's stimulant Provigil that keeps people awake with fewer side effects than caffeine or amphetamines; panel says drug, approved only for narcolepsy, can also be used to fight sleepiness in workers who cannot adjust to night shift jobs and in people who do not sleep well because of breathing disorder known as obstructive sleep apnea (M)

headline: TROUBLED UTILITY OWNER HIRES FORMER I.B.M. TREASURER
abstract: Allegheny Energy, Maryland utility owner that said last week that it might need new financing to avert bankruptcy, hires former IBM treasurer Jeffrey D Serkes as chief financial officer (S)

headline: U.S. Presses U.N. Members To Bear More of Iraq Burden
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell, in wake of bombing of United Nations headquarters in Baghdad, seeks to build support for new United Nations Security Council resolution that would lead other nations to contribute more troops and aid to secure and rebuild Iraq; appeal is not rejected out of hand by any Council members, but get wary reception by Germany and Russia and warning by France that sharing burden in Iraq would require sharing authority; photo (M)

headline: Swing Your Partner: A Square Dance of Synonyms and Antonyms
abstract: Visual Thesaurus by Plumb Design generates animated three-dimensional constellation that provides synonyms and antonyms; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BOSNIA: Serbs Open Search For Karadzic; EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT SUPPORTS GAY MARRIAGE; ITALY: A New Definition Of Judges; GERMANY: An Offensive Salute; BRITAIN: Hiker Stripped Of Some Charges;.

headline: Sydney Journal; Where Wombats Roved, and Aborigines Sketched
abstract: Paul S C Tacon, leading Australian anthropologist, describes unusually rare and pristine cache of ancient Aboriginal rock art found in cave in rugged wilderness not far from Sydney; says more than 200 images in giant mural stretch from 4,000 years ago to late 18th century when white settlers first ventured onto Australian soil; cave was discovered by hikers, but Tacon is only expert to have seen it so far; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 2.4% Annual Rate in 2nd Quarter
abstract: The gross domestic product grew at a rate faster than expected as military spending posted its biggest three-month increase since the Korean War.

headline: English Health Official Seeks a Broader Ban on Smoking
abstract: England's chief medical officer today called on the government to legislate a wide-ranging prohibition that would cover restaurants and the country's famously murky-aired pubs.

headline: With the Apples Arriving by E-Mail, Teachers Adapt
abstract: Teachers comfortable with new Internet technology are building Web sites where they display class news and schedules and where students can post examples of their work; some are asking for homework to be submitted electronically; class Weblogs may supplant static sites soon; education experts predict next trend will be rapid proliferation of hand-held devices with foldout keyboards, which will be easier to use, less expensive and easily adaptable to data sharing; photo; sites geared for teachers noted (M)

headline: Bronx Complex on Site Of Former Health Center
abstract: Office complex called Hutchinson Metro Center is nearing completion off Hutchison River Parkway in Pelham Bay section of Bronx, part of it built on site of state mental health facility Bronx Developmental Center; first tenant Visiting Nurse Service of New York has sign 12-year lease and expects to move about 825 employees into offices in mid-August; Mercy College has signed 20-year lease for 130,000 square feet and plans to move in beginning in January; Simone Development Co bought site at auction for $3.7 million from State of New York in May 2001; map; photo (M)

headline: Hewlett Profit For Quarter Falls Below Expectations
abstract: Hewlett-Packard's reports its profit in fiscal third quarter ended July 31 fell short of analysts' predictions; sales also came in below expectations, and would have fallen except for weakness in dollar; projects sales and earnings in current quarter, which ends in October, will probably fall short of Wall Street's estimates; reports profit of $297 million under standard accounting rules, compared with loss of $2.03 billion for year earlier; sales were $17.35 billion, compared with $16.54 billion year ago; says it will reduce its worldwide sales force of 140,000 by 1,300 employees, on top of cuts of 3,500 people it announced during most recent quarter; chief executive Carleton S Fiorina comments; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Date For Cleric's Verdict
abstract: Final verdict in Indonesian treason trial against Muslim cleric Abu Bakar Bashir, suspected Jemaah Islamiyah terrorist organization leader, will be announced in court next Tuesday (S)

headline: U.S. General Optimistic on Liberia Mission
abstract: American Gen Charles F Wald, in upbeat assessment of security situation, says West African-lead peacekeeping mission in Liberia is going well enough that American troops supporting it might soon go home; warns of continued unrest in rebel-controlled areas outside of Monrovia; says efforts to deliver aid are progressing well (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.75       Discount rate   2.00   2.00   N.A.       Federal funds   1.06   1.04   1.72       3-month T-bills   0.91   0.92   1.58       6-month T-bills   1.00   0.99   1.55       10-yr. T-infl.   2.33   2.31   2.65       10-yr. T-note   4.40   4.41   4.29       30-yr. headline: Swedish Foreign Minister Wounded in Knife Attack While Shopping
abstract: Unidentified assailant stabs Swedish Foreign Min Anna Lindh as she shops in store in Stockholm; she is in critical condition after surgery; attack stuns many Swedes and rekindles memories of killing of Prime Min Olof Palme in 1986; an emotional Prime Min Goran Persson says attack on Lindh is attack on Sweden's open society; Lindh has been leading voice in favor of adopting euro, which Sweden will vote on Sept 14 (M)

headline: Man in the News; A Veteran Of Exile Life
abstract: Man in the News profile of Ahmed Ali Sulieman Qurei, also known as Abu Ala, who has been nominated to serve as Palestinian prime minister; he was born in 1937; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer's Lawsuit Restored
abstract: Court of Appeals in London reinstates 2.6 billion British pound ($4.2 billion) negligence suit brought by insurer Equitable Life against its auditor Ernst & Young for failing to warn company about pension liabilities (S)

headline: Searching for a Dial Tone in Africa
abstract: Success of voice-over-Internet telephony is linking sub-Saharan Africa to outside world and could lead to development of region as center of information technology; potential particularly exists in Ghana, where US companies such as Rising Data Solutions are opening call center operations; government-owned telephone companies oppose Internet telephony as a threat to their economies; Ghana government on occasion has shut off lines of those suspected of making or receiving calls via Internet; photos (M)

headline: Sale of Shares Is Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Tax Reform
abstract: World Busin

headline: New Economy; Accusations against MCI open a debate on long-distance access charges, a relic from Ma Bell days.
abstract: Probe of MCI's alleged tactics for avoiding paying network access fees to local phone companies spurs debate over access charges themselves; industry executives, including some at companies accusing MCI of wrongdoing, generally agree that rules MCI allegedly abused are relics of another era, as Americans increasingly turn to newer forms of communication that incur lower access charges, or none at all, for using same local phone company switches and wires; there is little agreement on how or whether to update rules; drawing (M)

headline: VEOLIA TO SELL NORTH AMERICAN WATER OPERATIONS
abstract: Veolia Environnement plans to sell most of its US Filter water operations in North America; unit includes Culligan and Everpure, leading distributors of water filters and bottled water (S)

headline: U.S. Plans More Sea Exercises On Halting Illegal Arms Trade
abstract: Bush administration plans 10 joint military exercises with other nations in coming months to train for interception of shipments to and from nations suspected of having illegal arms programs in effort to make it expensive and hard for Iran and North Korea to transmit components of chemical, biological and nuclear arms, and missiles to deliver them; also edges back from intensive drive to get International Atomic Energy Agency to declare Iran out of compliance with international safeguards on its nuclear programs; Kenneth Brill, American envoy to agency, says US agrees with other nations to give Iran 'last chance to stop its evasions' and come into compliance before Nov; photo (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: TODAYNone.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: U.S. Extends Domain Deal With ICANN
abstract: Commerce Department and Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers agree to extend for three years agreement to shift management of Internet domain name and numbering system to private sector from federal government; department services as steward of critical elements of domain name and number system, while Internet Corp is private sector entity responsible for day-to-day management of system (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    TODAY  None

headline: Profits at Coke Climb 11% And Beat Analysts' Estimate
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says second-quarter profits increased 11 percent, largely on strong sales of is noncarbonated drinks; net income rose to $1.36 billion compared with $1.22 billion year earlier; revenue rose 6 percent, to $5.69 billion, from $5.37 billion in quarter year ago; photo (M)

headline: Look, Up in the Sky! It's Jackie Chan!
abstract: United Airlines will show video starring Jackie Chan on its flights in October to promote pleasures of Hong Kong, Chan's hometown; is offering incentives for Hong Kong flights (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sale Offer Lifted
abstract: Baltimore Technologies, unprofitable British maker of computer security programs, says it will not pursue bids it has received for sale of company; will continue talks to sell some assets (S)

headline: The addition of two British executives helps bolster McCann-Erickson during a shaky time.
abstract: THE revolving door at the McCann-Erickson World Group is, for a change, spinning in a different direction, ushering in highly regarded outsiders rather than brooming out now-derided insiders.    The World Group, seeking to regain its footing after an awful year of financial and operational problems, is hiring two senior managers to join its largest unit, McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Broader NATO Role Hinted
abstract: NATO Secretary General Lord Robertson, on visit to Kabul (Afghanistan) to meet with Afghan defense and interior ministers, suggests expanding NATO's role outside of capital (S)

headline: Sears to Sell Lands' End Goods at All Stores
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co will begin offering itmes from its Land's end unit at all Sears stores starting in August; Sears and New York State reach settlement over accusations by state Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer that Sears overcharged customers for some car-battery sales; Spitzer says Sears assessed fees of more than $5 permitted under law when selling batteries to some consumers who did not turn in used batteries for recycling; Sears agrees to make $105,000 available to consumers for restitution and to pay $10,000 in civil penalties (M)

headline: Business People; Courtroom Couture: Stripes Are Optional, But Lose the Tie
abstract: Dress code appears to be emerging for executives on trial: business casual; photo (S)

headline: Canadian Legislators Narrowly Reject Move Against Gay Unions
abstract: Canadian government wins key victory in its efforts to extend marriage rights to same-sex couples as House of Commons, 137-132, rejects opposition motion reaffirming current federal position that marriage is by definition heterosexual union; close vote means government's bill to make same-sex marriage legal throughout nation may face difficult fight in 2004 (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Passengers Lose Blood Clot Case; SLOVAKIA: Abortion Bill Roils Parliament; GERMANY: SchrÖDer Denies Misleading Voters; GERMANY: Everybody'S Worst Nightmare;.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: House Passes Bill to Block New Media Rule by F.C.C.  The House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed legislation to block a new rule supported by the Bush administration that would permit the nation's largest television networks to grow bigger by owning more stations.    The vote, 400 to 21, sets the stage for a rare confrontation between the Republican-controlled Congress and the White House. There is strong support in the Senate for similar measures, which seek to roll back a decision by the Federal Communications Commission to raise the limit on the number of stations a network can own. [Page A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Airline Layoffs
abstract: Singapore Airlines to layoff 182 pilots and cabin crew members because demand has not recovered enough to fill flights after SARS virus outbreak (S)

headline: Private Sector; Guests Pay a Quarter-Million. Buffett Picks the Restaurant.
abstract: Online auction for private lunch with billionaire investor Warren E Buffett raises $250,100 for Glide Foundation, San Francisco-based charity for homeless; winning bidder is Greenlight Capital Inc founder David Einhorn; Einhorn and up to 10 guests will have lunch with Buffett in May 2004 in New York (S)

headline: AMERICAN EQUITY IS SEEKING $247 MILLION IN OFFERING
abstract: American Equity Investment Life Holding Co plans to raise as much as $247.3 million in initial public offering (S)

headline: Bias for Boys Leads to Sale of Baby Girls in China
abstract: Preference for boys over girls in Yulin, rural backwater of southern China, overwhelms all other impulses, and leads many families to sell baby girls; in March, police found 28 unwanted baby girls on bus being transported for sale like farm animals; all had been purchased by trafficker from same distributor in Yulin, most sold by poor farmers so parents could attempt to have son; family planning limits, which permit second child only if first is girl, contribute to trafficking, and violations bring $3,500 fine; market for babies is wide: some go to to childless city couples, while others are reared to be brides in remote areas; still others are destined for adoption abroad; map; photo (M)

headline: ESTÉE LAUDER SETTLES A LAWSUIT FILED BY CONSUMERS
abstract: Estee Lauder Cos settles class-action lawsuit under industrywide agreement with cosmetics consumers and records fourth-quarter costs for case; $13.5 million expense covers some free products company will give consumers and legal costs for plantiffs; Estee Lauder was among major cosmetics manufacturers and retailers sued in 1998 by some consumers who suspected price fixing; company does not admit any wrongdoing (S)

headline: Finalists Chosen For Jergens Account
abstract: Andrew Jergens Co narrows review for ad account of its personal care brands; brands had been handled by Bozell until it was merged by its parent Interpublic into sibling Lowe & Partners Worldwide (S)

headline: Bush's Comments on Truck Bombing in Baghdad
abstract: President Bush's statement in response to the truck bombing at the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad.

headline: Market Place; Shareholders Win in Effort To Alter Pay
abstract: Siebel Systems, maker of customer service software and company known for giving its management and directors plenty of stock options, agrees to change its executive compensation practices, modify its board and improve its disclosure of executive and director pay; company agrees to changes as part of settlement in lawsuit brought by shareholder Teachers Retirement System of Louisiana; settlement is latest in series of concessions made by large US companies to their increasingly restive shareholders; chief executive Thomas M Siebel comments; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: 2 New Fronts in Heartburn Market Battle
abstract: Novartis says it will soon start selling heartburn drug omeprazole, generic version of Prilosec, even though court has yet to approve sale; aggressive move could open Novartis to huge damages if judge eventually rules that its generic version infringes patents owned by AstraZeneca, which sells Prilosec; Procter & Gamble Co says it will begin selling over-the-counter version of Prilosec on Sept 15, priced about 70 cents per pill, or $22 or so for month's supply (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: PROFIT DECLINED 95% FOR NETWORK ASSOCIATES; PEOPLESOFT SETS FINAL PRICE FOR J. D. EDWARDS;.

headline: People
abstract: Bernhard Glock is named to new post of manager for global media and communication at Procter & Gamble Co; Michelle Edelman is named managing partner and director for account planning at Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, succeeding Sarah Patterson, who resigned; Mark Kristol is named chief operating officer at TNS Media Inte lligence/EntertainmentServices Group; Thom Dean is named president at Imagemark Brand Resources (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: VeriSign Asked To Suspend New Service
abstract: Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, asks VeriSign to suspend voluntarily new service that redirects Web surfers to VeriSign's site when they try to reach unassigned Web addresses (S)

headline: Praise Runs Into Politics at S.E.C.
abstract: Interview with SEC Chmn William H Donaldson, almost six months after he was named to revive agency that was adrift in political storms, plagued by insufficient resources and overwhelmed by corporate filings; he has set about to reshape agency; through skillful diplomacy, he earns cautious support from Democrats and wide praise from Republicans as well as from investor groups and Wall Street institutions; he has lifted morale at agency; Harvey J Goldschmid, Democratic commissioner, asserts SEC is 'in enormously better shape'; Donaldson photo (M)

headline: DYNEGY SAYS IT WILL REPORT A LOSS FOR THE 2ND QUARTER
abstract: Dynegy Inc announces unspecified loss for second quarter and warns that 2003 earnings will not meet earlier expectations (S)

headline: Microsoft's Setback in Patent Case Ripples Through World Wide Web
abstract: Internet software companies and big commercial Web sites are anxious about changes that Microsoft Corp says it will have to make in its Internet browsing software to comply with jury finding that it infringed on work done by Michael Doyle while he was adjunct professor at University of California at San Francisco; technology enables browser to summon programs automatically over Internet and was not only used by Microsoft in its Explorer software, but has also become standard feature in software for coding Web pages, so-called hypertext markup language, that has been ratified by World Wide Web Consortium, leading Web standards organization; all remedies proposed by Microsoft would require some adjustments from companies, but should not affect ordinary PC users significantly (M)

headline: These Days, a Relaxing Vacation Takes Work
abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column says vacations are measure of year, barometer of individual and collective working lives; says years people most need vacation, many feel least able to take them; some fear employers will discover they are dispensable; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Misuse Of Immunity Law Alleged
abstract: Opposition leaders criticize Italian Justice Minister Roberto Castelli for his use of new legislation giving immunity from prosecution to top officials; law brought to close investigation into Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's financial dealings and his corruption trial; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Mayor Re-Elected
abstract: Anibal Ibarra, ally of President Nestor Kirchner, wins second term as mayor of Buenos Aires (Argentina) in runoff election against financier Mauricio Macri; photo (S)

headline: More Weapons-Grade Uranium Found in Iran
abstract: Inspectors for the International Atomic Energy Agency have found traces of highly enriched uranium at an electrical plant on the outskirts of Teheran.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Selling PC'S At Military Base Stores
abstract: Gateway is selling discounted personal computers to US military personnel through base stores under agreement with Army and Air Force Exchange Service (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Solutions Settles F.T.C. Charges
abstract: Federal Trade Commission says Network Solutions unit of VeriSign Inc settled FTC charges of misleading customers of competitors into transferring their registered Internet names to company for fee; unit last year mailed to consumers what look like notices from their current registrars stating that their registrations would expire soon, when that was months or years away in some cases; FTC says Network Solutions offered renewals that actually moved address to company, and those who accepted paid 'significantly higher' fees (S)

headline: Mortar Shell Kills at Least 7 Iraqis Near U.S. Position
abstract: Mortar shell crashes down in Baquba town square, killing at least seven Iraqis; photos; map; US soldier is killed and two injured by grenade in Kirkuk; soldier is killed in Tikrit; Akila al-Hashimi, slain member of Iraqi Governing Council, is bured in Najaf (M)

headline: In Torn Liberian Town, Hospital Itself Is a Fatality
abstract: Hospital built by American missionaries in 1930's in Ganta that once took in patients from all over Libetia's rural northeast lies in ruins; for three months, as government and rebel forces fought over Ganta, hospital was turned into base; it has since been stripped of everything useful; tiny health clinic more than two-hour drive away is now nearest hospital in area; photo; map (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Settles Proxy-Votes Case
abstract: Deutsche Bank's investment advisory unit Deutshe Asset Management agrees to pay $750,000 to settle accusations from Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to disclose conflict of interest as required when it voted its clients' proxies in favor of Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of Compaq Computer in 2002 (M)

headline: Finding (or Honing) the Cutting Edge
abstract: Joyce Cohen Online Shopper column finds online sites for buying and sharpening shears and scissors for haircutting; drawing (M)

headline: COMPETITOR TO VIAGRA RECEIVES F.D.A. APPROVAL
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline and Bayer wins approval from Food and Drug Administration for their Levitra impotence treatment (S)

headline: CHAMPION ENTERPRISES HIRES A NEW CHIEF AS DEBT RISES
abstract: Champion Enterprises Inc., a maker of mobile homes, hired Albert A. Koch, the former chief financial officer of the discount retailer Kmart, to run the company after its first-quarter loss doubled. Mr. Koch will take over as chairman from Walter R. Young and become president and chief executive until Champion Enterprises finds a permanent replacement, the company said. Its shares increased 26 percent yesterday. First-quarter revenue fell 64 percent from a peak in mid-1999 as lenders curtailed credit amid mounting bad loans, prompting Mr. Young in April to predict a full-year loss.

headline: A Recorded Voice, Said to Be Hussein's, Calls for Resistance
abstract: Arab satellite channel Al Jazeera broadcasts part of audiotape with voice claiming to be that of toppled Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein urging Iraqis to resist American and British invaders; tape comes as fighting intensifies further in Iraq and day after Bush administration offered $25 million reward for Hussein's capture; voice exhorts Iraqis to protect fighters attacking American and British forces and avoid cooperating with occupation authorities; American officials say troops killed 11 Iraqis that tried to ambush them on road near Balad; map; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Panama City; City Rests Many Hopes On a Canal
abstract: Travel article on Panama City, Panama, as business destination; photo (M)

headline: The Geography Factor In Nursing Home Bills
abstract: MetLife Mature Market Institute study finds nursing home costs vary widely by location; puts nationwide average at $181 a day, up from $168 in Apr 2002 (S)0

headline: A Speedy Drive That Can Slip Into Your Pocket
abstract: Verbatim Store 'n' Go USB Drive with up to one gigabyte of memory makes short work of data retrieval and is small and travels easily; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Rights For Gay Couples; ITALY: Immunity Law Appealed; FRANCE: Muslim Withdraws Resignation; TURKEY: Reform Vetoed; CZECH REPUBLIC: Official Hired Killer;.

headline: Earnings Increase For Gap, Limited And Foot Locker
abstract: Profit in second quarter increased at Limited Brands, Foot Locker and Gap; Limited Brands says profit rose 22 percent; net income rose to $102 million from $83.2 million year earlier; revenue in period ended Aug 2 increased 5.3 percent, to $2.01 billion; sales at stores open at least year rose 3 percent; Foot Locker says earnings rose 16 percent; net income in quarter ended Aug 2 climbed to $36 million from $31 million year ago; sales increased by 3.5 percent to $1.12 billion from $1.09 billion; Gap's net income surged to $209.3 million from $56.8 million year earlier; sales in quarter ended Aug 2 rose 13 percent, to $3.69 billion (M)

headline: C.I.A. Said to Find Nuclear Advances By North Koreans
abstract: American intelligence officials reportedly now believe North Korea is developing technology to make nuclear warheads small enough to fit atop country's growing arsenal of missiles, potentially putting Japan and US troops there at risk; CIA reports satellites have identified advanced testing site at Youngdoktong; map; US reportedly uses new data to support warnings to Asian nations, especially South Korea and China, that threat is so urgent it requires unified diplomatic response (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Corporate Regulator Named
abstract: Graeme Samuel is named Australia's chief corporate regulator, succeeding Allan Fels; photo (S)

headline: Online Get-Togethers For Linux Newcomers
abstract: Q. About a year ago I bought a computer with Linux Red Hat 7.1 installed. I have looked at several books for Linux users but have found them unhelpful. Is there a way to exchange ideas with other users?    A. Modern versions of Linux have a graphical user interface that makes the operating system seem more like the familiar Macintosh and Windows systems.     Nevertheless, Linux, created in 1991 by the Finnish programmer Linus Torvalds and later improved by a worldwide community of programmers, can still be a bit of a challenge. There are many editions, called distributions, each of which can operate in a slightly different way.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chohung Posts Loss
abstract: Chohung Bank post loss of 419.3 billion won ($353 million) in 2003 first six months, compared with year-earlier profit of 53.9 billion won (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rights For Gay Couples
abstract: British government proposes expanding legal rights for gays and lesbians to allow them same rights as heterosexual married couples (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Food Company To Expand
abstract: San Miguel Corp, one of Asia's largest food-and-beverage companies, will invest $700 million in China and other Asia-Pacific countries; plans to build plants in Cambodia, Malaysia and Thailand and invest more in existing breweries in Australia, China, Indonesia and Vietnam (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Stake In Auto Venture
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp may sell 10 percent of its Indian unit, Toyota Kirloskar Motor, joint venture with Kirloskar Systems Ltd, in 2004; has 99 percent stake in venture and has invested 9 billion rupees ($195 million) in India (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Growth Forecast Cut
abstract: Korea Development Institute reduces its forecast for economic growth this year, to 3.1 percent from previous forecast of 4.2 percent (S)

headline: Europe Is Examining Utility Issues in Italy
abstract: European Commission says it may open inquiry into Italian holdings of Electricite de France, French government-owned power company, after limits are lifted on company's voting rights in Italenergia SpA, which controls Edison SpA; Italian government, which controls Italenergia in partnership with Fiat SpA, limits Electricite de France's voting rights in Italenergia to 2 percent although it owns 18 percent; commission has threatened to take Italy to court on issue (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Auctioning Off the Past to Make a Future in Music
abstract: David J (David Haskins), singer and bassist for bands Bauhaus and Love and Rockets, auctioned personal items on eBay in 1999 to finance his new CD; winning bidders will be listed in CD's liner notes; photo (M)

headline: UNION WILL REVIEW CONTRACT OFFER FROM GOODYEAR
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber gives its biggest union new contract offer after three days of nonstop talks, and union leaders are reviewing proposal (S)

headline: Expat adviser : Maternity leave:U.S. vs. Europe
Canada's Push to Legalize Gay Marriages Draws Bishops' Ire
abstract: Canada's Roman Catholic bishops lead opposition to legalization of same-sex marriages; are unlikely to succeed, but gay marriage could emerge as sleeper issue in 2005 elections (M)

headline: Profit Falls By 9.7% At Toyota
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp, Japan's largest automaker, reports earning 222.6 billion yen ($1.9 billion) from Apr to June, down 9.7 percent from year-earlier period; global sales rose 5.6 percent, to 4.1 trillion yen ($34.2 billion) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Genesis Falls After Deal Fails
abstract: Shares of Genesis Microchip, a maker of chips for flat-panel computer monitors, fell 8.2 percent yesterday after Pixelworks dropped plans to buy the company for $513.5 million. Genesis shares declined 87 cents, to $9.70. The stock had fallen 22 percent since the agreement was announced on March 17. Pixelworks, which also makes chips for flat-panel computer screens, rose 90 cents, or 13.4 percent, to $7.60. The companies did not say in statements on their Web sites yesterday why the deal would not go through. The agreement was in doubt after Genesis, based in Alviso, Calif., said on July 30 that sales for the quarter would be less than forecast. Pixelworks, based in Tualatin, Ore., will pay $5.5 million in expenses to Genesis.

headline: Old Virus Has A New Trick: Mailing Itself In Quantity
abstract: Rogue computer program on Internet known by security companies as SoBig.F spreads rapidly by e-mail messages across computer networks; mail program that virus uses is 'multithreaded,' which allows it to send out many companies at once; iDefense Inc manager Ken Dunham says creator of program appears to have gone step further, using computers that were taken over by previous versions of SoBig virus to mass-mail copies of program, as spammers do; virus experts say infection can be prevented by deleting suspect e-mail messages without clicking on attachments (M)

headline: A Single Father's Reward
abstract: Clorox Co chief executive Gerald E Johnston writes The Boss on being single father of two young sons when he was in his late twenties, coping with baby-sitter disasters while traveling in sales job; photo (M)

headline: Rwanda Is Said to Seek New Prosecutor for War Crimes Court
abstract: Rwandan government, with quiet support of United States, is campaigning to have Carla Del Ponte replaced as chief prosecutor for tribunal dealing with mass killing in Rwanda in 1994; Rwandan government said to be furious that she has been investigating senior civilian and military members of present Tutsi-led government for reported atrocities at time of bloodshed, rather than focusing exclusively on Hutu-led slaughter; US, apparently concerned about stability in that country, is privately pressing Del Ponte to drop those investigations and let Rwandan government itself deal with them, move human rights advocates say would be tantamount to granting immunity; decision about replacing Del Ponte is up to United Nations Security Council (M)

headline: Al Shati Journal; Rising Above, With Sticks, Paper and String
abstract: Palestinian children at Al Shati Refugee Camp fly kites to escape from tensions that grip Gaza Stip; most kite-fliers are boys, but some girls join in; children are serious about their kite-flying, even naming their kites; flimsiness of their kites makes for frequent mishaps, but children are adept at making repairs; photos; map (M)

headline: Japan Detains the Sole Ferry to and From North Korea
abstract: Citing safety violations, Japan detained today the lone ship that ferries passengers between Japan and North Korea.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CHIQUITA BRANDS INTERNATIONAL INC., Cincinnati, said it had sold about two-thirds of its holdings in Chiquita Brands South Pacific, an Australian produce company, for $14 million in cash.    HOME DEPOT INC., Atlanta, said it agreed to buy Installed Products USA, Tampa, Fla., and Installed Products of California Inc., installers of replacement roofs known collectively as IPUSA, for an undisclosed price.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toshiba Strategy
abstract: Toshiba Corp will introduce flat-panel television on global basis, rather than just in Japan, to tap into stronger markets overseas; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Wins First Trial On Ink Cartridges
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co wins first trial of almost three dozen lawsuits accusing it of duping consumers by selling them new printers with cartridges that were only half-full of ink; consumers' lawyer Richard McCune says jury at state court in Hillsborough, NC, finds that consumers typically did not expect cartridge in new printers to be same as replacement cartridges they bought (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Utility Executive Named
abstract: AES

headline: Cadbury Schweppes Chooses McCann
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes.

headline: ABBAS STEPS DOWN, DEALING BIG BLOW TO U.S. PEACE PLAN
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas submits resignation as Palestinian prime minister; many Palestinian politicians and analysts believe Yasir Arafat emerges stronger, while others think he will re-appoint Abbas with more authority to keep peace effort alive; move is disappointment to Bush administration, which pinned hopes for peace process on Abbas and shifting of power away from Arafat; if resignation is accepted, Abbas will serve as head of caretaker government until Arafat appoints successor; Abbas blames Israel, Bush administration and Arafat for undermining government; highlights of tenure cited; Israel attempts to kill Hamas leader Sheik Ahmed Yassin with airstrike in Gaza City; attack leaves 15 people wounded and prompts vows of retaliation from Hamas; map; photos (L)

headline: Profit Climbs 68% at Principal Financial
abstract: Principal Financial Group Inc, seller of 401(k) retirement plans, reports second-quarter net income climbed to $202.2 million, up 68 percent from $120.2 million in 2002 period (S)

headline: U.N. Gives Iraqi Governing Council Qualified Welcome
abstract: UN Security Council extends qualified welcome to new Iraqi Governing Council, greeting three members as informed citizens but not representatives of legitimate government, as they had requested; photo; Sec Gen Kofi Annan sees steptoward restoration of Iraqi sovereignty (S)

headline: G.O.P. Senators Say Money for Iraq Must Be Grant, Not Loan
abstract: Senate Republican leaders prepare for votes on Bush administration's request for $87 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan, forcefully rejecting growing Congressional sentiment to lend, rather than give, $20.3 billion of that to Iraq for its reconstruction; Sen Ted Stevens says Iraq is too economically fragile to bear more debt, and Sen John McCain says such a strategy would make it appear US was only after Iraq's oil riches (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Unemployment Rate Falls, But Job Losses Continue  The economy shed 44,000 jobs in July, the Labor Department reported, though the overall unemployment rate edged down.     The rate fell, to 6.2 percent from 6.4 percent in June, because the number of people looking for jobs declined faster than the number of people holding them. People have been withdrawing from the labor market because of their poor job prospects. [Page A1.]

headline: ASTROPOWER ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS FOR 10% OF WORK FORCE
abstract: AstroPower Inc., the maker of solar-power equipment that was delisted from the Nasdaq stock market in July, said yesterday that it laid off about 55 workers, or 10 percent of its work force, to try to control costs. The company said in a news release that it now employs about 500 people. Last month, AstroPower hired Bridge Associates L.L.C., a turnaround firm, to handle the daily operations and help the company stabilize its finances.

headline: A Chinese Robin Hood Runs Afoul of Beijing
abstract: China's liberal-leaning intellectuals rally to support Sun Dawu, who is in jail awaiting trial on charges of running illegal credit cooperative in Hebei Province and luring millions of dollars in deposits away from state banks; say state finance and trade cartels are draining savings of China's 800 million peasants to support urban development; portray Sun as modern Robin Hood who has showed how to improve life in vast, backward Chinese country; support for Sun is part of broader effort to bring about gradual political change by pressing top leadership in Beijing to apply their sometimes high-profile promises to real solutions; photo; map (M)

headline: Coach Plans 2-for-1 Split
abstract: Coach Inc, large seller of luxury leather goods, plans a 2-for-1 split of its common stock; Coach raises its sales and profit forecasts; shares rise (S)

headline: U.S. aid offer prods Turkey on troops for Iraq
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  There were hints Tuesday that the U.S. decision to seek a broader United Nations mandate in Iraq might be starting to pay off: The Bush administration said it was ready to provide Turkey with up to $8.5 billion in loans, and the acting Iraqi president said he would welcome up to 10,000 peacekeeping troops from Turkey, under certain conditions.

headline: Owners of sport utility vehicles strike back at environmental critics with an ad of their own.
