abstract: Sport Utility Vehicle Owners of America begins running ad in regional editions of USA Today titled 'What Does Jesus (Rivera) Drive?'; ad is intended to increase membership of owner's group and promote its Web site, which offers facts and figures in support of SUV ownership; ad is direct hit at campaign created by 90 religious leaders last year called 'What Would Jesus Drive?'; that campaign maintains that vehicle choice comes with moral obligation and that vehicles like SUV's pollute environment through their emissions and drilling for oil they use; new pro-SUV ad comes as one of religious group's organizers, Rev Jim Ball of Evangelical Environmental Network, follows 11-city tour of Bible Belt with meetings in Washington to promote group's agenda; pro-SUV ad was created by Stratacomm; photo (M)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON SUES RIVAL OVER COMPETING STENT
abstract: Johnson & Johnson sues to block

headline: Shares Decline on Technology Losses; Treasuries Advance
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 4.41 points, to 9,200.05; Nasdaq composite index falls 10.46 points, to 1,720.91; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 1.79 points, to 987.49; 10-year Treasury note jumps 1 4/32, to 94 18/32, to yield 4.31 percent; 30-year Treasury bond rises 1 12/32, to 101 27/32, to yield 5.25 percent; stock price table and graph; key rates table (M)

headline: Mortgage Index Declines
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Sharon and Abbas Meet and Stress Future
abstract: The leaders declared their mutual respect and hopes for peace, while Israeli forces prepared to withdraw from Bethlehem.

headline: Officials Say Shortages Could Cause More Riots in Basra
abstract: British troops remain on edge in wake of riots that have shaken Basra, Iraq, for two days; 21 British soldiers are either stabbed or wounded by thrown bricks or rocks during riots; more unrest is feared if fuel supplies and electric service does not improve quickly; American soldier is killed and two others wounded by homemade bomb north of Baghdad; another soldier is killed and one wounded when their vehicle strikes homemade bomb south of Tikrit; photo; maps (M)

headline: Iraqis' Bitterness Is Called Bigger Threat Than Terror
abstract: Defense Department officials privately say new intelligence assessments warn United States' most formidable foe in Iraq in months ahead may be resentment of ordinary Iraqis increasingly hostile to American military occupation; cite cultural factors that magnify anger over foreign military presence; picture is far different from Bush administration's public stance; national security adviser Condoleezza Rice denies Iraqis are broadly dissatisifed with American troop presence, interview; holds US is making progress in places like Baghdad and Tikrit, where much of resistance is centered; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; 2 Are Out in Shake-Up at Consumer Reports
abstract: Consumer Reports magazine abruptly dismisses Julia Kagan, editorial director, and Eileen Denver, executive editor and associate editorial director; shakeup baffles employees; Consumers Union official Joel Gurin says increasingly important Web presence requires editors with different skills (M)

headline: Hotels Are Tilting Toward Luxury to Lure Convention Business
abstract: Hotels are leaning toward luxury to lure convention business; five-star hotels have been opening or renovating facilities in resort areas like Hawaii, California, south Arizona and elsewhere; more meetings are also being planned on cruise ships; corporate meetings and conventions account for almost $102 billion in annual spending worldwide; photo (M)

headline: Meet the Neighbors, Friend and Foe
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews latest persistent-world games Star Wars Galaxies: An Empire Divided, Planetside, A Tale in the Desert and Toontown; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: War Games Collision; BRITAIN: Fashion Blunder Excavated;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Better Rating Sought
abstract: Hong Kon

headline: Disney and Bruckheimer Close to a New Pact
abstract: Film and television producer Jerry Bruckheimer reportedly is close to extending his contract with Walt Disney Co for added five years; photo (M)

headline: G.E. Enters Exclusive Talks for Control of Vivendi Assets
abstract: If completed, the transaction would create the world's sixth-largest media company.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AK STEEL HOLDING CORP., Middletown, Ohio, the U.S.'s largest supplier of steel for cars and trucks, said it would buy an exhaust tube factory in Columbus, Ind., from ArvinMeritor Inc., Troy, Mich., the world's largest maker of vehicle exhausts. Terms were not disclosed.    MOLINOS RIO DE LA PLATA, Buenos Aires, Argentina's largest food maker, said it had bought ConAgra Argentina from ConAgra Foods Inc., Omaha, for $48 million.

headline: Buy.com Chief Starts Site To Sell Music Downloads
abstract: Scott Blum unveils new Web s

headline: Plenty of Clues In Iraqi Crimes, But Few Trails
abstract: Investigators searching for clues into tremendous bomb that exploded Aug 19 outside United Nations mission in Baghdad recover severed hand, Iraqi license plate and vehicle parts bearing unique identification number from Russian flatbed truck that carried bomb; senior government officials say that even with so much physical evidence, classic crime-solving techniques are running into harsh realities of postwar Iraq, which is almost devoid of police records and motor vehicle registration files, not to mention databases of fingerprints or DNA; bombing at UN compound, as well as other large attacks, have underscored fragility of peace in Iraq and tenacity of resistance to American-led occupation; they also point to futility, to date, of efforts to bring people behind bombings to justice; map (M)

headline: Hyundai and Union End 7-Week Strike
abstract: South Korea's biggest car manufacturer and its union reached an agreement today to end a lengthy strike with executives meeting many of the workers' demands.

headline: Market Place; Viacom Cuts Forecast As Local Advertising Is Slow to Rebound
abstract: Viacom Inc tells investors that its revenue and profit for full year would come in below earlier forecasts because market for local advertising has not recovered strongly as company had expected; president Mel Karmazin comments; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE NETHERLANDS: Phone Shares Sold; GERMANY: Trial In Mannesmann Bonuses;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Airline Cuts Salaries
abstract: Singapore Airlines Ltd,

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ex-Marine To Be Extradited To Britain
abstract: Toby Studabaker, ex-marine from Michigan, will be extradited to Great Britain after his arrest in Frankfurt (Germany) for allegedly abducting 12-year-old British girl he met on internet (S)

headline: Rollovers Led the Rise in Traffic Deaths Last Year
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration statistics show rollovers were leading contributor to increase in number of deaths on nation's roads last year; says total of 42,815 people died in traffic accidents in 2002, most since 1990 and up from 42,196 in 2001; rollovers are particularly deadly type of accident that continues to rise as more Americans buy light trucks, particularly sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, which are more prone to rollovers than passenger cars because they ride higher off ground; auto industry groups have said concerns about rollovers are mitigated by fact they account for only 3 percent of all accidents; industry is developing technologies to try and curb problem (M)

headline: Bomb Blast in Baghdad Kills One and Wounds 26
abstract: A bomb in a pickup truck exploded this morning near the office of the Baghdad police chief, missing him but killing one officer and wounding 26.

headline: Shutting Doors in Syria May Not End Militants' Attacks
abstract: Palestinian leaders claim they have closed headquarters of at least 10 militant groups bent on waging war against Israel; in Syria, two largest militant groups, Hamas and Islamic Jihad, have closed their doors, but it is not apparent that they have ceased activities that prompted American demands in first place; Palestinian leaders say most of senior commanders of groups are still in Syria, or planning to return soon; American officials regard closing of offices in Syria as important test of willingness of Syrian leaders to modify their historic hostility toward Israel; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Oman: Oil Investment
abstract: Petroleum Development Oman, in which Royal Dutch/Shell Group has 34 percent stake, plans to spend $1.5 billion per year in next five years to reverse decline in oil output; plans to pump 730,000 barrel per day after output fell close to 15 percent over last two years (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Man Arrested In Death Of Son's Tennis Rival
abstract: Christophe Fauviau, father of two teenage tennis players, is arrested in Dax (France) after son's opponent is killed in auto accident; traces of antidepressant are found in rival's bloodstream and Fauviau is suspected of of spiking his water bottle before match (S)

headline: U.S. Cutting Loan Guarantees To Oppose Israeli Settlements
abstract: Bush administration, in almost totally symbolic move, cuts loan guarantees to Israel to meet Congressional curbs on financial support to Israeli's continued expansion of settlements in West Bank and Gaza; says it might further limit guarantees to protest Israel's construction of barrier dividing what it considers its land from Palestinian territory; move comes as Israel sells $1.6 billion of bonds on Wall Street, all backed by United States guarantees; is rare but widely expected slap at Israeli policy as US struggles to keep its peace proposal alive; national security adviser Condoleezza Rice says US opposes any move by Israel to exile or kill Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, but that international community must decide how to deal with him as obstacle to peace, interview; says he systematically undermined Mahmoud Abbas, who resigned as Palestinian prime minister (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Hospitals Prepare For SARS
abstract: Hong Kong government panel approves plan to turn 520 public hospital rooms into isolation wards as precautionary measure in event of SARS outbreak this winter (S)

headline: Both Sides See Verizon Talks Inching Toward an Agreement
abstract: Negotiations between Verizon Communications and its two main unions inched forward yesterday, with officials on both sides saying that they expected an agreement in the next few days.    But several union officials warned that although the sides continued to negotiate specific contractual language, things could still fall apart and the 78,000 workers from the two unions could go on strike. A strike would affect 13 states and Washington.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: TV Bond Deal
abstract: Controlling shareholder of Mexico's television network Azteca Holdings reaches exchange agreement with bondholders that will allow company to pay off $150 million bond that falls due July 15 (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CORNING INC., Corning, N.Y., the world's largest maker of fiber optic cable, said it sold most of CIV, its venture capital investment unit, to Scimitar Capital Partners, a private equity firm. Terms were not disclosed.    SPRINT CORP., Overland Park, Kan., the nation's third-largest long-distance telephone company, said it had awarded five-year contracts to International Business Machines Corporation, Armonk, N.Y., and Electronic Data Systems Corp.,Plano, Tex., to manage software and maintain computer systems. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: U.S. Court Rejects Tire Safety Rule, Saying Margin for Error Is Too Great
abstract: A panel of three federal judges rejected a proposed tire safety regulation yesterday, saying it allowed for too much error.    Two Bush administration agencies have disagreed over how to satisfy a Congressional demand to install tire pressure monitoring systems in cars and light trucks.

headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
abstract: Corporate chief executives comment on books they are reading

headline: U.S. Says It Captured Hussein's Suspected Bodyguards
abstract: U.S. troops rounded up several people suspected of belonging to Saddam Hussein's personal security detail.

headline: Nokia Says It Expects Flat Sales Of Handsets
abstract: Nokia, world's largest mobile phone maker, forecasts that its third-quarter profit will come in at high end of its expectations, but that it will earn less on its handset sales; investors seem unimpressed, apparently sensing that Nokia has set low targets that will be easy to meet (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Venture In Picture Phones
abstract: Texas Instruments and Sharp Corp will jointly develop and sell components used in cellphones with cameras to cut down on design and production time (S)

headline: Palestinian Ends Defense in Murder Trial
abstract: Marwan Barghouti, top leader of Palestinian uprising, is on trial for orchestrating killing of 26 Israelis; suggests that Israeli occupation of Gaza and West Bank could lead to Israel's being submerged in 'one state for two peoples,' with Jews and Palestinians living under common rule; his yearlong trial has become focal point for Israelis and Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: Techies By Necessity, Not by Choice
abstract: Many people are becoming more proficient at handling their own technical needs as consumer electronics and computers proliferate but technical support operations fall short of need; as electronic equipment becomes more sophisticated, it generally requires programming before use, forcing people to become their own troubleshooters, albeit reluctantly; photos; drawing (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Support For Budget Limits
abstract: European Union finance ministers defend set of rules intended to ensure sound bookkeeping by governments in euro zone, after French Pres Jacques Chirac calls for them to be temporarily eased; Netherlands' Finance Min Gerrit Zalm says prevailing view among finance ministers is that Stability and Growth Pact signed before use of euro began in 1999 is flexible enough to manage current economic downturn; pact calls for governments to keep their budget deficits below 3 percent of gross domestic product; French Finance Min Francis Mer announces France will exceed limit again next year, third consecutive year; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Inquiry Into Book Merger
abstract: WA

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Bomb Kills 3 In South
abstract: Bombing in Mindanao (Philippines) market kills 3 people and injures 25 others; military blames Moro Islamic Liberation Front, but group denies involvement; map (S)

headline: People
abstract: *McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising names Max Gosling, president, chief executive and representative director at McCann-Erickson Japan, to added post of regional director for Asia-Pacific, succeeding Peter Hamilton, who retires; names Andrew Schirmer managing director of McCann HumanCare, new division; Jim Mack resigns as Frankel, Chicago, chairman; president and chief executive Dick Thomas will assume his duties; Dudnyk Advertising and Public Relations names John A Powers Jr president, succeeding Edward Dudnyk, who continues as chief executive (M)

headline: Economics Can't Solve Everything, Can It?
abstract: Daniel Skst column says federal government should make Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac operate by market rules, without guarantee that federal government will not let them fail; cartoon (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airlines' Ratings Cut
abstract: Moody's Investors Service cuts credit ratings of Japan Airlines Co and All Nippon Airways Co; outlook for two carriers remains negative (S)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: Dept of Defense confirms deaths of three Americans in Iraq (S)

headline: Wide Contrasts In Demeanor Of the Pope
abstract: Pope John Paul II, visiting

headline: Hometown Honors Its Famous Homemaker
abstract: Nutley, NJ, names former resident Martha Stewart to its new Hall of Fame; will also induct Annie Oakley, who lived in Nutley for ten years, and Wakefern Food chairman Thomas Infusino (S)

headline: Pfizer Moves to Stem Canadian Drug Imports
abstract: Just days after the House of Representatives voted to legalize the import of cheap prescription drugs from Canada, Pfizer has moved to squelch the nascent trade at its source.    The company confirmed yesterday that it had sent letters to 50 Canadian pharmacies that it believes are exporting to the United States, telling them that they would have to begin ordering their drugs directly from Pfizer, rather than from wholesalers. If Pfizer decides that the pharmacies are ordering more drugs than they need to meet Canadian demand, it will cut off or curtail shipments to them, the company said.

headline: MediaTalk; Blender Magazine Reviews Its Owners Live Blues Album -- Very Carefully
abstract: Felix Dennis comments on review in Blender, music magazine published by his Dennis Publishing, of live recording documenting blues festival he helped organize and sang at, phone interview; careful review was written by editor in chief Andy Pemberton; photo (M)

headline: Italian Puzzle: The Land That Doesn't Seem to Fit
abstract: Italy's awkward place among Western nations is symbolized by Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi, who has garnered more attention than respect in recent months; past Italian leaders have failed to make a mark on world scene because of their parochialism, but Berlusconi, who wants to change that, illustrates another of Italy's enduring problems: porous, oddly fuzzy boundaries between public and private domain; photo (M)

headline: COURT CUTS BOND FOR PHILIP MORRIS APPEAL
abstract: Illinois Supreme Court cuts to $6.8 billion from $12 billion the bond that Philip Morris USA must post to appeal class-action verdict won by smokers of 'light' cigarettes; will also hear company's challenge of $10.1 billion awarded to smokers in original verdict (S)

headline: British Show Military Muscles In Town Where 6 Were Killed
abstract: British troops take forceful step toward re-establishing control of Iraqi village where six soldiers were killed, swooping in with tanks and helicopters and questioning witnesses in police station where soldiers were gunned down (S)

headline: For the Kitchen, Top-Drawer Touches
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on search for spice drawer inserts; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Moved to Undermine Iraqi Military Before War
abstract: US military, CIA and Iraqi exiles reportedly began broad covert effort inside Iraq at least three months before war to forge alliances with Iraqi military leaders and persuade commanders not to fight, but US war planners elected not to try to enlist these Iraqi military leaders after war to help keep peace, decision some now see as missed opportunity; Gen Sultan Hashem Ahmed al-Tai, Iraqi defense minister, reportedly promised cooperation and gave veiled signal to troops during television appearances during war that they should not fight invading allies; remains No. 27 on 55-member American list of most-wanted Iraqis; among central players in program were Whitley Bruner, former CIA officer working on behalf of Iraqi-American businessman named Saad al-Janabi, Iyad Alawi, now member of Iraq's Governing Council, Muhammad Abdullah Shahwani, former Iraqi general, Abdul Karim Muhammadawi, Shiite Muslim guerrilla leader, and Mishan al-Jubouri, Sunni Muslim who worked with American support from Kurdish region in north Iraq; photos (M)

headline: Iran Confirms Test of Missile That Is Able To Hit Israel
abstract: Foreign Ministry spokesman in Tehran confirms that Iran has successfully conducted final test of midrange missile with range of 806 to 930 miles, meaning it can reach Israel and American troops stationed in Saudi Arabia and Iraq; Iran contends missile relies entirely on Iranian expertise, but it is widely believed that it employs North Korean technology; United States State Dept has imposed penalties on North Korean company and five Chinese companies, saying they sold missile technology to Iran; US says it views Iran's missile program as threat to region and to American interests; diagram (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Minimum Wages Rising
abstract: Argentina's Economy Min Roberto Lavagna announces plan to raise monthly minimum wages to 250 pesos ($90) from 200 pesos ($72) in July and then gradually to 300 pesos ($108) by December; pensioners' allowances will rise to 220 pesos ($80) from 200 pesos (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Pipelines To Be Developed
abstract: CNOOC Ltd, China' No. 3 oil and gas producer, will spend as much as $700 million building pipelines and developing gas fields in South China Sea to supply Macau and southern city of Zhuhai by 2006; Mark Qiu, CNOOC's chief financial officer, comments; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: COLOMBIA: Videotape Shows Hostages; BRAZIL: Police Killings In Rio De Janeiro;.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    TODAY  Factory Orders: June    TOMORROW  None

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Retail Sales: June

headline: Paris Frees Head of Group Opposing Iran
abstract: Appeals court in Paris, France, orders release on bail of Maryam Rajavi, leader of long-established Iranian opposition group People's Mujahedeen; public prosecutor contends that Rajavi and her husband Massoud Rajavi pose threat to public order; order hinders effort by French counterintelligence service to shut down People's Mujahedeen operations in France; Rajavi was arrested June 17 in huge sweep that led to detention of more than 150 members of group, most of whom are released within hours; police also seize more than $8 million in $100 bills; Rajavi and 10 others have been held on suspicion of planning possible terrorist attacks against Iranian targets and individuals in Europe; Mujahedeen has been designated terrorist organization by both American State Dept and European Union (M)

headline: BBC Reporter Testifies in Inquiry of Dead Scientist
abstract: A journalist today stood by his disputed report that suggested a senior Blair aide had exaggerated the threat from Saddam Hussein's weapons systems before the Iraq war.

headline: PRESIDENT DENIES HE OVERSOLD CASE FOR WAR WITH IRAQ
abstract: Pres Bush, in first full-scale news conference in nearly five months, says he did not exaggerate urgency of going to war with Iraq, and says American forces are 'on the hunt' for Saddam Hussein; says he takes 'personal responsibility' for assertion in his State of Union address about Iraq's nuclear weapons program that turned out to be based on questionable intelligence; calls his national security adviser Condoleezza Rice an 'honest, fabulous person' when asked if she should be held responsible for inclusion of disputed assertion; says he remains confident that banned weapons will be found; says he understands need to produce evidence to 'placate the critics and cynics'; says he does not know how close American forces are to capturing Hussein (M)

headline: New Treasury Rule Taxes Some Insurance Policies
abstract: Treasury Department issues new tax rules that sharply reduce appeal of life insurance benefit that corporations have provided to top executives; executives, in some cases, will be required to pay taxes on premiums at significant higher rate; in others they will be required to pay corporation interest on premiums, as if they were loans; should corporation charge interest at below-market rates, executive will be required to pay tax on difference between market rate and actual interest paid; American Council of Life Insurers spokesman Jack Dolan expressed disappointment (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: BiZBash Media grants publishing and trade-show licenses in Florida and Canada (S)

headline: Leasing of Retail Space Shows Signs of Softening
abstract: Studies by Marcus & Millichap and by Reis Inc find retail real estate leasing market, which remained surprisingly stable during economic downturn, may be softening; vacancies are occuring in smaller, older regional malls, which have been losing tenants to larger malls; graphs of rising retail vacancies and rents (M)

headline: Publishing Siblings Will Compete In Bridal Suite; Parent Approves
abstract: Fairchild Publications is expected to announce it will purchase Elegant Bride, quarterly magazine owned by Pace Communications; acquisition would put Fairchild, division of Advance Publications, in competition for wedding advertisers with sibling division Conde Nast Publications, which owns Bride's and Modern Bride magazines; Fairchild Publications' head Mary Berner will inherit Elegant Bride; Bride's and Modern Bride are overseen by Conde Nast's president Steven T Florio; photo (M)

headline: SHAREHOLDERS CANCEL SALE OF MEXICAN RAILROAD
abstract: Shareholders in Grupo TMM, debt-burdened Mexican transportation company, votes to cancel sale of stake in Transportes Ferroviarios Mexicanos, Mexico's largest railroad, to Kansas City Southern Industries, opposing recommendation from TMM's board; TMM agreed in April to take $200 million in cash and $212 million in stock for its 43 percent stake (S)

headline: Israel to Continue Building Security Fence Criticized by Bush
abstract: With President Bush by his side, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today insisted that Israel would keep building a security fence.

headline: Private Sector; They Prefer to Answer to No One
abstract: Profile of Jeff and Rich Sloan, brothers and entrepreneurs, whose latest venture, StartUpNation, is both radio call-in show and consulting concern for people who want to start up their own small businesses; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Self-Immolation Attempt
abstract: New China News Agency reports man from Anhui Province tried to light himself on fire in Tiananmen Square to protest government seizure of his home; he was only slightly injured in attempt (S)

headline: Refugee Plan For Mongolia Adds to Dispute On North Korea
abstract: Mongolia is caught in middle of plan developed by South Korean missionaries and American Congressional staff members who share common vision to create transit camp there for North Korean refugees traveling to new life in United States; alarmed by idea, North Korea sent foreign minister to Mongolia to renew friendship and cooperation treaty; China objects to idea of camp and South Korea does not want to anger North Korea; missionaries were running underground railroad of sorts for North Korean refugees but stopped after China intercepted travelers (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: SHARES OF MULTIMEDIA GAMES SURGE; INTEL INVESTS $450 MILLION IN MICRON TECHNOLOGY; NETWORK SOLUTIONS SETTLES F.T.C. CHARGES;.

headline: DELTA PILOTS' UNION FILES GRIEVANCE OVER FURLOUGHS
abstract: Air Line Pilots Association at Delta Air Lines files grievance against management for putting 250 pilots on furlough in last three months; union spokesman Mike Pinho says that while Delta was forced to make cutbacks because of traffic slump during invasion of Iraq, pilots should be called back because major fighting has ended (S)

headline: Wal-Mart, Aware Its Image Suffers, Studies Repairs
abstract: Wal-Mart is using consultant Fleishman-Hillard, part of Omnicom Group, to analyze its public image and has commissioned radio and television ads to try to reverse criticism from local officials, consumers and others; this is first time that Wal-Mart, known for parsimony in its business practices, has invested in 'reputation research'--using polling techniques, focus groups and phone interviews--and then spent more money to try to repair distressing aspects of what it found; effort indicates concern at Wal-Mart's highest levels about fallout from company's rapid growth and enormous economic influence; with its ascent has come scrutiny of Wal-Mart's penchant for hiring part-time workers as well as its treatment of female employees, subject of pending federal lawsuit, and its resistance to organized labor; photo (M)

headline: After Enron, Bankers Weigh Clients' Motives
abstract: Analysis: Lawyers, bankers and other financial industry participants say standard is emerging that banks and investment houses need to know their customers' intentions and could be responsible for huge sums of money if they do not in wake of unusual settlement between Merrill Lynch & Co and federal prosecutors investigating Enron; Merrill settlement is latest step in lien of actions by regulators, prosecutors and courts that have effectively established new level of liability for bankers and investment houses involved in business known as structured finance, which involves hundreds of billions of dollars (M)

headline: Framework Set For Reduction Of Subsidies
abstract: US and European Union agree on way to reduce subsidies and import duties used to protect their farmers; agriculture subsidies have been chief obstacle in current round of talks at World Trade Organization; delegates from 146 member nations of organization will meet in September in Cancun, Mex, and poorer nations have said that trade talks would be doomed unless developed nations cut back sharply on subsidies; Pascal Lamy, Europe's top trade official, says agreement moves talks 50 percent or 60 percent forward; Allen F Johnson, chief agriculture trade negotiator for office of US trade representative, gives equally cautious welcome to accord; photo (M)

headline: Business People; Lawyer Gets Inside Look At War Crimes Tribunal
abstract: New York lawyer Petal Modeste comments on her recent 6-week stint with International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, doing research, writing prosecution briefs and shadowing prosecutors as they visited genocide sites; her firm, Shearman & Sterling, has sent several other associates to Africa to help in pro bono project it began in 1999 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Arrests Of Ex-Officers Ordered
abstract: Argentine court issues arrest warrants for 46 individuals that were part of military dictatorship from 1976 to 1983, at request of Spanish Judge Baltasar Garzon; Argentine President Nestor Kirchner still needs to sign official decree allowing human rights violators to stand trial abroad; General Jorge Videla and Admiral Emilio Massera are among those indicted (S)

headline: Way Is Clear For Spike TV
abstract: Viacom will soon move forward with plans to rename its TNN cable network Spike TV, now that director Spike Lee has stopped his legal challenge to name change (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BOEING, Chicago, the world's largest maker of aircraft, said it had received orders for five 737's, worth about $203 million, bringing the company's total orders this year to 151.    HOME DEPOT, Atlanta, the world's largest home improvement retailer, raised its quarterly dividend to 7 cents a share from 6 cents and doubled its share buyback program to $1 billion.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA-PAKISTAN BUS SERVICE RESUMES; HONG KONG: Bus Crash Kills 21;.

headline: Strong Earthquake Rocks Northern Japan
abstract: Powerful earthquake shakes northern Japan, causing power failures, setting fire to oil refinery and derailing train; at least 164 people are injured but no deaths are reported; photo; map (M)

headline: PRESIDENT OF KRAFT'S NORTH AMERICAN BUSINESS LEAVES
abstract: Irene B Rosenfeld, president of Kraft Foods' North American business, resigns; company does not plan to fill position (S)

headline: Israelis Sense They've Won
abstract: News analysis of Israeli officials' growing confidence that, after 33 months of violence, they have defeated Palestinian uprising, although some analysts criticize reaction as premature; Fatah leader Samir al-Mashharawi points out that Palestinians who three years ago were discussing how to divide Jerusalem under potential peace agreement are now back to demanding return to partial control of cities that were then under Palestinian control; violence could erupt again at any time, and Palestinians have shown they can inflict tremendous pain, including economic loss; Israel also warns that Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas must act against militants in two or three weeks or peace process will freeze (M)

headline: Ethnic Violence in the Balkans
abstract: Bosnia split from Yugoslavia in 1992 and became embroiled in ethnic war. Following is a brief chronology.

headline: Iranians Mourn for Twins They Had Watched Grow Up
abstract: Today in Iran, people wept as state television announced the 29-year-old twins' deaths.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Dissenter Said To Be Well
abstract: Red Cross officials report they were permitted to meet with Myanmar pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and she was in good health and high spirits, despite her two-month detention; Myanmar military government continues crackdown on pro-democracy movement amid international criticism and recently enacted US sanctions (S)

headline: French Leader Outlines Two-Stage Proposal
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac says France will approve new United Nations resolution only if it recognizes need for immediate transfer of sovereignty in Iraq to Iraqis, int; lays out two-stage plan for Iraqi self-rule, with first stage being symbolic transfer of sovereignty from American hands to existing 25-member Iraqi Governing Council, followed by gradual ceding of real power over period of six to nine months; says France is ready to train Iraqi police officers and soldiers--either in or out of Iraq--if Security Council could agree on empowering Iraqis at once; says France has no intention of sending troops to be part of American-led occupation force, but suggests that circumstances could change; says he does not intend to veto Bush administration's proposed United Nations resolution to attract more foreign troops and international funds to Iraq unless it becomes 'provocative'; but says France will abstain unless resolution includes deadline for transfer of sovereignty and timetable for transfer of power, as well as 'key role' for UN; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Redback Holders To Exchange Debt
abstract: Redback Networks, telecommunications-equipment maker that has lost money each year since it want public in 1999, says group of bondholders has agreed with plan to convert their notes into shares; chief financial officer Tom Cronan says holders of about 67 percent of company's $467.5 million in covertible subordinated notes agree to exchange their debt for common shares; at least 98 percent of notes must be tendered for transaction to be completed; debt holders will own 95 percent of company's common stock; graph (S)

headline: Calls Grow for a Board With Fewer Ties to Wall St.
abstract: Growing number of participants inside and outside securities industry believe New York Stock Exchange's board should have fewer ties to Wall Street firms; Henry M Paulson Jr, who runs Goldman Sachs and serves on exchange's board, is suggesting that brokerage firms like his be dropped altogether from board membership; Securities and Exchange Commission's former chairman David S Ruder says new independent directors, not associated with industry and not chief executive officers of listed companies, should be majority; exchange's interim chairman H Carl McCall says board committee on corporate governance will make its recommendations to full board on Oct 2; chart (M)

headline: India Decides Not to Send Troops to Iraq Now
abstract: India refuses to send peacekeeping troops to Iraq in spite of considerable pressure on Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee to do so by Bush administration; administration was hoping that India would send full army division of 17,000 or more soldiers to serve in Kurdish region around Mosul; war in Iraq is extremely unpopular in India; it was condemned by Indian Parliament as American troops approached Baghdad in early Apr (M)

headline: I.B.M. Expected To Announce Deal With Lego
abstract: Lego, toy company, reportedly plans to replace virtually all of its Hewlett-Packard computer systems by end of year with broad suite of hardware, software and services from IBM; centerpiece of deal is accord that lets Lego pay IBM based on amount of computing power it is using (M)

headline: Mortgage Loans Lift Profit at Wells Fargo
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co says second-quarter profit rose more than 7 percent; net income increased to $1.53 billion from $1.42 billion year earlier; revenue rose 12 percent, to $6.76 billion; FleetBoston Financial says second-quarter net income was $624 million compared to loss of $386 million year ago; revenue rose 4.7 percent, to $2.78 billion (S)

headline: Hong Kong Stirs, and Its Neighbors on the Mainland Take Note
abstract: Chinese officials are concerned that Hong Kong's peaceful and at least partly effective street demonstrations could prod bolder action by mainland China's many discontented groups, especially in adjacent Chinese province of Guangdong; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; If Past Is Prologue, Rally May Start Cooling Down
abstract: History suggests that pace of stock market rally will slow over next six months; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has had 19 rallies of six or more consecutive up months since 1941; average gain over six months was 21.6 percent, slightly above increase of last six months, through Aug 27; Standard & Poor's 500 index rose average of 5 percent, and it has 6 declines in 19 succeeding six-month periodds; while 5 percent gain through February would be disappointing for many investors, it still would be little better than average six-month gain for S&P since 1941, which was 4.3 percent; Dow Jones industrial average has had only 11 period since 1941 in which average rose for six months or more consecutive months; there have been six times when Nasdaq composite index rose for seven or more consecutive months since its inception in 1971; charts (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Rubber Grip Glues a Precious Player to Your Hand
abstract: Toshiba portable DVD player has what it calls sure-grip design preventing users from dropping it; photo (M)

headline: World Bank Says Constitution Must Precede Loans to Iraq
abstract: World Bank's president James D Wolfensohn suggests that bank would lend money for reconstruction of Iraq only after country writes constitution and conducts national elections; says indeterminate number of Iraq's state-owned industries would have to be shut down or restructured; his comments may put pressure on Iraq's new Governing Council to accelerate deliberations about its own leadership and other decisions; council has not yet selected any cabinet officials and has taken little substantial action on other matters; it is expected to take at least year to draft new constitution (M)

headline: Sound, Fury and Cellphone Users and Abusers
abstract: Amtrak's Washington-New York has 'quiet car' on which cellphone use is not allowed, and tempers will fly if rule is violated; Dr Lawrence Schwartz has joined fellow Metro-North passengers to lobby MTA for quiet car, so far, to no avail; other passengers find cellphones indispensable and oppose quiet car segregation; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Broadcaster Has Profit
abstract: British Sky Broadcasting Group says n

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Company Cuts Jobs And Shuts Offices
abstract: Computer Network Technology Corp cuts about 150 jobs after it combines some operations and closes offices; expects to save about $20 million from its cost-cutting; reports second-quarter loss widened to $25.8 million, from $2.1 million year earlier; revenue almost doubled to $96.7 million in period ended July 31, from $48.9 million year earlier (S)

headline: Divorce in South Korea: Striking a New Attitude
abstract: Divorce rate is soaring in South Korea, reflecting social transformation that is shaking country still anchored in Confucian values of family and patriarchy; majority of divorces are initiated by women, who are more educated and more likely to be employed than they were in past and who are no longer placed at disadvantage by divorce laws; personality conflict is reason most often cited for seeking divorce; Love and War, reality television show about troubled marriages and divorce, consistently ranks high in ratings; divorce rate graph; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: IRELAND: Elan Gets Deadline Extension; BRITAIN: Profit Dips At Mine Company;.

headline: Iraq Bombings Pose a Mystery U.S. Must Solve
abstract: American military, intelligence and law enforcement officials are wrestling with several competing theories about who is behind postwar violence in Iraq; thousands of insurgents from Saddam Hussein's former government have organized into cells to resist US-led occupation, but nature of resistance is clouded by presence of freed criminals and foreign fighters, mainly Islamic militants, who have filtered into Iraq from surrounding countries; one document suggests that secular Baathists are joining forces with Islamist radicals, but this is impossible to verify; methods of attacks may suggest involvement by former members of Iraqi military or paramilitary forces; attacks aimed at convoys using roadside explosives may reflect expertise of terrorist organizations based outside Iraq; chart and map of attacks against US-led forces; photo (L)

headline: Islamic Filipino Rebel Dies
abstract: Salamat Hashim, founder of Moro Islamic Liberation Front, movement in Philippines fighting for separate state in south, dies of heart attack on July 13; had sought involvement of United States in group's peace talks with government (S)

headline: ALLIANT ENERGY SELLS HOUSING UNIT TO LOWER DEBT
abstract: Alliant Energy Corp sells its low-income apartment developments in Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin to several buyers and plans to reduce debt by $105 million with proceeds from deal (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 17 article about investing in Intrado

headline: Joseph M. Magliochetti, 61, Chief of Auto Parts Company
abstract: Joseph M Magliochetti, chairman and chief executive of Dana Corp, dies at age 61 (M)

headline: Japan Faces Burden: Its Own Defense
abstract: First article in The New York Times series Can Japan Change? discusses country's debate over becoming what it calls 'normal nation,' armed and able to defend itself after half-century under US-written Constitution that renounces war as tool of diplomacy; discussion includes possibility of acquiring nuclear weapons, sacred taboo since World War II and one with huge impact on region once traumatized by Japanese military; security during long postwar boom rested on US protection and deep pockets that could buy country's way out of problems; China's expanding power is growing concern, but most immediate spur to change is North Korea, which has ballistic missiles and is pursuing nuclear warheads; military analyst Nisohachi Hyodo discusses his four-year plan for nuclear armament; photos; graph (M)

headline: Identity Theft Thriving, And Proving Expensive
abstract: Harris Interactive survey suggests that at least 13 million Ameicans have been victims of identity theft since 2001 alone (S)

headline: Unions May Ask Verizon Customers to Try AT&T
abstract: Labor officials involved in contract talks at Verizon plan to announce campaign to collect names of people who would be willing to switch their service to AT&T, competing provider of local, long-distance and wireless phone services; union officials say that AFL-CIO, which is coordinating effort to appeal to millions of Verizon customers, would not yet urge them to switch phone companies; threat is seen as effort to increase bargaining position of unions representing 78,000 Verizon technicians and operators who have worked without contract for 10 days and also sign that there may be more rancor in talks than had been indicated earlier; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Disappointing Software Profit
abstract: Indian software company Wipro Ltd earned 1.8 billion rupees ($39 million) in quarter ended June 30; sales rose 28 percent, to 11.7 billion rupees ($253 million) (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Weak Bond Auction
abstract: Latest monthly auction of 10-year Japanese government bonds receives poor reception, sign that investors are getting jittery about recent sell-off that has sent yields more than doubling in past three weeks (S)

headline: Microsoft Exceeds Forecast for Sales, But Not for Profit
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports 11 percent gain in revenue in its fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30, surpassing Wall Street's expectations; profits were slightly below analysts' expectations; revenue was $8.07 billion, increase from $7.25 billion year earlier; net income was $1.92 billion, up from $1.53 billion year ago; chief financial officer John Connors comments (M)

headline: CATHAY PACIFIC SAYS FIRST 6 MONTHS SWUNG TO HEFTY LOSS
abstract: Cathay Pacific Airways, the airline based in Hong Kong, yesterday reported a loss of $159 million in the first half of the year, its worst six-month performance ever. In the period last year, Cathay had a profit of $181 million. Revenue was $1.6 billion, down 21 percent from a year earlier. The loss was a result of fears over SARS, which kept travelers from flying to many parts of Asia in the spring. In April, at the height of the SARS scare, Cathay parked 22 aircraft and reduced its schedule by canceling up to half of its regularly scheduled services in May and June. The airline has since restored much of its schedule and now has four planes sidelined , said Mary Jersin-Shammas, a Cathay spokeswoman. Cathay still runs a reduced schedule between Los Angeles and Hong Kong: one nonstop flight a day instead of two.   Edward Wong (NYT)

headline: Anger Over Car Insurance Rates in Canada
abstract: Canada's auto insurers, squeezed by soaring injury claims, falling investment income and slow-moving regulators, are hitting drivers with huge increases in premiums; public outcry has led politicans across country to promise mandatory cuts in premiums and other reforms; insurance executives are wondering whether their industry, already flooded with red ink, will be chief casualty, or whether their long campaign for regulatory change is finally paying off (M)

headline: Farming Is Korean's Life And He Ends It in Despair
abstract: Lee Kyung Hae's suicide outside World Trade Orgn talks seen as heroic act to fellow farmers in South Korea struggling to maintain age-old agrarian tradition in fast-developing country; to keep markets open for its economy, South Korea has made concessions on food imports, and with each concession, life gets little harder for its farmers; Lee had been protesting farm policies for 30 years; photo; map (M)

headline: Berkshire Loses Bid for Secrecy
abstract: Warren E Buffett loses bid for confidentiality from Securities and Exchange Commission, meaning that public may learn more about which stocks Buffett was buying last fall; SEC turned down appeal filed by Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway to keep secret its holdings in two securities (S)

headline: Executive of Firm Under Inquiry Quits as a Big Board Director
abstract: Robert M Murphy, senior executive of LaBranche & Co, one of biggest stock trading firms at New York Stock Exchange, resigns as vice chairman of exchange amid tense standoff over investigation into trading practices (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Trenton; The Changing Face of a State Capital
abstract: Advice for business travelers on places to stay, eat and visit in Trenton, NJ; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP., Portland, Ore., the biggest North American maker of paneling for floors and roofs, agreed to sell 465,000 acres of forest in Texas for $285 million to reduce debt.    AMERICAN CAPITAL STRATEGIES LTD., Bethesda, Md., a buyout firm, said it had invested $23 million in Riddell Sports Group Inc., which makes helmets for the National Football League.

headline: Spanish Builder Bids for Larger Rival
abstract: Spanish construction co ACS offers 2.1 billion euros ($2.4 billion) worth of stock for its larger rival Grupo Dragados; merger will create one of Europe's largest construction and services companies; ACS already owns 33.5 percent of Dragados; it says new group will be called ACS Actividades de Construccion y Services, and that construction business will keep Dragados name; two companies say merged company would be organized in four sectors: construction, urban and logistical services, industrial services and concessions; photo (M)

headline: CABLE MAKER SEEKS TRANSFER TO ITS CREDITORS
abstract: Superior TeleCom Inc, which filed for bankruptcy protection in March, wins court permission to seek creditors' approval of reorganization plan to transfer ownership to senior secured lenders (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the euro on optimism that the economic recovery in the United States will outpace growth in Europe. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1305, down from $1.1374 on Thursday.

headline: CHIQUITA TO SELL ITS STAKE IN CITRUS JOINT VENTURE
abstract: Chiquita Brands International to sell its stake in citrus joint venture Packers of Indian River to partner for undisclosed cash and assumption of debt (S)

headline: A Chip-Based Challenge to a Car's Spinning Camshaft
abstract: Automobile researchers are working on ways of making mechanical valve controls obsolete, allowing for improved fuel efficiency, among other benefits; systems would be controlled electronically and could result in elimination of camshaft; drawing (M)

headline: Some Contingencies, But Lots of Closings
abstract: Most stores closed in areas affected by blackout; many malls in Michigan, Ohio and around New York City remained closed next morning, as did most stores on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue; photos (M)

headline: Fired McCann executive gets back in the game with a newly created senior post at Euro RSCG.
abstract: James R Heekin, fired in February from McCann-Erickson Worldwide Group as chairman-chief executive, will be named president and chief operating officer at Euro RSCG Worldwide; Heekin comments; photo (M)

headline: Explosion of Brazilian Rocket During a Test Kills at Least 16
abstract: At least 16 people are killed and 20 wounded in blast during test of rocket at launching site, Alcantara, used by Brazilian government space agency; blast, major setback to Brazil's space program, caused launching pad platform to collapse, burying technicians preparing rocket for launching next week; map (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Consumer Borrowing -- May

headline: With a Big Victory, Japanese Premier Gains Momentum
abstract: Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi is re-elected leader of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party in decisive victory that could give him renewed momentum to push through political and economic reforms; lawmakers who hope to ride Koizumi's coattails in coming general election revolt against faction leaders to support him; photo (M)

headline: For Agencies, The Blackout Was Well Timed
abstract: Ad agencies, their clients and news media and entertainment companies that depend on them scramble to recover from disruptions they suffered because of Aug 14 blackout and determine just how far viewership fell below guarantees pledged to sponsors; blackout hits at opportune moment such a disaster: before new television season gets under way, when ad agencies are still on their summer-hours work schedules and when several major weekly magazines have double issues on newsstands and do not have to get new issues right into production (M)

headline: Twins Die Trying to Live Two Lives
abstract: Ladan and Laleh Bijani, 29-year-old Iranian twins born joined at the head, die of blood loss within 90 minutes of each other, after team of surgeons at Raffles Hospital in Singapore work for 50 hours to separate their brains; diagram; twins had asked doctors to proceed despite warnings of peril; adoptive father says German doctors told him when girls were two that one would die in surgery, and Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's advised that operation was not permissible under Islam because doctors knew in advance that one twin would die (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Advertising executive Donny Deutsch agrees to finance Open City Films productions for three years; production company is renamed Deutsch Open City (S)

headline: Viacom Cuts Profit Forecast as Ad Sales Remain Sluggish
abstract: Viacom gets about half its revenue from businesses that rely on advertising sales.

headline: Ex-Treasurer of Enron Is Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison
abstract: Ben F. Glisan Jr. is the highest-ranking former Enron executive to admit wrongdoing in the accounting scandal.

headline: Indonesia Ready to Free Itself of I.M.F.
abstract: Indonesia, recovering from 1997 financial crisis, says it will not seek to renew its program with International Monetary Fund when it expires at end of year; appears, despite lingering resentment of IMF, to have resisted calls to reject fund's advice once it stops taking its aid; Min Dorodjatun Kuntjoro-Jakti says Indonesia will accept post-program monitoring while it pays down roughly $10 billion it will still owe fund; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: June Production Rose 7.8%
abstract: South Korea reports industrial outpurt rose 7.8 percent in June from June 2002 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retail Expansion
abstract: KarstadtQuelle, Germany's largest department store operator, plans to double mail-order sales in Eastern Europe in next five years (S)

headline: A Strike by Workers In a College's Backyard
abstract: Mark McKone-Sweet letter on Sept 14 art

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alstom's Sales Fall
abstract: French power and transportation company Alstom says sales in its most recent quarter fell 18 percent, to $4.34 billion euros; sales in Power Turbo-Systems branch were down 50 percent (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: HYPERION TO BUY BRIO SOFTWARE; COMPUTER ASSOCIATES POSTS FIRST PROFIT IN TWO YEARS;.

headline: A Member of Jac's Pack Has Her Own Pack Now
abstract: Kathleen Ligocki, Ford Motor vice president for customer service, is named chief executive at Tower Automotive (S)

headline: California Official Campaigns Again, This Time for Insurance Overhaul
abstract: California insurance commissioner John Garamendi is expected to make third run for governor after receiving wide approval for bringing attention to soaring cost of worker's compensation insurance; Garamendi is advocating standardized medical procedures and fees, use of generic drugs, creation of medical review panel and ombudsman to resolve disputes; photo (M)

headline: The N.F.L. wants to open its season with Super Bowl intensity.
abstract: National Football League will open its season with $35 million promotional campaign NFL Kickoff Live 2003 on Sept 4 in Washington; Britney Spears is serving as face of campaign; Spears will be featured performer in hour-long concert before season-starting game between New York Jets and Washington Redskins; among those scheduled to join her in concert, to be aired on ABC, are Aerosmith, Mary J Blige and Aretha Franklin; photo (M)

headline: Grim News About Iraq
abstract: President Bush prepared the electorate for years of occupation, billions more in expense, and many bad days.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PINNOAK RESOURCES, Pineville, W.Va., which bought two coal mines last month from US Steel, said it would lay off 353 out of the 982 workers at the mines.    BRINK'S CO., Richmond, Va., said it had agreed to sell its natural gas business to First Reserve Corporation, Greenwich, Conn., and its timber business to Forestland Group, Chapel Hill, N.C., for a combined $119 million.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Talks With Rebels To Resume
abstract: Nepal's government negotiator Kamal Thapa announces that third round of peace talks between government and rebels will take place in Nepalgunj (Nepal) (S)

headline: AMETEK BUYS INSTRUMENT MAKER FOR $50 MILLION
abstract: Ametek Inc acquires Chandler Instruments Co for about $50 million to add to its oil and gas equipment business (S)

headline: Arabs View Cease-Fire With Cautious Optimism
abstract: Arab world greets news of Palestinian cease-fire and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza Strip with wary optimism, tempered by long frustration over conflict (M)

headline: Trying for Taste in a $10 Airline Meal
abstract: Article on LSG Sky Chefs, largest worldwide supplier of airplane food and other in-flight supplies, focuses on its food-for-sale program called In-Flight Cafe; US Airways has become first carrier to offer In-Flight Cafe meals in coach seats on most domestic flights of 700 miles or more; lunch or dinner costs $10; breakfast is $7; LSG Sky Chefs' development chef Randal L Shircel comments; drawing (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: S.E.C. Chief Addresses Recent Tension With States  The Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, William H. Donaldson, tried to correct the impression that the S.E.C. was at odds with enforcement actions taken by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. At the same time, he repeated his criticism of charges filed by Oklahoma's attorney general against WorldCom.    Mr. Donaldson, speaking at a conference of state securities regulators, also announced an initiative to promote increased cooperation between state and federal securities regulators. [Page C2.]

headline: DataBank; Markets Show Biggest Declines in Months
abstract: Stock and bond market performance in week of Sept 22-26 noted; graphs; tables (S)/

headline: Golf Club Maker Adds Top-Flite to Its Bag
abstract: Callaway Golf Co to acquire Top-Flite Golf Co for about $125 million; deal is expected to create golfing giant close to $1 billion in revenue; Callaway's chief executive Ronald A Drapeau comments (M)

headline: SHARON TELLS BUSH ISRAEL WON'T HALT ITS FENCE PROJECT
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon meets with Pres Bush at White House and rebuffs pressure to halt construction of Israeli security fence along West Bank, calling on Bush to persuade Palestinians leaders to do more to dismantle terrorist organizations; photos; Bush repeats 'unshakable' commitment to Israel's security and praises Israeli measures to ease tensions but suggests Israel do more to help Palestinian people and urges Sharon to show restraint as two sides weigh difficult next steps (M)

headline: Engineered Drugs Open New Issue Of Regulation As Patents Expire
abstract: Swiss pharmaceutical firm Novartis files application to produce Omnitrop, its generic version of growth hormone somatropin, in Europe; Omnitrop would be first generic version of genetically engineered medicine sold in Europe if approved; until recently, pharmaceutical companies did not believe generic copies of genetically engineered drugs such as Omnitrop were possible, due to complex technological challenges; Novartis's application has prompted pharmaceutical companies in US and Europe to push for legalization of generic genetically engineered drugs (M)

headline: A Bigger Hard Drive Says 'Hold Everything'
abstract: Samsung introduces its first digital video recorder, which has 120-gigabyte hard drive and capacity to store 100 hours of programming; other features noted; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Trade Concessions For Hong Kong; SOUTH KOREA: Bank Cuts Forecast; SOUTH KOREA: Decline In Overdue Debt; THAILAND: Bank Bailout; JAPAN: Carmaker Expects A Loss;.

headline: 4% Rise in Auto Sales in June Fuels Optimism at the Big Three
abstract: Ward's AutoInfoBank reports US auto sales rose 4 percent in June from year earlier, to seasonally adjusted annualized sales rate of 16.4 million cars and trucks; General Motors' sales rose 1.3 percent; sales at Ford Motor Co fell 0.1 percent, while sales at DaimlerChrysler, parent of Chrysler Group, rose 7 percent; domestic industry continues to lose ground to foreign competitors like Toyota, Honda Motor and Nissan Motor despite spending heavily on consumer purchase incentives; Toyota sales rose 10.9 percent, while American Honda sales rose 8.7 percent and Nissan sales were up 21.5 percent; Toyota and Honda report record sales for first half of year, while combined sales for Big Three fell to 60.6 percent of market, down from 62 percent in first half of 2002; charts; photo (M)

headline: Peacekeepers Take Liberia, Foot by Foot
abstract: Government of Liberia and two rebel groups sign accord aimed at ending war by sharing power in interim government; hope is that this accord offers hope for lasting end to killing, unlike past peace agreements that failed; mediator for talks is retired Nigerian Gen Abdulsalami Abubakar; in Monrovia, some life returns to street markets; people who had fled fighting in countryside begin slowly trickling back home; no outsiders have been in great parts of country for years; from those provinces come unconfirmed reports that killings continue; photo (M)

headline: Potholes and Promises Line an Afghan Highway
abstract: Efforts are under way in Afghanistan to improve conditions on road between Kabul and Kandahar, which is choked with trucks creaking and jangling over the ruts and potholes, and jeeps and taxis making their way through clouds of dust; it is perhaps most important highway in country and a key to Afghanistan's future security and unity; it links Tajik-dominated capital, Kabul, to Pashtun city of Kandahar in south, once the city of country's kings and later spiritual home of Taliban; photos; map (L)

headline: Olestra Label Not Required, F.D.A. Says
abstract: Food and Drug Administration announces that foods containing zero-calorie fat substitute Olestra will no longer require special labels; FDA required in 1996 that all foods made with Olestra include label warning of possible digestion problems related to fat-substitute; subsequent research indicates only low incidence of digestion problems related to Olestra (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: ASIAN CURRENCY CONTROLS; SOUTH KOREA: Bank Investment; JAPAN: Nec Credit Downgraded; JAPAN: Cuts At Electronics Maker;.

headline: As China Gallops, Mexico Sees Factory Jobs Slip Away
abstract: Mexico, known for low-wage plants that export goods to United States, is fast being supplanted by China and its hundreds of millions of low-wage workers; job toll is mounting rapidly as more and more plants scale back operations or close; Mexico's $67 billion worth of exports to US in 2003 first half still topped China's, but just barely; Mexico's exports to US were flat in 2002, while China's grew 20 percent; Mexico, lagging in exports from low-skilled, labor-intensive industries, still leads in big-ticket items; Chinese-made products are also flooding Mexico; graphs of US imports and of leading imported products; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Inquest Into Diana's Death
abstract: British officials announce impending formal inquiry into Paris car crash in which Diana, Princess of Wales, and her companion Emad Mohammed al-Fayed were killed; French inquiry into 1997 accident determined their chauffeur Henri Paul, who was also killed, was driving too fast (S)

headline: Bush to Hold Economic Meetings
abstract: Pres Bush is expected to hold meetings at his Crawford, Tex, ranch on Aug 13 with large group of his economic advisers (S)

headline: Accusations Rise From Wine Cellars of Bordeaux
abstract: Hanna Agostini, French representative of Robert Parker, publisher of Wine Advocate, is accused of using newsletter's letterhead for invoices to bill French-Belgian winemakers for helping to develop premium wines and later taking wines she helped develop to Parker for private tasting; acknowledges doing work but asserts that it was separate from her responsibilities with Parker and that invoices are forgeries meant to discredit her and taint Parker's reputation; fraud charge revives long-simmering debate over whether the French should listen to Parker's pronouncements about their wines and reveals unseemly side to Bordeaux's distinguished wine business; Parker has delayed his visit to spring tasting season in Bordeaux; photo; map (M)

headline: Debt Trouble Could Be Piling Up Overseas
abstract: IMF report to warn that some Asian and Latin American governments have loaded up with much more debt than acknowledged (M)

headline: Bush Team Says It's Weighing Intervention in Liberia's Torment
abstract: Bush administration says it is considering intervening to halt fierce fighting in Liberia between rebel groups and government of Charles Taylor (S)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: TODAYNone.

headline: Israel Decides to Release Some Prisoners
abstract: Palestinians are demanding freedom for all Palestinian prisoners, while the Israeli government appears willing to release them by the hundreds, not thousands.

headline: U.S. Commander Confirms Search for 2 Top Targets Is Over
abstract: The deaths represent the elimination of the two most sought-after members of the Baath Party after Saddam Hussein.

headline: A Dot-Com Sing-Along
abstract: Abby Ellin reviews book Karaoke Nation: Or, How I Spent a Year in Search of Glamour, Fulfillment and a Million Dollars by Steve Fishman (S)

headline: With Sun on Roof, More Yen in the Pocket
abstract: Japan becomes world's largest market for solar energy; is almost completely dependent on imported fuel, which makes its prices for electricity among highest in world; in response, Japanese have worked for decade to build up their renewable energy resources, and effort is starting to pay off; Japan now generates half world's solar power, and market there for solar energy is expected to grow fivefold, to about $4 billion by end of decade; comment on success story of neighborhood in Yoshikawa, where about 70 families live in largest collection of solar-powered homes in Japan; photo; charts (L)

headline: MediaTalk; Magazine in Camouflage: Will the Enlisted Man Buy Sex in Fatigues?
abstract: John Brown Publishing and two American investors plan to launch Drill, lifestyle magazine for men who serve in military; editor in chief Lance Gould comments; photo (M)

headline: Cheney Asserts No Responsible Leader Could Have Ignored Danger From Iraq
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney, in rare speech in Washington, offers White House's most forceful rebuttal to growing tide of skepticism about justifications for war in Iraq; argues it would have been 'irresponsible in the extreme' to ignore threat from Saddam Hussein's weapons program; his comments reflect effort to recast Iraq war as part of broader campaign against terror, linkage that administration officials say puts Iraq in better political light for them; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld has made similar comments at recent news conference; Cheney's speech seeks to put administration's critics on defensive, saying safety of Americans was at stake; reads from four sections of recently declassified National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq's weapons programs; that report's conclusions have come under increasing scrutiny; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    TODAY  Consumer Borrowing: July    TOMORROW  None

headline: Tax-Exempt Issues Scheduled for Pricing
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 0.98 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 1.05 percent.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hynix Posts Loss
abstract: Hynix Semiconductor reports net loss of 530 billion South Korean won ($449 million) for second quarter, up from loss of 418 billion won ($354 million) year earlier (S)

headline: Opinions on Economy Are Easy; Proof Is Tough
abstract: Analysis: Bush administration officials are wrangling with Democratic critics over merits of tax cuts; proponents argue that cuts will lead to increased economic growth and new jobs while critics see looming budget deficits and higher interest rates; many economists warn is too early for either side to make any predictions (M)

headline: French, German and British Leaders to Meet on Saturday
abstract: The leaders will hold a summit meeting that seems aimed at working out a position on the American request for help in Iraq.

headline: The U.S. Option: Staying the Course
abstract: News analysis: resignation of Mahmoud Abbas as prime minister of Palestinian Authority has caught Bush administration by surprise, and is dismaying setback for for its 'road map' to peace; official reaction expressing hope that successor could serve as effective partner in peace talks is coded appeal for Palestinians to choose someone who can succeed where Abbas could not in wresting control from Yasir Arafat, quelling violence against Israelies and making it possible for Israel to ease its grip over Gaza and West Bank; but administration has little choice but to watch and hope as Palestinians choose successor; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motorola Posts 2nd-Quarter Net Income
abstract: Motorola Inc reports second-quarter net income of $119 million; sales fell 10 percent (S)

headline: Fast Spreading Worm Attacks Microsoft Windows
abstract: An Internet worm aimed at the Microsoft Windows operating system was rapidly spreading around the world today, infecting home users and company networks alike.

headline: Agencies Selected In 3 Pfizer Accounts
abstract: Pfizer, world's largest pharmaceutical company, awards large consumer advertising assignments to McCann-Erickson, Kaplan Thaler Group and Berlin Cameron/Red Cell (S)

headline: Tenet Discloses S.E.C. Is Investigating Its Medicare Billing
abstract: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation is being investigated by the S.E.C., as well as the Justice Department, for its past Medicare billing and financial disclosures.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: MOROCCO: Separatists To Release Prisoners; ZAMBIA: President Dodges Impeachment;.

headline: HERCULES, MAKER OF SPECIALTY CHEMICALS, HAS PROFIT
abstract: Hercules Inc, specialty chemicals maker, reports second-quarter net income of $32 million, compared with year-earlier loss of $11 million (S)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Chief Of Biggest State Quits; MYANMAR: New Prime Minister; VIETNAM: Sentence Cut;.

headline: Rebels in Nepal End Cease-Fire; Government Puts Army on Alert
abstract: Maoist rebels withdraw from peace talks in Nepal and declare end of their seven-month cease-fire; they signal they might resume talks if government gives in to principal demand, that new assembly be formed to draft constitution and define king's role in Nepal, which is constitutional monarchy; goal of insurgency is to abolish monarchy; observers are divided over whether Maoists are bluffing or serious about resuming hostilities; six-year insurgency has killed more than 7,000 people and paralyzied country's tourist-dependent economy (M)

headline: Business People; She's Not a Surfer, but He Is
abstract: Kathleeï

headline: And Now, the Weather Report for Your Neighborhood
abstract: Some companies, equipped with supercomputers and weather-modeling programs customized to local conditions, hope to carve niche in forecasting business by providing short-term, highly focused predictions covering specific locations; IBM is fine-tuning system called Deep Thunder; researchers produce high-resolution forecasts twice a day for prospective customers and their own analysis as they increase power of simulation models, using data from National Centers for Environmental Prediction; photo (M)

headline: Comcast Studies a Bid for Vivendi Units
abstract: Comcast Corp executives and their advisers meet to consider making offer for entertainment businesses of Vivendi Universal SA; Liberty Media reports preliminary financial results showing its loss in second quarter narrowed to $464 million compared with $3.1 billion year earlier; revenue fell to $500 million from $510 million (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Vote On Libya Delayed
abstract: United Nations Security Council postpones resolution to lift sanctions against Libya for one week so France can complete negotiations regarding compensation from Libya for 1989 bombing of French plane over Niger that killed 170 people (S)

headline: Agriculture Tops W.T.O. Talks in Mexico
abstract: The talks represent the developing world's first chance to bring some balance to a marketplace they see tilted against them.

headline: GEORGIA-PACIFIC MAY SELL LUMBER DISTRIBUTION UNIT
abstract: Georgia-Pacific Corp might sell unit that distributes building products to pay down debt and focus on consumer goods; hires Goldman, Sachs & Co to advise company on options for unit (S)

headline: The Robot Returns, Cleaning Up
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column reviews Roomba Pro and Roomba Pro Elite, robotic vacuum cleaners by iRobot; drawing, photo (M)

headline: Idi Amin, a Brutal Dictator of Uganda, Dies at 80
abstract: Idi Amin's eight year reign of terror in Uganda encompassed widescale killing, torture and dispossession of multitudes and left the country pauperized.

headline: Business People; Keeping a Top Dog Away From the Leash At the Ritz-Carlton
abstract: keeping a top dog away from the leash at the

headline: DaimlerChrysler Is Planning Mercedes Production in China
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG agrees to expand its operations in China to include production of Mercedes C-Class and E-Class cars and large trucks; DaimlerChrysler is struggling to catch up in world's fastest-growing major market for vehicles (M)

headline: R.P.G. Alley
abstract: American convoys delivering supplies to the troops in Iraq are being attacked more frequently than during the war.

headline: Turkey Says U.S. Has Detained Some of Its Soldiers in North Iraq
abstract: Turkey protests in unusually harsh language what it calls detention of 11 Turkish soldiers by American forces in Sulaimaniya, northern Iraq, where there are signs Turks want to play more aggressive role; Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Americans have released some of soldiers; scores incident; Turkish newspaper reports Americans acted on intelligence reports that Turkish commandos were plotting to assassinate Kurdish governor of nearby Kirkuk; Turkish officials deny claim; Min Abdullah Gul phones Sec Colin L Powell; hundreds of Turkish troops have operated in northern Iraq since mid-1990's, mainly to hunt down Kurdish guerrillas (M)

headline: London Journal; Disillusionment Over the Thames
abstract: David Blaine, American magician who has made name for himself with series of odd and well-publicized stunts, entered large plexiglass box that is suspended from crane over Thames River in London on Sept 12, vowing to spend 44 days there with no food and only water to drink; some spectators have expressed awe; others have thrown eggs; photos (M)

headline: Investing; In Technical Analysis, Markets Know Best
abstract: Technical analysis and its emphasis on preeminence of market patterns may help mitigate risks assumed by investors who rely on company fundamentals as main stock-picking tool; technical analysts ignore company-specific data such as revenue and earnings growth and instead concentrate on myriad of buy-sell signals that form distinct patterns on stock charts; graph (M)

headline: Bush Officials See Long Road To Resolution
abstract: Pres Bush holds intensive round of meetings with allies to press for help in Iraq but he wins no immediate offers of aid; senior administration officials say it might take month to negotiate United Nations resolution on Iraq; but they claim that president has won considerable understanding for American point of view that transfer to self-rule should not happen too quickly; on second and final day of Bush's meetings with world leaders attending General Assembly of United Nations, difficulty in negotiating resolution reflects what diplomats say is continuing difference between United States and other countries over Iraq's future government; many countries are sympathetic to view of French, that bombings and insecurity in Iraq stem in large part from deep resentment that American occupation is stirring in Baghdad, and that there should be quick transfer of power; American response to that is that 25-member Iraqi Governing Council, which was handpicked by US, might stir even more resentment among Iraqis who believe it lacks legitimacy; photo (M)

headline: Business; A Path to Helping the Poor, and His Investors
abstract: Interview with Alexandre de Lesseps, international businessman whose great-great-grandfather developed idea for Suez Canal; he believes that only way to solve problems of poverty and terrorism in world today is through investment; as a co-owner of BlueOrchard Finance in Geneva, he is one of leading figures in world of microfinance; microfinanciers and allied institutions typically make loans in amounts of $1,000 or less to poor people in poor countries who are ignored by commercial banks; chart shows BlueOrchard loans to microcredit lending institutions in 20 countries; photo (M)

headline: Brazil Cuts Key Interest Rate In Bid to Revive Its Economy
abstract: Brazil's central bank drops 2.5 percentage points off its overnight interest rate, lowering important lending rate to 22 percent (M)

headline: Europe Is Not a Counterweight
abstract: Washingtons former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright discusses the feud between transatlantic allies, the US governments unilateral action, and the Europeans failings.

headline: Once Mild, Islam Looks Harsher In Indonesia
abstract: Indonesia's moderate strand of Islam is being eroded, some fear at rapid pace; change, long under way but masked during Gen Suharto's authoritarian rule, is response to political and economic leadership that remains corrupt and inordinately selfish; growing strength of militant, anti-Western groups has been accompanied by stricter religious observance by mainstream Muslims; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Force For Liberia Approved
abstract: United Nations Security Council approves deployment of up to 15,000 troops to keep peace and disarm rebels in Liberia; United Nations Mission in Liberia will take control of region on October 1 and relieve West African Forces currently in place (S)

headline: Market Place; A Summer Uptick For the Airlines, But Then What?
