abstract: Airline stocks jump, continuing rally in which some shares have doubled or even tripled in value this year; latest gains are driven by analyst forecasts of even better days ahead; other experts warn that many of industry's fundamental problems--particularly shortage of business travelers--have not gone away, and many airlines face grim autumn; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: U.S. and Canadian Inquiries Into Energy Trader
abstract: Daniel Gordon, former chief energy trader for Merrill Lynch, is being probed on suspicion of embezzling $43 million from Merrill in 2000 by disguising theft as energy trade; Jane Levine, assistant US attorney in Manhattan, in letter to Canadian law enforcement officials, says usual credit check and due diligence procedures in place at Merrill were not followed with respect to Gordon's transactions; Canadian prosecutor Gregg Lepp says officials are alleging Gordon defrauded Merrill of $43 million and laundered money with help from Canadian offshore-banking consultant (M)

headline: Japan's Hakuhodo Expands in U.S.
abstract: McCaffery Ratner Gottlieb & Lane sells 49 percent stake to Hakuhodo, Japanese agency company; will keep its name; Jerry Gottlieb will be chairman and chief executive and William McCaffery president; they will be part of management committee along with Haruhiko Jitsukawa (S)

headline: New fashion statement:'Save Africa' : British designer agitates for AIDs awareness
abstract: LONDON:—  The words were spelled out in rhinestones across the chest of one of the world's sexiest models: "Use a condom" read Naomi Campbell's tank top.

headline: Judge Won't Revive 2 Suits Against Merrill
abstract: Federal Judge Milton Pollack refuses to revive lawsuits by investors who accused Merrill Lynch and its former top technology analyst Henry Blodget of biased research; Pollack ruled on July 1 that investors could not prove direct link between their stock losses and comments by analysts; plaintiffs owned shares in 24/7 Real Media and Interliant (S)

headline: Boston PBS Station Creates Sponsor Unit
abstract: PBS's Boston station WGBH is creating division to seek national corporate sponsorship for programs it produces after disbanding of similar venture with several other public broadcasting stations (S)

headline: Can a thirsty army of car engines help Pennzoil stand out from its competitors?
abstract: Pennzoil, leading brand of motor oil, is abruptly switching advertising pitches, proclaiming to drivers that it is engine, stupid; estimated $30 million campaign for Pennzoil brand, first from its new agency TBWA/Chiat/Day, is focused on needs of car engines that, through special effects in elaborate television commercials, are brought to life as characters with minds of their own; photo (M)

headline: China Angered by Reported Orgy Involving Japanese Tourists
abstract: Police in China say they have detained six people in connection with assertions that hundreds of Japanese tourists hired similar numbers of local prostitutes and staged public display of promiscuity at luxury hotel in city of Zhuhai on sensitive anniversary in Sino-Japanese relations, day that China records as start of Japanese occupation of Manchuria in 1931 (M)

headline: Saintly Spirit Remembered, in a Truly Balkan Way
abstract: Mother Teresa, soon to become Catholic saint, has become center of Balkan tug-of-war between her birthplace of Skopje, now in state of Macedonia, and Albania, nationality she always claimed; Albanians are outraged that copy of statue in Skopje to be donated to Vatican inscribes her as 'Macedonian daughter'; photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: Timothy Copacia is named executive vice president and managing director at Wunderman (S)

headline: U.S. Remains Leader in Global Arms Sales, Report Says
abstract: New Congressional report finds United States maintained its dominance in international arms market last year, especially in sales to developing nations; total worldwide sales for US in 2002 was $13.3 billion, or 45.5 percent of global conventional weapons deals; Russia is second in sales to developing world, with $5 billion, followed by France with $1 billion (M)

headline: Pope Names 31 Cardinals, Future Voters on Succession
abstract: Pope John Paul II announces selection of 31 new cardinals, move that significantly deepens his already profound influence over elite group of Roman Catholic leaders who will choose his successor; announcement comes months earlier than many Vatican officials had expected; some suspect that pope and his closest aides are increasingly worried about his health and want him to seize at least one more chance to mold future of church with estimated one billion followers worldwide; photo; chart (M)

headline: A.C.L.U. Challenges Music Industry in Court
abstract: American Civil Liberties Union, stepping up its role in legal conflict over file sharing, files motion to stop music industry efforts to force Boston College to identify student accused of being large-scale file trader; claims subpoenas go beyond even broad rights digital copyright law gives copyright holders; also challenges law itself because it does not provide for judicial review of subpoena requests or notification of target of probe (M)

headline: Iraqi Political Groups Move to Help Quell Hussein Loyalists
abstract: Iraqi political groups said today that they would join the first postwar interim government later this month.

headline: Hundreds of Afghans Attack Pakistan Embassy in Kabul
abstract: Hundreds of Afghans ransack Pakistan's embassy in Kabul amid tensions over charges that Pakistan allows Taliban fighters to use its territory for attacks on US and Afghan forces in southeastern Afghanistan; photo; Pakistanis say they have posted 70,000 troops along lawless border for first time and have arrested 500 suspected Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters; attack comes after Afghan Pres Hamid Karzai criticizes Pakistan Pres Pervez Musharraf for saying Karzai government has little countrol outside of Kabul (M)

headline: Chinese Economy's Underside: Abuse of Migrants
abstract: Article in series, The World's Sweatshop: Migrant Despair, describes migrant workers as dark underside of China's economic success; says China's 100 million migrant workers work long hours in dangerous jobs for low salaries and no benefits; says they are barred from forming unions and liable to be fired on boss's whim; says they leave family behind in rural areas to live on fringes of urban society with limited access to housing, education, medical care and courts; says they would not come to cities if opportunities did not outweigh dangers; says even official news media offer regular examples of their extreme distress; photos; map (M)

headline: Japanese etiquette : An initiation in cleanliness rites
abstract: TOKYO—  In Japan, cleanliness is not just a personal issue, but a public one. The day I realized this, I was sitting on the Tokyo subway and a man seated across from me leaned over and pointed at my shin.

headline: Comeback Glories Elude Seagram Heir
abstract: Some in media business express sympathy for Edgar Bronfman Jr's final failure of his bid to recapture part of his former business Vivendi Universal and measure of his pride; Bronfman family still holds big stake in Vivendi Universal but Bronfman resigned his seat on board earlier this year to bid for Universal entertainment business; photo (M)

headline: New York and S.E.C. Charge Broker in 'Late Trading' Case
abstract: New York State's attorney general said the charges were the first of several expected in his investigation into the mutual fund industry.

headline: Berlin Journal; Tacky Marxist Edifice to Bow to Hohenzollerns
abstract: Palace of the Republic, built in early 1950's as East Berlin's entertainment showcase, then closed in 1990 after reunification of Germany, is to be razed; it will be replaced by copy of what was there before--palace of Hohenzollerns, rulers of Prussia, that was dynamited by East German government; when plan will be carried out is open question, because city of Berlin is broke and money for demolition and reconstruction is not in coffers; photos (M)

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Endures Rebuke, Despite Putting Law Above Politics
abstract: House vote to derail new media ownership rules is setback for Federal Communications Commission Chmn Michael K Powell; he has failed to used post effectively in this case to build support for policy backed by Pres Bush, approaching issue with subtle legalistic arguments that have not swayed public; Powell defends rule changes, holding they were mandated by Congress and courts; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Bank Suspensions Challenged
abstract: Philippine central bank governor Rafael Buenaventura will appeal his one-year suspension without pay; was suspended by Philippine Court of Appeals for decision to close local commercial bank in 2000 (S)

headline: Private Lynch Pulls Out of Proposed Movie Deal With NBC
abstract: Representatives for Pfc. Jessica Lynch have pulled out of a proposed deal with NBC that would have added her cooperation to a television movie the network is producing.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: CHECHNYA: Groups Decide Against Observers; POLAND: Miners Protest; SWEDEN: Assassination Suspect Identified; BELGIUM: One In 10 Tries Suicide, Survey Finds; GERMANY HEALTH PACKAGE APPROVED; BRITAIN: Serving God And Mammom;.

headline: IMPATH CONSIDERS FILING FOR BANKRUPTCY AMID INQUIRY
abstract: Impath Inc is considering filing for bankruptcy protection and is in default of credit agreement after internal accounting probe; company's shares, which have not traded in almost month, will be delisted from Nasdaq stock market on Aug 27; Impath has received inquiry from Securities and Exchange Commission about its accounting (S)

headline: Japan Moves to Ward Off Potential North Korean Threats
abstract: TOKYO, Aug. 29 — Hours after North Korea reportedly threatened to test a nuclear bomb, Japan's Defense Ministry asked lawmakers here to spend $1 billion a year through 2007 to build an American-designed missile-defense shield to defend the main cities of the Japanese archipelago.

headline: Vatican Says Lawmakers Have Duty to Oppose Gay Marriage
abstract: Catholic politicians were told how to stop the legislative momentum in favor of gay marriages in North America and Europe.

headline: Gas Project In Peru Gets Crucial Loan
abstract: Camisea project to develop Peru's natural gas fields, sharply criticized by environmental advocates, receives significant endorsement when Inter-American Development Bank approves $75 million loan; loan opens door to another $60 million in financing that will help alliance of companies, including Hunt Oil Co of Texas, company that has close ties to Bush administration; development of gas fields is led by Argentina's Pluspetrol; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Branson Plans U.S. Airline
abstract: Sir Richard Branson, founder of Virgin Group, says he plans to introduce airline in US by first half of 2004; says he will confine his voting stock to 25 percent of company, as US regulations dictate; adds new carrier will have low-cost flights; photo (S)

headline: French Health Official Quits Over Heat Wave Deaths
abstract: The withering temperatures of the last several weeks in France claimed its first political victim today.

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: NOKIA TO BUY GAMING ASSETS OF SEGA NETWORK; CROSSWAVE SEEKS PROTECTION FROM CREDITORS; JUDGE APPROVES AT&T WIRELESS SETTLEMENT;.

headline: Netflix Uses Speed to Fend Off Wal-Mart Challenge
abstract: Netflix, which has built profitable, fast-growing business renting DVD's by mail through innovative online service, faces bruising challenge from Wal-Mart Stores, which has recently started competing rental business with nearly same offerings; co-founder and chief executive Reed Hastings comments on Netflix's competitive edge; graphs of subscribers and movie rentals; photos (M)

headline: U.S. AND THE IRAQIS DISCUSS CREATING BIG MILITIA FORCE
abstract: American and Iraqi officials, stung by deadly car bombing, say they are discussing possibility of forming large Iraqi paramilitary force to help improve security in country; Iraqis involved in talks say force could consist of thousands of Iraqis already screened by various political parties for prior affiliations with Saddam Hussein's government; Iraqi officials say such a militia could ultimately take control of Iraqi cities from American soldiers (M)

headline: A Toolbox for Improving Your PC's Performance
abstract: For Windows.

headline: F.T.C. ASKS FOR INFORMATION ON TAKEOVER BID FOR DANA
abstract: Dana Corp and ArvinMeritor ask Federal Trade Commission for more information about ArvinMeritor's hostile $2.2 billion takeover bid for Dana (S)

headline: Analysts See Tension in China Within the Top Leadership
abstract: China analysts say conflict between supporters of Pres Hu Jintao and predecessor Jiang Zemin exposes tensions within top leadership and makes it more difficult for new generation to put its stamp on politics; Jiang, 76, retains enormous political muscle by keeping allies in key posts and staying on as chairman of Central Military Commission; Hu, 60, solidifies his stature with strong handling of SARS epidemic, but has to navigate between liberal intellectuals calling bluntly for political change and Jiang allies, who fear instability and reportedly try to reverse trend toward government openness (M)

headline: Bush and Blair News Conference
abstract: Following is a transcript of a joint news conference yesterday by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

headline: Africans' Burden: West's Farm Subsidies
abstract: Uganda and other African governments have begun battling Western cotton and other crop subsidies that keep world prices low, hurting African farmers; are demanding compensation for their farmers until subsidies are wiped out; other factors hurting Uganda's cotton farmers noted; map; photo (M)

headline: The Most Popular Media Products
abstract: American consumers seem to want simple cellphones. Plus: the most popular television shows, CD's, magazines and software.

headline: Technology Briefing | People: Information Technology Chief Named
abstract: Energy Department's chief information officer Karen S Evans will succeed Mark A Forman, who resigned in early August, as director of e-government programs and information technology at Office of Management and Budget; photo (S)

headline: KEYSPAN REPORTS LOSS AFTER SALE OF CANADIAN ASSETS
abstract: The KeySpan Corporation reported a second-quarter net loss of $5.9 million yesterday, and it cited the costs of selling stakes in Canadian assets. The loss per share was 5 cents after payment of preferred dividends, in contrast to net income of $9.5 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier, KeySpan said. Revenue rose 16 percent, to $1.41 billion. Expenses from selling stakes in the gas processors KeySpan Canada and Taylor NGL were $34.1 million, or 22 cents a share, the company said. KeySpan, which is based in New York, used $120 million from the sales to pay debt. KeySpan sells gas to about 2.5 million customers in cities including New York and Boston.

headline: TIAA-CREF Places Account in Review
abstract: TIAA-CREF Places Account in Review TIAA-CREF, the financial services company that sells mutual funds, has placed its account in review. The account has been handled for more than 15 years by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

headline: Turkish Soldiers Released by U.S.
abstract: Eleven Turkish soldiers return to their base in northern Iraq after their release by American soldiers, ending bitter diplomatic quarrel between Turkey and US: American officials say they acted on intelligence that suggestd Turks were involved in plot to assassinate American-backed Iraqi official belonging to Kurdish ethnic group (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Japans Hakuhodo.

headline: Bush Chooses U.S. Executive For AIDS Job
abstract: Pres Bush nominates Randall Tobias to run $15 billion program to fight AIDS worldwide; he is major donor to Bush and Republican Party, and former chairman and chief executive of Eli Lilly & Co; has little experience with AIDS issues or with Africa, where most of program's money will be directed, but Bush hails him as person with ability to manage complex organizations and navigate government bureaucracies; if confirmed by Senate, Tobias will have rank of ambassador and will report directly to Secretary of State Colin L Powell, who has said he regards AIDS as pre-eminent crisis facing world today (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Mortgage Rates Rise
abstract: Singapore's United Overseas Bank, DBS Group Holdings and Oversea-Chinese Banking lift rates they will charge for home loans to about 3 percent; United Overseas had been offering borrowers no interest for first year of mortgage, but will now charge 1.5 percent (S)

headline: Ex-President Said to Urge Complex Deals
abstract: Baker Botts report for Freddie Mac's board holds former company president David W Glenn contributed to corporate culture that prized steady earnings growth at buyer of home mortgages and authorized erroneous accounting techniques to achieve goal; finds Glenn, ex-chief executive Leland C Brendsel and various chief financial officers over some 10 years encouraged use of complex, capital-market transactions and, to lesser extent, reserve adjustments, to achieve strong, steady earnings growth; says top executives approved such transactions even though they knew internal accountants lacked skill and resources to assure activities complied with accounting rules (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Delay In Grocer Bidding
abstract: British government pushes back release of report weighing bidders for Safeway grocery chain after unnamed bidder asks for another meeting with regulators; report will be released on Aug 18; grocers Tesco, J Sainsbury and Asda, which is part of Wal-Mart Stores, expressed interest in Safeway and it agreed to deal in January with William Morrison Supermarkets (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Interest Rate Cut
abstract: Bank of Korea cuts its basic interest rate to 3.75 percent from 4 percent; Asst Finance Min Kim Young Ju says economy is in recession; photo (S)

headline: LOCKHEED SELLS ITS REMAINING STAKE IN LORAL SPACE
abstract: Lockheed Martin, which bought stake in Loral Space and Communications for $344 million seven years ago, sells its remaining holding in Loral for less than $750,000 (S)

headline: Wolfowitz Stands Fast Amid the Antiwarriors
abstract: Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz gives 90-minute interview at New School University about Iraq; plunges into bastion of antiwar liberalism--Greenwich Village--to voice vigorous defense of Bush administration's policy; alternately chides audience for not giving administration enough credit for toppling Saddam Hussein's brutal government, and takes pains to explain rationale for war and costly, difficult future in rebuilding Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Personal E-Mail at Work
abstract: Nelson Marans letter contends people should maintain separate e-mail addresses for home and work and says using work e-mail for personal use is infringement on company time (June 26 article)

headline: IZOD PLANS 155 STORES IN CHINA
abstract: Izod, sportswear brand owned by Phillips-Van Heusen, announces deal with China's Hempel International Group to open 155 stores in China over next five years; licensing deal also covers Hong Kong and Taiwan (S)

headline: After Heat Wave, Europe Gives Nuclear Power a Second Look
abstract: Europe's nuclear industry is trying to rehabilitate its reputation and attract new investment after pushing its power plants to limit during summer heat wave; no new reactors have been built in Western Europe since 1986 and several countries have declared themselves forever nuclear-free, including Italy, which shut plants it had already built; industry has survived only because countries like Germany and France are already too heavily dependent on nuclear energy to scrap it (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Phone Acquisition
abstract: Vodafone Group will

headline: Italy Loses Ruling on Modified Food
abstract: European Court of Justice rules that Italy's grounds for banning foods derived from certain genetically altered corn seeds are unjustified; was asked to intervene by Italian court, which was handling appeal of ban on foods containing four strains of genetically modified corn that had been submitted by biotechnology companies Monsanto, Syngenta and Pioneer Hi-Bred International shortly after ban was introduced in 2000; Italian government imposed ban because it feared that presence of synthetic protein in foods might be risk to human health (M)

headline: High Costs Bring Indian Motorcycle to a Halt
abstract: Indian Motorcycle Co will halt production in its factory in Gilroy, Calif, and lay off about 380 workers, virtually entire staff; will keep skeleton crew of workers to sustain basic operations; company is controlled by Audax Group; photo (M)

headline: RUMSFELD SEEKING TO BOLSTER FORCE WITHOUT NEW G.I.'S
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld will order sweeping review of Pentagon in effort to increase nation's combat power without hiring more troops; review will include everything from wartime mobilization and peacekeeping commitments, to reservist training and incentives for extended duty; will be seen in some circles as response to powerful members of Congress who have demanded more active-duty troops for military; Rumsfeld has said he would seek additional troops if required, but only if case is proved through detailed analysis (M)

headline: Argentina Reaches Deal On 3-Year Aid Package
abstract: Argentina reaches three-year aid package from International Monetary Fund without having to make any major concessions on points it considers crucial to help revive its moribund economy one day after defaulting on $3 billion debt payment to fund; Pres Nestor Kirchner says Argentina and IMF agreed on three-year deal to roll over about $12.5 billion of multilateral debt, opening way for country to renegotiate about $90 billion of privately held debt it defaulted on in January 2002 (M)

headline: In a Christian-Muslim Dispute, Israel Blocks a New Mosque
abstract: Israel, caught in dispute between Christians and Muslims, orders demolition of mosque being built next to Roman Catholic Basilica of the Annunciation in Nazareth; photo; long-running feud has drawn sharp criticism from Vatican, which objects to new mosque (S)

headline: No SARS Link Seen in 2nd Vancouver Case
abstract: Canadian health official says patients at second nursing home in Vancouver area do not appear to have SARS-like illness that affected another nearby nursing home (S)

headline: Retailers in the Lead as Fed's Decision Spurs a Rally
abstract: Stocks rise after Federal Reserve says lowest interest rates in 45 years are helping economy; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 9.76 points, or 1 percent, to 990.35; Dow Jones industrial average gains 92.71 points, or 1 percent, to 9,310.06; Nasdaq composite index advances 25.50 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,687.01; US Treasury notes decline; price of 10-year note falls 21/32, to 98 16/32; yield rises to 4.43 percent from 4.36 percent; 30-year bond loses 1 3/32, to 100 11/32; yield rises to 5.35 percent from 5.27 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Suez Is Expected to Sell Off Its Water Treatment Division
abstract: French utility Suez is expected to announce it is selling Ondeo Nalco, its water treatment and environmental service business, to alliance of private equity investors for about $4 billion; Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, Blackstone Group and Apollo Management are expected to buy unit, with each buyer taking equal share (M)

headline: Geneticists Report Finding Central Asian Link to Levites
abstract: Geneticists studying ancestry of Jewish communities finds unusual genetic signature that occurs in more than half of Levites of Ashkenazi, or European, descent; signature on Y chromosome apparently originated in Central Asia, traces perhaps to one man who lived about 1,000 years ago, and may come from Khazars, Turkic tribe whose king converted to Judaism in eighth or ninth century; DNA variation is common in region north of Georgia that was Khazar kingdom; map; work of Drs Michael Hammer and Karl SKorecki explained (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Another Delay In Milosevic Trial
abstract: Slobodan Milosevic war crimes trial is postponed for two weeks because of his continuing health problems (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Reliance Profit Rises; SOUTH KOREA: Sk Telecom Income Gains; JAPAN: Nissan Sales Grow; JAPAN: Bigger Loss For Airline;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Partnership Talks
abstract: German printing equipment maker Heidelberger Druck enters into partnership talks with US-based Goss Graphic Systems aimed at strengthening its position in North America and increasing earnings at its newspaper printing division (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Appeals Court Blocks Easing of Media Rules  A federal appeals court issued a surprise order blocking the Federal Communications Commission from imposing rules that would make it easier for the largest media conglomerates to grow bigger by moving into new markets and areas of business.    The decision came a day before the new rules were scheduled to go into effect, preventing media companies from moving forward with plans to take advantage of the rules. It was a setback for the commission's chairman, Michael K. Powell. [Page A1.]

headline: In Bush's Words: 'Advance of Democratic Institutions in Iraq Is Setting an Example'
abstract: Text of Pres Bush's speech to United Nations General Assembly

headline: CATALINA MARKETING DELAYS REPORTING RESULTS
abstract: Catalina Marketing Corp says auditor Ernst & Young resigned and it has delayed filing earnings reports; also says previously filed financial results are not reliable (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Dabhol Claims
abstract: Bechtel Corp and General Electric Co file arbitration claims of about $600 million each against Indian government to recover investments in Dabhol power plant; companies hold 10 percent each in $2.9 billion Dabhol Power; Enron Corp holds 65 percent and government-run power utility owns rest; plant ran into trouble in June 2001 and stopped generating power when utility run by government of Maharashtra, which was trying to buy plant, defaulted (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Some Creditors of SK Global Object to Bankruptcy Plan  The foreign creditors of SK Global, the troubled trading arm of the SK Group, denounced a proposal by Korean creditors to ask a court to place the company under receivership.    The position of the foreign creditors reflected deep differences between Korean and foreign interests over how to deal with companies that are mired in debt and on the brink of failure. SK Global's debts total about $8 billion, including about $6 billion owed to Korean creditors and the rest to foreigners. [Page C2.]

headline: Gateway's Chief Insists the PC Yield To a Digital Future
abstract: Gateway founder-chief executive Ted Waitt plans to revive company by offering consumer broad range of entertainment products designed to work together; Gateway's new pilot store in San Diego is first of 192 Gateway retail stores to have face lift, with goal of transforming underused outlets from bland showrooms into touch-feely retail boutiques; photo (M)

headline: MCDONALD'S REPORTS 9.9% INCREASE IN U.S. SALES
abstract: McDonald's says that sales in United States rose 9.9 percent in July, driven by demand for new salads and McGriddle breakfast sandwiches (S)

headline: Detecting Signs of Life In Japan's Economy
abstract: Interview with Stephen Mitchell of J P Morgan Fleming Asset Management on prospects for recovery in Japanese economy and stock market; photo (M)

headline: G.E. Proposes A Way to Ease Finnish Deal
abstract: General Electric Co, in bid to secure European regulatory approval of its $2.3 billion acquisition of Finnish medical devices maker Instrumentarium, offers to sell Spacelabs, recently acquired unit of Finnish company; Spacelabs, unit that makes machines used for emergency care and anesthesia, was bought by Instrumentarium year ago (M)

headline: France Télécom Makes Bid For Rest of Shares in Orange
abstract: France Telecom, which has been struggling to bolster its flagging finances, will issue stock to raise fresh capital that it will use to acquire 13.7 percent stake of cellphne provider Orange that it does not own; deal is worth as much as $7.7 billion; France Telecom chief executive Thierry Breton comments; photo (M)

headline: Verizon and WB Join for Promotion
abstract: Verizon Wireless is introducing its largest promotion with television network to date, teaming with WB to encourage customers to use text messaging in campaign that also includes commercials and product placements; multimillion-dollar promotion is centered on third-season premiere of WB series Smallville, which is scheduled for Oct 1 (M)

headline: 3 Leaders' Views on Iraq, Not Quite Unified
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany, Pres Jacques Chiraq of France and Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain meet in Berlin in effort to reach common position on American draft of Security Council resolution authorizing countries to contribute money and troops in rebuilding of Iraq, but they appear to make no progress; agree that sovereignty should be transferred to Iraqi civilian authority as soon as possible and that UN should have key role in that process; Pres Vladimir Putin of Russia echoes their views; photo (M)

headline: Saudis Trying To Drum Up Investment In Gas Fields
abstract: Saudi Arabia plans three-day sales pitch to dozens of companies, London, to revive foreign interest in its natural gas fields; presenters, including Min Ali al-Naimi, seek investors for $25 billion in gas exploration projects after breakdown of two years of talks with major oil companies; nation plans to break up foreign investment needed into smaller, more specific contracts that can be farmed out to specialists for each development step; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP., El Segundo, Calif., a maker of semiconductors, said that it had $721 million on its balance sheet and that it would use its cash for acquisitions.    LABONE INC., Lenexa, Kan., a conductor of tests for insurance companies and drug screening for employers, said it would acquire an insurance-testing laboratory in Elmsford, N.Y., from MetLife Inc., New York, and provide laboratory services to MetLife. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Whipping Up Supper, Mouse in Hand
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on niche-market approach to online food shopping used in Manhattan by freshdirect.com; narrower strategy is more appealing to busy consumers, who are wary of big, impersonal companies like Webvan or Homegrocer; similar sites in other locations noted; drawing (M)

headline: Disaster Plans Get New Scrutiny After Blackout
abstract: Companies are taking harder look at their disaster recovery plans in light of Aug 14 power failure that stretched from Northeast to Midwest; Sungard Availability Services Jim Simmons says many companies that tried to manage their own disaster recovery plans fround that backup sit they created was still within blackout area; many companies are looking to services like Sungard and IBM to handle their computer systems; they can create disaster-hardened backup offices ready to go on short notice and linked directly to their computer networks in ways that ensure against any loss of important information and little, if any, interruption of business transactions (M)

headline: Sweden's Foreign Minister Dies of Wounds From Attack
abstract: Anna Lindh, widely respected Swedish foreign minister, dies of stab wounds suffered when unidentified assailant slashes her with knife in Stockholm department store; was mentioned often as potential leader of nation; was not routinely assigned bodyguards; her death stirs painful memories of 1986 killing of Prime Min Olof Palme; killing sharpens quandary of country seeking to balance traditional openness against newer dictates of security; Lindh, who was 46, was powerful figure in Social Democratic Party; there is no indication whether killing had been inspired by her fervent support for referendum on Sweden joining euro single currency; Prime Min Goran Persson says referendum will be held as planned on Sept 14; photo (M)

headline: Interim Iraqi Government Holds Inaugural Meeting
abstract: As its first act, the council abolished six national holidays that had been celebrated under Saddam Hussein and created a new one to celebrate his ouster.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nikkei Tops 10,000
abstract: Japan's Nikkei 225 stock index rises 1.7 percent to finish at 10,032, putting it 32 percent above its 20-year low, which was reached at end of April (S)8

headline: Indonesia Identifies Hotel Bomber
abstract: Indonesian police identify suicide bomber who attacked J W Marriott Hotel, Jakarta, as Asmar Latin Sani, member of militant Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah; terror experts says group has close links to Al Qaeda and planned and carried out Oct attack in Bali; American officials say both attacks were aimed at Americans; no Americans died in Jakarta attack and only 7 Americans were among 202 killed in Bali; Indonesian Red Cross says 10 people died in Jakarta bombing and 152, mostly Indonesians, were wounded; vehicle Sani drove reportedly was so heavily loaded with explosives that it had trouble ascending hotel's driveway and exploded before it could move close enough to hotel lobby entrance to cause many more casualties; photo (M)

headline: Shares Are Mostly Higher, Led by Telecommunications
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 32.07 points, to 9,186.04; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.67 points, to 982.82; Nasdaq composite index drops 1.56 points, to 1,714.06; stock price graphs and tables (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: TODAYNone.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: U.S. Presents New Weapon; KASHMIR: 14 Islamic Militants Killed; NEPAL: 5 Die During Strike Called By Rebels;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Semiconductor Sales To Rise 11.2%
abstract: Gartner Inc says sales of semiconductors will increase 11.2 percent this year to $173 billion; says worldwide semiconductor revenue rose 1.4 perent, to $156 billion in 2002 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 7 Afghans Die In Taliban Attacks
abstract: Taliban-led attacks kill 7 Afghan police and soliders on Kabul-Kandahar highway, disrupting road reconstruction efforts (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Flextronics Will Acquire Microsell
abstract: Flextronics International Ltd agrees to buy Microcell Group for about $80 million in cash or stock to win more business from mobile-phone makers (S)

headline: InterActive Pays $655 Million for Travel Site
abstract: Barry Diller's InterActiveCorp to buy Hotwire.com, online travel site, for $665 million in cash; deal incomes assumption of $20 million in options and warrants (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks End Second Quarter With Best Gains Since 1998  The stock market posted its best quarterly performance since the end of 1998, producing the most encouraging rally since the long slide began in 2000.    The 14.9 percent climb in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the three months was the eighth-best quarterly performance since World War II. The 12.4 percent increase in the Dow Jones industrial average and the 21 percent gain in the Nasdaq composite index resulted in their best quarters since the last three months of 2001. Although technology stocks led the way, the breadth of the rebound was enormous. [Page A1.]

headline: New Tape, Said to Be From Hussein, Urges Iraqis to Resist
abstract: Middle East television stations broadcast new audiotape, apparently recorded by Saddam Hussein, in which almost desperately sounding voice urges Iraqis not to cooperate with American occupiers; US forces are attacked west of Baghdad; photo (S)

headline: Can Truth Be Told When Using Selective Information?
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin column on ethics of politicians adapting widespread business practice of selectively using data to sell their message while campaigning and governing; cites Pres Bush's Jan speech staking part of his support for war against Iraq to British intelligence data about nuclear arms not supported by United States intelligence; holds more is at stake when president selectively uses information than when business executive tries to sell product (M)

headline: Lawyers Ease Code
abstract: The American Bar Association narrowly approved a change to its model code of conduct that would allow -- but not require -- lawyers to disclose clients' confidences to prevent or rectify crime or fraud causing financial injury. Business Day, Page C2.

headline: In the Cross Hairs
abstract: There were warning signs that the U.N. could be targeted by forces battling the U.S.-led coalition in Iraq.

headline: If Walls Could Talk, Streets Might Join In
abstract: Article explores trend of building digital interactivity into public spaces, such as reception or waiting areas or spaces with no defined purpose; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Jim Harrington is named president at O'Leary & Partners, succeeding David Robinson, who is named to new post of chief executive (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Cuts Forecast
abstract: South Korea's Shinhan Bank reduces net profit target for year to 550 billion won from 650 billion won (S)

headline: Patents; Some soldiers in Iraq want a drinking pack invented for a bike race as a part of their combat equipment.
abstract: CamelBak Products Inc, which makes custom backpacks that serve as personal water-carrying and drinking systems, is receiving letters asking that it donate CamelBaks to troops in Iraq who do not have them; CamelBak system started as recreational product, and company introduced one for military market only after learning that special forces were buying them and sneaking them into their equipment; latest Camelbak patent, covering mechanism that keeps water from leaking out, is response to soldiers' use of CamelBaks as pillow; photos (M)

headline: Melted Ice Cream Is Just the Beginning
abstract: Grocery companies scramble to assess damage as power failure wears on, causing product losses; some chains quickly switch to emergency plans already in place; Stop & Shop stores use generators to stay open and move perishables into refrigerated trucks; other chains have no fallback and are forced to discard perishables; photos (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.75       Federal funds   1.00   0.94   1.76       3-month Libor   1.14   1.42   1.78       3-month T-bills   0.93   0.93   1.65       6-month T-bills   1.01   1.01   1.64       10-yr. T-infl.   2.24   2.17   2.32       10-yr. T-note   4.42   4.35   4.06       30-yr.
