headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Explosion Ends Hostage Siege
abstract: Three-hour standoff between disgruntled employee of Keikyubin, Japanese courier company, Nagoya branch, and police ends with huge explosion that kills perpetrator, company branch manager and police officer; eight people, previously held hostage by man, witness him sprinkling office with flammable liquid; 41 people are injured in explosion (S)

headline: 3 Women, 3 Paths, 10 Years On
abstract: Profiles of Ellen Spertus, Stephanie Winner and Megan Smith, MIT graduates originally profiled in 1993 as women who might change face of computer industry; industry was, and is, known for scarcity of women; some larger companies, notably IBM and Microsoft, are focusing on attracting women to their ranks; photos (M)

headline: French Veto Threat Delays U.N. Vote on Libya Sanctions
abstract: The threat of a French veto threw a hurdle today in the way of a resolution to finally lift U.N. sanctions against Libya.

headline: 50 years of truce — and tension — in the DMZ
abstract: PANMUNJOM:—  Five days before the 50th anniversary of the signing here of the truce that ended the Korean War on July 27, 1953, American and South Korean officers were busy Tuesday, planning what they call a "commemoration," not a celebration.

headline: Goodby Is Selected By AT&T Wireless
abstract: AT&T Wireless adds Goodby, Silverstein & Partners to its roster of ad agencies, naming it to handle corporate brand advertising, which since 2001 has been one of duties of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide (S)

headline: BUSH LIKELY TO GET MONEY HE SOUGHT, LAWMAKERS AGREE
abstract: Members of Congress expect Pres Bush to get $87 billion he requested for Iraq and Afghanistan, but not before sharp questioning of request and renewed debate about its effect on federal spending, taxes and record-setting deficit; amount requested in single bill represents fifth of all money to be spent next year on nonmilitary programs, many of which are already being squeezed by deficit that will reach $480 billion; some skeptical Republicans wonder why more Iraqi oil money could not be used for reconstruction, and they question some of grander plans for rebuilding country; Democrats, aware of growing pressure on their own spending priorities, say staying in Iraq should not require domestic sacrifices; Sen Carl Levin calls spending bill 'stunning' in size; Rep William M Thornberry, Republican, predicts that some members would now be far more reluctant to approve prescription drug benefit for Medicare or other big-ticket spending proposals; photo (M)

headline: Bush Backs Bid To Block Gays From Marrying
abstract: Pres Bush says he remains firmly opposed to gay marriages and that administration lawyers are working to ensure the term 'marriage' would cover only unions between men and women, news conference; says Americans should treat gays in welcoming and respectful manner, but that marriage should be between man and woman; his comments about codifying way to prohibit same-sex marriages suggests that he may be open to idea of constitutional amendment to ban them; his remarks come as many social conservatives, important element of his political base, are seething over Supreme Court ruling in June which struck down Texas law outlawing pivate gay activity; Bush is unambiguous about his views on gay marriage; Democratic presidential candidates confronted with questions about their views on issue have often given ambiguous and calibrated answers; Bush's response has political clarity, but it leaves supporters on both sides of issue puzzled as to legal aspects, since 1996 Defense of Marriage Act already prohibits federal recognition of gay marriage and relieves states of any obligation to recognize gay marriages performed in other states (M)

headline: U.S. and Britain, at U.N., Back French Congo Plan
abstract: US, France and Britain unite behind French draft resolution to impose UN arms embargo in eastern Congro, increase ceiling on UN peacekeepers and strengthen mandate (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: AZERBAIJAN: President Flies To U.S. For Treatment; ITALY: A Horse Of The Same Color; FRANCE: Man Arrested In Death Of Son'S Tennis Rival; GERMANY: Hostage Holders Seek Contact; ICELAND: Whale Hunts To Resume;.

headline: Snap a Photo And Ship It, Without Hanging Up
abstract: Digital cameras on cell phones are getting more sophisticated and one from LG includes zoom control, three different resolutions, color and special effect; photo (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Members of United Airlines Red Carpet Club and Delta Air Lines Crown Room will lose access to each other's lounges starting March 1 (S)

headline: From PC to TV Screen, A Stream of Multimedia
abstract: Hauppauge introduces MediaMVP, which aims to bridge gap between computer and television by fetching media files from PC and playing them on TV; photo (M)

headline: Vehicle Sales Dipped in July For Big Three
abstract: General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler report falling sales of cars and trucks in July, despite offering largest buying incentives in collective history; Autodata reports industry's annual selling rate for July was estimated 17.3 million vehicles, compared with 18.1 million year earlier; says over all, sales declined 4.82 percent in July from year ago; foreign carmakers captured 40.1 percent of new-car market, third month this year in which they have sold two of every five new cars bought in country; graph; chart (M)

headline: Creditors Disagree Over Rescue of SK Global
abstract: Foreign creditors of SK Global, troubled trading arm of SK Group of South Korea, score proposal by Korean creditors to ask court to place company under receivership; Sovereign Asset Management, biggest stakeholder in SK Corp, group's flagship company, calls for company's liquidation; foreign banks hold proposal by SK Global's Korean creditors for resolving company's debts at 43 percent of their value is far too low; seek return of 72 percent (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Broker Penalty Sought
abstract: Japan's Securities and Exchange Survei

headline: Train Bombing Kills 5 and Hurts 30 Near Chechnya
abstract: At least five people were killed and more than 30 were injured today when two bombs exploded under a passing commuter train near Chechnya.

headline: Hostile Bid, a Throwback Tactic
abstract: Analysis of recent rash of hostile bids--Oracle Corp's pursuit of PeopleSoft, Alcan's stalking of Pechiney and ArvinMeritor's unsolicited bid for Dana Corp--holds it is not indicative of takeover tactic made popular back in 1980's; says recent unfriendly bids appear to be aberrations, not part of larger revival of hostile takeovers (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Colleges Resist Record Industry Subpoenas
abstract: Boston College and Massachusetts Institute of Technology say law that requires them to notify students before releasing any personal data bars them from immediate compliance with Recording Industry Association of America subpoenas seeking names of users of KaZaa, file-sharing service; industry seeks to identify and sue individuals who illegally distribute copyrighted music over Internet (S)

headline: Boise Cascade Is Near Buying OfficeMax as Outlet for Its Paper
abstract: Boise Cascade is expected to acquire OfficeMax for about $1.1 billion in cash and stock; price represents 25 percent premium over OfficeMax's share price (M)

headline: Automakers Sue Over Asbestos Maneuver
abstract: General Motors Co, Ford Motor Co and DaimlerChrysler sue to block Honeywell International Inc from transferring its Bendix brake unit to bankrupt Federal-Mogul Corp, contending transaction would unfairly saddle car companies with increased asbestos liabilities; Honeywell seeks to use transaction to extricate itself from more than 50,000 asbestos lawsuits against Bendix (M)

headline: Investing; Poised to Ride the Next Wave In Digital Media Equipment
abstract: poised to r

headline: A.I.G.'s Profit Rises on Higher Prices
abstract: American International Group, world's largest insurer, says that its second-quarter profit rose 26 percent to record after company raises prices on property and casualty coverage; net income climbs to $2.28 billion, or 87 cents a share (S)

headline: Looking Beyond Vivendi At G.E.
abstract: Market Insight interview with General Electric chairman Jeffrey R Immelt; photo (S)

headline: Bush Insists Liberian President Go Before Troops Come In
abstract: Pers Bush, enmeshed in internal debate within administration on whether to send US peackeeping troops to Liberia, strongly implices that no soldiers will be deployed until Pres Charles Taylor leaves, interview with African reporters; US military officials meet in Ghana with West African representatives; photo of demonstrators in Monrovia (M)

headline: Pension Overhaul Wins Key Vote in Brazil
abstract: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva scored his first major legislative success today since taking office in January, winning resounding approval in the lower house of Congress to overhaul Brazil's debt-ridden public pension system.    Despite strong opposition from workers in the public sector and the more extreme fringes of his own Workers Party, Mr. da Silva, who canceled an African trip to stay in Brasília and shepherd the bill through Congress, marshaled enough support to carry the initial vote in the lower house by 358 to 126, with 9 abstentions.

headline: 2nd Deadly Bombing in Moscow Linked to Chechen Conflict
abstract: A Russian security agent was killed early today during an effort to defuse a bomb that had been brought to a restaurant here by a woman officials characterized as a suicide bomber from Chechnya.

headline: Business People; One of the Few That Got Away From Icahn
abstract: VISX chief executive Liz Davila comments on successfully fending off Carl C Icahn's attempt to gain control of company; Icahn photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Adidas-Salomon Posts Profit
abstract: Adidas-Salomon, one of the world's leading sporting goods makers, said its second-quarter net profit rose 26.8 percent to 32 million euros ($36.4 million) from 25 million euros in the same quarter a year earlier, beating most analysts' expectations. Operating profit, however, fell 10.5 percent to 62 million euros ($70.1 million) in the April-June period and sales were down 8 percent at 1.4 billion euros, as a result of both the strength of the euro against the dollar and the weak economic environment.   Victor Homola (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Business Confidence Rises
abstract: Italy's index of business confidence rises to 95.3 during first two weeks of August, sign country's economy may be emerging from mild recession (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy Issues Alert About Threats In Indonesia
abstract: American Amb Ralph L Boyce calls meeting of American residents of Indonesia and warns them that future terrorist attacks like one at Marriott Hotel in Jakarta are likely; there are 10,000 Americans living in Indonesia, about half of them in Jakarta; meeting is held in courtyard inside American Embassy, which is deemed safest place to assemble; Indonesia has arrested scores of people suspected of being Islamic terrorists, but there are thought to be several thousand Indonesians who trained at Al Qaeda camps in Afghanistan who are unaccounted for; compounding alarm is switch in terrorist tactics, to use of suicide bombers; photo (M)

headline: LENS MAKER WINS PATENT FIGHT IN EUROPE
abstract: Bausch & Lomb, maker of contact lenses, says European Patent Office has revoked Novartis patent, clearing way for it to reintroduce its long-wear contact lens in Germany; company stopped selling its PureVision lenses in Germany in April after court ruled in favor of Novartis (S)

headline: Commentators In Arab World Call Attack A Catastrophe
abstract: Commentators in Arab world view suicide bombing of United Nations headquarters in Baghdad as utter madness; sprinkled among universal condemnations are conspiracy theories that Washington was involved, hoping to spread chaos so that its extended rule is only alternative; some think Al Qaeda was involved, given Osama bin Laden's contempt for UN; Arab people at large view UN with certain affection; idea that anyone could kill 20 people working for organization with its many charitable branches leaves many in disbelief (M)

headline: Procter & Gamble Buys Time on Super Bowl
abstract: Summer has barely begun, but already advertisers are thinking about buying commercial time during Super Bowl XXXVIII, to be broadcast on CBS.

headline: Militant Gets Life Term for Bali Bombing
abstract: An Indonesian court sentenced an Islamic militant to life imprisonment today for his role in the Bali bombings that killed 202 people last year.

headline: Fallon Is Chosen For Subway Account
abstract: Subway Restaurants names Fallon Worldwide to handle creative and strategic planning duties on its ad account; those duties have been handled for three years by Euro RSCG MVBMS; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: Another Choice; Wireless Rival Boasts Speed and a Roomy Keyboard
abstract: Palm's new wireless model is fast and powerful and has built-in antenna for Wi-Fi networks but no automatic connect feature; has thumb keyboard and includes range of software; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; Vivendi Seems Unusually Willing To Do a Deal With a Handshake
abstract: Vivendi Universal plans to accept preliminary agreement for its entertainment assets, equivalent of mere handshake; final deal could still take weeks to complete; suitor appears to be either General Electric's NBC unit or consortium led by Edgar Bronfman Jr (Market Place column) (M)

headline: 'End the Occupation'
abstract: INTERVIEW: VOLKHARD WINDFUHR

headline: DataBank; Bulls on Wall St.'s Radar, or Merely a Blip?
abstract: Stocks began the third quarter last week on the same solid footing as they ended the second quarter, leading some market watchers to wonder whether the bull market may be returning.     ''The equity market now has the wind behind its back,'' said Joseph T. Keating, chief investment officer at AmSouth Asset Management, in an interview with The Associated Press. ''We are in a bull market.''

headline: William Smith, 90, Whose Firm Made Snapper Lawn Mowers
abstract: William R Smith, owner of Snapper lawn mower company, dies at age 90 (S)

headline: Napster's Descendants; His Beyoncé, Her Beatles: A Primer on Trading
abstract: Article describes how file-sharing networks like KaZaA adn Napster allow users to search Internet for specific music that may be on somebody else's computer; user gets copy of file and, in exchange, makes folder of files that can be shared with others (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Conglomerate's Earnings Rise
abstract: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd reprots its unaudited earnings rose 2 percent in first six months of year, to $777.8 million (S)

headline: Executive Life; The Career Break That's No Holiday
abstract: Drawn out months of unemployment in this recession leads many displaced executives to take lower-status jobs rather than focusing only on finding work at their own levels; Michael Warren comments; photo (S)

headline: Showdown Looms in Europe Over Proposals on Accounting
abstract: Battle over accounting rules for financial institutions is breaking out in Europe; proposed new rules by International Accounting Standards Board have been denounced by AXA chairman Claude Bebear, his successor Henri de Castries and BNP chief accountant Gerard Gil; some of harshest critics of international board concede that rules in some European countries are weak and subject to abuse, but they are furious about proposed rules that would require many derivative securities to be shown at market value on financial statements, something that often does not happen and that some suspect could be allowing companies to hide losses; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Global Trade
abstract: SINGAPORE: Chip Partnership Ends; SINGAPORE: Economy Shrinks; HONG KONG: Air Traffic Improves; CHINA: Economy Maintains Growth;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Liquor Executive Arrested
abstract: Prosecutors arrest Chang Jin Ho, former chairman of Jinro, world's biggest liquor manufacturer, and company's two top executives in investigation into suspected misuse of 634 billion won ($544 million) intended to rescue company before 1997-98 economic crisis in South Korea; say Chang diverted funds to four affiliates and to his personal use (S)

headline: After Nepal Killings, a Tough King Gets U.S. Backing
abstract: Nepal has been holding off-and-on peace negotiations with Maoist guerrillas during unsteady six-month ceasefire; two years ago country was shaken when royal family was all but wiped out in murky attack that was offically attributed to Crown Prince Dipendra, who also died; every-shifting struggle in Nepal involves three power centers: Hindu monarchy, far weaker political parties, and Maoists; some politicians worry that King Gyanendra will make deal with Maoist rebels; United States, Britain and India, fearing instability in volatile corner of world, appear to be backing king with aid and support; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Abiomed Gets Approval To Sell Heart Device
abstract: Abiomed Inc, developer of first fully implantable artificial heart, wins Food and Drug Administration approval for device that can temporarily aid blood flow to natural heart; graph (S)

headline: Profit at Edison Drops on Charge
abstract: Edison International, electric utility, reports second-quarter net income fell to $24 million, down from $665 million in 2002 period; revenue rose 11 percent, to $3.13 billion (S)

headline: Wolfowitz Visits Mass Graveyard of Hussein's Victims and Promises Help in Hunting Killers
abstract: Deputy Defense Sec Paul Wolfowitz visits mass gravesite in Hilla, one of 62 such sites that American and allied investigators have discovered in southern Iraq; about 3,000 bodies have been unearthed, but townspeople say thousands more probably decomposed in shallow water table over last decade; Wolfowitz promises group of local Iraqis that occupying forces will lend whatever aid is ncessary to track down killers, but Iraqis say Americans have already squandered opportunities to capture suspected executioners and want them to do more (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Reinsurer Posts Gain
abstract: Reinsurance company Swiss Re earned 691 million Swiss francs ($488 million) in first half of year, up from 118 million francs ($83 million) year earlier (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Air Traffic Improves
abstract: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways says passenger traffic in July dropped 21.2 percent from year earlier, but up 90 percent from June; graph (S)

headline: Hong Kong Party Calls for Delay in Security Legislation
abstract: The leaders of the main pro-Beijing political party called today for the delay of internal-security legislation.

headline: China Life Initial Offering to Seek $3 Billion
abstract: China Life Insurance president Wang Xianzhang says China's largest life insurer will seek to raise up to $3 billion in initial public share offering; state-run company seeks funds from foreign investors and equities market (S)

headline: AT&T Files Racketeering Charges Against MCI and Onvoy
abstract: Telephone company AT&T said today it filed federal civil racketeering charges against bankrupt rival MCI and Onvoy.

headline: Qurei Accepts Palestinian Premier Post
abstract: Israeli warplanes destroy home of Hamas political leader Dr Mahmoud Zahar in Gaza, wounding him and killing his son and bodyguard; threat of broader Israeli military action prompts Ahmed Qurei to end three days of hesitation and accept post of Palestinian prime minister; Qurei drops demands for Israeli and international help and says he will present 'emergency government' to parliament for its approval; says his top priority would be to unify tangled branches of Palestinian security forces, central Israeli and American demand; Prime Min Ariel Sharon cuts short trip to India and returns home after two suicide bombings by Hamas kill 15 people in separate attacks in Israel; photo (M)

headline: Tax Fugitive's Son Pleads Guilty to Evasion Charges
abstract: Brett G Tollman, son of fugitive hotel and travel executive Stanley S Tollman, pleads guilty to charges of income tax evasion and admits role in scheme to funnel unreported income to accounts in Guernsey, GB; Justice Department is seeking extradition of Stanley Tollman from Great Britain and Richard S Masefield, executive in Tollmans' firm Tollman-Hundley, from Australia; California authorities arrest George Hesson and wife Trina on tax evasion charges; couple, who own electronics su pply business No Time Delay Electronics, had boasted that no law required them to pay taxes or withhold taxes from their workers' paychecks; California Franchise Tax Board says Jessons paid no taxes on $3 million of income from 1997 through 1999; photo (M)

headline: Scholastic Loss Narrows to $24.8 Million
abstract: Scholastic Corp's loss narrows to $24.8 million in its fiscal first quarter ended Aug 31 from loss of $44.6 million year earlier; sales rose 55 percent, to $475.4 million (S)

headline: Question for 'David' at 500: Is He Ready for Makeover?
abstract: Heated debate rages over whether Michelangelo's David should be cleaned, restored or left untouched; 14-foot-high statue has stood inside Galleria dell'Accademia in Florence since 1873; Agnese Parronchi, experienced restorer first hired to clean statue, resigned in Apr, charging that officially approved method is too harsh and could cause damage; petition signed by 39 international scholars proposes suspending any action pending review by independent commission of experts; Antonio Paolucci, superintendent of Florentine art who has final say, announces that cleaning of David will begin in Sept with new restorer, Franca Falletti; Paolucci seeks to play down dispute between advocates of various methods of cleaning; last year he canceled plans to restore Leonardo's Adoration of the Magi in face of international protests; photos showing streaks and blotches of old age on statue of David (M)

headline: Foes of Venezuela's President Take First Step Toward Recall
abstract: Venezuelan opposition groups presented elections officials today with 3.2 million signatures calling for the removal of President Hugo Chávez.

headline: PROFIT AT ECKERD UNIT OF PENNEY IS EXPECTED TO FALL 30%
abstract: J C Penney Co says third-quarter profit at its Eckerd drugstore division will fall about 30 percent amid increased competition and sluggish sales (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Posts Loss
abstract: Munich Re reports net loss of 365 million euros ($397 million) in second quarter, compared with loss of 383 million euros ($417 million) in quarter year earlier; earned 737 million euros ($802 million) in quarter, compared with 1.3 billion euros ($1.4 billion) loss year ago; graph (S)8

headline: Digital Dealmakers Meet in the Middle
abstract: Software companies are developing programs to conduct negotiations, relying on algorithms to gauge what might constitute acceptable offers in growing field of electronic mediation; most uses of automated negotiation have been settling insurance claims and other similar applications, but scope for such negotiations is vast; computers have capacity to consider millions of offers and counteroffers in seconds and also to consider terms that human negotiator might miss, and can deal with more parameters that comprise substance of complex arbitrations; photo; drawing (M)

headline: There's No Way To Justify These Fees
abstract: Market Watch column on exorbitantly high fees charged by some mutual funds, in comparison with low fees of Vanguard funds (M)

headline: Sun Will Trim 1,000 Jobs
abstract: Sun Microsystems will eliminate as many as 1,080 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, to concentrate on products and services that are doing well (S)

headline: The Ultimate in Parental Supervision
abstract: Readers share their experience of working in family business, with parents as boss; cartoons (M)

headline: Utterances Not Made in Heaven
abstract: Following are some quotes from Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin of France:.

headline: Russian Authorities Search Office of Powerful Oil Tycoon
abstract: Russian prosecutors step up criminal investigation of oil tycoon Mikhail B Khodorovsky, sending police, some in ski masks, to search offices of Yukos Oil Co (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: War Games Collision
abstract: Two gunship helicopters collide during Russian war games killing six crewmen; Defense Minister Sergei B Ivanov contends accident was fault of pilots (S)

headline: U.S., Russia And Europe Meet at U.N. On Mideast
abstract: US, European Union and Russian senior envoys meet at UN on deteriorating situation in Mideast, renewing appeals to Palestinians to stop suicide bombings and to Israel to exercise restraint in responses; European Union, which finances about one-third of Palestinian Authority, will press Yasir Arafat to allow prime minister Ahmed Qurei to crack down on terrorists; Prime Min Ariel Sharon says US objections to expelling Arafat will be taken into account; Sec Colin Powell reportedly says US will press Israel to free more Palestinian prisoners, ease security measures, dismantle some settlements and stop construction of barrier; Sec Gen Kofi Annan bluntly acknowledges dead end and calls for bold steps (M)

headline: Arms expert apparently killed himself : Blair won't resign over adviser's death
abstract: SEOUL:—  Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said Sunday that he had no intention of resigning as a result of the apparent suicide of the British defense adviser identified by the BBC as the source of its story saying the British government had inflated claims of Iraqi weapons of mass destruction.

headline: Pressure Up, Washington Is Split on Liberia
abstract: Pentagon officials say they resist significant expansion of American forces already sent ashore in Liberia as Pres Charles G Taylor edges closer to leaving nation, meeting one of Pres Bush's conditions for greater American military role; Bush faces rising pressure from United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan and African and European allies to send in larger force to help secure Monrovia, port and capital, and open up relief column; Annan aide says Annan again pressed for more sizable US military role at meeting with Sec Colin L Powell; State Department says Powell backs goal of securing Monrovia, but that US military role must still be decided (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH -- Brian C. Rogers; T. Rowe Price Equity Income Fund
abstract: Profile of Brian C Rogers, manager of $11.5 billion T Rowe Price Equity Income Fund; he says he expects more companies to pay dividends as part of their corporate finance strategies; photo; table (L)

headline: Sale of Shares Is Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      The American Superconductor Corporation, 4 million shares. Needham.

headline: PROVIDIAN TO CLOSE CALL CENTER AND LAY OFF 232 WORKERS
abstract: Providian Financial Corp, credit card issuer, to close El Paso call center and eliminate 232 jobs; reports earning $39 million in second quarter, down 75 percent from $153.9 million in 2002 quarter (S)

headline: Business People; American Idols Switch To a New Model
abstract: Ruben Studdard and Clay Aiken, winner and runner-up on American Idol, television show sponsored by Ford Motor Co, entertain at Toyota's annual dealer meeting; photo (S)

headline: Alstom Finds Irregularities At U.S. Unit
abstract: French power and transportation equipment maker Alstom discovers accounting irregularities at American subsidiary Alstom Transportation Inc that signficantly understated losses on rail-car contract; will take charge of 51 million euros ($58.3 million) as result; US Securities and Exchange Commission and FBI have begun inquiries into unit; Alstom, in partnership with Kawasaki Rail Car, won $2.3 billion contract to build as many as 1,700 subway cars for Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York; graph (M)

headline: New Low In High Mutual Fund Fees
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column criticizes fees charged to investors in mutual funds that are closed for marketing intended to attract more investors; notes Standard & Poor's study that found 139 stock, bond and money market funds closed to new investors that charge such fees; graph (M)

headline: A Warning Shot to Banks On Role in Others' Fraud
abstract: Floyd Norris analysis of settlements that SEC and district attorneys reached with J P Morgan Chase and Citigroup over their role in helping Enron mislead investors, in violation of securities laws; photo (L)

headline: Iraq Arms Critic Reacts to Report on Wife
abstract: Joseph C Wilson IV, retired ambassador who was secret envoy of Bush administration to Africa and who publicly voiced doubts about reported Iraqi weapons program, says he has become target of administration campaign to discourage others like him from going public; says after he reported findings in Op-Ed article in The New York Times, his wife was identified as covert CIA operative in column by conservative columnist Robert Novak, who attributed information to senior administration official; says he was moved to write Op-Ed article after concluding that national security adviser Condoleezza Rice and others were passing off his findings as having been shared only with low-ranking officials; notes that after his article appeared, White House acknowleged that it erred in including disputed accusations about Iraqi arms purchases from Africa in Pres Bush's State of Union address; photo (M)

headline: First Aid; For a Creaky Mac, Tricks to Jog the Memory
abstract: Free utilities are available to help Macintosh computers perform to optimum capability even if some memory is being used to manage extensions, small programs that may strain computer's available memory (M)

headline: 'Hussein' Tape Calls U.S. Withdrawal From Iraq Inevitable
abstract: The broadcast came as the U.S. military cast further doubt on the possibility that six prisoners might be American, as they claimed.

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: SYMANTEC TO BUY POWERQUEST FOR $150 MILLION; ORACLE AND ENERGY DEPT. INCREASE SOFTWARE SECURITY;.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: President Declares His Wealth
abstract: Kenyan President Mwai Kibaki makes declaration of wealth and calls on others in government to do same; disclosure is part of effort by administration to reduce corruption in government; photo (S)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: JetBlue Airways plans to offer more legroom in most seats on its planes, without increasing fares, starting this fall; Continental Airlines says its passengers can now use their cellphones and make calls as soon as their planes touch down, unless flight attendants announce otherwise; Smith Travel Research's 2003 Hotel Operating Statistics report shows full-year 2002 domestic hotel industry profits were $14.2 billion, 12 percent decrease from 2001; revenue per available room, standard measure of hotel earnings, fell 2.4 percent in 2002, as average room rate fell 1.5 percent (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: Al Jazeera Reporter Jailed
abstract: Spanish judge jails Tayssir Alouni, correspondent for Al Jazeera, after he is accused of being member of Al Qaeda; Alouni's lawyer claims client's dealings with Al Qaeda were limited to his reporting (S)

headline: Freed Palestinians Get Joyous Welcome
abstract: Although the official Palestinian position is that today's releases are insignificant, the mood at the scene was celebratory.

headline: INTERIM LEADERS, SUPPORTED BY U.S., MEET IN BAGHDAD
abstract: Members of Iraq's first interim government meet in Baghdad, announcing plan to begin meeting in continuous session to decide on rotating presidency or similar leadership structure; Governing Council's first act is to abolish six national holidays celebrated under Saddam Hussein's 24-year rule and create new national day, Apr 9, day Baghdad fell to allied forces and Hussein went into hiding; Governing Council is made up of 25 prominent Iraqis from variety of political, ethnic and religious backgrounds; Council must decide on process to write new constitution and to hold first democratic elections; Council member Iyad Alawi says first priority will be security and resumption of services; Council was selected through negotiations between main Iraqi opposition groups and office of American administrator L Paul Bremer 3d; occupation leaders have agreed to cede considerable executive powers to Iraqis on Council after initially resisting anything greater than advisory role; they did so in face of daunting reconstruction agenda, critical shortage of money and security environment that resembles low-intensity war for more than 160,000 allied troops; photos; chart listing members of new Governing Council and their backgrounds (L)

headline: A Frail Pope Meets Slovak Twins in an Anti-Abortion Gesture
abstract: Roman Catholic officials dramatize church's opposition to abortion by having Pope John Paul II appear at outdoor Mass in Slovakia with three-year-old girls who were joined at birth and later separated (S)

headline: Merrill Lynch's Earnings Surge After Cost-Cutting
abstract: Merrill Lynch reports 61 percent gain in its second-quarter earnings, to $1 billion, driven by combination of robust bond trading profits and vigilant cost-cutting; its stock rises 4.4 percent (M)

headline: CARNIVAL CRUISE CHIEF PLANS BIG SHARE SALE
abstract: Carnival Corp says chief executive Micky Arison and his family plan to sell as many as 32 million shares valued at about $1.11 billin to diversify their finances (S)

headline: Consumer Debt Increased by $6 Billion in July
abstract: Federal Reserve reports borrowing through credit cards, auto loans and other personal debt increased 4.1 percent, or $6 billion, to $1.77 trillion in July; adds consumer credit increased by revised $151.3 million, or 0.1 percent, in June (S)

headline: Phony Charities Tap Into AIDS Money for Africa
abstract: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 9 — The Neema Children's Center has disappeared into thin air, authorities here say, and so have other groups that claim to be fighting AIDS in this African capital.

headline: Spike Lee and Viacom Settle Dispute Over 'Spike TV'
abstract: Spike Lee has dropped his legal challenge to Viacom's plans to change the name of its TNN cable network to Spike TV.

headline: JetBlue Chief's Message to Customers
abstract: Text of e-mail message by JetBlue chief executive officer David Neeleman to customers following disclosure that company provided passenger information to Defense Dept contractor involved in antiterrorism project (M)

headline: Budget Office Says 10 Years of Deficits Could Total $5 Trillion
abstract: The new 10-year projections are based primarily on the cost of three programs that President Bush and the Republican majority in Congress broadly support.

headline: INVESTING WITH: Carl Domino; Northern Large Cap Value Fund
abstract: Interview with Northern Large Cae

headline: AOL Time Warner Drops the 'AOL'
abstract: AOL Time Warner changes name to Time Warner; chief executive Richard D Parsons says change is intended to end any confusion between corporate name and America Online brand name; company's stock ticker symbol will change to TWX from AOL (M)

headline: Saxon Riley, 64, Lloyd's Leader In Post-Sept. 11 Insurance Crisis
abstract: Saxon Riley, who helped to reorganize Lloyd's of London and also helped it through aftermath of Sept 11 crisis, dies at age 64 (M)

headline: Lui Journal; Sudan's Luckless Children, Locked in Land of Nod
abstract: About 300 children in and around jungle village of Lui in southern Sudan have mysterious neurological ailment called 'nodding disease'; their necks begin to swing forward and back, typically during or just after eating; children who begin nodding eventually stop growing when still small; their brains stop developing, leaving them mentally retarded; eventually, disease kills them; disorder, which appears unique to southern Sudan, has left epidemiologists baffled; photos; map (M)

headline: Fed's Decision to Maintain Rate Moves Shares Higher
abstract: Stocks rise as Federal Reserve decides to keep benchmark interest rates at 45-year lows; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 14.51 points, to 1,029.32; Dow Jones industrial average climbs 118.53 points, to 9,567.34; Nasdaq composite index gains 41.55 points, to 1,887.25; 10-year Treasury note drops 5/32, to price of 99 25/32, and its yield rises to 4.28 percent; 30-year bond loses 10/32, to 102 19/32, and its yield climbs to 5.20 percent; graph (M)

headline: Asian Stocks Rally After U.S. Reports a Rise in Spending
abstract: Asian stocks rally, sending benchmark indexes in Japan and South Korea to 14-month highs (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker's Revenue To Miss
abstract: Nvidia Corp, maker of chips for computer graphics, warns second-quarter revenue and gross margins will be lower than analysts forecast (S)

headline: 2 Suicide Bombers Fulfilled Their Fathers' Worst Fears
abstract: Fathers of two Palestinian teen-age boys who carried out separate suicide attacks on Aug 12 meet for first time to receive condolences and talk about what prompted their sons to do what they did; both say that they were not surprised and that they tried to talk their sons out of becoming extremists; say it is no coincidence that two bombers came from Nablus, where just last week Israeli military killed four people, including two men Israel says were Hamas bomb makers; most Israelis are outraged at suggestion that they are somehow to blame; they call suicide bombing singularly heinous moral crime and they blame Palestinian parents who teach or tolerate hate, as well as militant groups like Hamas and Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, groups that claim responsibility for latest attacks; photo (M)

headline: U.S. MAY BE FORCED TO GO BACK TO U.N. FOR IRAQ MANDATE
abstract: Refusal of some nations to send peacekeeping troops to Iraq or contribute money for its reconstruction without United Nations mandate is putting pressure on reluctant Bush administration to seek such approval; Russia says it will consider sending peacekeeping troops only with UN mandate that sets out specific mission and timetable; discussions reflect growing sense that reconstruction of Iraq will require new alliance, both to help diffuse responsibility for operation and to help rebuild relationships with France, Germany and other countries that were strained in dispute over going to war (M)

headline: 3 Blinks Means You're Hot: A Wireless Network Tracker
abstract: Kensington introduces WiFi finder that indicates when user is near wireless network; photo (M)

headline: ILLINOIS COURT ORDERS TOBACCO DECISION REVIEW
abstract: Illinois appeals court orders trial judge to reconsider his decision reducing how much Philip Morris USA must deposit to appeal $10.1 billion verdict for misleading Illinois smokers about dangers of 'light' cigarettes; judge cut bond for Philip Morris to $6.8 billion from $12 billion (S)

headline: Tenet Vows Improvements in Patient Care
abstract: Tenet Healthcare, hospital chain under investigation for various wrongdoing, pledges stress on improving patient care, annual meeting; much of criticism of company at meeting comes from California Nurses Association, which is striking at one Tenet hospital and trying to organize nurses at others; photo (M)

headline: U.S. WILL ASK U.N. FOR MOVE TO WIDEN THE FORCE IN IRAQ
abstract: Bush administration is preparing new United Nations Security Council resolution that would urge other nations to send troops and aid to secure Iraq; new resolution, coming days after bomb attack on United Nations headquarters in Baghdad, would allow American military to maintain control over any international forces in Iraq--something Pentagon insists on; administration hopes resolution, if it is passed, would encourage nations like India, Pakistan and Turkey to contribute troops; those nations and others have balked at acting without UN resolution backing such troop deployments; in addition to troops, UN officials say wealthy countries are reluctant to provide assistance to Iraq without more authority being given to UN; Defense Sec Rumsefeld says that despite bombing in Iraq, he sees no need to increase troop levels, at least for now; diplomatic maneuvering at UN suggests some officials in administration, particularly in State Department, believe bombing demonstrates that military reinforcements are needed; photo (M)

headline: West African Group to Send Troops to Liberia
abstract: The group announced today that it would send at least 1,000 peacekeeping troops to Monrovia within the next two weeks.

headline: Rethinking Health Care as a Haven for Investors
abstract: Study of Medicare data has led some analysts to challenge conventional wisdom that health care sector is a safe haven for investors during economic downturns; proponents of view argue that increased economic sensitivity of sector may be result of consumers' need to shoulder increased share of own costs through copayments and deductibles; skeptics contend that sector, while maturing, continues to be valid defensive play and operates independently of economic cycles; many portfolio managers recommend that hospital and drug stocks be analyzed by company fundamentals rather than industry characteristics; graph (M)

headline: People
abstract: Fallon Worldwide's New York office names Francis Anderson connection planning director; Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos names Andrea Bouchante to head new broadcst spot-buying unit at its San Francisco office (S)

headline: Hilfiger Announces New Chief Executive
abstract: Tommy Hilfiger Corp names David F Dyer chief executive, succeeding Joel Horowitz, who remains chairman; photo (M)

headline: The poodle's core
abstract: He's charming, charismatic and eloquent. In the United States, Prime Minister Tony Blair is being celebrated as a loyal ally, but at home his star is sinking. For the first time in more than a decade, Blair's Labour Party is more popular than he is.

headline: Company That Cloned Sheep To Sell Assets and Shut Down
abstract: Scotland's PPL Therapeutics, spinoff of Roslin Institute that propelled biotechnology industry into new realm seven years ago when it cloned sheep named Dolly, will sell its last assets and close; says chief executive Geoff Cook and four board members will step down immediately; PPL's market value has declined 99 percent, to about 6 million pounds or about $9.6 million from high in February 1997 after announcement of Dolly's creation; photo (M)

headline: Deadly Car Bombing Shakes Marriott Hotel in Jakarta
abstract: The explosion seriously damaged the lower floors of the 33-floor hotel, killed at least 10 people and injured nearly 150.

headline: Court Halts a Bid by Intel to Stop E-Mail
abstract: California Supreme Court rules that former Intel Corp engineer Kenneth Hamidi is free to send e-mail messages to current company employees, overturning lower court's injunction; court rejects Intel's argument that messages represent illegal trespassing to its computer systems; argument is increasingly used by companies and Internet service providers in fight against spam, or unsolicited commercial e-mail; case also attracted free-speech rights of current and former corporate employees; court only rules on trespass issue (M)

headline: Credit Card Ruling Upheld
abstract: US Appeals Court rules Visa International Inc and MasterCard International Inc cannot bar 34,000 member banks from distributing credit cards in US that are issued by rivals American Express Co and Morgan Stanley; upholds ruling by lower court in case brought two years ago by Justice Department; Visa is expected to appeal; court says rules harm competition (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Increase In Bar Production
abstract: Sú

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: SARS Alarms Investors
abstract: Confirmation of new case of SARS in Singapore sends airline and other tourism-related stocks tumbling; investors worry that another outbreak might send region's travel industry back into tailspin (S)

headline: U.S. Steel Reports Loss on Personnel Costs
abstract: US Steel reports second-quarter net loss of $49 million, compard with year-earlier net income of $27 million (M)

headline: Afghan Warlords Thrive Beyond Official Reach
abstract: Warriors of Afghanistan, armed by two decades of war and unimpeded by weak government, are fighting one another for land, money and power; outman and outgun police, collecting for themselves taxes Afghan officials say government could use to build stronger police force; situation in Sholgarah Valley of northern Afghanistan shows how limited government's reach is; map; photo (M)

headline: African Held for War Crimes Dies in Custody of a Tribunal
abstract: Foday Sankoh, warlord from Sierra Leone who made mutilations his signature weapon of war and came to symbolize face of deranged cruelty, dies in custody of United Nations-backed war crimes tribunal; was 66 and was being treated for variety of ailments at hospital in Freetown; had been charged with crimes against humanity in connection with civil war that plunged his country into more than decade of terror; photos (M)

headline: As Serbia Slows Its Reforms, Europe Drifts Farther Away
abstract: Slowdown of reform efforts in Serbia raises fears that country's entry into European Union will be delayed and that nationalist candidates will benefit; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: MALI: Tourists' Kidnappers Demand Ransom; RWANDA: 105 Convicted In Ethnic Killings; KENYA: Bomb Suspect Kills Policeman; SUDAN: Political Detainees Released;.

headline: Tavera Journal; On Trailblazing Corsica, Sausages With a Pedigree
abstract: Julian Raffalli, pig farmer and charcuterie maker in Tavera, Corsica, refuses to sell to shops or to advertise, but his products are legendary; customers learn by word of mouth about his sausages and hams and flock to his small shop; Corsicans have been making same charcuterie for 1,000 years; to stem adulteration of charcuterie, representatives of Corsican pork industry have launched campaign to identify race of Corsican pig; project is intended to be first step toward introducing France's first official inspection and naming system for charcuterie; photos; map (M)

headline: Market Place; Lehman to Buy Neuberger Berman For $2.6 Billion
abstract: Lehman Brothers to acquire Neuberger Berman, money management firm catering to wealthy individuals, for $2.6 billion in cash and stock; deal could presage move by other brokerage firms to exploit recent jump in their stock prices to acquire money management firms, whose revenues tend to be less volatile than their other businesses; Neuberger, Berman will retain its brand name; Jeffrey B Lane, Neuberger's chief, will become Lehman vice chairman and member of office of chairman; photo (M)

headline: An Exhausted Pope Finishes Visit to Slovakia
abstract: Over four days, the pope's appearances provided the most vivid examples yet of the heavy toll that Parkinson's disease has taken on him.

headline: The Country That a President Never Gets to See
abstract: Comment on ordinary life in Nigeria that Pres Bush did not see on whirlwind visit; most populous nation in Africa is former military dictatorship that has become flawed democracy, rich in oil but with long lines at gas pumps; photos (M)

headline: Ericsson Cuts Losses and Predicts Return to Profitability in '03
abstract: Ericsson reports second-quarter net loss of 2.73 billion Swedish kronor ($331 million), roughly equal to loss during same quarter last year, but down from 4.3 billion kronor loss in first quarter; sales fell 28 percent to 27.6 billion kronor ($33.5 billion); chief executive Carl-Henric Svanberg comments (M)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: Defense Department confirms death of another American in Iraq

headline: Scripps Earnings More Than Double
abstract: E W Scripps Co says net income increased to $64.7 million in second quarter ended June 30 from $27 million year earlier; revenue rose to $474.8 million from $380.4 million (S)

headline: Igen's Right to End Roche Pact Is Upheld
abstract: Roche Holding AG may lose its license to use Igen International Inc technology to evaluate body fluids for illnesses like cancer and thyroid disorders after appeals court upholds Igen's right to end contract; Roche has spent more than $350 million developing diagnostic tests based on its agreement with Igen; court also throws out jury's decision that Roche must pay Igen $86.4 million in compensatory damages and $400 million in punitive damages for unfair competition; court upholds $18.6 million breach-of-contract judgment (S)

headline: Auto Deal or Bust
abstract: Analysis contract agreements between Big Three automobile manufacturers and UAW workers; says while auto workers see contract that extends lifeline to struggling Big Three, Wall Street sees baby steps that amount to glass half-full in some minds and fully empty in others (M)

headline: Sam's Club Bolsters Wal-Mart; Federated Says Its Net Is Halved
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores says fiscal second-quarter operating profit rose about 15 percent after earnings increased at it's Sam's Club warehouse-store chain and overseas sales surged; Federated Department Stores says net income fell by more than half; Wal-Mart says profit from continuing operations rose to $2.28 billion compared with $1.99 billion year earlier; revenue rose 11 percent, to $63.2 billion and sales at stores open at least year rose 3.2 percent; Federated's net income fell to $120 million from $282 million year earlier; revenue in period fell 1.5 percent, to $3.43 billion; sales at stores open at least year dropped 1.2 percent (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Privatization Advancing; INDIA: Oracle Adding Jobs;.

headline: Air France and KLM May Form a Broad Alliance
abstract: Air France and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines appear to be moving toward alliance, possibly including takeover of KLM by Air France; such move would change shape of both airlines and reconfigure European industry; Dutch Prime Min Jan Peter Balkenende says government remains open to alliance of KLM with another airline; photo (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Dan Allen was named senior account supervisor at NKH&W, Kansas City, Mo. He had been president at the GMS Group, Fayetteville, Ark.. He will continue to work from Fayetteville.

headline: FirstEnergy's Cash Position Declines Sharply
abstract: FirstEnergy Corp says its cash postion fell sharply during second quarter; financial statements show company had $64.2 million in cash on hand on June 30, down from $290 million on March 31 and $359.1 ilion previous June; reports positive cash flow of $21.7 million in second quarter, but that was dwarfed by needs for capital spending and for debt repayment (M)

headline: 3 Bombs in Russian City Kill at Least 3
abstract: Three bombs exploded nearly simultaneously in a regional capital in southern Russia early today, killing at least 3 and wounding 17, some of them seriously, officials said.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Putin Presses Chechen Refugees And Vote; RUSSIA: Prosecutors Quiz Oil Magnate; THE HAGUE: Prison Camp Commander Extradited; GREECE: Cabinet Reshuffle; FRANCE: Deputies Approve Pension Bill; FRANCE: Pension For Nazi Collaborator; GERMANY: Jewish Museum Targeted; POLAND: Abortion Boat Sails Away;.

headline: Powell Is Now Pressing Arafat to Combat Hamas
abstract: US Sec of State Colin L Powell, after year of trying to sideline Yasir Arafat, calls on Palestinian leader to enlist security forces under his control to help crush Hamas and other groups held responsible for Jerusalem bus bombing; Bush administration officials have until now been reluctant even to mention Arafat's name, instead investing their hopes in Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas to work with Israel on carrying out peace plan (M)

headline: Swiss Freeze Funds
abstract: The Swiss authorities have frozen about $1.5 million in the bank accounts of two associates of President Charles G. Taylor of Liberia.

headline: A DVD Recorder to Settle Those Thursday Night Fights
abstract: Panasonic DVD recorder can record and play video and display digital pictures in various formats; unit's hard drive can hold up to 12 hours of video; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Soldier's Body Found; Fracas Over West Bank Fence
abstract: Israeli authorities today found the body near an Arab village, and the police called it a "terrorist killing."

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Indonesia: Gas Deal Advances
abstract: Indonesia signs preliminary agreement on liquefied natural gas sales with consortium led by Marathon Oil Corp to supply Mexico and West Coast of United States (S)

headline: Hollywood Producer Makes 2nd Bid for German TV Group
abstract: Haim Saban, whose first bid for bankrupt KirchMedia's German television group, ProSiebenSat.1, collapsed, reportedly revives bid with financing from five wealthy American backers; creditors are set to weigh bid; photo (M)

headline: Postwar Deaths of U.S. Troops in Iraq Exceed Combat Toll
abstract: The number of U.S. soldiers who have died since May 1 has surpassed the number of American deaths in the first stage of the war.

headline: Worry Over a New Conflict for Accounting Firms
abstract: Law intended to ensure independence of auditors has some accountants concerned about new conflict of interest; auditors have been barred from providing information technology, legal, internal audit or bookkeeping services to companies that they audit; firms are advising clients on what are called internal controls, systems of checks and balances to ensure reliable financial reporting and to deter fraud; four biggest accounting firms are all selling such services to their clients; companies want their advice; corporate managers will have to report on their controls to securities regulators as soon as next year; their auditors will be required to assess those controls and say if they are adequate; critics worry that auditors will advise companies on their controls and then end up approving their own work (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Rate Cut
abstract: South Africa's central bank cuts benchmark lending rate by 1 percentage point after inflation slows to 19-month low in June (S)

headline: Report of North Koreans' Claim on Nuclear Rods Appears in South
abstract: North Korea claims to have reprocessed all its spent nuclear fuel rods, a South Korean report said today.

headline: Burlington Made to Order For Investor Seeking a Test
abstract: Wilbur Ross, who recently agreed to pay $620 million for bankrupt Burlington Industries, says company can be viable American company, despite competition from overseas products that is hurting domestic textile industry; is banking that new technology can help dig Burlington out of hole that is swallowing entire American textile industry; photo (M)

headline: Many Went to the Movies When the Lights Came Back
abstract: Movie audiences return to theaters in droves after power failure that knocked out lights and air-conditioners from Cleveland to New York City; box office receipts are up 4 percent from previous weekend; biggest winner is slasher film Freddy vs Jason, but most of previous weekend's new releases also fare well, including Kevin Costner's western drama Open Range and American Splendor (M)

headline: War Budget Request More Realistic but Still Uncertain
abstract: Analysis of Pres Bush's bid for $87 billion for next year for effort to stabilize Iraq and begin reconstruction; notes he has set off fiscal and political aftershocks with admission that earlier expectation of relatively low costs was based on erroneous assumptions that Pentagon would be able to cut military presence quickly and that Iraq was reasonably well developed economically; chronology of administration's statements on cost of war (M)

headline: Postwar G.I. Deaths Now Exceed Toll From War
abstract: Death toll of American troops killed in Iraq since Pres Bush declared end to major combat May 1 rises to 140, compared with 138 killed during war in Mar and Apr; most of soldiers who died during war were killed in combat; only 62 of deaths since May 1 were in combat situations, with 78 classified nonhostile (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lexmark Misses Forecasts; Shares Plunge
abstract: Lexmark International shares plunge after company says it will miss analysts' profit forecasts for third quarter; stock price graph (S)

headline: New Campaigns In Fast-Food Battle
abstract: McDonald's Corp and Wendy's International are introducing new advertising campaigns (M)

headline: LINCOLN NATIONAL SAYS QUARTERLY PROFIT NEARLY TRIPLED
abstract: Lincoln National, Philadelphia-based life insurer that is cutting as many as 1,000 jobs, says second-quarter earnings almost tripled, to $142.7 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: 30 Million Guns
abstract: Peter Batchelor, Small Arms Survey independent research group director, reports there are estimated 30 million small arms in sub-Saharan Africa, not 100 million generally believed; number suggests conventional methods of gun control can succeed in reducing unnecessary firearms (S)

headline: Bring Back 30-Year Bond? No Guide From Greenspan
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan seems inclined toward favoring return of 30-year bond, whose issuance was halted by Treasury in October 2001, but diving what Greenspan means can be difficult because his language is carefully nuanced; price of 10-year note is up 13/32, to 97 20/32; yield falls to 3.92 percent from 3.99 percent; 30-year bond rises 1 9/32, to 107 8/32; yield drops to 4.90 percent from 4.97 percent; chart on key US interest rates (M)

headline: Bomb Explodes Outside U.N. Mission in Iraq, Killing Officer
abstract: The bombing came a month after 23 people died, including the U.N. envoy to Iraq, in a suicide attack on the U.N. compound.

headline: Israeli Envoys Will Sound Out U.S. on West Bank Barrier
abstract: Israel resolved today to test how strongly the Bush administration will resist construction of the West Bank barrier.

headline: Israel Calls Arafat Obstacle to Peace Effort
abstract: Israeli government tries to focus international blame on Yasir Arafat for setbacks in peace efforts; urges European leaders to isolate Arafat and warns that it may eventually arrest or deport him; allies of Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas say Israel must advance peace efforts by making concessions, like releasing large numbers of prisoners; Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon says he is preparing to release 300 prisoners (M)

headline: Big Board Chief Will Get A $140 Million Package
abstract: New York Stock Exchange board discloses that its chairman Richard A Grasso will receive lump-sum payments totaling $140 million in accrued savings and incentives, in addition to base salary of $1.4 million and bonus of at least $1 million; disclosure of compensation--first in exchange's 200-year history--raises new questions about size of Grasso's pay and guaranteed rate of return that investor watchdogs say exchange has applied to his deferred compensation; corporate governance experts say big payout is highly unusual for head of regulatory body; photo (M)

headline: Big Board to Eliminate Rule On Moving to Another Market
abstract: New York Stock Exchange will drop rule that has made it difficult for companies whose shares are listed on exchange to leave it and move to another market, like Nasdaq stock market; rule, known as Rule 500, has long drawn bitter complaint fropm Nasdaq (M)

headline: World Trade Talks End in Failure, Delegates Say
abstract: The talks dissolved when a group of developing nations walked out of the final session, saying wealthy nations had failed to offer sufficient compromises.

headline: In picking a new leader, J. Walter Thompson is pursuing a simple goal: staying relevant.
abstract: J Walter Thompson will name Bob Jeffrey to become chief executive, succeeding Peter A Schweitzer, who will become chairman, post that is now vacant; Schweitzer will also relinquish his duties as worldwide president to Michael Madel, now president for Thompson operations in Europe, Middle East and Africa; Jeffrey, who joined agency five years ago, will become first Thompson chief executive to have spent most of his adveritising career outside agency; photo (M)

headline: Apple Co-Founder Creates Electronic ID Tags
abstract: Stephen Wozniak and his new company, Wheels of Zeus, are set to introduce wireless location-monitoring technology that uses electronic tags to help people keep track of their animals, children or property; company has initial accords with two large American consumer electronics makers to produce first commercial systems based on its technology; Wozniak says simple and inexpensive wireless network uses radio signals and global positioning satellite data to keep track of cluster of inexpensive tags within one- or two-mile radius of each base station, interview; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: AT&T Will Offer Wi-Fi
abstract: AT&T plans to offer wireless Internet access in more than 2,000 locations in fourth quarter, using software from GRIC Communications (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Current Account Grows; SINGAPORE: Economy Slows; INDONESIA: Interest Rate Cut; SOUTH KOREA: New Debt Terms; SOUTH KOREA: Interest Rate Cut;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telecom Profit
abstract: China Mobile (Hong Kong)B

headline: Hong Kong's Chief to Amend Internal Security Legislation
abstract: Hong Kong chief executive Tung Chee-hwa says he will remove or amend several of most controversial provisions of unpopular internal security bill, but not delay legislative consideration of bill; gambles that he can push through bill despite calls for delay by even one of two pro-government parties; bill calls for long jail sentences for people involved in sedition, secession and treason (M)

headline: DIRECTV AND ECHOSTAR SUE TENNESSEE OVER SALES TAXES
abstract: DirecTV Inc and EchoStar Communications Corp sues Tennessee, claiming they are being unfairly taxed more than cable-TV companies; two companies say state places 8.25 percent sales tax on satellite subscribers' bills (S)

headline: After a Hot and Bothered Night, a Trickle of Power and a Forecast of Fitful Service
abstract: Electricity slowly returns to Toronto, Ottawa and other parts of Ontario, but conditions in large sections of province remain far from normal; officials set rolling brownouts to ensure all Toronto residents will have power soon; Mayor Mel Lastman urges public to stay clam, stay home and avoid strenous activities; most residents say first night without lights was uneventful; others complain of major inconveniences; maps and charts of blackouts and power restoration (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Official Faults China And Japan
abstract: South Korean Deputy Finance Min Kwon Tae Shin berates country's two huge regional competitors, China and Japan, for their reluctance to let their currencies float to higher levels for fear of having to increase prices of products on world market (S)

headline: Business People; Next: A Family Book Tour?
abstract: Advertising executive Linda Kaplan Thaler, co-author of book Bang! Getting Your Message Heard in a Noisy World, cites her children's literary achievements; photo (M)

headline: With Hussein as Target, U.S. Launches Dozens of Raids
abstract: U.S. soldiers intensified their search today, detaining more than 175 suspected loyalists to Saddam Hussein.

headline: No Penalties Due for G.I.'s For Killings
abstract: Lt Gen Ricardo Sanchez, commander of allied forces in Iraq, says American soldiers will probably face no penalties for two recent incidents in which they killed at least dozen people who apparently offered little or no resistance; says troops had reason to believe they were facing hostile forces (S)

headline: Ford Names a Finance Chief From Its Ranks
abstract: Ford Motor Co names veteran company executive Don R Leclair as chief financial officer, succeeding James C Gouin (M)

headline: Kraft Plans to Rethink Some Products to Fight Obesity
abstract: Kraft Foods says it will rethink some product lines and introduce steps to help fight worldwide problem of obesity; promises to eliminate in-school marketing to children, introduce smaller portion sizes and develop healthier, more nutritious produces; announcement comes at time when large food companies are being blamed, and even sued, for marketing products that have contributed to growing array of health ills and obesity problems that some experts say is out of control in US; co-chief executive Betsy D Holden comments; photo (M)

headline: Under Fire, F.C.C. Chief Plans Study of Media 'Localism'
abstract: The F.C.C. chairman said a panel will study how media outlets serve their communities, including how many hours stations already devote to local issues.

headline: New Industry In Baghdad: Kidnapping For Ransom
abstract: Iraqi officials report wave of kidnappings in Baghdad by members of Saddam Hussein's security and intelligence services; say kidnappers are well armed and organized, and often use torture techniques similar to those used against political prisoners under old government; say kidnappers seem to have access to information about capital's wealthiest families and have been paid as much as $100,000 in ransom; American officials working with Iraqi police say vast majority of kidnappings are not reported, out of fear or lack of faith in new police force; number of kidnappings over past three months appears to be at least 40 in Baghdad alone; one kidnapping victim describes his ordeal; photo (M)

headline: Europeans Plan Own Military Command Post
abstract: Prime Min Guy Verhofstadt tells meeting of Belgian ambassadors that Belgium will go ahead with plans to build new European military command headquarters near Brussels in 2004 despite opposition from United States and Britain; says headquarters is needed for Europe to plan and execute European operations autonomously (M)

headline: Phnom Penh Journal; Children Scavenge a Life, Of Sorts, in the Garbage
abstract: Hundreds of children, some as young as 7, search through mounds of garbage at dump in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, looking for discarded items to recycle or sell; children toil for about 50 cents a day; it is perilous work; waste is soggy, and huge bulldozers dump pile upon pile as children scavenge; health officials say dump site is extremely treacherous; many of children were born into impoverished families that moved to area from countryside after end of Pol Pot's murderous rule; many others are orphans who lost parents to AIDS, prostitution or drug abuse; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Film Industry Begins Antipiracy Campaign
abstract: Major motion picture companies plan blitz of television ads and movie trailers opposing online piracy as theat to film industry jobs (S)

headline: A Controller Grows, Making Room For a Keyboard
abstract: Logitech offers Netplay Controller for PlayStation 2, which includes keyboard as well as standard game controllers; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Buffalo; A City Shakes Off Its Rust-Belt Image
abstract: Advice for business travelers on places to stay, eat and visit in Buffalo, NY; photo (M)

headline: Iranians Divided on Nuclear Inspection Issue
abstract: Tension among political groups is intensifying over whether Iran will allow more aggressive inspections of its nuclear sites.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Cuts Forecast
abstract: South Korea's Hana Bank estimates its n4

headline: Reykjavik Journal; Drop That Harpoon! Whale Hostilities Revisited
abstract: After 14-year hiatus, Icelandic whale hunters bag their first whale as part of new scientific research program that falls outside 1986 ban on commercial whaling; photos (M)

headline: Merrill Lynch Plans to Rehire Recently Departed Executive
abstract: Seeking to rebuild its senior management, Merrill Lynch is expected to rehire Robert J. McCann to oversee its brokerage and money-management businesses.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Contractor Cuts Loss
abstract: BAE Systems reports loss of 47 million pounds ($74.9 million) for first six months of 2003 compared with loss of 63 million pounds ($100.4 million) in year-earlier period; chief executive Mike Turner expects earnings over all will be flat in 2003; photo (S)m

headline: Bali Bomber Is Sentenced To Life Term
abstract: Indonesian court sentences Islamic militant Ali Imron to life imprisonment for his role in Bali bombings, which last year killed 202 people, many of them tourists; he is alleged member of Indonesian-based group Jemaah Islamiyah, and is only defedant who appears in court to express remorse; defendants Imam Samudra and Amrozi bin Nurhasyim were sentenced to death last month (M)

headline: Rebels Push Toward the Heart of the Capital in Liberia
abstract: Rebels advance swiftly into Monrovia, Liberia, shelling buildings, firing bullets and sending streams of civilians searching for safety where there is none; fighting continues for control of two bridges leading to city's main commercial artery; injured trickle into makeshift clinics run by international aid groups; rebels are frustrated with Pres Charles Taylor's promises to step aside and Pres Bush's so-far unfulfilled pledge to play active role in bringing stability; Taylor is urging his fighters to defend city and vows to remain until peacekeepers arrive; accuses US of failing to assist him in providing adequate protection for people; American Amb John W Blaney calls on rebels to stop advancing and participate in peace talks in Ghana; angry civilians, who feel they have nothing left to lose, are confronting government militias and demanding peace and end to looting; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Reform Vetoed
abstract: Turkish President Ahmet Necdet Sezer vetoes legislation that would give more freedom for Kurds to express themselves and their separatist views; photo (S)

headline: Shenyang Journal; The G.I.'s Were Japan's Worker Slaves. Believe It.
abstract: Three American prisoners of war who became slave laborers for Japan during World War II revisit prison site in Shenyang, China; about 1,500 Allied prisoners endured forced labor, sub-zero temperatures and what they claim was Japanese-administered germ warfare program that used them as guinea pigs; three have returned, in part, because they do not want this brutal chapter of history to be forgotten; talks are under way with Chinese officials to preserve remains of prison camp to build museum; photo; map (M)

headline: Preparing for 'Tell Us About Yourself'
abstract: Job Recruiters offer advice on making successful job interview; photo (M)

abstract: World Business Briefing:

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia:Tobacco Profit Falls
abstract: Hanjaya

headline: Vivendi Is Said to Get 2 Bids for U.S. Units
abstract: Investor group led by Edgar Bronfman Jr that includes Cablevision Systems and by Liberty Media bid for Vivendi Universal's American entertainment assets; NBC, division of General Electric, is also still interested in Vivendi's entertainment assets although it does not make formal offer (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel's Net Income More Than Doubles
abstract: Nextel Communications raises its 2003 profit forecast, after second-quarter income more than doubled on rising demand for its walkie-talkie service; net income was $309 million compared with $123 million year ago; sales rose 19 percent to $2.56 billion (S)

headline: Investor Drops Out of Bidding for British Retailer
abstract: Aletheia Partners drops out of bidding for British department store chain Selfridges, clearing way for Galen Weston to buy it; Weston has submitted bid valuing comany at 598 million pounds ($997 million) (S)

headline: Grocers' Strategy: Be What Wal-Mart Is Not
abstract: Many supermarket chains across country are trying to counter Wal-Mart's entrance into their markets by offering services and products Wal-Mart does not; Bill Breetz Jr, longtime grocer who runs Southwest for Kroger Co, says strategy at Highland Park store in Dallas is to be anti-Wal-Mart, with formula that combines deep selection of luxury foodstuffs with high level of service in upscale setting; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Senate Approves Repeal Of New Media Regulations  The Senate approved a resolution to repeal all of the new regulations that would make it easier for the nation's largest media companies to grow bigger.    By a vote of 55 to 40, the Republican-controlled Senate defied the White House and issued a stinging political rebuke of Michael K. Powell, the Republican chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and architect of the rules. [Page A1.]

headline: Korean Steel Maker Finds Strength in Flexibility
abstract: Profile of Posco (Pohang Iron and Steel Co) of South Korea, model of efficiency and one of world's most profitablle steel makers; company must remain agile because South Korea's market is virtually wide open, with essentially no import barriers; has invested heavily in computerization and customer service, sharply cutting average inventories of finished steel and delivery lead time; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Hundreds Arrested In Protests
abstract: Chinese police have arrested wealthy businessman Zhou Zhengyi after months of investigation into $240 million in questionable loans he was given from state-run Bank of China in Shanghai (S)

headline: 6 Held in Iraq By U.S. Claim To Be American
abstract: Brig Gen Janis Karpinski says six people identifying selves as Americans and two saying they are British are among 4,400 'security detainees' being held in connection with guerrilla attacks on allied forces in Iraq; says classification means they have fewer rights than prisoners of war; makes remark during tour of Abu Ghraib prison, outside Baghdad, where they are among some 10,000 prisoners; Sec Donald Rumsfeld and other officials say there is little certainty about men's identities, nationalities or even what they were doing in Iraq; military reports scattered attacks on occupying forces; Khaldiya's small and beleaguered police department vows to stay on duty despite slaying of new chief Col Khudheir Mikhlif Ali; photos (M)

headline: Supercomputing's New Idea Is Old One
abstract: Scientists in government, industry and academia are reviving late Seymour Cray's elegant approach to building ultra-fast computers; Burton J Smith, founder of Tera, which bought original Cray Research in 2000, has become industry's leading champion of Cray's design philosophy; Cray's custom machines are known as vector supercomputers and have special hardware intended to handle long strings of numbers in complex scientific computing problems; had been largely replaced by massively parallel processors, designs based on linking thousands of inexpensive, mass-produced microprocessors; such MMP machines are now proving to have limits; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nasdaq Composite Index Hits Highest Level in a Year  Investors bought stocks aggressively, pushing the Nasdaq composite index to its highest level in more than a year. The index gained 57.25 points, or 3.4 percent, to close at 1,720.71.    Other major gauges also posted strong gains, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rising above 1,000 and the Dow Jones industrial average increasing 146.58 points. The rally came on a day with little economic, corporate or political news, leaving traders and strategists pointing to rumors and obscure data points to explain the gains. [Page C9.]

headline: On a Plasma TV Screen, Ghosts of Images Past
abstract: Q. I'm thinking of buying a flat-screen plasma TV but recently heard that the screens are prone to ''burn-in'' static images. How concerned should I be? Are there differences between plasma TV's?    A. With their large, flat screens, vibrant colors and thinness, which allows them to be hung on walls, plasma televisions have edged further into the home-theater market. Unlike flat-screen televisions that use liquid-crystal-display technology to provide the high-resolution picture on the screen, plasma television screens are subject to a burn-in effect if a stationary image is displayed in the same place on the screen too often or for too long.
