abstract: Tens of thousands of people

headline: Evolution of an African Republic
abstract: Liberia's history noted; nation, Africa's first independent republic, was formed to repatriate free blacks from United States (S)

headline: Tokyo Journal; At Long Last, the Salarymen Are Given Their Due
abstract: Millions of Japanese watch television series Project X: Challengers, which documents technological and other innovations of common Japanese salarymen; each advance recalls age when values went unquestioned; in Japan, country groping its way out of long economic malaise, program illuminates recent past when all seemed possible, inspiring feelings of validation and nostalgia among older Japanese, envy and desire among some younger ones; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Algerian Held In Bomb Plot
abstract: Hamburg (Germany) police arrest Algerian man Abderrazak M, who was allegedly planning to bomb resorts around Costa del Sol (Spain) (S)

headline: 3 G.I.'s Killed in Ambush in Iraq
abstract: Three soldiers with Army's 101st Airborne Div are killed in ambush in Qaiyara, Iraq; local resident says insurgents were armed with rocket-propelled grenades and Kalashnikov assault rifles; ambush undermines hopes that killing of Saddam Hussein's two sons would weaken resistance to American forces; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: World Church Group Wants U.S. Out
abstract: World Council of Churches, meeting in Geneva (Switzerland), urges American and coalition forces to withdraw from Iraq, turn over control to United Nations and pay reparations to Iraqi people for war damage to country (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airlines Post Profits
abstract: Korean Air reports second-quarter profit of 90.6 billion won, down 81 percent from second quarter of last year; Asiana, South Korea's second airline, reports net income of 34.7 billion won for quarter, compared with 34.5 billion won a year earlier (S)

headline: Midseason at the Movies
abstract: Second half of summer's film season opens with box-office total nearly 2 percent below midway total last summer, which was most successful movie summer ever; graphs of box-office revenues and top-grossing films; photo (S)

headline: Find Brass Frames Too Boring? Try a Razzle-Dazzle Exhibition
abstract: Micro Research Institute software creates three-dimensional virtual gallery for digital photos, allowing users to format and display their work in exhibition-type setting; photo (M)

headline: New Study Links Hormones to Breast Cancer Risk
abstract: Study of one million British women finds higher death rate from breast cancer among those who took combination hormone therapy than those who did not use it or took estrogen alone; study is largest so far to determine effects of hormones on breast cancer; results build on compelling evidence from United States that risks of invasive breast cancer from combination hormone therapy are greater than many doctors had predicted; British study finds risk of developing breast cancer roughly doubles for women taking estrogen-progestin hormone combination compared with those not taking hormones; for those taking only estrogen, increased risk is 30 percent; finds no evidence for belief of some proponents of hormone therapy that using patch to deliver hormone is safer than pills; questions about safety of combination progestin and estrogen hormones for short-term use to treat symptoms that plague women at menopause may not be resolved until American study is completed in two years; British study is printed in journal The Lancet (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WHIRLPOOL CORP., Benton Harbor, Mich., the nation's largest appliance maker, said it had bought 10 percent of Alno, Pfullendorf, Germany, a maker of kitchen furniture, as part of a deal that involved Whirlpool's selling its Casawell Service furniture business to Alno. Terms were not disclosed.    TETRA TECH INC., Pasadena, Calif., a provider of engineering and technical services, said it had received a one-year $65 million contract from the United States military to check captured munitions and destroy selected items as part of the revitalization plan for postwar Iraq.

headline: American Cars Show Gains In a Survey of Dependability
abstract: J P Power & Associates' survey of auto dependability finds Toyota's luxury brand Lexus has fewest problems; Lexus owners in survey reported 163 problems per 100 vehicles, versus industry average of 273; Nissan's luxury brand Infiniti comes in second and Buick brand of General Motors Corp third; Chrysler and Dodge brands outperform Mercedes-Benz, which in turn only narrowly edges out Chrysler's Jeep brand; Japanese automakers continue to lead in durability; Porsche is among industry's best, and BMW and Jaguar division of Ford Motor Co are better than average, as is GM's Saab division; Volkswagen and its Audi division continue to have quality problems; charts; photos (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Table of Americans Defense Department confirms as newly killed in Iraq

headline: Islamic Traditionalists Sweep Liberals in Kuwaiti Election
abstract: Islamic traditionalists, both Sunni and Shiite, take more than third of seats in Kuwait's 50-seat Parliament in weekend elections; voting is stunning setback for Kuwaiti liberals hopeful that downfall of Saddam Hussein would strengthen their efforts at modernization; liberals had made extending vote to women a major rallying cry; several of most prominent liberal figures lose their seats; one spokesman for traditionalists accuses liberals of trying to Westernize Kuwait society; photo (M)

headline: C.I.A. Says bin Laden Tape Is Likely Authentic
abstract: CIA says audiotaped message broadcast by Al Jazeera was probably recorded by Osama bin Laden; Al Jazeera broadcasts videotape of man it says was one of 9/11 hijackers, Saeed Alghamdi, and it pictures him reading his will and saying it is Muslim's duty to fight 'American enemy' (M)

headline: A Shadowy Kind of War Still Grips Liberia's Countryside
abstract: Thousands of Liberians continue to flee sounds of gunfire and rumors of war in countryside; some 750,000 of nation's three million people have been driven from their homes, some many times over; none of new refugees say they have seen real clashes in past three days; all say they saw government militias retreating before their rebel counterparts; both sides use sounds of war to drive people from their homes and steal what they leave; refugees must choose between Monrovia, where there is food but little space, and refugee camps, where there is space but little food; map; photo (M)

headline: On the Scent of Natural Remedies
abstract: I HAVE lived in Northern California for a year now.  So I believe it's perfectly normal to live around the corner from a shoe store that doubles as an art gallery and exhibits oil paintings alongside the Dansko clogs.     I blithely walk my first grader to school past storefronts with signs that say ''traditional Thai massage,'' ''mineral makeup'' and ''Angel of Healing.''

headline: J. P. Morgan Selected to Run New Trade Bank in Iraq
abstract: J P Morgan is chosen to operate bank US is creating in Iraq to manage billions of dollars to finance imports and exports; will lead group that includes 13 banks representing 13 countries; operating Trade Bank of Iraq wil give banks access to Iraq's financial system; bank will start with $5 billion in cash and $95 million line of credit from fund controlling Iraqi oil revenue operated under auspices of United Nations

headline: Sears Plans to Sell National Tire and Battery for $260 Million
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co will sell its chain of National Tire and Battery service centers to TBC Corp for $260 million; deal does not involve more than 800 Sears Auto Centers that are adjacent to Sears department stores (M)

headline: McCann Executive To Become Consultant
abstract: Hank Wasiak, vice chairman at McCann-Erickson World Group, is leaving to become consultant at Concept Farm, where his son is partner and co-owner (S)

headline: PEOPLESOFT BUYS REMAINING SHARES OF J. D. EDWARDS
abstract: PeopleSoft buys all remaining shares of J D Edwards not tendered in its exchange offer (S)

headline: Palestinians Allow Militants to Stay in Arafat's Compound
abstract: Palestinian officials back away from attempt to arrest Palestinian militants holed up in Yasir Arafat's West Bank compound; decision eases stalemate with militants, who refused to cooperate, but it prompts Israel to accuse governing Palestinian Authority of buckling to terrorists; most militants are members of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, violent offshoot of Arafat's mainstraem Fatah faction; Palestinian officials are urging Israel to pull its forces out of Ramallah and other West Bank cities, in compliance with international peace plan; Israel says Palestinian Authority must first comply with its own obligation under plan to begin collecting illegal weapons and take other steps against militants; photo (M)

headline: Path to Ballot to Oust Chávez Set by Court
abstract: Venezuela's Supreme Court appoints provisional elections board to organize recall referendum that could end presidency of Hugo Chavez in as little as 90 days; government opponents intent on ousting him consider Supreme Court their last option (S)

headline: Full Disclosure, or Not
abstract: Michael S Josephson letter on obligation of political leaders to tell the truth (Aug 17 Jeffery L Seglin column)

headline: Federal Work Ban Is Possible for Qwest
abstract: Qwest Communications International, already investigated for overstating sales by more than $2 billion, says government is considering banning it from federal contracts; says inspector general of General Services Administration has recommended that agency consider disbarment (S)

headline: Events of Mahmoud Abbas's Tenure
abstract: Key events of Mahmoud Abbas's tenure as prime minister.

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: Blair Aide Says Arms Expert Agreed With Britain on Iraq
abstract: Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon said today that Dr. David Kelly told him he supported the government's position on war with Iraq.

headline: A. O. SMITH SHARES FALL ON PROFIT WARNING
abstract: A O Smith Corp cuts its profit forecasts for third quarter and 2003, setting off 14 percent decline in its share price (S)

headline: Hong Kong Protest Movement Pauses to Weigh Its Next Steps
abstract: Leaders of protest movement in Hong Kong, divided over what goals to pursue next and how, are leaning toward not holding any more large rallies until near end of year unless government takes strong action to limit civil liberties before then (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Suspects Tied To Hotel Bombing
abstract: Mombasa (Kenya) police report one of two suspected terrorists arrested last week has been transfered to Nairobi for more questioning regarding involvement in hotel bombing last November; other suspect was killed, along with one police officer, when he detonated grenade in police van (S)

headline: BP SOLVAY POLYETHYLENE TO CLOSE TEXAS PLANT
abstract: BP Solvay Polyethylene North America, plastics maker that is joint venture of BP of Britain and Solvay of Belgium, is closing Deer Park, Tex, plant that makes polyethylene to replace it with cheaper production from new factory in Cedar Bayou, also in Texas (S)

headline: Will 25 be too many at EU's new table?
abstract: BRUSSELS—  The European Union's headquarters here was a hive of activity during the normally languid summer months. Workers tore down walls, laid cable and assembled furniture — literally making space for the 10 countries set to join the European Union in May.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: DOLLAR SLIDES. The dollar declined against the euro after a government report showed the United States lost jobs for a seventh consecutive month. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1109, up from $1.0923 on Thursday.

headline: Loral Files for Bankruptcy; Boeing to Take $1.1 Billion Charge
abstract: Two leading satellite manufacturers weakened by a long slump in new orders swallowed bitter financial medicine today.

headline: Trade in Mahogany Is Threat to Amazon
abstract: A murky multimillion-dollar trade in mahogany in Peru's rain forest is whittling away the Amazon, endangering isolated indigenous groups and threatening the commercial future of an ever scarce tree, officials and environmental groups say.

headline: For Spiriting Away Spy Files, A Watch With Hidden Depths
abstract: ThinkGeek distributes Laks watch, which offers memory storage; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: McData To Acquire 2 Companies
abstract: Shares in McData Corp fall nearly 18 percent after company says sales this quarter will miss forecasts; will pay about $83 million in cash and assume $2 million in debt to acquire Nishan Systems and will pay about $102 million for Sanera Systems; graph (S)

headline: Leap Wireless Opens Review on Account
abstract: Leap Wireless International begins review for agency of record on its ad account, which has been handled by Johnson Group in Chattanooga, Tenn (S)

headline: Oxford Investigates Scientist Who Denied Israeli Application
abstract: Andrew Wilkie, geneticist at Oxford University, is investigated for violating antidiscrimination rules in rejecting Israeli scholar's job application because of disagreement with Israeli policies on Palestinians; Wilkie apologizes to Amit Duvshani after deluge of messages from scientists around world (M)

headline: In Defense of a Squawk
abstract: To the Editor:     Re ''Muting the Squawk in a Modem Mating Call'' (Q&A, July 10): That modem mating call is the sweetest in the world.

headline: Few Gold Stars In the Workplace
abstract: Diary column notes that only ten percent of 1,002 employed adults surveyed this summer say supervisors have thanked them daily for job well done (S)

headline: Looking for Calm, Merrill Rehires Popular Executive
abstract: Merrill Lynch moves to repair damage from its latest burst of management turmoil by rehiring Robert J McCann as vice chairman overseeing its brokerage and money-management operations; McCann, who left five months ago and joined Axa Financial in June, will rank second only to chairman-chief executive E Stanley O'Neal; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Investment
abstract: French bank BNP Paribas invests additional $23.8 million in South Korea's Shinhan Financial to maintain its 4 percent stake (S)

headline: Fox Plays Terminator, Ending Schwarzenegger Movie Puns
abstract: Fox News Channel, known for its irreverent graphics and packaging, orders staff to avoid puns about Arnold Schwarzenegger's movies in coverage of California gubernatorial recall campaign; holds puns belittle his candidacy and are not fair and balanced (M)

headline: U.S. Official Tells Iraqis To Assert More Authority
abstract: American administrator L Paul Bremer 3d is said to hold tense meeting with 25-member Iraqi Governing Council, demanding that it exert more authority, communicate better with Iraqi people and strongly condemn bombing of United Nations headquarters in Baghdad; confrontation reflects growing American conviction that greater and more visible Iraqi involvement in government might allay some hostility to American-led occupation; Iraqi officials say council responded by telling Bremer it lacks authority to convince Iraqis it is effective or relevant; political tensions surface as American FBI agents combing scene of bombing say flatbed truck used in attack carried about 1,500 pounds of explosives, including 500-pound Soviet-made bomb; note that flatbed truck was also used in bombing attack on Jordanian Embassy earlier this month; photo (M)

headline: China Pushes North Korea And U.S. Talks
abstract: China steps up its efforts to broker negotiations between United States and North Korea, dispatching senior diplomat to Washington and urging both sides to revive discarded 1994 accord on ending North's nuclear program; some Bush administration officials reject possibility of reviving 1994 accord, saying it amounts to blackmail; China's unusual public campaign suggests it intends to play more assertive mediating role in new round of talks; Secretary of State Colin L Powell says US is open to discussions with North Korea and that he expects reopening of diplomatic channel very soon (M)

headline: Islamic Cleric Gets Mixed Verdict In Indonesian Trial for Terrorism
abstract: Indonesian court acquits radical Islamic cleric Abu Bakar Bashir of charges he ordered series of terrorist attacks in Indonesia and plotted to assassinate Indonesian president; finds prosecutors failed to prove that he heads Jemaah Islamiyah, Al Qaeda affiliate; finds him guilty of aiding and abetting treason, apparently based on his support of group's goal to establish Islamic state, and of minor immigration violations; sentences him to four years in prison; he plans appeal; verdict is serious setback for Bush administration, Australia and regional governments; will reinforce view of many Indonesians, including senior political leaders, that United States has exaggerated Indonesia's terrorism problem; most Indonesians, who are moderate Muslims, see drive against terrorism as war on Islam; photo (M)

headline: As Factory Jobs Disappear, Ohio Town Has Few Options
abstract: Canton, Ohio, long booming industrial center, has been so hard-hit by loss of factory jobs that many workers are losing hope; many of unemployed are reluctantly turning to less steady or lower-paying jobs; laid-off workers comment; photos (M)3

headline: Sure-Fire Morning Wreckers: Green Eggs and Spam
abstract: Survey by McAfee Security finds nearly half of Americans spend more than 40 minutes per week deleting 'spam' e-mail; graphs (S)

headline: Accusations Against MCI Could Drive Clients Away
abstract: Industry consultants says charges that MCI used fraudulent methods to reduce access fees it pays to other phone companies could make it harder for MCI to keep some of its current customers and sign up new ones; charges are raising new questions about reliability of financial data and projections MCI is giving creditors and bankruptcy court overseeing its reorganization; court approves settlement by which MCI, still technically named WorldCom, agrees to pay Verizon $60 million to resolve fee disputes; timeline and photos of MCI's chief executives (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Standard Microsystems Raises Forecast
abstract: Standard Microsystems Corp, which designs semiconductors for personal computers, raises its forecast for 2004 profit as sales of personal computers, neworking and mobile products improve (S)

headline: Incomes Fall for Top 1%
abstract: The incomes of the richest Americans fell 18 percent in 2001, and the resulting decline in their tax payments cost the government $66 billion in revenue. Page C1.

headline: WorldCom Agrees to Pay $750 Million In S.E.C. Suit
abstract: Federal Judge Jed S Rakoff approves agreement for WorldCom to pay $750 million to settle accounting fraud lawsuit by Securities and Exchange Commission; ruling ends monetary phase of complex suit, which is unfolding in tandem with WorldCom's bankruptcy proceedings in another federal court in New York; deal reflects WorldCom's agreement to $2.25 billion penalty, but settlement assumes that actual payment will be reduced as part of WorldCom's proposed reorganization in bankruptcy (M)

headline: Israel Relaxes Amnesty Policy On Palestinians
abstract: Israel backs away from demand that Palestinian authorities jail wanted terrorists, accepting in principle Prime Min Muhammad Dahlan's assurances that he will monitor whereabouts and prevent them from mounting attacks; Bush administration signals acceptance for now of milder approach, which Palestinian officials say clears way for effective amnesty for those who renounce violence; final agreement would be major shift in static negotiating postures; Israeli concession was crucial to Dahlan's acceptance of plan for Israel to give Palestinians back policing duties for Jericho and Qalqilya (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: F.T.C. Chief Doubtful Of Antispam Legislation
abstract: Federal Trade Commission chairman Timothy J Muris says he is skeptical that several federal legislative proposals to reduce growing flood of unsolicited e-messages can be successful; says efforts in Congress miss mark in addressing what he calls daunting consumer-protection problem (S)

headline: Bremer Is Upbeat on Sunday News Programs
abstract: International Herald Tribune.

headline: British Soldier Is Killed in Clash With a Mob in Southern Iraq
abstract: British soldier is killed and another wounded when their convoy encounters angry mob of Iraqis blocking road in Ali as-Sharqi in southern Iraq as they return to base after arresting two suspected loyalists of Saddam Hussein; British troops arrest eight people in connection with shooting (M)

headline: Stock Offerings Planned
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Retailer's Sales Rise
abstract: Retailer Woolworths Ltd reports record Jan-June sales of 26.3 billion Australian dollars ($17 billion), up 12.2 percent on adjusted basis; photo (S)

headline: LINCOLN NATIONAL TO CUT AS MANY AS 1,000 JOBS
abstract: Lincoln National Corp, life insurer, says it will cut up to 1,000 jobs, about 17 percent of its work force, after combining its life insurance and annuities businesses (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Once Scorned, Now Mayor
abstract: Tuam (Ireland) Town Council selects Martin Ward, who was once Traveler, also known as tinker, to serve as mayor; he is first mayor appointed from this nomadic ethnic group (S)

headline: New case not viewed as harbinger of massive outbreak : Experts see less SARS danger
abstract: PARIS:—  Singapore's reports of the first confirmed SARS case since May has placed governments in Asia on high alert, but experts at the World Health Organization say that a massive resurgence of the disease is unlikely.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: HOT, HOTTER, HOTTEST; BELGIUM: People Smugglers Sentenced;.

headline: Clear Channel To Begin Tie-In To Restaurant
abstract: Clear Channel Communications, nation's largest radio station owner, has licensed name of Minnesota sports radio station to start KFAN the Restaurant, Roseville, Minn; restaurant, set to open by early Dec, will be first of what may become many tied to Clear Channel stations throughout United States; will offer patrons sports and music programming from company's seven area radio stations; is owned by Grand Management, which will pay Clear Channel 5 percent of sales and get back half of amount in form of advertising time (M)

headline: Archbishop of Canterbury Acts to Prevent Rift on Gay Bishop
abstract: The spiritual leader of the world's 79 million Anglican Christians will convene a meeting of Church leaders to try to avert a formal schism over the confirmation of a gay bishop.

headline: U.S. Resists Entreaties to Send Peacekeepers to Liberia
abstract: Bush administration resists pleas from UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan and West African countries to send troops to Liberia as fighting there intensifies; US says Liberia's neighbors should act first and calls on rebels and Pres Charles Taylor's government to respect cease-fire; photos of Annan and Sec Donald Rumsfeld (M)

headline: Next Reality Show: Airline!
abstract: Southwest Airlines' operations, from ticket counter to baggage claims to cockpit, will be focus of 10-part series on A&E Network called Airline (S)

headline: I.R.S. Inquiry Creates Anxiety in Synthetic Fuel Industry
abstract: Internal Revenue Service review of tax credits for synthetic fuels industry may result in rescission of billions of dollars in credits claimed by plant owners and investors; at issue is whether companies' processes involve significant chemical change, as required by 1980 Federal law that established tax credit program; review could result in IRS not only declining to grant future credits but revoking past credits; Progress Energy, which is among largest synthetic fuel producers, has generated nearly $1 billion in tax credits since it entered business in 1988 (M)

headline: Road Rules for Recovering Alcoholics
abstract: Article on various programs avaiable to business travelers who are recovering alcoholics; photo (M)

headline: Janus Plans To Reimburse Shareholders
abstract: Janus Capital Group, mutual fund manager accused by New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer of letting hedge fund Canary Capital Partners LLC make short-term trades in exchange for fees and deposits in longer-term accounts, says it will make restitution to shareholders hurt by such abuses; will also pay shareholders in affected funds all fees it got from market-timing activities; says up to $750 million in assets may have been invested by market timers in Janus funds in 2002 and 2003; chief executive Mark Whiston apologizes (M)

headline: W.T.O. Rules U.S. Tariffs on Steel Imports Are Illegal
abstract: The World Trade Organization's decision was greeted by defiant statements from both sides in the dispute, and threatens to overshadow next month's trade meeting.

headline: Ex-Managers at Bank May Face Charges
abstract: Bank of America has been notified that Securities and Exchange Commission and New York Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer are considering bringing cases against former employees of bank later this week; potential charges relate to bank's activities in connection with Canary Capital Partners, hedge fund managed by Edward J Stern (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Interest Policy Defended
abstract: Bank of Japan governor Toshihiko Fukui defends bank's zero-interest policy; says bank will keep rates low until consumer prices rise; photo (S)

headline: With Hussein's Heirs Gone, Hopes Rise for End to Attacks
abstract: Deaths of Saddam Hussein's sons Uday and Qusay in battle with US troops in Mosul could be important victory in effort to control guerrilla attacks in Iraq, particularly if Iraqis are emboldened to come forward; raid also raises hopes for tightening noose around Hussein himself and learning more about possible hiding places; Mosul house was so heavily fortified it took missiles to blast it open; US has conducted hundreds of raids recently to confiscate huge caches of weapons and money, gold and jewels intended to finance long-term resistance; Lt Gen Ricardo Sanchez notes importance of proving deaths to Iraqis and Arab world; his photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises as some investors say its recent drop against euro reflects too much pessimism about outlook for economy; euro settles at $1.1216, down from $1.1235 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: HUGE SUICIDE BLAST DEMOLISHES U.N. HEADQUARTERS IN BAGHDAD; TOP AID OFFICIALS AMONG 17 DEAD
abstract: Suicide bomber drives cement mixer full of explosives into side of United Nations compound in Baghdad, Iraq, blowing it up, killing 17 people and wounding at least 100; compound was filled with hundreds of people responsible for array of relief and reconstruction duties; among dead are top UN officials, including Sergio Vieira de Mello, secretary general's special representative in Iraq, whose office was just above site of impact; bombing is apparently calculated to destroy any sense of security for people charged with reviving Iraq in aftermath of war; also seems intended to intensify guerrilla war under way against American soldiers and to increase domestic pressure on Pres Bush, who faces growing unhappiness about course of American occupation; speculation about who carried out attack ranges across wide spectrum of possibilities, but immediate focus of attention is on Ansar al-Islam, militant Islamic group suspected of plotting attacks against Western targets in Baghdad; photos; map; drawings (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New Scrutiny for Liberty Media's Starz Deal
abstract: Liberty Media's acquisition in March of about half of 10 pecent stake in cable network company Starz Encore Group owned by John J Sie for cash and stock valued at $275 million is being questioned by analysts; Liberty on Sept 10 gave investors and Wall Street surprise by saying Starz Encore was facing possibility of big cost increases in 2004 because payments to Hollywood studios will probably rise; increases are possible result of contract dispute with Comcast Corp; dispute, which is subject of lawsuit filed by Comcast against Starz Encore, could result in Starz Encore's having to pick up bigger share of Hollywood fees by itself; projected cost increase, which could be as high as $225 million, has led some analysts to cut their 2004 projections for Starz Encore's operating cash flow by nearly 50 percent; graph; photo of Liberty Media owner John C Malone (M)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: Dept of Defense identifies two American service members who died in Iraq (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Adaptec Says Quarterly Sales Missed Forecast
abstract: Adaptec says first-quarter sales in quarter ended June 30 were about $107 million, less than $115 million to $120 million company had forecast (S)

headline: Hamas Placed On Terror List By Europeans
abstract: European Union foreign ministers decide to officially declare all wings of militant Palestinian group Hamas terrorist organization and freeze its assets; decision is prompted by suicide bombing in Jerusalem in August that killed 22 people; photo (M)

headline: G.A.O. Faults Cost Estimates On Boeing-Air Force Jet Lease
abstract: General Accounting Office official Neil Curtain tells House committee Air Force plan to lease 100 Boeing 767's for use as aerial refueling tankers will cost $173 million per plane, not $138 million Air Force estimates; questions why Air Force agreed to 15 percent profit margin on deal, citing 6 percent margin on planes sold for commercial use; Boeing chief executive Philip M Condit tells stock analysts he expects program to win approval; Boeing reports second-quarter net loss of $192 million, compared with year-earlier net income of $779 million; cuts its 2004 sales and earnings estimates; photo (M)

headline: China Moves Troops to Area Bordering North Korea
abstract: China sends soldiers to replace police along country's border with North Korea, to defend 870-mile-long frontier that is often violated by hungry refugees from North; move marks subtle but significant change in relations between two Communist nations; it comes as China exerts new pressure on North to abandon its nuclear weaopns program and is serving as main sponsor of negotiations involving North Korea, United States and three other countries (M)

headline: Language of Experience
abstract: The Boss interview with David Heleniak, senior partner of Shearman & Sterling law firm; photo (S)

headline: House Approves AIDS Bill
abstract: House approves measure that would bring spending on global AIDS to $2 billion in 2004, $1 billion short of what was promised in bill Pres Bush signed in May; two amendments proposed by Democrats to increase financing are defeated (S)

headline: Zimbabwe Police Close Down Nation's Largest Daily Paper
abstract: Zimbabwe police shut down major newspaper, Daily News, after court rules paper has been publishing illegally; action silences one of few independent news outlets (S)

headline: U.S. Says Shot Fired at Hotel Was Justified
abstract: American military inquiry into shelling that killed two foreign journalists at Palestine Hotel, Baghdad, in April finds troops were justified in firing at what they had reason to believe was enemy position; cameramen killed, Taras Protsyuk and Jose Couso, had been filming fighting from hotel balconies (M)

headline: Lehman to Acquire Neuberger Berman in a Bid to Diversify
abstract: Lehman Brothers announced that it would acquire Neuberger Berman, a money management firm catering to wealthy individuals, in a deal valued at $2.625 billion.

headline: British Panel Clears Blair of Charges of Doctoring Iraq Data
abstract: A committee said the report resulted in Prime Minister Tony Blair's unknowingly misinforming the House of Commons on reasons for going to war.

headline: Fire Breaks Out at Top of Eiffel Tower
abstract: The fire tonight sent brown smoke from the tower's topmost observation deck and tourists scurrying to descend.

headline: Liberty Media Won't Bid on Vivendi Assets
abstract: Liberty Media Corp withdraws from bidding for Vivendi Universal's entertainment assets; NBC unit of General Electric is believed to have inside track in bidding (M)

headline: S.E.C. Passes Rule Changes For Options
abstract: Companies trading on New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq must obtain shareholder approval before granting stock options and other equity compensation under rules approved by Securities and Exchange Commission; changes are made to listing for more than 6,200 companies; SEC chairman William H Donaldson comments (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Debt Extension
abstract: Irish drug maker Elan Corp pays debtholders $2.1 million to waive right to early repayment of as much as $2 billion in debt (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: KENYA: Suspects Tied To Hotel Bombing; ZAMBIA: More Charges For Ex-Leader;.

headline: Blair Denies He Gave Name Of Arms Aide To the Media
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair denies that he approved making public name of weapons inspector David Kelly in running battle between his government and BBC; Kelly died last week, an apparent suicide; his name was disclosed to British newspapers earlier this month by Defense Ministry, where he had worked, as likely source for BBC report saying one of Blair's top aides had 'sexed up' intelligence dossier to overcome public doubts about military action in Iraq; Kelly had confided to officials that he had met with BBC reporter but disagreed with reporter's version of their talk; Kelly underwent humiliating round of questioning in televised hearings before House of Commons on July 15, and two days later he was reported missing; formal judicial inquiry is to begin next week (M)

headline: Grasso's Deal Is Said to Save $3.5 Million, Despite Payout
abstract: New York Stock Exchange will save as much as $3.5 million this year by renegotiating contract with Richard A Grasso; savings is significant for exchange, which made $28 million last year; board last week disclosed that it would pay Grasso lump sum of $140 million in accrued savings and incentives, in addition to base salary of $1.4 million and bonus of at least $1 million; exchange's directors say that by ending old contract exchange would save on interest it would have owed Grasso through 2005, when contract would have expired; savings amounted to $3.5 million for this year (M)

headline: COACH LEATHER RAISES FORECASTS FOR FIRST QUARTER
abstract: Coach, luxury leather goods retailer, raises its forecast for its first-quarter earnings and revenue (S)

headline: A Resignation at Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft Corp's senior vice president Richard Emerson resigns; no replacement will be named (S)

headline: Shares Drop as Euro Disney Warns It Is Low on Cash
abstract: Shares of Euro Disney fall 61 cents, or 11 percent, after company warns it may not be able to pay debts owed to banks and to Walt Disney Co; says overall revenue in fiscal third quarter ended June 30 was 275.6 million euros ($309.8 million), down 7 percent from 297.3 million euros ($334.2 million) year earlier; revenue for first three fiscal quarters was 748.2 million euros ($841 million), up 2 perent from year ago (M)

headline: Industry Fights to Put Imprint on Drug Bill
abstract: Second article in series, Re-examining Medicare, focuses on how pharmaceutical industry helped shape Medicare drug benefit in bill that Congress will present to Pres Bush; bill would use private health plans to deliver Medicare prescription drug benefits, as drug industry proposed; drug industry has achieved its single goal, to defeat any legislation that would let Medicare negotiate steep discounts on prices of medicines for its 40 million beneficiaries; drug industry made calculated decision to throw its financial weight behind Republican Party, with $50 million in campaign contributions over last four years; it also pursued dogged campaign that included small army of lobbyists in Washington and network of industry-financed groups, which carried drug makers' message to public; industry was spurred into action during Clinton administration, when Pres Clinton proposed giving elderly Americans some relief from cost of prescription drugs in plan that would be administered by Medicare; photos; graphs (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO., -- St. Louis, operator of David's Bridal, said that it had purchased some assets of the closely held Desmonds Formalwear, a renter and seller of tuxedos, and that the Desmonds stores would become part of its After Hours Formalwear business. Terms were not disclosed.    UAL CORP., -- Elk Grove Township, Ill., parent company of United Airlines, was granted a five-month extension for submitting its reorganization plan. A bankruptcy court judge gave the airline the exclusive right to file a recovery plan until March 6.

headline: Sharon to Visit Britain and Meet Bush in U.S. to Press Peace Effort
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon to visit Britain and US to build momentum for Mideast peace effort; Palestinian security chief Muhammad Dahlan meets with Israeli Defense Min Shaul Mofaz and demands release of more than 5,000 prisoners; Palestinian demonstrators march through Jabalya refugee camp in Gaza demanding more releases (M)

headline: Bank of England Cuts Rates to Lowest Level in 48 Years
abstract: The Bank of England surprised investors by cutting short-term interest rates by a quarter-point, to 3.5 percent, in an attempt to encourage economic growth.

headline: Cadbury Schweppes Chooses McCann
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes is expanding its agency roster by naming offices of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising to handle global assignments for gum and mint brands acquired from Pfizer; brands were handled for Pfizer by Bates Worldwide (S)

headline: Leader of I.R.A. Offshoot Convicted in Bombing That Killed 29
abstract: Ireland's antiterrorism court today convicted the head of the guerrilla group Real I.R.A., Michael McKevitt, for his direction of the organization, which killed 29 people in a car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998.    Mr. McKevitt, 53, was found guilty of directing terrorism, a new crime introduced by Ireland's Parliament after the bombing. But he did not face any charges specifically related to the attack because the prosecution's evidence only related to a period starting in 1999. He could be sentenced to up to life in prison at a hearing on Thursday.

headline: Rights Groups Criticize Egypt's Change in Court System
abstract: Human rights groups in Egypt say government's decision to eliminate one emergency court has not improved access to fair trials; court, before it was eliminated, had convicted prominent Egyptian-American rights advocate Saad Eddin Ibrahim on charges that he defamed Egypt in connection with his work on voter rights; he was ultimately acquitted with help of vocal international support; Human Rights Watch has written to Pres Hosni Mubarak, protesting charges brought against Ashraf Ibrahim, leftist who has criticized Mubarak's economic policy; photo (M)

headline: Baghdad on the Blackout: A Path to Enlightenment?
abstract: Baghdad residents, accustomed to blackouts since United States invasion, gloat over massive Northeast blackout; offer sweltering Americans survival tips, both humorous and practical; question American government's ability to fix power grid; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Aid Workers Die In Ambush
abstract: Two Afghan aid workers with VARA, Voluntary Association for Rehabilitation of Afghanistan, are shot by suspected Taliban insurgents west of Kandahar; CARE, relief agency, reports attacks on aid workers have dramatically increased over past year (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Starbucks and McDonald's lead the drive for the customer that uses wireless Internet technology.
abstract: Internet retailers are expected to benefit eventually from growth of wireless 'hot spots,' such as those that McDonald's Corp and Starbucks are creating in their restaurants; analysts and executives agree that few wireless users log on to buy goods, at least in this country, but they say online entertainment -- whether fee-based or free -- could gain foothold; photos (M)

headline: One Hundred and Twenty Degrees in the Shade
abstract: During this long, hot summer in Iraq, each side has been studying and trying to outthink the other.

headline: Campus Eye on Music Swapping
abstract: Diary column reports that college students are being warned by schools against swapping copyright-protected music and movies over campus Internet connections (S)

headline: Rwanda to Elect President For 1st Time Since Killings
abstract: Pres Paul Kagame draws support from both Hutu and Tutsi in first presidential election since mass killings in Rwanda in 1994, but many people accuse government of stifling opposition candidates with its overwhelming military, political and economic power; Kagame's main opponent, former Prime Min Faustin Twagiramungu, struggles to reach voters, with his party banned, his supporters harassed and rallies frequently canceled; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Real Estate Spinoff
abstract: World Business Briefing: Canada: Real Estat

headline: Ad Buyers Cold To TV Season But Still Plan To Spend Big
abstract: Media-buying advertising executives, while committed to spend record sum on prime-time television, are disappointed with new season; do not expect any of 36 new shows on six broadcast networks to be big, breakout hit; say some shows will succeed only because they follow returning favorites; photo (M)

headline: Expulsion of Arafat Threatened by Israeli
abstract: Defense Minister Shaul Mofaz said that Israel might move to expel the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, by the end of the year.    ''I believe that he has to disappear from the stage of history,'' Mr. Mofaz told Israel's Army Radio, adding that Israel ''made a historic mistake by not expelling him some two years ago.''

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: President Ratifies Reform
abstract: Turkish President Ahmet Necdet Sezer signs reform bill giving Kurds greater freedoms; initially vetoed, measure was passed second time by Parliament and could not be vetoed again; reforms are essential if nation is to be admitted to European Union (S)

headline: G.E. TO POST $150 MILLION GAIN ON EDISON SALE
abstract: General Electric Co to post gain of $150 million on sale of its Japanese life insurance unit to American International Group; GE agreed in June to sell GE Edison Life Insurance and other insurance units to AIG for total of $2.15 billion (S)

headline: SELLER OF MEDICAL GEAR GETS BIG AWARD IN SUIT
abstract: Beckman Coulter Inc, which sells testing equipment to medical laboratories and drug companies, wins $934 million jury verdict, which includes $931 million in punitive damages, from Flextronics International Ltd; jury concludes that Flextronics defrauded Beckman by forcing it to pay $655,000 and concealing $355,000 overpayment (S)

headline: Monsanto Sues Dairy in Maine Over Label's Remarks on Hormones
abstract: Monsanto Co sues Oakhurst Dairy Inc over Oakhurst's labeling of its products; suit charges that labels make disparaging insinuations about use of growth hormones on dairy cows; key Monsanto product is Posilac, growth hormone used on approximately one third of milk cows in US; critics have charged that milk produced by cows receiving growth hormones is different from natural milk and may cause cancer in humans; photos (M)

headline: A Chilling Tale at The Hague: How 6 Muslims Died in Bosnia
abstract: Retired Capt Momir Nikolic, former chief of intelligence in Bosnian Serb army brigade, testifies at Hague against former commander Col Vidoje Blagojevic; tells of Serbian brigades organizing execution of 7,000 unarmed Muslim men and boys, and how he and other officers used UN vehicle to lure unsuspecting Muslims hiding in woods; Nikolic has pleaded guilty to war crimes; Blagojevic has pleaded not guilty (M)

headline: U.S. Says China Is Stepping Up Short-Range Missile Production
abstract: Pentagon, in annual assessment of Chinese military, says China has accelerated production of short-range ballistic missiles, not only to hold Taiwan at peril but also to 'complicate United States intervention' in any conflict with Taiwan; says China is also developing advanced, medium-range version of missile which, if deployed, could strike Japanese or American forces within arc across western Pacific as far away as Okinawa; report estimates that China's military spending could total up to $65 billion a year (M)

headline: Senior British Official Defends Report on Danger of Iraqi Arms
abstract: John Scarlett, senior intelligence figure who compiled Britain's dossier on Iraqi arms, testifies at inquiry into death of weapons expert David Kelly that attention-getting claim that Saddam Hussein could deploy unconventional weapons in 45 minutes was backed by reliable evidence and its inclusion was supported by security chiefs; admits it was hearsay data from single source; is opening witness at inquiry led by Lord Hutton that focuses on period last fall when Prime Min Tony Blair sought support for intervention in Iraq (M)

headline: Bush Seeks $2.1 Billion More for Iraqi Oil Industry
abstract: Bush administration requests additional $2.1 billion to repair damage to Iraqi oil and electrical infrastructure; request, which originally was for $1.1 billion, is part of $87 billion Iraq reconstruction package that administration is expected to propose shortly; new estimate, which is being challenged by Democratic Reps Henry Waxman and John Dingell, is seen as underscoring difficulty of halting sabotage to Iraqi oil sector and electricity grid; country's oil exports totaled only 800,000 barrels per day in August, compared to pre-war average of 2 million barrels; photo (M)

headline: Net Income Doubles for Helen of Troy
abstract: Helen of Troy Ltd says net income rose to $14.8 million in its fiscal first quarter ended May 31 from $6.59 million year earlier; sales rose 4 percent, to $106.5 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Drop For Electronics Maker
abstract: LG Electronics Inc unit of South Korea's LG Group reports second-quarter net income fell 24 percent to 258 billion won ($218 million), down from 341 billion in 2002 period (S)

headline: Executive Life; It's Back to School, To Become a Teacher
abstract: Many executives are returning to school, aiming to become public school teachers; unusually large numbers of highly skilled professionals, many with decades in corporate world under their belts, are taking advantage of recently created programs that prepare new teachers; photo (L)

headline: E-Mail Hucksterism, Offensive but Effective
abstract: Millions of unsolicited e-mails, or spam, are sent out over Internet each day to unwilling recipients, hawking male-enhancement pills that are cheap to produce and highly profitable for new generation of hucksters; unregulated herbal pills, carrying medically impossibe promises, are sold annually by at least 50 companies, producing revenue of more than $100 million; torrent of such messages is pushing bipartisan regulatory effort in Congress, but most pill makers sell products through thousands of independent affiliates and spammers hide identities by bouncing messages off computers in countries with lax regulation; photos; sales pitches for unlikely products are as old as human gullibility, but male-performance marketing, while going back to mail-order business, took off when Pfizer opened door with ads for Viagra (M)

headline: For Managers on a Mission, It's Character Over Charisma
abstract: William H Holstein business column reviews book Authentic Leadership: Rediscovering the Secrets to Creating Lasting Value, by Medronic's retired chief executive Bill George; cover photo (M)

headline: Business; Sifting Through 'Junk' in Search of Dining Ambience
abstract: Lucrative business has been created selling memorabilia to restaurant chains such as Applebee's, Ruby Tuesday and Cracker Barrel, for whom items serve as conversation pieces providing customers with visual stimulation; companies spend as much as $50,000 furnishing new outlet; Beverly, Mass-based Hospitality Solutions runs network of 25 buyers nationwide to locate memorabilia for restaurants; photos (M)

headline: When All Hope Seems Lost, The Disc Data Is Rescued
abstract: Arrowkey software program can help recover data from damaged CD's or DVD's and copy it back to hard drive; photo (M)

headline: Frontier tries comedy even as many wonder whether flying has a humorous side anymore.
abstract: Frontier Airlines becomes latest low-fare carrier to try to build name recognition and business with humor; new campaign, developed by Sticky Grey, features witty talking animals; photo (M)

headline: Oil Executive Is Arrested, and Russians Look for Putin's Role
abstract: Authorities have arrested a top executive at the financial group that controls Russia's largest oil company.

headline: Hope Mingles With Doubt On the Streets of Baghdad
abstract: Residents of Baghdad agree that new Iraqi Governing Council will be heavily influenced by its American overseers, but disagree about whether this is good situation; some describe Council's 25 members mostly as compliant frontmen installed by Americans; others say Council will pave way toward better life for all Iraqis (M)

headline: High Official Quits Treasury And Woman Is Named No. 2
abstract: Bush administration makes changes in its economic team, including appointment of Susan C Schwab as first woman to be deputy Treasury secretary and resignation of Peter R Fisher as under secretary for domestic affairs; Fisher will be succeeded by Kenneth Leet, investment banker from Goldman Sachs; photos (M)

headline: Investors Keep Trading After Wall Street Power Outage
abstract: The power outage that darkened Wall Street today caused little disruption or panic in the financial markets, with back-up generators and technology helping to keep the money flowing.

headline: 4 EX-EMPLOYEES OF CHARTER CHARGED WITH FRAUD
abstract: Charter Communications, cable television operator controlled by Paul Allen, a founder of Microsoft, says that two former execs and two other former employees were indicted on fraud charges by federal grand jury; former execs are Kent Kalkwarf and David Barford; former employees are James Smith and David McCall (S)

headline: Consultant to Grasso on Pay Is Also Adviser to Exchange
abstract: Lawyer Martin Lipton, chairman of New York Stock Exchange's legal advisory committee and chief counsel to corporate governance committee, reportedly was also sounding board for Richard A Grasso, who resigned because of controversy over his $139.5 million pay package; investor advocates and board members score multiple roles as posing potential conflict of interest; Lipton, who defended Grasso's initial plan to take $48 milion in future payments, was told by corporate governance committee not to stay on their conference call when Grasso tendered resignation; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Blood Test Settlement
abstract: Chiron Corp and Roche Holding settle complaints made to European Commission by German Red Cross and others that two diagnostic companies fixed prices for blood-screening kits for hepatitis and HIV (S)

headline: German Trial Begins for Student Accused of Aiding 9/11 Plot
abstract: The trial opened today in Hamburg, home to an Al Qaeda cell whose members are believed to have played the central role in the plot.

headline: Paris Journal; A Photo Op: O Say, Can You See the Eiffel Tower?
abstract: Laura Bush's five-day trip to Paris and Moscow is considerd part of campaign to dispel criticism of Pres Bush's administration as unilateralist as it seeks to win international support for new United Nations resolution for more money and troops for American occupation of Iraq; she delivers 25-minute address inside headquarters of UNESCO, organization that US is rejoining after 19 years; photo (M)

headline: Man Receives Death Sentence for Bali Blasts That Killed 202
abstract: An accused member of the Islamic militant group Jemaah Islamiyah is the first defendant to be convicted in the Bali case.

headline: Russian Colonel Guilty of Murder in Death of Chechen Woman
abstract: Russian military court convicts Col Yuri D Budanov of murder in Mar 2000 strangling death of Chechen woman Elza Kungayeva, 18, in his quarters; he is highest-ranking officer convicted for what rights group say are routine abuses against civilians in Russia's war against Chechen rebels; was acquitted in first trial on temporary insanity grounds, but Supreme Court threw out verdict; is sentenced to 10 years in prison and stripped of rank and awards; officials announce discovery in village near Moscow of cache of five explosive devices like those used in recent wave of Chechen suicide bombings (M)

headline: A Suicide and Uncertainty in Korea
abstract: In life, Chung Mong Hun was this capitalist nation's economic ambassador to the Communist North, negotiating for South Korean tour buses to drive across the demilitarized zone, setting off fireworks to inaugurate North Korea's first industrial park, and posing with the North's reclusive leader, Kim Jong Il.    All that abruptly ended when Mr. Chung's body was found Monday morning below an open window of his 12th-floor office at the headquarters of his troubled company, Hyundai Asan. Since then, Koreans have watched every turn of the case, fascinated by a prominent clan that is sometimes called the Korean Kennedys.

headline: Trades Decline at Schwab
abstract: Charles Schwab & Co says daily average of trades made by its customers declined more than 5 percent in July, compared with June, first drop in five months (S)

headline: Merck and Partner Form Alliance to Develop Drugs Based on RNA
abstract: Merck & Co forms alliance with small biotechnology company Alnylam Holding Co to develop drugs using widely watched new technology aimed at precisely shutting off genes involved in disease; deal represents one of first substantial steps by large pharmaceutical company toward making drugs using technology, known as RNA interference (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit At Siemens Drops
abstract: Germany's largest engineering company, Siemens, says that third-quarter profit dropped 13 percent; net income for April through June fell to 632 million euros ($725 million) (S)

headline: Mexico Arrests 8 Called Top Drug Smugglers
abstract: Mexican authorities arrest eight drug traffickers from violent cartel that smuggles some thirty percent of cocaine, heroin and marijuana into US (S)

headline: A Gallery of Panoramic Images From Around the Web
abstract: Tito Dupret

headline: Private Sector; The Accidental Entrepreneurs
abstract: PrivateSector profile of Octagon Research Solutions, founded by Kirk Gallion, Dr Neal Walker and James Walker to use technology to help speed up and simplify application process for new drugs; interviews; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: WHEAT RISES. Last-minute buying by commodity funds pushed wheat prices higher. On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for December delivery was 8.75 cents higher at $3.81 a bushel.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Biotech Food Labeling Rule Advances in European Union  The European Parliament approved legislation to require strict labels for food and feed made with genetically altered ingredients, a move that was hailed by environmentalists but pilloried by American farmers. Final European Union approval is expected this fall.    The Bush administration criticized the legislation, saying it would be burdensome for food producers, could prejudice consumers against genetically modified food and become a barrier to free trade. [Page A3.]

headline: 2 Sexes Separated by a Common Levi's
abstract: Levi Strauss last week opened its first jeans boutique for young women in Paris, hoping to lift sales inits vital European market; new store, called Levi's for Girls, is aimed at women 19 to 25, though company admits average customer may be more like 15 to 22; photo (M)

headline: Annan Urges U.N. to Make Structural Changes
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan argued today that fundamental weaknesses in the architecture of the institution must be remedied for it to retain any effectiveness in combating genocide, terrorism and nuclear proliferation.

headline: E*Trade Has Ordered A Review of Its Account
abstract: E*Trade Group places in review creative duties on its advertising account; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, which had handled duties, declines to take part in review (S)

headline: Tomsk Journal; His Joy Is to Lampoon The Business of Russia
abstract: Profile of Tomsk, Siberia, entrepreneur Yuri M Lirmak, who delights in lampooning Russia's transition from socialism to free enterprise and views capitalism with touch of cynicism; Tomsk is busy getting fixed up for its 400th anniversary next year; map; photo (M)

headline: Bavaria's Conservatives Show Strength in German State Election
abstract: Bavaria's conservative party swaggers to victory in state parliamentary election, extending its four-decade reign over Germany's most economically vibrant region and dealing worse-than-expected defeat to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's Social Democratic Party; lopsidedness of victory leads analysts to assume that Bavarians think little of Schroder's handling of German economy; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Reverses Loss
abstract: Irish drug maker Elan Corp, which is making changes to address concerns about its past accounting practices, reports second-quarter net profit of $17.3 million compared to net loss of $719.7 million year earlier; revenue fell 46 percent, to $245.5 million from $451.6 million (S)

headline: Microsoft to Give Its Employees Stock Instead of Options
abstract: Microsoft said this afternoon that it would no longer grant stock options, relying instead on restricted awards of stock to help pay its almost 50,000 employees.

headline: Court Decides To Sentence Bali Bomber To Death
abstract: Indonesian court sentences man known as Amrozi to death after convicting him for plotting Bali nightclub terror attack that killed 202 people last Oct; Amrozi, suspected member of Islamic militant group Jemaah Islamiyah, grins as he hears sentence; he is first defendant to be convicted in case; he said he wanted to be martyr, and he mounted little defense during trial; more than 30 others have been arrested and trials of some are drawing to close; Bush administration has praised government of Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri for its investigations into Bali attack, and for conduct of trials; urges Indonesian government to show same commitment to investigating blast of J W Marriott Hotel in Jakarta on Aug 5; photo (M)

headline: ConAgra Grants No Stock Options
abstract: ConAgra Foods Inc chief executive Bruce Rohde and other top executives were awarded no stock options in last year as company turned to other forms of incentive pay (S)

headline: Multitasking, for What?
abstract: Susan S Collins letter questions why people feel they need to multitask on all kinds of technological gadgets (July 6 article); drawing

headline: Britain to Send 1,200 More Troops to Southern Iraq
abstract: The deployment was far smaller than the thousands of extra troops that Foreign Secretary Jack Straw was reported to have been urging.

headline: Harlan Waksal Resigns From ImClone Posts
abstract: Dr Harlan W Waksal resigns as ImClone Systems chief scientific officer and director; says departure is not linked to any concern about company's cancer drug, Erbitux; resignation within 90 days of his demotion from chief executive apparently entitles him to $4.1 million and vesting of his remaining stock options; photo (M)

headline: EARNINGS AT DUPONT RISE 24% ON STRONG SALES
abstract: DuPont reports second-quarter net income rose to $675 million, up 24 percent from $543 million in 2002 quarter (S)

headline: France Telecom Tries to Increase Stake in Cellphone Provider
abstract: France Telecom will issue stock to raise fresh capital that it will use to acquire the 13.7 percent stake of the cellphone provider Orange.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Love, Dears
abstract: Bristol (England) government receptionists and security have been directed to eliminate use of dear or love in addressing public; they are instead advised by City Council leader Barbara Janke to use sir or madam; change has raised some controversy (S)

headline: EMERSON SHARES PLUNGE ON WARNING ABOUT SALES
abstract: Emerson Radio Corp says sales in quarter eª

headline: Why Mexico's Political Machine Keeps Chugging
abstract: Mexico's PRI, which lost longtime grip on presidency three years ago, remains potent force, winning slim majority in crucial elections for lower Chamber of Deputies; answer to party's hold lies in places like Campeche, at southern tip of Mexico, where PRI has used vast system of patronage to buy loyal support for decades; photo; map (M)

headline: Pepsi Picks BBDO For Aquafina Account
abstract: Pepsi-Cola Co expands its relationship with BBDO Worldwide by assigning agency creative duties on ad account for Aquafina bottled water, which have been handled since early last year by Element 79 Partners; billings estimated at $35 million (S)

headline: Gunfire Sends Liberian Civilians Fleeing to Capital
abstract: Liberian refugees flee from outskirts of Monrovia toward city after gunfire is heard; government says rebel forces have begun attack on military base near city; United Nations officials grow increasingly frustrated over delays in sending West African soldiers to enforce fragile cease-fire; officer of Economic Community of West African States says assessment team is scheduled to arrive in Monrovia to lay groundwork for deployment, which would begin in 10 to 15 days; Bush administration says it will not consider sending soldiers so long as Pres Charles Taylor is in power there; photo (M)

headline: Sleuths Try to Stay Step Ahead of Online Worms
abstract: Mikko Hypponen and his researchers at F-Secure, computer security company based in Finland, identified SoBig.F computer worm on Aug 19, readied computer patch and distributed update to their customers, just as dozens of other antivirus companies were doing same; F-Secure researchers found list of 20 Internet protocol addresses linked to home computers in US, Canada and South Korea as they continued to dissect worm, that were apparently unwitting transmitters of virus; SoBig.F was veritable time bomb, set to use those 20 machines to send out malicious instructions to millions of computers at exactly 3 pm on Aug 22; F-Secure officials contacted FBI, which quickly began taks of taking computers offline in hopes of isolating problem; Hypponen's team and dozens of other researchers throughout world helped to get computers off line; photo (M)

headline: Curfew's Gone, but Troops Still Hem In Hebron Family
abstract: More than 80 members of extended Palestinian family live in two large stone homes inside walled property in Hebron on West Bank; for them, Middle East peace initiative has brought hope, but no real confidence, that some normalcy might return to their constricted lives; Hebron, where 450 Jewish settlers live in few small enclaves among some 150,000 Palestinians, illustrates how complicted it will be to move forward with peace plan when mutual suspicion runs so deep; under previous agreement, Israel is permitted to keep troops in center of Hebron to guard settlers, even if soldiers leave other parts of town; this allows military to maintain strict control over 30,000 Palestinians; Palestinians complain of not being able to move about and of continued curfews; photos; map (M)

headline: Sun Posts a Small Profit but Misses Forecasts
abstract: Sun Microsystems, network computer maker, reports net income of $12 million for fiscal fourth quarter, down from $61 million in year-earlier period; reports fiscal 2003 net loss of $2.4 billion, compared with year-earlier loss of $587 million (M)

headline: RECREATIONAL BOAT BUILDER BUYS MARINE HARDWARE UNIT
abstract: Brunswick Corp acquires Attwood boat hardware and accessory business of Steelcase Inc for $47.9 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Court Rules On Pop-Up Ads
abstract: Federal Judge Gerald Bruce Lee ruled last week that pop-up ads did not infringe copyright or trademark rights of Web sites on which they appear; Lee rejected U-Haul's claims that pop-up ads delivered by WhenU.com, online advertising company, violated federal copyright and trademark laws; legal analysts say decision is significant for all pop-up companies, including Gator Corp, which faces several federal lawsuits on similar grounds (S)

headline: Dutch Grocer Tries to Calm Furor Over Pay
abstract: Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold, in effort to quell national outcry over corporate compensation in Netherlands that has spread to its own supermarkets, says chairman Henny de Ruiter will resign and it will overhaul its chief executive's multi-million-dollar pay package; Ahold, having already admitted to some $1.1 billion in accounting irregularities, is trying to quell outrage surrounding two-year contract given to new chairman Anders C Mosberg, as it lays off hundreds of employees at its flagship grocery chain Albert Heijn; photo (M)

headline: Infomercials Get Some Advice
abstract: The people who make those infomercials for products that promise to enlarge breasts, improve virility and silence snoring were told by the government last week to stop making what it calls unsubstantiated claims.     Wellquest International, Tony Hoffman Productions and several others agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they made false claims for three products: Bloussant, sold for breast enhancement; EnerX, for men's virility; and D-Snore, to relieve snoring. The defendants also agreed to pay $3.2 million in the settlement.

headline: A Lump-Sum Threat to Pension Funds
abstract: Many workers at companies like US Airways, Delta Air Lines, American Airlines, Polaroid Corp, Xerox Corp and Lucent Technologies are opting for lump-sum retirement payments instead of waiting for monthly checks, exposing hidden risk to pensions; accelerating withdrawals can work like bank run, draining so many assets that plan's solvency can be threatened; if sudden withdrawals reduce plan's finances below certain level, company can be required to make large catch-up contributions in short time; photos (M)

headline: Goodby Is Selected by AT&T Wireless
abstract: Goodby Is Selected By AT&T Wireless AT&T Wireless said yesterday that it had added Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco to its roster of agencies, naming it to handle corporate brand advertising, which since 2001 has been one of the duties of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York. Billings were not disclosed; overall spending was estimated at $700 million.

headline: Muslims Gather in New York to Remember Revered Cleric
abstract: Hundred Muslims gather in Queens, to mourn Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, Shiite cleric killed in bombing in Najaf, Iraq, calling him a martyr who endured lifetime of oppression; rallying cry that quickly emerges at memorial service is for United States to leave Iraq; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; As Amazon moves into sporting goods, online retailers wonder whether to see it as a competitor or a partner.
abstract: Amazon.com's entry into $1.5 billion online sporting goods market caps yearlong effort to add group of products that have proved well suited to online commerce; e-commerce companies that have been finding success in market are watching to see whether Amazon emerges as competitor, partner or both; Amazon draws on retailing might of outside retailers to supply and ship to Amazon customers hundreds of thousands of items they also carry on their Web sites; photo (M)

headline: Times Company Names a Board Member
abstract: Thomas Middelhoff, former chairman and chief executive of Bertelsmann, joins board of New York Times Co; photo (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.75       Discount rate   2.00   2.00   N.A.       Federal funds   1.00   1.00   1.67       3-month T-bills   0.89   0.90   1.65       6-month T-bills   0.93   0.94   1.65       10-yr. T-infl.   2.03   2.11   3.52       10-yr. T-note   4.10   4.12   4.47       30-yr. T-bond   5.05   5.04   5.35       Telephone bd.   6.02   6.03   7.45       Municipal bds.   5.06   5.10   5.17          (Sources: Bloomberg News; Telerate The Bond Buyer)

headline: Business People; Some Give, Some Take
abstract: On the one hand, we learn that Jack B. Grubman, the former golden boy of telecom analysts who left Salomon Smith Barney a year ago, is reportedly getting $50,000 every three months from his former employer. After all, there must be lots of work to do as the firm deals with legal claims.    Mr. Grubman left the firm -- well, it now appears that he didn't 100 percent leave -- after accusations that he embellished his research reports on certain telecommunications companies to help CitiGroup win banking business. Citigroup, which owns the brokerage firm, had made one other payment to Mr. Grubman: a severance package valued at $33 million.

headline: Talbots' Profit Falls 7.6%
abstract: Talbots Inc says net income fell to $18.5 million in second quarter ended Aug 2 from $20 million year earlier; sales rose 5 percent to $389.6 million (S)

headline: SoHo-Inspired Lofts With Views of Houston
abstract: Houston, Tex, developers are putting up apartment buildings that look like century-old factories; buildings offer loft-style apartments that try to mimic faded mystique of Manhattan neigborhoods like SoHo; trending is taking root in several other cities without much of a loft tradition, including Las Vegas, Atlanta and Washington; most active and creative proponents are in Houston, where migration from suburbs to areas closer to downtown has become increasingly fashionable; photos (M)

headline: INVENSYS SELLS SEMICONDUCTOR UNIT TO LITTELFUSE
abstract: Invensys sells semiconductor business Teccor Electronics to Littelfuse Inc for $44 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.00   4.00   4.75       Discount rate   2.00   2.00   N.A.       Federal funds   1.25   1.45   1.72       3-month T-bills   0.86   0.88   1.68       6-month T-bills   0.93   0.95   1.70       10-yr. T-infl.   1.82   1.75   3.01       10-yr. T-note   3.55   3.52   4.73       30-yr. T-bond   4.59   4.56   5.44       Telephone bd.   5.60   5.84   7.55       Municipal bds.   4.72   4.66   5.25          (Sources: Bloomberg News; Telerate The Bond Buyer)

headline: Chief Confirms Viacom Wants Vivendi Cable Units
abstract: Viacom Inc chairman Sumner M Redstone confirms his company is seeking to acquire Vivendi Universal's cable assets but not its other entertainment businesses; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Confidence Rises
abstract: Germany's Ifo Institute business c

headline: Workers in Argentina Take Charge of Abandoned Factories
abstract: At least 160 factories employing an estimated 10,000 people are now being run as cooperatives by their employees.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Shots Close British Embassy
abstract: British Embassy in Tehran (Iran) closes after gunfire at compound; shooting, which causes no injuries, is thought to be related to Great Britain's arrest of former Iranian ambassador to Argentina, who was allegedly involved in 1994 bombing of Buenos Aires (Argentina) Jewish community center; embassy shooting follows Iran's recall of its envoy to Britain (S)

headline: SCHOLASTIC EXPECTS $2.2 BILLION IN SALES IN FISCAL 2004
abstract: Scholastic Corp chief executive Richard Robinson says company, American publisher of Harry Potter books, will have sales of $2.1 billion to $2.2 billion in 2004 fiscal year, about 7 percent to 12 percent higher than year earlier; adds cash flow in year started June 1 will be $40 million to $50 million (S)

headline: France Defends Its Flouting Of Europe's Rules on Deficits
abstract: France's Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin defends his country's continued violation of Europe's budget rules, saying his primary job is to restore growth and increase employment in France; urges that rules underpinning euro be interpreted in more flexible way to allow countries with faltering economies to stimulate growth; European Commission president Romano Prodi suggrests that fundamental rift inside European Union over budget spending will once again dominate group's agenda this fall (M)

headline: Gauging the Strength Of F.D.A. Regulation
abstract: Adonis Hoffman letter responds to June 29 article on Federal regulation of pharmaceutical advertising; says prescription drug advertising is doing what it is supposed to do: encourage Americans to visit their doctors and get appropriate treatment

headline: Shortcut or the Long Way? Device Helps You Decide
abstract: Gadget from TrafficGauge receives real-time data about traffic, allowing driver to decide on alternate route if necessary; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: General Strike
abstract: Chile's Central Workers Union stages national strike in hopes of persuading government to improve poor working conditions and expand limited health-care coverage in first general strike in over 10 years; strike appears to have limited impact (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Forecast Of PC Shipments Is Increased
abstract: IDC says worldwide shipments of personal computers will grow more than forecast this year because of heavier consumer spending and better-than-expected second quarter; says shipments will rise 8.4 percent, to 148.2 million units, compared with company's prior estimate of 6.3 percent; adds shipments in 2004 will increase 10.3 percent, to 163.3 million units (S)

headline: Chevrolet Aims to Take Lead From Ford With Nine New Models
abstract: Chevrolet division of General Motors plans to introduce nine new models over 20 months, starting in January, setting up battle to overtake Ford as nation's top seller; Honda safety official says company had been redesigning its vehicles with aim of reducing injuries to passengers; drawings of new Chevrolet designs (M)

headline: Some Optimism From Intel Stirs Broader Hopes
abstract: Intel shares increase by as much as 10 percent following upward revision in third quarter sales projections by about 5 percent; forecast is seen as additional evidence of pickup in economic growth; company is projecting third quarter sales in range of $7.3 billion to $7.8 billion, up from $6.9 billion to $7.5 billion, and gross margin of about 56 percent, up from earlier estimate of 54 percent; chief executive Andy D Bryant comments; photo (M)

headline: SBC Communications Is Target of Antitrust Suit
abstract: Four California companies that sell broadband Internet service over telephone lines file antitrust complaint against SBC Communications, Baby Bell that controls lines to customers (S)

headline: C.I.A. Chief to Face Panel On Dubious Iraq Arms Data
abstract: CIA Dir George J Tenet will testify before Senate panel about reliability of intelligence suggesting Iraq tried to buy uranium in Africa, report that was later quoted by Pres Bush in State of the Union address (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Credit Card Losses
abstract: South Korea's nine credit card companies lost $2.6 billion in first six months of 2003 as result of increasing household debts; LG Card was biggest loser with $642 million loss during period (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Sentence Cut
abstract: Vietnamese appeals court reduces political dissident Pham Hong Som's prison sentence to 5 years from original 13 years levied (S)

headline: As Many as 6 Bids Are Expected For Freedom Communications
abstract: As many as six bidders are preparing to submit offers for all or part of Freedom Communicaitons, privately held newspaper and television comany; at least one bid is expected to be at least $2 billion (M)

headline: Colombian Warlord, Facing U.S. Charges, Turns On Charm
abstract: The United States has called him a major drug trafficker, and human rights groups want him tried for the slayings of thousands of villagers in Colombia's long war.     But Salvatore Mancuso, one of Colombia's most notorious warlords, is not hard to find these days. He has embarked on a kind of charm offensive, trying to lure the United States into negotiations to drop its year-old indictment of him for drug running, even as his organization, a paramilitary group called the United Self-Defense Forces, begins what Colombians once thought impossible: peace negotiations with the government, announced last month.

headline: Insurance Firm Acquired
abstract: Arthur J Gallagher & Co, insurance broker that does business in more than 100 countries, acquires J A Lorenzo & Co; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: 2 Big Advertisers Pick New Agencies
abstract: Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits in Atlanta names Cramer-Krasselt as creative agency of record; assignment has been handled since 1996 by Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos; billings estimated at $20 million; HarperCollins Publishers names Ziccardi Partners Frierson Mee to handle account of all HarperCollisn book imprints in US; spending has not been determined (S)

headline: SCO Changes Tactics In Dispute Over Linux
abstract: SCO Group, which has sued IBM, leading supporter of Linux operating system, and warned other large companies that Linux violates its copyright, shifts tactics and says it will offer large corporations licenses so they can continue to use Linux without fear of copyright infringement suit; says Copyright Office has granted it copyright registration for its Unix code; holds Linux is unauthorized derivative of Unix (M)

headline: North Korea to Face Pressure in Talks to Scrap Nuclear Plans
abstract: The U.S., North Korea and its neighbors begin unusual negotiations on Wednesday on how to resolve the Korean arms crisis.

headline: Ticketmaster Auction Will Let Highest Bidder Set Concert Prices
abstract: Ticketmaster plans to begin online auctioning of best seats to concerts through ticketmaster.com; with no official price ceiling on such tickets, Ticketmaster will be able to compete with brokers and scalpers for highest price market will bear; photo (M)

headline: Iraqis Name Team to Devise Way to Draft Constitution
