abstract: Iraq's interim government appoints 25-member team to draw up procedure to produce new constitution; new constitution is seen as cornerstone of democratic Iraq that American leaders overseeing occupation are trying to bring about; process, ultimately expected to lead to democratic elections, is part of effort under way to erase history of dictatorship and misrule and begin tradition of representative government; in Basra, rioting eases as British soldiers ferry in millions of gallons of fuel and restore electricity to large parts of city; photo (M)

headline: PENTHOUSE MAGAZINE'S PUBLISHER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Penthouse Magazine's Pub

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Ruling On Marcos Money
abstract: Philippine Supreme Court awards $650 million of former President Ferdinand Marcos assets to government after his heirs fail to establish rightful ownership of funds; President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo plans to use money to help impoverished citizens and human rights victims (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Kuwait: Leadership Shift
abstract: Kuwait's Emir Sheik Jabar al-Ahmad al-Sabah appoints Foreign Minister of past 40 years Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah to position of Prime Minister; new appointment effectively divides once joint office of crown prince and prime minister (S)

headline: Former Dictator to Seek Guatemalan Presidency
abstract: Efrain Rios Montt registers as presidential candidate in Guatemala; he is former military dictator accused of presiding over atrocities during harshest era of country's civil war; registration comes after Constitutional Court rules in his favor, ending judicial crisis over legal challenges filed in lower court by opposition parties; mobs apparently organized by his political party have rampaged through upper-class neighborhoods in Guatemala City demanding that he be allowed to run; Constitutional Court rulings in 1990 and 1995 prohibited him from seeking presidency; opposition leaders fault court's latest 4-to-3 decision, saying judges have conflict of interest; report published after 36-year civil war ended with peace accords in 1996 accuses Rios Montt's troops of numerous massacres of men, women and children; he has immunity as president of Congress; photo (M)

headline: West African Group to Send Troops to Liberia
abstract: The group announced today that it would send at least 1,000 peacekeeping troops to Monrovia within the next two weeks.

headline: Japanese Election Exposes Rents in Party Fabric
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi, who has vowed to smash governing Liberal Democratic Party's weakening factional system, is expected to easily win election as party's leader over Takao Fujii, candidate backed by party's most powerful faction; two-week campaign for party presidency has focused on factional system, which is seen as obstacle to birth of real two-party democracy; Hiromu Nonaka, boss of largest faction, scores defectors who plan to back Koizumi and says he will retire from political life, news conference; campaign is revealing just how much factional system has eroded; photo (M)

headline: Euro Vote Is Unlikely Soon As Britain Focuses on Iraq
abstract: Early vote on Britain joining euro single currency is unlikely soon as British government is embroiled in public scrutiny of its reasons for goign to war against Iraq; likelihood of referendum on euro has been hostage much of year to Iraq conflict, not because of any direct link between issues but because of effect war has had on popularity of Prime Min Tony Blair, and thus his ability to persuade skeptical nation to abandon British sterling; photo (M)

headline: Typhoon Hits South Korea Economy
abstract: Typhoon Maemi left trail of wreckage that threatens to slow South Korea's economic recovery; took some 124 lives and caused $1.6 billion in damage to South Korea's southeast industrial heartland; winds hit 134 miles an hour, South Korean record; storm damage to Pusan port has left exporters scrambling to find alternative ports; photo (M)

headline: WorldCom Report Recommends Sweeping Changes for Its Board
abstract: WorldCom will reach milestone with court filing outlining changes in how board will govern company in effort to transform bankrupt, scandal-ridden telecommunications giant into paragon of good management known as MCI; report's author Richard C Breeden says 78 recommendations reflect specific weaknesses exposed by WorldCom's collapse but are also intended to be model for other companies; Breeden has been serving as court-appointed monitor of WorldCom's efforts to overhaul itself and restore trust in its accounting under new management; MCI's chairman-chief executive Michael D Capellas supports recommendations, including requirement that chairman's title be turned over to outsider who would run board; chart (M)

headline: Publisher That Went Bust Is Hoping to Go Boom Again
abstract: Future Network USA is expected to announce it is buying Guitar World magazine and three ancillary publications from Harris Publications for $16 million; purchase of Guitar World properties is effort by technology-obsessed publisher to broaden its base into less cyclical consumer-enthusiast market in Britain; company still plans to increase its technology holdings and beginning in January will publish Mobile PC magazine; no publishing company flew higher than Future Network in late 1990's, propelled by booming new-economy magazine Business 2.0, and few fell harder in bust; graph (M)

headline: Iraq to Take a Seat At OPEC Meeting
abstract: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, after months of resistance, will let delegation from occupied Iraq take part in its meeting next week, Vienna; Min Ibrahim Bahr al-Uloum will lead Iraqi delegation; Iraq's lingering problems in raising output and exports are likely to limit its role in meeting (S)

headline: Families of 2 British Terrorism Suspects Oppose Military Trials by the U.S.
abstract: Families of British terrorism suspects Moazzam Begg and Feroz Abbasi score United States plan to try them by military tribunals at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, naval base; Britain calls on US to conduct tribunals with fairness on issues like access to lawyers, evidence standards and right to appeal; opposes imposition of death penalty; stops short of demanding two be returned home for trial; family of David Hicks, Australian seized in Afghanistan, confirms he is on list of six Guantanamo prisoners likely to be first to face tribunals; photos (M)

headline: South Africa's Wines Come of Age
abstract: Quality and sales of South African wines have improved sharply since fall of apartheid and lifting of international sanctions; South Africa is seventh-largest producer of wine in world and fourth-largest exporter to Britain; wine exports grew tenfold from 1992 to 2002, to more than 215 million liters; only 0.1 percent of wines sold in America are made in South Africa, and only 2 percent of South Africa's wine ends up on American shelves; Gary Shearer, managing director of Cape Classics Exports, one of first companies to begin selling South African wines to America, winemaker Giorgio Dalla Cia comment; photos (M)

headline: Annan Tells General Assembly That U.N. Must Correct Its Weaknesses
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan, in allusion to Iraq war, cites need to give United Nations robust and flexible new structure to answer concerns that drive some states to unilateral action, speech to General Assembly; tells delegates that they must do better job of protecting UN and its over 9,000 employees; cites need to reform Security Council; chides audience for slow pace of reform; plans to set up panel to assess current security threats and best use of collective action to respond to them and to recommend changes in UN; photo (M)

headline: New Activism by African Nations: Joining Forces to Referee Their Own Disputes
abstract: Analysis: Liberia is latest example of Africa's new activist approach toward its trouble spots and its troublemakers; Africans are taking lead in peace efforts under way in Congo, Burundi, Somalia and Sudan; some critics say Africa's approach toward its leaders really has not changed and that Pres Charles Taylor's departure from Liberia is not sign of new African engagement; but others see hopeful signs in prominent role of Economic Community of West African States in Taylor's departure (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Interest Rate Unchanged
abstract: Bank of Korea leaves basic interest rate unchanged at 3.75 percent (S)

headline: SOUTHWEST BEAT RIVALS IN PASSENGER TRAFFIC IN MAY
abstract: Bureau of Transportation Statistics says Southwest Airlines flew 6.54 million passengers in May, down from 6.61 million passengers year earlier, but still ahead of any rival carrier; second-highest was Delta Air Lines, with 6.34 million passengers (S)

headline: Stowaway on Bush Press Plane Is Arrested in Uganda
abstract: Ugandan authorities arrest unidentified man who stowed away on press plane accompanying Pres Bush from South Africa to Entebbe; photo; man then rode bus with journalists and entered hotel where Bush was speaking (S)

headline: Poillé-sur-Vègre Journal; The Tail Gunner Said It: 'I Love Them People'
abstract: Residents of Poille-sur-Vegre, France, gather at newly repainted 'Monument Americain,' dedicated to David Butcher, American bomber pilot who was shot down by Nazis during World War II and hidden by members of French Resistance until he could be escorted to safety; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Official Faults China And Japan; HONG KONG: Drop In Retail Sales Slows; SOUTH KOREA: Interest Rate Unchanged;.

headline: The Illusions Of Progress
abstract: Analysis: Bombing of Israeli bus by Palestinian suicide bomber and return of Israeli troops to their old positions in West Bank and Gaza erase images of peace both sides sought to project, leaving new Palestinian leadership of Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas as last and quickly fading illusion of progress; Bush administration now faces grim reality that his peace plan has produced no basic change (M)

headline: I Just Love Your Duds, Baby
abstract: Clothing designer Cynthia Steffe notes that bringing her infant daughter to work with her in office building that houses many leading designers means she has to give thought to what baby is wearing (S)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: LAOS: Envoy Says Journalists May Be Freed In Days; AFGHANISTAN: Disarmament Plan Delayed; CAMBODIA: Top Smoker; JAPAN: Prime Parcel. No Vu.;.

headline: Business People; World War II Ace for a Day
abstract: world war II ace for a day

headline: New Premier Of Quebec Keeping Vow To Cut Back
abstract: Quebec Premier Jean Charest, vowing change in provincial government, has cut cabinet by one-third, cut taxes on small businesses, slashed spending and promised to cut income taxes by 27 percent over next five years; engineered Liberals' landslide defeat of Parti Quebecois by playing down old debate over sovereignty and promising to cut government sloth (M)

headline: In Frayed Networks, Common Threads
abstract: Article discusses common threads evident in various networks, and interconnectedness as strength--and weakness--as illustrated in recent blackout and with proliferation of Blaster worm that has wreaked havoc on computer networks; since 1917, when railroads adopted standard track width, there have been challenges in managing modern technological societies and dealing with problems inherent in networks (M)

headline: CHRYSLER RAISES REBATES TO COMBAT SALES DECLINE
abstract: Chrysler unit of DamilerChrysler AG is adding incentives to most 2004 models to increase sales and reverse 4.7 percent sales decline so far this year (S)

headline: With Strong Quarter, Shell May Be Industry Harbinger
abstract: Energy conglomerate Royal Dutch/Shell says that its second-quarter net income increased 28 percent, to $2.8 billion, from same period year ago; net profits increased 51 percent, to $3.3 billion; photo of Sir Philip Watts, chmn, and Judy Boynton, chief financial officer (M)

headline: The Talking E-Mail Blues
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on advantages and disadvantages of voice e-mail; assesses available programs; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Who Controls Children's Diets?
abstract: Stop the Commercial Exploitation of Children aide Joshua Golin letter on Aug 3 article holds children must be protected from all marketing, not just junk-food ads; drawing

headline: Afghans Report New Attacks by Resurgent Taliban Forces
abstract: Afghan officials have reported another serious attack on their troops in the southeastern part of the country.

headline: Tenet Hospital Is Accused of Illegally Paying for Patient Referrals
abstract: Tenet Healthcare's Alvarado Hospital Medical Center in San Diego is indicted by federal grand jury on charges that it illegally paid doctors to refer patients to hospital; indictment claims Alvarado paid more than $10 million for more than 100 physician-relocation agreements from 1992 to 2002; such agreements are supposed to be used to recruit doctors to move to community served by hospital; says Tenet arranged for substantial portion of money to go not to doctors being recruited but medical practices in Alvarado service area that they were joining; contends money was in exchange for patient referrals; Federal law prohibits payments to induce referral of any patients covered by Medicare or other federal health programs because such decisions are supposed to be based solely on best interests of patient; Tenet Healthcare says it will defend itself vigorously (M)

headline: Bear Stearns Officer Will Get $117 Million in Deferred Pay
abstract: Bear Stearns Companies chairman James E Cayne is receiving $117 million in company stock as deferred compensation, with most of distribution earned from single bonus that has compouned in value for decade; company will also distribute shares worth total of $210 million to Alan C Greenberg, chairman of executive committee, and co-presidents Warren J Spector and Alan D Schwartz (M)

headline: Business People; A 20-Minute Guilt Trip
abstract: Fashion designer Joseph Abboud is honored at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn, where he will be teaching night course in fall (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Variety of Roles Played By Big Board's Top Lawyer  Martin Lipton, left, a founding partner of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, has worn a number of different hats as the opposition to Richard A. Grasso's $139.5 million pay package built over the last month.    As chairman of the New York Stock Exchange's legal advisory committee since 2001, he has been the Big Board's top lawyer. He has also been offering advice to Mr. Grasso on his contract and compensation, and he is preparing a report about how the New York Stock Exchange needs to reform its corporate governance practices. [Page A1.]

headline: Iraqi Factions Seek to Take Over Security Duties
abstract: Five leaders of Iraqi Governing Council devise sweeping new security proposal that would call for most American troops to withdraw to their bases and turn over day-to-day police duties to Iraqi militia forces working under new interior ministry; proposal, which is subject to approval from full Iraqi Governing Council and American authorities, represents strongest action to date on deteriorating security climate in Iraq by leaders of former Iraqi opposition to Saddam Hussein; they are Massoud Barzani, Jalal Talabani, Ahmad Chalabi, Iyad Alawi and Adel Abdul Mahdi; they say they were prompted to act out of deep frustrations over continuing instability in country; Barzani, leader of Kurdish Democratic Party and host of meeting, says US forces are making serious mistakes by trying to become 'front line' occupation forces; says Iraqi militia will work with Iraqi civic and tribal leaders to draw up security arrangements tailored to each part of country; proposal raises questions of how disparate Iraqi militias will function together, if at all, and whether their return to streets will foment warlordism in Iraq; photos and brief sketches of five leaders (M)

headline: Argentina Revisits 'Dirty War': Will General Be Tried?
abstract: Case of Gen Antonio Domingo Bussi, who personified excesses of Argentina's 'dirty war' of 1970's, shows practical difficulties of bringing human rights abusers to justice; he is under house arrest on human rights charges after parlaying his fame as hardest of hard-line generals into narrow victory in Tucuman mayoral race; his partisans say he should be allowed to take office Oct 29; others say he should never have been allowed to run; Spain, which seeks to try him for crimes against humanity, says he personally supervised executions and shot prisoners; human rights groups have documented 680 disappearances during his tenure in city; photos (M)

headline: KONICA GETS U.S. ANTITRUST APPROVAL TO ACQUIRE MINOLTA
abstract: Konica Corp is cleared by Justice Department to buy Minolta Co and become one of Japan's largest makers of camera and imaging equipment; combined company will be called Konica Minolta Holdings (S)

headline: Israelis to Go to U.S. to Discuss Barrier Rift
abstract: Israel to send envoys to United States to test how strongly Bush administration will resist construction of contentious stretches of West Bank barrier near Ariel, large Israeli settlement; Prime Min Ariel Sharon and other Likud Party ministers agree on options to offer US; Al Quds University president Sari Nusseibeh says barrier, which is set to slice through school's sports facilities, Abu Dis, will create pockets of Palestinians isolated from one another, protest rally at site; many Palestinians call barrier land grab; Israel calls it security fence to protect residents from terrorists; Israeli forces enter Jenin and raze former home of suicide bomber who killed 15 Israelis in Haifa last year; incursion sparks gun battles in which two Israeli soldiers are hurt; map (M)

headline: At Sea or on Safari, Satellite Phones Hook Users
abstract: Dozens of companies rent satellite phones to customers going on vacation to remote areas or on cruises where shipboard rates are very high; list of network providers and major retailers; photos (M)

headline: TV Units Help News Corp. Beat Targets In 4th Quarter
abstract: News Corp, media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reports better-than-expected results for its fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30; says net income was $370 million compared with loss of $1.7 million year earlier; revenue rose to $4.6 billion from $3.8 billion; Fox Entertainment Group, which is 80 percent owned by News Corp, says fourth-quarter net income rose to $258 million from $40 million; operating income rose 59 percent, to $505 million; revenue rose 15 percent, to $2.8 billion (M)

headline: A Disgraced Mexican Leader Is Making a Comeback
abstract: Former Mexican president Carlos Salinas de Gortari, whose name became synonymous with fraud, corruption and economic devastation, appears to be staging political comeback; after his fall in 1994, he lived life of outcast, spending time in secretive exile; he returned to Mexico three years ago after country freed itself from seven decades of authoritarian rule by his Institutional Revolutionary Party; there are signs that he has regained some appeal among average Mexicans; his high-profile appearances are setting off alarms among political opponents who denounce him as threat to nation's first multi-party system; nation's growing disillutionment with Pres Vicente Fox, who has been unable to deliver on important economic promises, has some people longing for Salinas's forceful leadership style; Salinas rules out run for political office; photo (M)

headline: Alcan Tries Again to Buy French Rival
abstract: Canada's Alcan, hoping to revive deal blocked once before by European antitrust regulators, offers to acquire France's Pechiney for 3.4 billion euros ($3.85 billion) in cash and stock; combination would create close rival to Alcoa for top rank among world's aluminum producers; aluminum prices have been weak for years, in part because of rapidly expanding production in Russia and China; Alcan says Pechiney would help it cut costs and bolster its market position; Alcan chief executive Travis Engen says company is willing to re-examine plans for its Alunorf mill in Germany, plant that troubled regulators considering earlier merger offer; graphs; photos (M)

headline: A Complaint Box Turns Frustration Into Fun
abstract: This Is Broken is online forum where consumers can air gripes about just about everything; founder Mark Hurst hopes to make businesses and other organizations more aware of their customers when they design products or provide services; photo (M)

headline: Job Training That Works, and It's Free
abstract: Home Front column on Consortium for Worker Education, union-affiliated organization that trains 110,000 people a year; organization, which has contracts to train both union and nonunion workers, offers classes in basic skills like computers and English language; study by Center for an Urban Future praises consortium and other labor-affiliated training efforts, saying they generally do better than programs run by nonprofit organizations or government because training is focused on real jobs, is geared directly to employers and helps prepare for career; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Inflation Slows
abstract: South Africa's inflation slows to 21-month low in August, fueling expectations that central bank will cut interest rates next month for fourth time since June as strong rand reduces prices of imports (S)

headline: Last Respects Are Paid to Head of U.N. Mission in Iraq
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan suggests United Nations Security Council could set up new multinantional force in Iraq that would be led by United States as largest troop contributor; says continuing security concerns in Iraq are part of larger challenge of persuading Iraqis that foreigners there are acting in their interest and intend to restore Iraqi sovereignty quickly; he believes new UN mandate is required to give UN clearly defined role and assure Iraqis that they will regain control over nation's future; travels to Brazil for memorial service for Sergio Vieira de Mello, UN coordinator killed in Baghdad bombing; says his skills cannot be replicated; Mexico angers United States by calling for vote on its moribund resolution on security of UN employees abroad, which US opposes because of its invocation of International Criminal Court powers; diplomats say it would be hard for US to veto resolution so soon after Baghdad bombing of UN staff; map; photo (M)

headline: Liberians Grow Impatient With Waiting for Help
abstract: Thousands of Liberians who have set up camp inside American Embassy-owned compound in Monrovia are growing impatient for arrival of promised help from abroad, particularly US (M)

headline: TERROR GROUP SEEN AS BACK INSIDE IRAQ
abstract: L Paul Bremer III, top civilian administrator in Iraq, receives intelligence that fighters from Ansar al-Islam, militant Islamic organization that US tried to destroy during war, escaped to Iran and has slipped back across border into Iraq, where it plans to conduct major terrorist attacks; says hundreds of Islamic militants are now in Iraq; says Al Qaeda may be in Iraq but there is no conclusive proof of that; says it is impossible to say whether foreign militant organization or former members of Saddam Hussein's government carried out deadly attack on Jordanian Embassy in Baghdad; photo (M)

headline: Reporter Admits BBC Report on Iraqi Arms Had Errors
abstract: Andrew Gilligan said today that there had been errors in his report at the heart of a battle between the BBC and the government.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Odjfell Chief To Be Jailed
abstract: Odfjell, world's biggest operator of deep-sea chemical tankers, says chief executive Bjoern Sjaastad will serve four months in jail in US as part of agreement with prosecutors, vice president Erik Nilsen will serve three-month sentence and company will pay $42.5 million fine after pleading guilty to price fixing (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GULFTERRA ENERGY PARTNERS, Houston, a builder and owner of pipelines and other facilities, and Valero Energy Corp., San Antonio, one of the U.S.'s largest refiners, agreed to form a joint venture in a 390-mile, $458 million pipeline to deliver oil from the Gulf of Mexico to Texas refineries.    EDENS & AVENT, a real estate firm, said it had bought seven shopping centers anchored by Giant Food stores in the Washington, D.C., area from Royal Ahold, the Netherlands, owner of the Stop & Shop and Giant grocery chains. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: New Arbitration Claim in Battle Over Czech TV Station
abstract: Central European Media Enterprises controlled by Ronald S Lauder begins new arbitration claim for $275 million against Czech television station Televize Nova it lost control of in 1999; Central European Media chief executive Fred Klinkhammer says company will keep only $72 million company is still owed by Televize Nova if it wins case before arbitration panel in Vienna, and will return remaining $203 million to Czech treasury; TV Nova calls suit attempt to bribe Czech state into 'killing' station, which has openly attacked government; legal fighting began in 1999, when Central European Media accused Vladimir Zelezny, its partner in TV Nova, of skimming revenue; accusations are still being investigated by Czech police; Zelezny lost control of TV Nova to Czech financial concern PPF Group, which appears to have been indirectly involved in TV Nova for years; Central European Media's latest claim is against PPF (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Economy Shrinks
abstract: Hong Kong's economic output was 3.7 percent lower in second quarter than in first, mainly because of SARS outbreak (S) 2003; drop is atrributed to SARS outbreak (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Acterna Set To Leave Bankruptcy
abstract: Acterna Corp, maker of fiber optic network test equipment, wins bankruptcy judge's approval for its reorganization plan and says it will leave court protection within 10 days (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 29 Private Sector column on eWeek magazine publisher Chris Dobbrow (S)

headline: The Death of an Expert Witness
abstract: News analysis on Lord Hutton's inquiry into death of British weapons expert Dr David Kelly, and overwhelming sense that verdict will mold history's view of whether Prime Min Tony Blair misled nation into going to war against Iraq; also very much at stake is prestige of famous BBC; its naming of Kelly as source of report suggesting government exaggerated Iraqi threat precipitated crisis and culminated in his suicide (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel Reports Operating Profit
abstract: French telecommunications company Alcatel reports second-quarter operating profit of 21 million euros ($24.1 million); posts net loss of 675 million euros, compared with loss of 1.44 billion euros in 2002 period; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Chinese Envoy Arrives
abstract: Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Wang Yi visits North Korea to exchange views in advance of next month's six-party meeting scheduled in Beijing; China is seeking to renegotiate mutual defense treaty (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BANK ONE CORP., Chicago, said it had agreed to buy some real estate operations from a unit of General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn. Terms were not disclosed.    LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS INC., New York, the fourth-biggest securities firm by capital, agreed to buy the Crossroads Group, Dallas, a private equity fund manager. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: THOMSON SELLING HEALTH CARE MAGAZINES TO ADVANSTAR
abstract: Thomson Corp sells its health care magazines to Advanstar Communications for $135 million (S)

headline: Bond Sales Are Scheduled for the Week
abstract: This week's schedule of Treasury auctions includes the sale of new three-  and six-month bills today and a four-week bill on Tuesday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.91 percent, the rate on the six-month issue was 1 percent and the rate on the four-week bill was 0.86 percent.

headline: U.S. Treasury Chief Pledges $1.2 Billion in Afghan Aid
abstract: American Treasury Sec John W Snow, in Kabul, promises $1.2 billion in new American aid to Afghanistan and says he will urge allies to donate at least $1 billion in reconstruction funds at upcoming financial conference in Dubai (S)

headline: Strike Up the Band: An Electronic Accompanist Jumps In
abstract: Francois Pachet designs electronic accompanist that can riff with musician, seamlessly extending and improvising on human player's musical output; photo (M)

headline: Verizon and Unions Meet With Mediator
abstract: Verizon, Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers meet with top federal mediator Peter Hurtgen in effort to avoid strike that could affect local and long-distance phone service in New England and Middle Atlantic States; unions charge company uses industry upheaval as excuse to demand undue flexibility in moving or removing workers; meeting comes after company reports second-quarter earnings of 12 cents a share and revenue gain of 14.3 percent, to $5.5 billion; Verizon reports continued erosion of its core local phone service, but unexpectedly strong growth in brutally competitive wireless business, which is not unionized; graphs of revenue and income; photos (M)

headline: Israel Arrests Irish Bombmaker in West Bank
abstract: The man, reportedly a member of the Real I.R.A., traveled to the West Bank to train Palestinians in making explosives.

headline: Microsoft Eases Licensing Under Pressure From U.S.
abstract: Microsoft makes series of changes intended to make it easier and less expensive for industry competitors and partners to license technical information from company; Justice Dept, which had prodded Microsoft to take such action, says in court filing that it remains concerned by certain Microsoft practices and plans to address those concerns in scheduled conference with federal judge on July 24; several states join in that court filing; focus of much of tension between government and Microsoft is over seemingly arcane software that enables Windows desktop operating systems to share data and work smoothly with Windows programs that run big server computers (M)

headline: As South Africa Awaits Bush, Anti-U.S. Feeling Is in the Air
abstract: South African officials in Pretoria make last-minute arrangements to ensure warm welcome for Pres Bush, but country's graffiti writers seek to convey very different greeting; 'Bush go home' is painted on many walls, and in Johannesburg, posters announce march to protest his visit; in another sign of wariness, Nelson Mandela is conspicuously out of country after criticizing Bush yet again over war in Iraq; coalition of 300 activist groups promises demonstrations against what they describe as America's 'imperial agenda'; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sovereign Rating Affirmed
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp reaffirms Japan's debt ratings and leaves its outlook for country negative because government has failed to produce economic turnaround or end five years of deflation (S)

headline: Factory Orders and Computer Sector Lead Shares Higher
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 38.50 points, to 1,678.73; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 11.43 points, to close at 993.75; Dow Jones industrial average gains 101.89 points, to 9,142.84; graph; chart (M)

headline: GENENTECH SEEKS F.D.A. APPROVAL OF CANCER TREATMENT
abstract: Genentech Inc files application with Food and Drug Administration for approval of its Avastin medicine as treatment for colon cancer (S)

headline: Patents; An economist strolls through history and turns patent theory upside down.
abstract: Prof Petra Moser is attracting attention of fellow scholars with stand in her PhD thesis that strong patent laws may not be good for emerging, largely rural economies; she questions theory that patent laws create incentive for innovation; notes many of best innovators in high technology of late 19th century came from small nations that did not have patent laws; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Mothers Lose Vaccine Appeal
abstract: British Court of Appeals rules two mothers must permit their daughters to be given controversial three-in-one vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella despite study possibly linking vaccine to autism; cases were brought by fathers of girls; court cites lack of evidence against vaccine and strong evidence supporting benefits of vaccinations (S)

headline: People
abstract: Fairchild Publications division of Advance Publications names Mary Murcko publisher of Elegant Bride magazine, which it is acquiring from Pace Communications; she succeeds J Daniel Brock, who is leaving (S)

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS AGREES TO BUY ROSENBLUTH
abstract: American Express Co acquires Rosenbluth International, private travel-management company (S)

headline: African Envoys Try in Vain to See Liberian
abstract: Saga of Pres Charles Taylor's long-awaited departure from Liberia takes new turn as arriving West African diplomats try in vain to see man whose ouster is chief stated goal of rebels attacking capital; photo (S)

headline: Business; It's Back. But Can the New Napster Survive?
abstract: Roxio Inc,

headline: NET INCOME AT NEWMONT MINING INCREASES $22 MILLION
abstract: Newmont Mining Corp, world's biggest gold producer, says that second-quarter profit rose 32 percent, to $747.2 million (S)

headline: Bush Team Faces Widespread Pressure to Act on Liberia
abstract: Bush administration denies deliberately delaying decision on sending troops to strife-torn Liberia; says both rebels and forces loyal to Pres Charles Taylor are being pressed to abide by cease-fire and that US is working with West African nations on deploying peacekeepers (S)

headline: Israelis, and Visitors, Revel in a Summer of Calm
abstract: Israelis enjoy three-month suspension of violence declared by Palestinian groups, but doubt if respite will last; peace plan is trying to reacquaint both Israelis and Palestinians about benefits of tranquillity to generate popular support for political concessions needed to sustain it; each day without terrorist attack is good for tourism; photos (M)

headline: Kennedy Lashes Out on Iraq, Angering G.O.P. Colleagues
abstract: Sen Edward Kennedy, who has worked with Pres Bush on domestic issues, angers Republicans with caustic criticism of Iraq war and postwar planning; Kennedy says troops are paying with their lives for administration's failure to plan for peace, calls rationale for war 'fraud' and says more Americans are coming around to his view (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pechiney Again Rejects Takeover Offer From Alcan  Pechiney, the French aluminum and packaging group, has rebuffed a second takeover offer from Alcan of Canada, but has left the door open for Alcan to raise its bid again.    Alcan, based in Montreal, valued its latest offer at 47 to 48 euros ($51.68 to $52.78) in stock and cash for each Pechiney share, a total of 4 billion euros ($4.4 billion). Alcan made its first, unsolicited bid for Pechiney on July 7 with an offer of 41 euros a share. [C4.]

headline: To the Battlements; Tools for Brooking a Torrent of Invaders
abstract: Roundup of computer antivirus and security software (M)

headline: Publisher at GQ Magazine Resigns
abstract: Conde Nast Publications said Ron Galotti will be leaving the magazine immediately and named Peter King Hunsinger as his replacement.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls aainst euro on weak manufacturing report that muddles outlook for US economic recovery; euro settles at $1.1563, up from $1.1484 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: After 3 Years, Mideast Conflict Shapes Life on Both Sides
abstract: Three years of violence have changed Jerusalem, and people who live and work there; Israelis and Palestinians, who say they have tried to resist altering their lives, describe changes have been forced upon them; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Tenet to Pay $54 Million In Settlement With U.S.  Tenet Healthcare agreed to pay $54 million to resolve government accusations that doctors at a hospital in Northern California conducted unnecessary cardiac procedures and surgical operations on hundreds of patients.    The settlement was the largest ever reached in a case involving what is known as ''medical necessity fraud'' -- in other words, billing government health programs for tests and treatments that the patient's condition did not require. [Page A1.]

headline: Pension Funds Weighing the Risks of Emerging Markets
abstract: Portfolios column on moves by four New York City pension funds to shift $1.7 billion of their assets to relatively risky emerging-market stocks; graph (S)

headline: Slain Cleric Offered Several Faces
abstract: Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, the influential Iraqi Shiite leader killed in Najaf today, tried to negotiate different worlds.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett In Joint Research Venture
abstract: Hewlett-Packard and Partners HealthCare System plan to announce multiyear, multimillion-dollar joint research program that seeks to accelerate progress in clinical genomics; goalis to use computer technology to help collect, store and analyze genetic information of patients, then tailor preventive and therapeutic regimens for individual patients, concept known as individualized medicine (S)

headline: With Issues to Resolve, Bush Welcomes Putin to Camp David
abstract: Pres Bush welcomes Pres Vladimir Putin to Camp David to demonstrate that two are problem-solvers working together, despite divisions on Iraq and Russia's sale of nuclear technology to Iran (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Heat Death Toll Put At 11,000
abstract: French Ministry of Health reports 11,435 more deaths than average for month of August; increase is being attributed to record-breaking heat wave (S)

headline: After Two Steady Years, UBS Shuffles Managers
abstract: UBS says Mark B Sutton will succeed Joseph J Grano Jr as chief executive of its US brokerage unit Paine Webber; president Peter A Wuffli will become chief executive (M)

headline: U.S. Considers Private Iraqi Force to Guard Sites
abstract: Pentagon is considering plan to create and train private Iraqi security force and make it responsible for guarding pipelines, government buildings and hundreds of other sites in Iraq; new private force would be composed primarily of former Iraqi soldiers armed with small weapons; it would take over from American troops guard duties at as many as 2,000 sites; proposed force would provide jobs to potentially thousands of unemployed Iraqis and ease burden on American military that is being stretched thin in Iraq despite presense there of nearly 150,000 soldiers; some Pentagon officials believe private Iraqi security guards could help ease tensions created by atmosphere of foreign military occupation; note that putting more weapons in hands of former Iraqi soldiers and other Iraqis would raise some security concerns; say cost of training force would be paid by United States taxpayers, as would their salaries until Iraqi government emerges; proposed force would be separate from new Iraqi Army and Iraqi police force; senior executive at Kroll Inc, private security consulting concern, says company has been involved in 'brainstorming sessions' in Baghdad with officials of Coalition Provisional Authority about possible role for Kroll in establishing private Iraqi security force (M)

headline: Low-Cost Airlines Become Big Spenders
abstract: Low-cost airlines in United States and Europe are buying planes at frenzied pace in bid for fast growth, raising question of whether their growth will outstrip demand for flights account for 61 percent of narrow-body jet orders so far this year and 75 percent in 2002, up from 15.5 percent in 2001; Southwest Airlines, world's most profitable carrier ever, is tempering its growth even as younger low-cost peers push ahead with ambitious expansion plans; graphs of carriers' share of jet orders; photo (M)

headline: Kmart Appoints 3 to Executive Positions
abstract: Kmart Holding Corp names Bruce Johnson se

headline: Edison Stays Afloat By Altering Course
abstract: Edison Schools, nation's first and largest for-profit school management company, has survived year in which it settled regulatory complaint over its accounting, was promptly sued by shareholders and was embroiled in ugly political battle in Philadelphia that resulted in cutting in half number of schools it was hired to manage there; chief executive H Christopher Whittle says Edison will now seek to manage public schools only in midsize markets; financial controls implemented by vice chairman Charles J Delaney discussed; chart; photos (M)

headline: In Patagonia, Sheep Ranches Get Another Chance
abstract: Vast sheep ranches of Argentina's Patagonia region are making comeback, spurred by rise in wool prices and demand for mutton; local producers are increasingly being joined by foreign investors; ranches are being bolstered by drastic devaluation of Argentine peso; photo (M)

headline: Burmese Defy U.S. Demands For Release Of Activist
abstract: Burmese military junta is not expected to release pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi any time soon; photo (S)

headline: Personal Finance In the Classroom
abstract: Walt Gardner letter responds to June 22 article on financial education for high school students; says inclusion of practical knowledge in area, as advocated by National Council on Economic Education and other organizations, faces big challenge in today's educational climate

headline: U.N. Says U.S. Eradication of Coca in Colombia Is Working
abstract: United Nations releases estimates showing that American-financed aerial eradication of Colombia's vast coca fields has caused size of crop to drop by 32 percent in first seven months of year; says production of coca--main ingredient in cocaine--is increasing slightly in Peru and Bolivia; American Congress is debating whether to provide another $700 million in aid to Colombia on top of $2.5 billion Washington has spent since 2000 to eradicate coca (M)

headline: Business People; Piano Man Pitches Japan: I'll Have Mine on the Rocks
abstract: piano man pitches japan: i'll

headline: Essay Texts? This Encyclopedia Booms, Flows and Rotates
abstract: New Encarta Reference Library 2004 from Microsoft offers interactive interface and video, as well as improved homework center that helps students plan and complete assignments; photo (M)

headline: Tense Meeting of Sharon and Abbas Ends in Stalemate
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers emerge from tense two-hour meeting in Jerusalem at loggerheads; Ariel Sharon rebuffs demands for immediate troop withdrawals and release of prisoners, saying Mahmoud Abbas must first dismantle military groups; both sides indicate some flexibility and willingness to keep talking; essential stalement in their positions shifts focus to Washington and to their coming separate meetings with Pres Bush; both sides seem to make concessions only in presence of Aemricans, to show willingness to compromise under Washington's so-called road map; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., the computer services company, won a contract for about $400 million to perform payroll and benefits work for Procter & Gamble, Cincinnati.    LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES INC., Murray Hill, N.J., the maker of telephone equipment, won an order from AT&T Corp., Bedminster, N.J., for fiber optic networking products. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Bremer Cites Marshall Plan in Bid for Iraqi Aid
abstract: American administrator in Iraq L Paul Bremer III, defending Bush administration's request for $87 billion on Capitol Hill, compares it to Marshall Plan; says that without aid, Iraq will become global menace; Bremer, asked why Iraq could not pay more of cost itself out of current or future oil revenues, notes sabotage of its oil production system that will take two or three years to fix; photo (M)

headline: Beijing Sends Officials to Review Hong Kong Discontent
abstract: The team of officials will ask local leaders and residents why they are so upset and to collect ideas for what to do next, pro-Beijing politicians said today.

headline: 3 G.I.'S ARE KILLED GUARDING HOSPITAL NORTH OF BAGHDAD
abstract: Three American soldiers with Fourth Infantry Division are killed and four are wounded in Baquba after assailant, who witnesses say was probably perched inside children's hospital they were guarding, throws grenade into group of soldiers playing cards next to building; military officials say that another American soldier was killed and two others wounded in attack on Army convoy in Abu Ghraib, just west of Baghdad; drawings, maps show American military deaths since beginning of war; photo (L)

headline: First Wave Of Suits Hits Mutual Funds Under Inquiry
abstract: Nearly dozen plaintiff law firms have brought lawsuits against companies that manage mutual funds in three weeks since New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer accused some fund companies of allowing favored investors to engage in trades not possible for most shareholders; Bank One, Strong Capital Management, Bank of America and Janus have been named in suits, as they were by Spitzer (M)

headline: Experts Attempt to Isolate Malicious Computer Program
abstract: Computer experts scrambled today to track down 20 computers around the world that had been infected with a malicious computer program.

headline: Executives Can See Problems Beyond File Sharing
abstract: Many record label executives say industry's problems go beyond file sharing; among problems they cite are consolidation of radio stations, making it harder to expose new bands and records, and lack of widely popular musical trend like teen-pop, which relied on stars like Britney Spears and 'N Sync to drive young people to record stores; also blame poor economy and competition for limited time and money of teenagers and young adults, their main customers, who often find that they prefer buying DVD's, video games and more; thousands of music retail stores have closed recently, and ones that are still open have given shelf space to competing programs, like DVD's and video games; introduction of CD's in early 1980's encouraged consumers to replace their vinyl records with copies in new format, but that sales spike has since abated; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Judge Approves AT&T Wireless Settlement
abstract: AT&T Wireless Services Inc wins Delaware Chancery Court Judge Leo Strine Jr's approval for $47.5 million settlement of shareholder suits challenging its purchase of TeleCorp PCS Inc last year (S)

headline: Business People
abstract: One of the Few That Got Away From Icahn.

headline: Afghanistan Speeds Up Purge of Officials After Bomb Attack
abstract: Central government in Afghanistan speeds up sweeping purge of provincial officials in regions hardest hit by intensifying pro-Taliban insurgency; move comes after more than 50 people are killed in clashes and bomb attack in single day; Interior Min Ali Ahmad Jalali announces replacements of security chiefs in provinces of Kandahar, Kunar, Paktia, Khost, Tahar and Logar; says 6 of 14 security district chiefs in Kabul have been fired; firings seen as effort to boost public confidence in Pres Hamid Karzai's government despite rising violence; photo (M)

headline: Investing; Lower Taxes Change Thinking on Options
abstract: Some financial advisers say employees holding nonqualified stock options trading above strike price should consider exercising them sooner rather than later, especially if they plan to hold on to shares, in order to take advantage of cuts in top marginal income tax rate, long-term capital gains tax rate and dividend tax cut; implication of tax cuts for holders of incentive options are more ambiguous (M)

headline: U.S. Weighs Reward if North Korea Scraps Nuclear Arms
abstract: Bush administration, preparing for next round of multilateral talks with North Korea, reportedly is again divided over concessions to North; weighs some conciliatory steps and might offer economic benefits after North Korea dismantles its nuclear program; United States official says US and Japan take harder line, while South Korea favors 'front-loading' some concessions in return for preliminary steps by North toward nuclear disarmament; administration says Under Sec John R Bolton, figure much reviled by North Korea, will not take part in next round of talks, Beijing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry Executive To Leave
abstract: Mike Metcalf plans to leave as Burberry Group's chief operating officer and finance head in Mar 2004 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cincinnati Bell Chief To Step Down
abstract: Cincinnati Bell Inc, local phone company, says chief executive Kevin Mooney is leaving (S)

headline: Threshold; HDTV for Less Than $1,000
abstract: Samsung is selling high-definition television set for under $1,000; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of chart in Sept 19 Business Day section showing which directors of New York Stock Exchange were on board in 1999 when it approved contract for then chairman Richard A Grasso

headline: Marketers Say They Intend To Join Effort To Fight Spam
abstract: Direct Marketing Association quietly begins working with federal law enforcement officials, regulators and Internet service providers to develop high-technology group dedicated to helping shut down most egregious users of bulk e-mail; intent will be 'to identify significant spam operators who are violating existing laws, develop cases and refer them to appropriate state, federal or international prosecuting authorities'; campaign is seeking $65,000 'participation fee' from association's members; move is attempt to blunt efforts to prod Congress and states into approving significantly tougher anti-spam laws; direct marketing group supports relatively mild legislation; photo (M)

headline: Sun to Introduce New Pricing Strategy for Its Software
abstract: Sun Microsystems, supplier of network computers, will announce new approach to selling its products and software; has been losing business in recent years to servers based on lower-priced personal computers; Sun's executives hope that new strategy--substantially reducing price of its network software for many customers while simplifying way it is purchased--will help company regain its diminishing market position; program is also central to Sun's efforts to portray itself as supplier of integrated software and computers that are more efficient for corporate users; photo (M)

headline: Disc Goal: Pain-Free Burning
abstract: Wilson Rothman State of the Art column explores popularity of CD burning as technology improves; compares software packages from Adaptec and Ahead; drawing; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Galen Ends Talks
abstract: Galen Holdings, Northern Irish pharmaceutical company, ends takeover talks with unidentified suitor, widely reported to be Barr Laboratories; Galen's stock falls; stock price graph (S)

headline: Bond Sale Schedule For the Week Ahead
abstract: This week's schedule of Treasury auctions includes the sale of new three-  and six-month bills today and a four-week bill on Tuesday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.87 percent, the rate on the six-month issue was 0.93 percent and the rate on the four-week bill was 0.80 percent.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Proposed Directors Back Out
abstract: Active Value, largest shareholder in British advertising firm Cordiant Communications Group, says executives Richard Wheatly and Stephen Davidson that it nominated to be Cordiant directors as part of attempt to take control of company have decided not to participate; Cordiant shareholders will vote on July 23 whether or not to accept WPP Group's merger bid (S)

headline: Stop Automatic Help
abstract: When It's Unwelcome    Q. How can I prevent Microsoft Word from formatting lists automatically as I work on a document?    A. Most recent versions of Microsoft Word include automatic formatting and correction features designed to make text styling, like bulleted or numbered lists, quick and easy. While this can sometimes be helpful, you may not want Word to make changes while a document is being composed.

headline: U.S. and Europe Set To Reduce Subsidies
abstract: In an effort to breathe life into global trade negotiations, the United States and the European Union said that they had agreed on a way to reduce the subsidies and import duties used to protect their farmers.    Agriculture subsidies have been the chief obstacle in the current round of negotiations at the World Trade Organization.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mutual Funds Closing
abstract: World Business Briefing: Mutual Fund Closingl

headline: Tough Times Force U.A.W. To Employ New Strategy
abstract: Nearly simultaneous deals United Automobile Workers reached with Ford Motor Co and Chrysler Group represent sharp break with tradition and underscore how tough times are for Big Three and their suppliers; contracts keep union workers' generous health care benefits largely intact, but UAW reportedly gives ground on other important issues, including scaling back wage increases and selectively lifting ban on plant closings; union continues talks with General Motors and Delphi, parts maker spun off from GM in 1999; graphs shows rising labor costs at Ford and DaimlerChrysler and rising cost of health care at DaimlerChrysler (M)

headline: No. 2 in Trucking, Yellow, Will Buy No. 1, Roadway
abstract: Yellow Corp, nation's second-largest trucking company, will acquire industry leader Roadway Corp for $966 million; Yellow's chairman William D Zollars, who will head new company, insists two will continue to operate separately; Roadway's chief executive James D Staley and Zollars comment; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: North Korea Security Pact Proposed
abstract: North Korean and South Korean officials meet with senior Russian diplomats in Moscow to discuss possible security agreement with North Korea; Russia, United States, Japan, China and South Korea hope adoption of security guarantees will persuade North Korea to abandon nuclear weapons program (S)

headline: AIDS-Afflicted Villagers Say Chinese Police Attacked Them
abstract: Residents of Xiongqiao, AIDS-afflicted village in central China, say police raided village, rampaging through homes, beating residents and arresting 13 people; say attack was apparently in retaliation for villagers' previous protests calling for better medical care; raid is largest such clash between officials and residents in rural Henan Province, where AIDS is claiming growing numbers of lives and medical care is minimal; Xiongqiao is one of many villages in province experiencing AIDS epidemic caused by government-induced blood trading in 1990's; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: KT Posts Net Profit
abstract: South Korean telephone service provider KT Corp reports net profit of 325.5 billion won ($275.8 million) for April through June, down from net profit of 488.5 billion won ($413.7 million) in second quarter year earlier; sales were 2.95 trillion won, up 2.9 percent, in quarter (S)

headline: Blair Did Not Knowingly Use False Report, Inquiry Is Told
abstract: Senior British government officials tell high-profile inquiry that intelligence officers registered their concern at way Prime Min Tony Blair's government presented threat from Iraq's weapons systems before going to war, but officials deny that government knowingly used false information to create sense of imminent threat from Iraq; question of whether government deliberately exaggerated threat is at heart of most serious challenge to Blair's credibility and popularity since he came to office in 1997 (M)

headline: For Absent-Minded Travelers, Electrical Gear at the Ready
abstract: If you have ever unpacked your travel bag to find that you left behind an essential power cord or adapter, you will understand how the people at American Power Conversion came up with its briefcase. The company's TravelPower case comes with an adapter that can recharge a computer and two other devices simultaneously from a single outlet.      A nylon version of the bag costs $100; leather is $130. They are available from American Power Conversion at www.apc.com, other online sellers like CDW Computer Centers (www.cdw.com) and at bricks-and-mortar retailers, including Office Max and Circuit City.

headline: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Trade Proposal Criticized
abstract: Japan, Australia and India criticize proposals made by United States and European Union to remove barriers to global trading in farm products; photo (S)

headline: Wave of Immigrants Breaks Against Italian Island's Shore
abstract: Italian island of Lampedusa, just 70 miles from nearest point in Africa, has become Italy's main portal for immigrants, many of whom die along the way; island's harbor is littered with half-submerged remains of more than dozen badly rotted boats that were used by latest wave of illegal immigrants; their determination underscores shortcomings of any crackdown on illegal immigration; current year is shaping up to be record one for immigrants; local officials say that in June, more than 2,000 illegal immigrants from across Africa arrived in boats; this brings total for year to more than 4,200; officials in Lampedusa say they cannot keep count of voyagers who die when their flimsy boats sink; Italy and other European nations have had limited success in getting African governments to halt boats and crack down on people-smugglers; photos; map (M)

headline: Schiaparelli's revolutionary legacy
abstract: 'Shocking attire" reads the invitation for next week's fashion event. That dress code might seem difficult at a time of visible bras and hipster pants. But the party in Philadelphia on Sept. 25 to launch an exhibition on Elsa Schiaparelli, 30 years after her death in 1973, will prove just how revolutionary the designer's work was to 20th-century fashion.

headline: Iraqi Shiite Calls Police Policy Unfair
abstract: The leader of the main Shiite political group lashed out at the occupation authorities for failing to integrate former Shiite militia members into the police force.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises after Commerce Department report shows US retail sales increased in July by most in four months; dollar settles at 119.20 yen, up from 118.45 yen, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Market Place; As More Markets Go Public, Salaries Are Under Scrutiny
abstract: Salary of James J McNulty, president and chief executive of Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, was less than $1.9 million last year, but when his stock options are added, his potential is many times larger; McNulty's options on shares of exchange, which recently went public, are worth $69 million; total value climbs to $86 million when options he holds that cannot be exercised yet are added; American Stock Exchange says its chairman and chief executive, Salvatore Sodano, was paid $5 million last year; his package includes pension, deferred compensation and severance agreement that totals about $22 million; Chicago Board of Trade, which is taking steps toward going public, appears so far to have decided not to give its top five executives stock options or shares in proposed public company; Meyer S Frucher, chairman and chief operating officer of Philadelphia Stock Exchange, was paid salary of $600,000 in 2002 and bonus of $300,000; board gave him $600,000 loan, which is being forgiven at $200,000 a year in effort to retain him; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Try Diplomacy Abroad
abstract: With little progress in the Mideast peace process, Palestinian and Israeli leaders set out on separate diplomatic missions today.

headline: U.S. Stand Is Headache for Ally in Colombia
abstract: Bush administration is withholding $5 million in military aid to Colombia and threatening to suspend $130 million more next year unless Colombia agrees to exempt all Americans there from being sent abroad for prosecution by newly created International Criminal Court; Colombia claims such an agreement is unnecessary because existing accord already denies Colombia legal jurisdiction over Americans working there in official capacity; standoff creates uncomfortable situation for Pres Alvaro Uribe, one of Washington's closest allies in Latin America; administration fears court may become forum for politically motivated charges against American officials or members of military (M)

headline: Gambling on Good Health
abstract: Abby Ellin article on risky game played by many middle-class young people unable to afford health insurance; cites relatively low-cost insurance options (M)

headline: How to Find That Needle Hopelessly Lost In the Haystack
abstract: How to Find That Needle Hopelessly Lost In the Haystack**Major manufacturers and retailers and Defense Department are pushing to speed development of new product tags equipped with microchips and tiny antennas that transmit digital response when contacted by radio signals from scanning devices; radio frequency identification devices that could be read by scanners anywhere in world would make it cheaper and more efficient to track flow of goods from global suppliers to consumers; Defense Department is expected to call on its suppliers to adopt new version of technology by 2005; growing business interest in technology spurs efforts by privacy advocates to strictly limit its use; graphs of uses of devices (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Power Failure Affects Ebay Service
abstract: Power failure in eBay's Web hosting center cripples Web auction service for nearly three hours; failure strikes Qwest Communications center in Santa Clara, Calif, that serves as host for many of eBay's Web servers (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer Upbeat On Results
abstract: SAB Miller chief executive Graham Mackay describes positive results for brewer for three months ended June 30, annual meeting (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Auto Growth
abstract: World Business BriÔ

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Outlook For Advertiser
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp lowers outlook on credit rating of Japanese advertising agency Dentsu Inc to negative from stable because of growing debts and investments in noncore businesses (S)

headline: Hoping to Ace Algebra the Second Time
abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column tackles issue of how much to help children with their homework; drawing (M)

headline: Former Economist at Goldman Is Indicted
abstract: Goldman Sachs former senior economist John M Youngdahl is indicted for insider trading, fraud, perjury and other charges in connection with purchase of about $318 million of 30-year bonds and bond futures minutes ahead of Treasury Department's announcement in 2001 that it was ending sale of 30-year bonds; Goldman Sachs and MFS Investment Management consent to Securities and Exchange Commission order that censures them in connection with trading of 30-year bonds and futures based on insider information; Goldman agrees to pay back $3.8 million in profits, $500,000 in interest and $5 million penalty; MFS will pay $200,000 penalty and $717,858 to cover losses of bond dealer who sold about $65 million in bonds to MFS manager Steven E Nothern ahead of official Treasury announcement on eliminating 30-year bond; companies do not admit or deny SEC findings; SEC says Goldman did all its buying in eight minutes on Oct 31, 2001 when Treasury helped confuse situation by inadvertently putting announcement on its Web site, 17 minutes early; Washington consultant Peter J Davis, who passed on information to Youngdahl and to Nothern, who pleads guilty to felony charges involving insider trading, conspiracy and theft of government property; also consents to civil SEC complaint on fraud charges, without admitting or denying accusations; SEC also files civil fraud complaints against Youngdahl and Nothern; is seeking $3.1 million in profits that MFS bond mutual funds made on insider information from Nothern, not from MFS itself; indictment is brought by US attorney James B Comey; photo (M)

headline: Hey, KFC: Make it Better, Sir Paul Says
abstract: Sir Paul McCartney challenges David C Novak, chief executive of KFC Corp parent Yum Brands, to improve living conditions of 750 million chickens served up annually; company says it buys and cooks, but does not slaughter, chickens (S)

headline: Commander Doesn't Expect More Foreign Troops in Iraq
abstract: Gen John P Abizaid, commander of United States forces in Persian Gulf, says he is no longer counting on foreign troops to relieve American soldiers in Iraq early next year; lack of such troops would require Pentagon to send active-duty and National Guard soldiers to fill gap; about 20,000 Reserve and National Guard troops are now in Iraq or Kuwait, and many are affected by Army's recent decision to keep reservists there for up to 12 months, months longer than usual for overseas deployments; Abizaid acknowledges that Army order has upset and confused many reservists, who, unlike active-duty soldiers, have not yet been given departure date from Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Bank of America Executive Is Said to Have Departed
abstract: Robert H Gordon, chief executive of Banc of America Capital Management, has left company; Gordon figured prominently in complaint filed last week by New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer against Canary Capital; complaint said Gordon allowed Canary, hedge fund run by Edward J Stern, to trade in and out of bank's funds quickly and improperly over last two years; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | South Pacific: Australia: New Post For Former U.N. Weapons Chief
abstract: Former UN weapons inspector Richard Butler, who is advocate of Australia breaking constitutional links with Great Britain, is to be appointed governor of Tasmania (S)

headline: Business; A Tech Company Wins Big in the War on Terror
abstract: a tï

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Monetary Meeting Minutes
abstract: Minutes of Monetary Policy Committee's July 9-10 meeting show seven of eight colleagues backed Mervyn A King, Bank of England's new governor, in voting to cut benchmark interest rate to 3.5 percent (S)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Online Diary column; BumpList is forum with no defined topic, which allows six subscribers at a time in discussion; when new person joins, someone is bumped off to make room and, to rejoin, user must resubscribe; new Internet site called Word combines texts from major religions in single database, which can be searched simultaneously for any keyword or phrase; cultish devotion has developed around Most Viewed and Most E-Mailed sections of Yahoo News; miscellaneous sites noted; drawing (M)

headline: Profit for Boston Scientific
abstract: Boston Scientific, stent maker, reports second-quarter net inco

headline: Driving Overtime, and Pushing the Limits
abstract: Article on growing number of business travelers who are involved in auto accidents because of driver fatigue; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration estimates that drowsiness is primary cause of 100,000 police-reported crashes each year, resulting in at least 76,000 injuries and 1,500 deaths; some devices to keep drivers awake at wheel noted; photo (M)

headline: NBC Is Hoping Short Movies Keep Viewers From Zapping
abstract: NBC plans to intersperse short movies, usually one minute long, among commercials accompanying its prime-time shows in bid to induce viewers to watch blocks of commercials and perhaps stay with network entire night to catch conclusion of minimovie; advertising executives welcome bid to tamp down channel-flipping; NBC has so far produced 10 one-minute movies, each broken into two 30-second installments, and one four-minute film; minimovies will not cut into time alloted commercials or network promotions; photo (M)

headline: Bush Declares Violence in Iraq Tests U.S. Will
abstract: Pres Bush calls continued fighting in Iraq 'point of testing in the war on terror' and vows United States will not back down there or anywhere it faces violent Islamic extremism, speech, American Legion convention, St Louis; Bush, in broad defense of his foreign policy, suggests pacifying Iraq, hunting down Al Qaeda in Afghanistan and bringing peace to Middle East are all part of larger struggle against terrorists fearful of democracy and civilized values; holds failing to fight terrorists abroad would expose US to attacks at home; photo (M)

headline: Arafat Orders Militants Jailed, but They Balk
abstract: Yasir Arafat acts to put some 20 Palestinian militants under detention at his compound at Ramallah on West Bank, but detainees refuse to be sent to jail in Jericho, as demanded by Israel as condition for withdrawal of its troops from Ramallah; standoff reflects division between Arafat and Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas over how to handle negotiations with Israel (M)

headline: S.E.C. Demands 6-Month Ban On New Ernst & Young Clients
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission repeats its demands that accounting firm Ernst & Young be banned from accepting new auditing clients for six months because it had improper business relationship with software firm PeopleSoft from 1994 to 1999; Ernst & Young spokesman says firm and SEC have presented their positions in case and it is time to leave matter to judicial process (M)

headline: 261 LAWSUITS FILED ON MUSIC SHARING
abstract: Recording industry files 261 lawsuits against people who share copyrighted music over Internet, charging them with copyright infringement in first broad legal action aimed at ordinary users of file-sharing networks; lawsuits seen as turning point for music industry, which has sought to avoid direct conflict with its potential consumers as it battles online piracy; industry officials say only way to stem widespread file-swapping is to make people realize they will be punished for participating; Carl Sherman, president of Recording Industry Assn of America, says his group is offering amnesty for file sharers who turn themselves in before legal action is taken against them; says defendants were selected by employing simple search techniques that allow anyone using major file-sharing services to see what files other users are making available to copy from their own computers; some critics say industry risks stirring widespread resentment in cracking down on activity embraced by estimated 60 million Americans; photo; graph (M)

headline: MGH Hires 4 From a Doner Office
abstract: MGH Advertising in Owings Mills, Md, hires four employees from Doner's Baltimore office--John Patterson, Sharon Kane, Peter Cline and Thomas Gill (S)

headline: The Ways to Pay Financial Advisers
abstract: Marc J Lewyn letter says excellent investment adviser is well worth one percent a year or more

headline: Canada Recalls Envoy From Iran After Burial of Detained Reporter
abstract: Canada announces it is pulling its ambassador out of Iran after Canadian freelance photographer Zahra Kazemi, who died in Iranian custody after blow to head, is buried in her birthplace in southern Iran; Canadian government had demanded that her remains be sent to Canada for autopsy and burial; Kazemi was arrested on June 23 as she took pictures of protests outside prison in Tehran, where many dissidents are jailed; Iranian government first said she suffered stroke, then later admitted she died from brain hemorrhage caused by blow to her head; Canadian Foreign Min Bill Graham warns of other sanctions being considered against Iranl photo (M)

headline: British Soldier Killed in Confrontation With Group of Iraqis
abstract: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 28 — A British soldier was killed on Wednesday and another injured when their convoy encountered a mob of Iraqis blocking a road in southern Iraq as they returned to their base after arresting two loyalists to Saddam Hussein, British military authorities said today.

headline: Northwest Chief Says Airline Will Not File for Bankruptcy
abstract: Northwest Airlines, which warned unions in the spring that it would have to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if workers did not grant nearly $1 billion in wage and benefit concessions, said today that a bankruptcy filing would not be necessary.    That does not mean the airline has given up on obtaining cutbacks. Indeed, company executives reiterated their need to reduce wages and benefits to levels achieved at other large carriers like United Airlines, American Airlines and US Airways.

headline: Studios Moving To Block Piracy Of Films Online
abstract: Movie industry is on coordinated offensive to thwart free downloading of films before it spins out of control; Motion Picture Assn of America, industry's trade group, has begun nationwide piracy awareness campaign in movie theaters and on television, and security guards at movie premieres are equipped with night-vision goggles to search for people in audience carrying banned video recorders; studios are aggressively putting electronic watermarks on movie prints so they can determine who is abetting file sharing; 'stealing is bad' message will be promoted in schools next month; some movie executives wonder whether it is wise to send out early DVD's to Academy Award voters, fearing films will be distributed online; many Hollywood executives say there is still time before free Internet movie swapping takes hold, noting Internet movie files are still large and take as much as two hours to download; but there is growing contingent who fear threat is closer than some in Hollyood want to admit; photo (M)

headline: 2 Giants Make Separate Deals for Drugs
abstract: Aventis agrees to pay $125 million up front, and possibly as much as $510 million, to license cancer drug V.E.G.F. Trap from Regeneron Pharmaceuticals; drug is in first of three stages of clinical trials, meaning itg has not yet fully demonstrated basic safety in humans; Amgen agrees to pay $86.5 million up front to Biovitrum, with up to about $400 million to come later, for rights to diabetes drug that works in novel way; that drug is in early stages of Phase 2 trials, meaning it has not yet demonstrated its efficacy (M)

headline: 47 Pakistanis Die in Attack On Shiite Rites
abstract: Suspected Islamic militants, including suicide bomber, attack mosque, Quetta, Pakistan, killing 47 Shiite Muslim worshipers and wounding 65 others; three attackers die; officials see effort to ignite cycle of violence between Sunnis and Shiites and destabilize nation; witness says attackers first killed security guards outside mosque and then moved inside and started firing on people; heavily armed police and troops flood city's streets in bid to prevent rioting and retaliatory killings; Pres Pervez Musharraf, in Paris, vows to pursue extremists (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Sciences To Add Jobs In India
abstract: Computer Sciences Corp plans to double its work force in India; expects to hire 1,000 employees in India this fiscal year (S)

headline: Microsoft to Give Its Employees Stock Instead of Options
abstract: The announcement is the clearest sign yet that stock options have lost some of the cachet they held just a few years ago.

headline: HCA LOWERS EARNINGS FORECAST AS ADMISSIONS SLOW
abstract: HCA Inc lowers earnings forecast for second quarter, citing slow admissions and its underestimation of amount of bills it might not be able to collect (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PARK PLACE ENTERTAINMENT CORP., Las Vegas, the world's largest casino operator, may have its credit rating cut to below investment grade by Standard & Poor's because it plans to build a casino near Chicago. Standard & Poor's said Park Place should pay down debt before expanding.    FIRSTENERGY CORP., Akron, Ohio, the fifth-largest utility owner in the United States, reported a second-quarter loss of $57.9 million, or 20 cents a share. The company plans to restate results from 2002 and the first quarter of this year.

headline: Novartis Meets Profit Forecast As Sales of Its Top Drugs Rise
abstract: novartis meets profit forecast as sal

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Deal In Credit Services
abstract: Fair Isaac Corp says it bought Narex, developer of UniScore credit rating system, for $10 million (S)

headline: The Big Mo in Stocks Hits a Wall of Trading Costs
abstract: Mark Hulbertr

headline: 2 Nations Set Aside Ill Will for an Ill Child
abstract: Noor Sajjad, age 2, and her parents have become symbols of re-established 'people to people' contacts between average Indians and Pakistanis since parents brought Pakistani child to India for heart surgery last month; partial re-opening of border that made trip possible has spurred unexpected groundswell of popular support for peace between longtime rivals; photo (M)

headline: Big Board's Interim Chief Tells Washington About His Plans
abstract: John S Reed spends his first day as interim head of New York Stock Exchange meeting with its directors and with top officials at Securities and Exchange Commission to go over his plans to overhaul way exchange governs itself; outlines for first time ambitious agenda he hopes to accomplish in coming months: propose new governing structure, figure out who ought to be on board, recruit full-time leader and return to retirement; meets with Securities and Exchange chairman William H Donaldson; dines with H Carl McCall, departing chairman of exchange's corporate governance committee, and Leon E Panetta, former director and current co-chairman of committee; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: New Ruling May Delay Start Of Do-Not-Call Registry  Congress overwhelmingly passed legislation aimed at allowing a national do-not-call registry against unwanted telemarketing to take effect next week as planned. But hours after the vote, which effectively overturned a federal judge's injunction against the registry, a second judge declared it a violation of free speech.     The new ruling was the latest twist in an on-again off-again drama involving the registry. Unless it is overturned, the latest judicial ruling effectively prevents the government from going ahead with the hugely popular federal program, which 50 million Americans have signed up for. [Page A1.]

headline: Cochin Journal; This Guru Hugs a Lot, and Gets Lots of Love Back
