abstract: Indian meritocracy, which has produced some of world's most successful technology enterpreneurs, has also transformed woman of humble roots into global guru worshiped by millions; guru, known as Amma, is joined by India's deputy prime minister, Hollywood stars, peace advocates and hundreds of thousands of devotees to celebrate her 50th birthday in Cochin in southern India; as part of event, Pres A P J Abdul Kalam brings together Indian and Indian-American business leaders to help realize his vision for making India developed nation by 2020; photos; map (M)

headline: I Dream of Royalties
abstract: iA

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: McDonald's Offers WI-FI
abstract: McDonald's Corp switches on wireless Internet access in 55 of its San Francisco area restaurants, with 20 additional outlets expected in next few weeks; customers who buy Big Mac Extra Value Meal during promotion spanning next six weeks will receive free wireless fidelity, known as Wi-Fi, Internet service for two hours; Wayport installed California network (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Concern For Opposition Leader
abstract: State Department spokesman Richard A Boucher expresses Bush administration concerns over health of Myanmar pro-democracy political prisoner Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who is reportedly staging hunger strike in protest of her detention; urges military government to release her and other political prisoners (S)

headline: Pentagon Asserts Baghdad Bombing Won't Alter U.S. Tactics
abstract: The bombing of the Jordanian embassy in Baghdad will not disrupt American military operations in Iraq, a high-ranking Pentagon official said today.

headline: Inquiry Into Death of British Arms Expert Concludes
abstract: While the final report is not due till December, a new poll shows that the hearings have already hardened negative public opinion about Prime Minister Tony Blair.

headline: COURT CLEARS SALE TO BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY
abstract: Tennessee appeals court rules that Clayton Homes can proceed with its sale to Berkshire Hathaway, dismissing accusations of fraud made by investor Denver Area Meat Cutters and Employers Pension Plan; fund asserted that Clayton Homes might have altered ballots to approve takeover, and that transaction helped only Clayton family, which owns 28 percent of company; ruling stops trial that had been scheduled to start within weeks (S)

headline: U.N. to Weigh Proposal to End 1988 Penalties Against Libya
abstract: Britain and Bulgaria propose that United Nations sanctions against Libya be lifted, saying its admission of responsibility for 1988 bombing of Pan Am jet, its willingness to pay $2.7 billion in compensation and its renunciation of terrorism meet conditions set by Security Council; prospects for quick passage of resolution are clouded by France, which has veto power on Security Council; at issue is 1999 settlement under which Libya agreed to pay families of victims of bombing of French UTA plane in 1989 total of $33 million, figure far less than Pan Am victims' families are getting (M)

headline: Dead in Iraq
abstract: Listing of Americans confirmed killed in Iraq by Department of Defense

headline: Of Stops and Starts (And Problems Solved)
abstract: of stops and starA

headline: In Abbas' Bid to Rein In Militants, an Echo of Ben-Gurion
abstract: Historical comparisons between the oratory of Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister, and that of David Ben-Gurion, Israel's first prime minister, can be easily made.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular Fined $12.1 Million By Regulator
abstract: Cingular Wireless is fined $12.1 million by California Public Utilities Commission for providing inadequate service and violating state law; says Cingular did not allow new users grace period to cancel service without paying contract-termination fees as high as $550 from January 2002 to May 2002; adds company did not tell users about problems with its wireless network in 2001; orders Cingular to reimburse customers who paid contract-termination fee during period (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In various ways, the new tax law affects how companies handle their dividends.
abstract: Market Place column on various ways new tax law affects how companies handle their dividends; says more companies are raising dividends now that such payouts are getting better tax treatment, but at same time, there has been increase in number of companies cutting or eliminating dividends; holds Standard & Poor's report shows 96 companies increased dividends in June, up from 87 year earlier; holds how much new tax law affected those decision is impossible to say, especially since number of companies raising dividends had been growing for much of last year, as economy gradually strengthened (M)

headline: Flash Point; Behind a Hacker's Book, a Primer on Copyright Law
abstract: Andrew Huang's book Hacking the Xbox: An Introduction to Reverse Engineering is self-published after Wiley Technology Publishing backed out of agreement over concerns that it violated Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998; No Starch Press has now agreed to publish book; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Iran Protests Ex-Envoy's Arrest
abstract: Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Hamidreza Assefi condemns Great Britain's arrest and possible extradition to Argentina of former Iranian diplomat Hadi Soleimanpour; Soleimanpour is accused of involvement in 1994 bombing of Jewish community center in Buenos Aires that killed 85 people (S)

headline: Hostesses in Shorts? This Is No Ordinary Flight
abstract: Article on new Hooters Air, which features buxom 'Hooters Girls' in tank tops and orange short-shorts; Hooters' owner Robert H Brooks comments on carrier's concepts; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Sept 14 column on companies t

headline: New Trade Bank to Extend Credit for Rebuilding
abstract: US administrator L Paul Bremer announces new Trade Bank of Iraq, program to allow Iraqi ministries easier access to credit to buy imported food, commodities and materials for reconstruction; money backing bank will come from $1.2-billion Development Fund for Iraq (S)

headline: Bush Admits Mideast Plan Is Stalled and Blames Arafat
abstract: Pres Bush acknowledges for first time that Middle East peace talks he sponsored have stalled; lays blame solely on Yasir Arafat; says Palestinian Prime Min Mahoud Abbas, now resigned, was undermined at all turns by Arafat; makes remarks at joint news conference with King Abdullah of Jordan at Camp David; Bush offers no clear path for how he will revive peace talks, nor does he mention Ahmed Qurei, Arafat's nominee to replace Abbas as prime minister; simply repeats his demand that Palestinian terrorism must end; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft to Award Stock, Not Options, to Employees  Microsoft said that it would no longer grant stock options, relying instead on actual awards of stock to help pay its 50,000 employees.    The announcement is the clearest sign yet that stock options have lost some of the cachet they held just a few years ago. Microsoft's move also comes as some big investors are putting pressure on companies to award fewer options, calling them a prime example of corporate excess during the 1990's. [Page A1.]

headline: Boomers Are Leaning On Retirement Plans
abstract: ING Financial survey finds that more than half of people aged 35 to 55, with incomes of $50,000 to $125,000, expect primary source of retirement income to be employer-sponsored plans (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Bank Candidate Endorsed
abstract: French central bank governor Jean-Claude Trichet wins endorsement of European Parliament in his bid to become president of European central bank, moving him closer to taking job on Nov 1; will succeed Wim Duisenberg; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Worm Variant Supplies Patch
abstract: Variant MSBlast spreads, but new worm has odd twist: it applies patch for vulnerability that it and other MSBlast worms use to infect Windows systems; new worm appears to properly download to patch for both Windows 2000 and Windows XP from Microsoft's Web site; variant will delete itself first time infected computer starts up in 2004 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomb Explodes At Mosque
abstract: bomb explodes during evening prayers in mosque in Kandahar, Afghanistan; 28 people are hurt; Taliban is blamed for bombing (S),

headline: Bank of England Surprises With a Rate Cut
abstract: Bank of England surprises investors by ordering 0.25 percent cut in interest rates, bringing benchmark rate to 48-year low of 3.5 percent; Mervyn A King, who succeeded Sir Edward George as governor of bank on July 1, has hinted that he views recent strengthening of British pound as most significant development since last month's meeting of Monetary Policy Committee; photo (M)

headline: A campaign by the Sierra Club chides General Motors about the Hummer's gas mileage.
abstract: Sierra Club to unveil Website that satirizes General Motor's Hummer sport utility vehicle, which has been assailed by conservationists and others as gas-guzzler; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Diamond Sales Rise
abstract: South African diamond mining company De Beers says sales in first half of year rose 2.7 percent to $2.92 billion and it expects sales for full year to exceed those of 2002; managing director Gary M Ralfe says company raised prices in January and February; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Net Rises 21% at Viacom; Company to Pay Dividend  Viacom posted a 21 percent increase in second-quarter profit, buoyed by a strong comeback in advertising.    The company also said that it would pay a quarterly dividend of 6 cents a share beginning Oct. 1. The announcement of a dividend comes at a time when taxes on corporate dividends have been reduced, prompting some big companies to offer one. [Page C4.]

headline: Prague Journal; Travel Advisory: British Abroad, Staggering About
abstract: Britons are earning reputation for bad behavior as tourists; lured by cut-rate airlines, they are descending on Prague, apparently with one goal in mind: to drink as much as possible; officials in Prague are loath to offend free-spending British visitors, but they have become so troublesome that some places refuse to serve Britons who arrive in large groups; hard-drinking British visitors have also caused problems in Greece, Spain and Ireland (M)

headline: U.S. Is Struggling to Make New Iraq Resolution Matter
abstract: United States is struggling at United Nations for new resolution that will change military and political realities in Iraq, not merely win Security Council passage; wants to spur contributions of troops and money; American diplomats say draft US proposes moves toward meeting other Council members' desire for clear timetable for transfer of power from occupation authority to Iraqis; it is unclear whether US is willing to surrender control of Iraq's political transformation to UN or to Iraqi provisional government; table of each nation's troop contingent in Iraq (M)

headline: A U.S. Soldier in Afghanistan Dies of Injuries
abstract: American military command says American Special Operations soldier died of injuries he received during military operations in eastern Afghanistan; soldier died during what appears to be offensive by Taliban fighters in Paktia Province, which lies on border with Pakistan; other incidents in Paktia Province have been reported recently (M)

headline: A DVR Update, Reflections on the Blackout and Column Notes
abstract: This week, it's brain-cleaning time. Below, four mini topics, none of which would merit a full-length newsletter treatment, but which I thought you might find timely.

headline: A Chronicle of Confusion in the U.S. Hunt for Hussein's Chemical and Germ Weapons
abstract: Pentagon plan to search for Iraq's unconventional weapons, described as bold and original, has fallen victim to chaos, disorganization, interagency feuds and shortages of supplies; flaws are serious enough, according to interviews with soldiers and government officials, that searches might have overlooked weapons or components if they were there to be found; some blame flawed intelligence and looting of promising sites; senior Iraqi military intelligence officer says Pres Saddam Hussein destroyed stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons; some soldiers involved sensed mission was not made priority until Bush administration came under fire for failing to find weapons and was accused of distorting intelligence; Col Richard R McPhee says he had only one month to prepare his troops for mission; Pentagon plan described; photo (M)

headline: Tape of 'Hussein' Urges Iraqis to Intensify Attacks on 'Infidels'
abstract: An audiotape of a voice purporting to be that of Saddam Hussein today broke the long silence since the American-led military campaign drove him from office in April.

headline: Stock Exchange Head to Give Up $48 Million in Compensation
abstract: Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said today he would give up $48 million in compensation that he was owed by the exchange.

headline: British Panel Clears Blair on Iraqi Arms
abstract: The panel, however, criticized the handling of intelligence, which resulted in Prime Minister Tony Blair's unknowingly misinforming Parliament.

headline: Decline in Dollar Lifts Estée Lauder Sales
abstract: Estee Lauder Companies reports profit in is fourth quarter ended June 30; net income was $53 million compared with loss of $25.4 million year earlier; sales rose 8.3 percent, to $1.22 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-Minister Questioned In '71 Massacre
abstract: Mario Moya Palencia, former Mexican internal security minister during Luis Echeverria's presidency, refuses to answer 96 questions asked by special prosecutors investigating government involvement in 1971 protest march massacre, but contends he will reply to questions in writing (S)

headline: Security Council Approves U.S. Resolution on Iraqi Council
abstract: The United Nations Security Council voted 14 to 0 to adopt a resolution welcoming the creation of Iraq's new Governing Council, with Syria abstaining.

headline: Connection to Terror Threats Is Seen in Jakarta Bombing
abstract: Deadly terror bombing at Marriott Hotel in Jakarta fits into pattern of threats and intelligence reports indicating there may be more attacks overseas or inside US; bombing follows release of audiotape warning said to be from Osama bin Laden deputy Ayman al-Zawahiri; Sec Donald Rumsfeld calls such tapes recruiting appeals by Al Qaeda (S)

headline: F.C.C. Chief Will Enforce Phone Curbs
abstract: Federal Communications Commission chairman Michael K Powell says agency will enforce restrictions on unwanted telephone solicitations are scheduled to take effect Oct 1; telemarketing industry asks Supreme Court to block FCC from enforcing new regulations, but court declines to issue emergency stay, allowing agency to move forward, at least for now; Pres Bush signs law giving Federal Trade Commission explicit authority to enforce do-not-call list; Bush comments; photos (M)

headline: IRAQIS SET TO FORM AN INTERIM COUNCIL WITH WIDE POWER
abstract: Representatives of major political, ethnic and religious groups of Iraq will declare first postwar interim government in Iraq this weekend, in form of 'governing council' of between 21 and 25 members with extensive executive power; new body of Kurds, Shiites, Sunnis, Christians and Turkmen will share responsibility for running country under United Nations resolution that will continue to vest Washington and London with ultimate authority until sovereign government is elected and new constitution ratified; there is no clear timetable for that transition; American administrator L Paul Bremer III says he agreed that majority of council's members would be Shiites, one of 'tactical adjustments' he made to meet demands of Iraqis; formulation of governing panel comes after eight weeks of negotiations with American and British occupation powers; process is speeded by deteriorating security situation and mounting American casualties from daily attacks on allied forces; Bush administration is eager to create credible Iraqi governing body to help counter negative image of foreign occupation that is being exploited by remnants of Saddam Hussein's forces; two American soldiers are killed and one is wounded in two separate attacks in latest round of violence against allied forces (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Hitachi Cuts Stake; CHINA: Auto Growth;.

headline: JUSTICE DEPT. SAYS ORBITZ DOES NOT IMPEDE COMPETITION
abstract: Justice Dept closes antitrust investigation of Orbitz Inc, Internet travel seller owned by five biggest US airlines, finding that it has not hurt competition or ticket buyers (S)

headline: Revlon Running Near Empty
abstract: Revlon's heavy spending on overhauling its cosmetics brands has some analysts forecasting that company will run out of cash early next year, unless Ronald O Perelman, who controls company, agrees to bail it out; analysts say Revlon is not generating enough cash to make dent in its huge dent load; company spent $84 million more than it took in and has lost money for last 19 quarters; Perelman has already invested or agreed to lend Revlon more than $200 million this year to support growth plan put in place by chief executive Jack L Stahl; Revlon may need to restructure its $1.8 billion in debt next year, possibly through Chapter 11 bankrupty, unless Perelman contributes more funds; Howard Gittis, Perelman's closest adviser, says bankruptcy proceeding is not possibly; chart; photos (M)

headline: Virus Leaves Few Answers In Its Wake
abstract: Computer security experts and law enforcement officials are struggling to understand motives of mysterious software author who appears intent on prying open many of electronic locks on Internet; program that is known as SoBig, which is transmitted as e-mail attachments and then is widely present on its own via Internet, is sixth variant in experiment by unknown attacker; one theory is that program is attempt to create software engines for sending spam by using unprotected computers that have been surreptitiously commandeered by virus; access to such computers could then be sold to e-mail marketing companies; writer of program appears to be engaged in dark game with antivirus companies, repeatedly eluding their defenses with ever more virulent adaptations (M)

headline: Franks Details Raid Near Syrian Line
abstract: Gen Tommy R Franks discloses new details of mysterious Special Operations attack on convoy crossing from Iraq into Syria on June 18; says mission sought to kill suspected leaders of ousted government and might also have closed smugglers' route used by fugitive Iraqi officials; says intelligence reports indicated that route and border crossing allowed members of Saddam Hussein's government to flee Iraq (M)

headline: S.E.C. Putting Mutual Funds Under Scrutiny On Late Trading
abstract: Top officials of Securities and Exchange Commission send letter to big mutual fund companies asking for additional information about trading in their shares; enforcement division wants all documents regarding companies' policies on who can trade their shares late in day and who can jump in and out of their funds quickly; is also asking if there have been any changes made to these policies; companies must respond by Sept 15; action underscores extent to which commission officials are moving to play regulatory catch-up after announcement by New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer that mutual fund companies encouraged fraudulent trading activities; Spitzer's complaint against hedge fund manager Edward J Stern, Bank of America and Janus says they set up relationships that allowed Stern to use them for market-timing; complaint includes excerpt from prospectus for Janus High Yield fund, one of fund's Stern traded, that described company's policy that funds are not intended for market timing or excessive trading; Spitzer also discloses memorandums of senior Janus officials discussing how detrimental practice of timing can be to fund shareholders; complaint says these executives said they would be willing to encourage such arrangements in return for more investments from client (M)

headline: Canada Drops Its Key Rate After Setbacks To Economy
abstract: Bank of Canada drops overnight lending rate to 3 percent from 3.25 percent, citing list of unexpected setbacks to economy; cautions that in recent months, there have been number of unanticipated developments that bear on outlook for inflation and economic activity; foreign demand for Canadian exports has been dampened by surge in Canadian dollar, caused partly by widening gap between Canadian and American interest rates in last year; Canadian dollar falls to 72.81 US cents in late afternoon, down nearly one cent (M)

headline: Police Encircle Rio Shantytowns As Gang Warfare Leaves 9 Dead
abstract: Scores of police officers from across Rio de Janeiro surround shantytowns on city's northern outskirts in effort to contain brutal gang warfare that has left at least nine dead in two days of battles involving police and rival drug gangs; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Beauty Is Only Skin Deep
abstract: Entrants in Miss Italia beauty contest experience reaction to traces of nickel found in make-up; metal caused unattractive skin reaction in at least 40 girls; judges had already cast ballots for finalists, but some girls eliminated are considering lawsuits (S)

headline: Blair to Be Called in Inquiry Of Weapons Expert's Death
abstract: Lord Hutton, senior British judge, will take testimony from Prime Min Tony Blair, his top aide Alastair Campbell, Defense Sec Geoff Hoon and BBC chiefs and correspondents on circumstances behind apparent suicide of weapons expert David Kelly; bitter struggle over BBC coverage of Blair's justification of war in Iraq included reporter Andrew Gilligan's naming of Kelly as source of information on government's use of data (M)

headline: VIVENDI TO CONTEST I.R.S. CLAIM OF TAXES OWED
abstract: Vivendi Universal will contest claim by Internal Revenue Service that company owes taxes of about $1.5 billion plus interest linked to sale of shares in DuPont Co in 1995 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Verizon Unions See Delays Because of New Proposals  The two main unions at Verizon Communications said there would be delays in reaching a settlement because of new proposals the company had made on job security. Union officials said those proposals would require several sets of regional talks.    But Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications company, immediately countered that the unions were unnecessarily stretching out the talks to win concessions. [Page C4.]    The company and its unions have often found themselves on the same side when it comes to lobbying politicians and regulators in Washington and state capitals. News Analysis. [C4.]

headline: Dear Campaign Diary: Seizing the Day, Online
abstract: Scores of candidates in California governor recall election have Web sites and at least 14 have started blogs; blog, with its spontaneous feel and wide reach, has gained acceptance as tool of technology-savvy political campaigns; Arianna Huffington is writing her own entries, as is Reva Renee Renz, Republican candidate; other blogs noted; photos (M)

headline: China at Korea Talks: Taking Diplomacy Upstage
abstract: China emerges as more assertive diplomatic power during six-nation talks in Beijing on North Korea's nuclear program; cajoled and badgered US, North Korea, South Korea, Russia and Japan to join negotiations and succeeds in pressing them to commit to another round despite obvious tensions between US and North Korea; assertiveness reflects alarm in top ranks of Communist Party that North Korean crisis could spiral out of control and perhaps also a new sense of engagement in world (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Helicopter Not Found
abstract: Konstantin Pulikovsky, Russian presidential envoy to Sakhalin region, reports helicopter, missing since Wednesday, violated several safety procedures such as not filing passenger manifest; as many as 21 people, including Governor Igor P Farkhutdinov, may have been aboard craft, which has not been found despite extensive air and sea search near Kamchatka Peninsula (S)

headline: Efforts to Stop Music Swapping Draw More Fire
abstract: Recording industry's stepped-up pursuit of online music swappers faces two new challenges, as SBC Communications questions constitutionality of industry's tactics and Sen Norm Coleman opens inquiry into whether anti-piracy camapign is violating rights of innocent people (M)

headline: A First at Bride's Magazine: A Report on Same-Sex Unions
abstract: Conde Nast's Bride's magazine includes article on same-sex weddings, first such article by any of five top-selling bridal magazines; article, by David Toussaint, discusses recent developments in same-sex ceremonies; offers advice on how to be good guest; photos (M)

headline: Bankrupt Thinking: How the Banks Aided Enron's Deception
abstract: Floyd Norris comments on banks' involvement in Enron's financial deceptions; cites report of Neal Batson, Enron's court-appointed trustee, who concludes that Citigroup knew Enron's accounting was improper; Batson photo (M)

headline: Joint Service From Reuters And Microsoft
abstract: Reuters Group will announce deal with Microsoft Corp to connect companies' instant messaging systems as offering for financial services companies; new service, to begin in early 2004, will allow customers of Reuters Messaging to communicate with any of 100 million people that Microsoft says use MSN Message (M)

headline: DELTA PILOTS SET CONDITIONS FOR RESUMING TALKS
abstract: Pilots for Delta Air Lines, who are being asked to take pay cuts, say they will resume labor talks only if airline agrees to extend their current contract and abandon proposal to match cost cuts made by competitors (S)

headline: Strains Emerge Between India and Pakistan After Bombings
abstract: The death toll from two powerful bombs planted on Monday in taxis here rose to 52 today.

headline: Patents; On a diet and craving French fries? Inventor has a low-carbohydrate version that contains cauliflower.
abstract: Randy Blaun applies for patent on cauliflower French fries that have as many nutrients and as much fiber as serving of broccoli and are also low in carbohydrates; says thorough cooking and pureeing eliminate cauliflower smell and fries have 'just enough potato to make it potato-y'; photo (M)

headline: Citigroup's Shadow Emperor
abstract: Perils of prolonged transition discussedl

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Former Minister Arrested
abstract: Former Argentine Cabinet Minister Maria Julia Alsogaray is charged with misappropriation of government funds as part of official campaign to fight corruption (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Unionist Killed
abstract: Colombian union leader Jesus Tobar contends Barranquilla union organizer Carlos Barrera was killed by gunman connected to right-wing paramilitaries; 45 unionists in Colombia have been killed this year (S)

headline: Former Chief Of Sony Music To Start Label At Universal
abstract: Thomas D Mottola, ousted chief executive of Sony Music, signs $40 million deal with Universal Music Group to start his own record label called Casablanca Records; label will focus on new acts, with Universal Music distributing recordings; Universal commits itself to putting $8 million a year intgo operation for five years (M)

headline: Victims of the Heat. Victims of Isolation.
abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column cites large number of elderly people who died in European heat wave in discussing problems faced by increasing number of aged living alone in industrialized nations; Prof Eric Klinenberg says toll exposes emergence of older, vulnerable population that lives and dies in isolation, major social change little noticed in news media; France has taken up problem as social and political issue; photo (M)

headline: Manufacturer Confidence Rises in Germany
abstract: The business confidence of German manufacturers rose in August at the fastest pace in four months as prospects for a recovery improved, the Ifo Economic Institute said yesterday.

headline: Online Booking Cuts Costs and Simplifies Corporate Trips
abstract: Online booking agencies like Orbitz, Expedia and Travelocity are cutting costs and simplifying corporate trips; agencies promote their own low fees, which are generally fraction of $25 to $45 reservation that traditional agencies have been charging corporate clients since airlines reduced, then eliminated commissions they paid (M)

headline: Newspaper publishers remain cautious about claiming a recovery in advertising revenues.
abstract: Most of big newspaper chains have reported only modest increases in advertising revenue for second quarter over year-earlier quarter; none forecast especially high earnings growth by year end; newspapers face rising costs, especially for newsprint; graph of print advertising sales (M)

headline: Daimler Chief Quits Stock Exchange Board
abstract: DaimlerChrysler chief executive Jurgen E Schrempp resigns from New York Stock Exchange board in face of fierce public criticism of big pay package board approved for former chairman Richard A Grasso; photo (M)

headline: The great darkness
abstract: The collapse of the power grid in the Northeast revealed the weaknesses of the superpower's infrastructure.

headline: Personal Business; Credit Card Rewards Turn From Nouns to Verbs
abstract: Credit card companies, which

headline: Harsh Style Runs Course And GQ Publisher Is Ousted
abstract: GQ magazine publisher Ron Galotti abruptly resigns; Peter King Hunsinger, president of Conde Nast Bridal Group, to succeed him; executives say leaders of Conde Nast grew uncomfortable with Galotti's harsh management style and Conde Nast president-chief executive Steven T Florio asked Galotti to resign; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Leftists Arrested In 'Dirty War' Inquiry
abstract: Two former Montonero guerrilla leaders are arrested for ordering comrades to return from exile between 1976 and 1983 even though they knew they were likely to be captured, tortured and killed; Montonero leader Mario Firmenich is in Spain and may face extradition for his crimes (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Chip Profit Forecast
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics projects its semiconductor group will return to profitability in fourth quarter; group lost $154.3 million in second quarter (S)

headline: Moving Up to a Grill With Extra Sizzle
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column finds several Web sites that sell grills online; drawing (M)

headline: Heat in Europe may have killed 20,000
abstract: ROME:—  As temperatures begin cooling throughout Europe thanks to rain, the number of people who may have died in this summer's heat wave is being put between 15,000 and 20,000.

headline: Afghanistan And Iraq Tab Of $87 Billion Is Submitted
abstract: President Bush formally asks Congress for $87 billion to rebuild Iraq and Afghanistan and support troops there; three-fourths of money would be used to pay for military occupation of Iraq; request also includes $5.7 billion to rebuild Iraq's electrical network, $3.7 billion for improved water and sewer system and $5.1 billion for new civil security system; $850 million is requested to build new hospital in Iraq along with other health improvements; Sen George V Voinovich, fiscally conservative Republican, says Americans will wonder about fairness of such vast public works programs in Iraq but not at home (M)

headline: Afghan Soldiers, Aided by U.S., Say They Routed Taliban
abstract: Government soldiers claimed success after 15 days of battling the Taliban, in what has been some of the most serious fighting in months.

headline: Chirac's Words: Sovereignty Must Shift
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Pres Jacques Chirac of France about Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Testimony Ends in Suicide Case of British Arms Expert
abstract: Inquiry into death of British arms expert David Kelly ends after six weeks of testimony from 74 witnesses; spokesmen from warring sectors of British establishment exchange charges of lying, hypocrisy, bullying and deceit; new poll shows hearings have hardened negative public opinion about Prime Min Tony Blair, even before Lord Hutton, senior judge, issues his final report; Kelly was found dead, an apparent suicide, on July 18, days after being named as probable source of Andrew Gilligan's BBC report claiming that government 'sexed up' dossier on Iraqi arms to win public support for war there; photo (M)

headline: Survivors Tell Of Massacre At Mosque In Pakistan
abstract: Survivors describe attack by three gunmen on Shiite mosque, Quetta, Pakistan, in which 48 Shiites died; says gunman killed patiently; attack ended when one of gunmen set off suicide bomb and worshipers beat other assailants to death; Pakistani Pres Pervez Musharraf vows to crack down on religious extremists; soldiers patrol Quetta for second day to deter rioting and revenge killings by Shiites; police question Pakistanis and Afghans from inside and outside city; Shiites rushed victims to nearby public hospital and started rioting when they found nobody on duty; victims were then taken to well-equipped military hospital; Shiites complain that no police officers were on duty at mosque (M)

headline: S.E.C. Money Is Likely to Go Unspent
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission says it will not spend $103 million of its record $716 million budget this fiscal year because it could not hire accountants and investigators fast enough; Congress increased budget 63 percent for year to help agency combat fraud and restore investor confidence; weighs raising budget to $841.5 million for fiscal 2004 (S)

headline: Trial Is Ordered in Clayton Homes Dispute
abstract: Tennessee Judge W Dale Young rules Clayton Homes investor can proceed with lawsuit to block Warren E Buffett's bid to buy company for $1.7 billion; orders trial in 30 to 45 days on fraud accusations by Denver Area Meat Cutters and Employers Pension Plan; fund says Clayton might have rigged sale, including doctoring proxy ballots to favor Buffett's company Berkshire Hathaway (S)

headline: Rwandan President Declares Election Victory
abstract: Pres Paul Kagame declares victory in Rwandan presidential election and will remain in office for another seven years; election has all trappings of democracy, but Kagame's government actively quelled any serious opposition in months leading up to vote; election officials say he got 94.3 percent of vote; Amnesty International has denounced government for instilling 'climate of fear' among population; photo (M)

headline: Fannie Mae's Loss Risk Is Larger, Computer Models Show
abstract: Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage finance company, faces much bigger losses from interest rate swings than it has publicly disclosed, according to computer models used by the company to estimate the value of its assets and debts.    At the end of last year, the models showed that Fannie Mae's portfolio would have lost $7.5 billion in value if interest rates rose immediately by 1.5 percentage points, internal company documents provided to The New York Times indicated. At that time, the market value of all the assets on Fannie Mae's books, minus all the company's debts, was about $15 billion. So it would have lost roughly half its market value from such a sharp increase in interest rates, according to the models.

headline: Drafting of Charter Deeply Divides Iraq
abstract: As the Iraqi Governing Council presses for a transfer of sovereignty to Iraqis, a dispute over who will control the drafting of a constitution is embroiling Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds.    Iraqi officials who have been deliberating for two months as a 25-member committee to recommend a procedure for drafting the constitution said they were deadlocked.

headline: Professor Teaches Change in His Indian Village
abstract: Prof Jagadish Shukla, Indian-American climatologist in Maryland, returns each year to home village of Mirda, in impoverished Uttar Pradesh, where he has used money earney in America to pay for relatives' education, marriages, homes and, in lean times, food; photos; Shukla is also setting aside ten percent of his income for more ambitious projects, such as community college and medical dispensary, that are bringing change to place where clock is still set by sun (M)

headline: Allegations range from simple bribes to stock swindles : Music scandal rocks Hong Kong
abstract: HONG KONG:—  A widening music industry scandal has transformed Hong Kong's top of the pops into a Ten Most Wanted list.

headline: E-Commerce Report; If You Liked The Web Page, Try the Ad
abstract: Online publishers like Washington Post's Web site and car-buyers advice site Edmunds.com have turned to Internet companies Google or Overture to sell ads pegged to content that each visitor selects; new service is extension of bid-for-placement service Overture pioneered, in which highest bidder gets to have their ad appear atop search results whenever user types certain word or phrase; photo (M)

headline: Credit Card Division Helped Lift Target's Second-Quarter Profit
abstract: Target Corp's fiscal second-quarter profit increases 4.1 percent, to $358 million (S)

headline: France and Germany Seek to Rev Up Europe's Economy
abstract: The leaders of France and Germany announced today a list of spending projects they would like to see adopted to revitalize Europe's sluggish economy and spur growth.

headline: Europe's Central Bank Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
abstract: The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged, raising the possibility that the bank will not tinker again with monetary policy until this fall.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: I.B.M. CORP., Armonk, N.Y., said it had won an order from Lego A/S, Billund, Denmark, the maker of toy building blocks, to provide server computers, data storage networks, software and related services. Terms were not disclosed. The deal is one of the largest replacements this year of Hewlett-Packard machines with I.B.M. hardware.    COOPER TIRE AND RUBBER CO., Findlay, Ohio, a leading tiremaker, said it would close an automotive-plastics factory in Cleveland early next year and eliminate 115 jobs to reduce costs.

headline: Pirates Attack Ships in Malacca Strait and Hold 3 for Ransom
abstract: Pirates attacked two ships in the last week, a sign of continued security problems in one of the world's busiest sea lanes.

headline: I.B.M. Looks to Genetics to Map a New Business
abstract: IBM is sponsoring genetic research by scientists with little business interest at its vaunted labs in bid to sell computer products and services tailored to science and medicine; effort has spurred projects like $100 million supercomputer designed to handle complex biological simulations and new software that translates paper-based research methods into searchable online system; photos (M)

headline: The Collections / New York : Kors puts fashion back on the sunny side of the street
abstract: As Britney Spears, pop angel turned temptress, hiked her black and white sweater dress above thigh-high boots, her appearance at the Diesel show summed up the mood of New York's summer 2004 season.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fund Group Acquisitions
abstract: Toronto-based CI Fund Management acquires Canadian operations of Assante Corp for $601 million; also acquires Synergy Asset Management of Toronto for 116 million Canadian dollars ($82.5 million) (S)

headline: Relentless Foe of the Amazon Jungle: Soybeans
abstract: Large portions of Amazon Jungle are increasingly being cleared for soybeans, Brazil's hottest cash crop; soy cultivation is driven by coincidence of global demand and local politics in Mato Grosso state, where Gov Blairo Maggi and his family are major participants in soybean industry; experts warn continuing spread of soybean farming through Mato Grosso and Para state will likely worsen threat to Amazon ecological system; environmentalist had hoped that Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva would act to combat deforestation, but he has instead stressed increasing agricultural output to swell exports and feed urban poor; map; photo (M)

headline: California Acts to Ban Junk E-Mail
abstract: Gov Gray Davis signs law that outlaws sending most commercial e-mail messages to anyone in California who has not explicitly requested them; law, which also prohibits companies inside state from sending unsolicited e-mail to anyone outside state, imposes fines of $1,000 for each message, up to $1 million for each campaign; gives people right to file private lawsuits; Sen Kevin Murray, who sponsonored bill, comments (M)

headline: New Sun Chip May Unseat the Circuit Board
abstract: Sun Microsystems researchers are set to announce that they have found way to transmit data inside computer 60 to 100 times faster than possible now by placing edge of one chip directly in contact with its neighbor; revolutionary advance could make traditional circuit board obsolete; new technology is being developed as part of military-financed supercomputer effort; Sun executives say they seek commercial uses; breakthrough is based on insight by Sun vice president Ivan E Sutherland; photo; diagrams (M)

headline: CANADIAN COMPANY BUYS DRUG RIGHTS FROM ABBOTT LABS
abstract: Canadian drug maker Axcan Pharma will pay Abbott Laboratories as much as $75 million in cash for rights to gastrointestinal treatment Itax; Axcan expects to submit drug to Food and Drug Administration in 2006 (S)

headline: Cultural gaffes : Bathing rituals in Thai village aren't always what they seem
abstract: It seemed like such a good idea at the time. The prospect of staying as a guest in a real Thai house, speaking nothing but Thai in a Thai village was too much to pass up.

headline: Bethlehem Shrugs as Israelis Leave It to Its Police
abstract: Palestinian police officers reassert their authority in Bethlehem, but Israel maintains its military cordon around town, continuing to barricade Palestinians inside in what it calls essential defense against terrorist attacks; Israel is also building fence around Bethlehem; Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas says Israeli departure from Bethlehem will be followed by its departure from rest of cities and towns and Palestinian refugee camps; no timetable has been announced; in return for ceding security, Israel is demanding that Palestinian officers act to break up militant groups and seize their weapons; despite suspension of attacks declared by three main Palestinian factions, scattered violence is reported around West Bank and Gaza; Palestinians are said to fire three anti-tank missiles into central square of Israeli settlement in Gaza; photos; map (M)

headline: Debating Matters of Life and Death in a Baghdad Barbershop
abstract: Photographs of bodies of Uday and Qusay Hussein, shown on Iraqi television, are closely scrutinized by men in barber shop in Baghdad; half the men exult that their former oppressors are dead, while others dismiss images as forgeries, saying Saddam Hussein's sons are in Spain; spokesman for American occupying authority says many Iraqis remain so nervous about comeback by Hussein dynasty that they believe any conspiracy theory; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit For Retailer
abstract: Carrefour says first-

headline: Finding Comfort in Strangers With an Online Diet Journal
abstract: Hundreds of overweight women, and some men, are sharing detailed reports of their calories and cravings on self-created online journals known as Web logs or blogs; especially for severely overweight, Web journals are serving as unlikely grass-roots support system; their collective readership appears to number in tens of thousands; dieters say online forum provides rare opportunity to publicly unburden themselves about stimatized subject that some are ashamed to share with family or friends; blogs feature short, frequent updates arranged chronologically, format that lends itself to long-term weight-loss projects; photos (M)

headline: General Says 'We're Still at War' in Iraq as Attacks Continue
abstract: The U.S. also announced a reward of up to $25 million for the capture of Saddam Hussein or confirmation of his death.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Technology Briefing | Research: Gartner Profit Declines
abstract: Gartner, information-technology consultant and researcher, says that second-quarter profit fell 30 percent, to $12.9 million; sales fall 9.7 percent, to $213.3 million; graph (S)

headline: Company Tries to Catch Up On Repairs on Long Island
abstract: About 2,400 orders for phone-line installations on Long Island go unfulfilled as Verizon workers scramble to respond to glut of repair orders in face of threatened strike (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Central Bank Stands Pat; SOUTH KOREA: Shinhan Income Falls; JAPAN: Machinery Orders Gain; SOUTH KOREA: Hyundai Workers Accept Pact; JAPAN: Mcdonald'S Sales Sour;.

headline: Home Insurers Appeal Rate Cuts in Texas
abstract: Property insurers State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance, Allstate and Farmers Group file appeal of June Texas state order reducing homeowner rates by 16 percent (S)

headline: Uncertainty Leaves Many Factories Shut
abstract: Many companies resist reopening plants as power is restored in some areas until they are sure power is reliable; backup power systems are adequate to keep vital data flowing and to keep substances from drying up and destroying vats or equipment; few, if any, manufacturers try to keep assembly operations running; at least three oil refineries in United States and four in Canada are shut by blackout, potentially squeezing supplies and prices (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: NORTHERN IRELAND; GREECE: Sweeping Party Changes;.

headline: Effort to Diminish Arafat Is Said to Strengthen Him
abstract: Recent events show that Yasir Arafat remains at center of Palestinian politics and efforts by United States and Israel to banish him may be major reason; political analysts say Arafat has upper hand in bitter power struggle with Palestinian Prime Min Mahmoud Abbas; Arafat seems determined to wield influence; has appointed new national security adviser, signal that he will not accede to international demands to give that authority to Abbas; has called on militant groups to reinstate ceasefire, stepping into situation that Abbas was trying to handle; Abbas was appointed--by Arafat--while Arafat was elected, and his status in Palestinian society is iconic even as he remains trapped in his ruined compound in Ramallah; photo (M)

headline: FEDEX REPORTS 19% DROP IN FIRST QUARTER INCOME
abstract: FedEx Corp says net income fell 19 percent in its first quarter ended Aug 31; net income dropped to $128 million from $158 million year earlier; revenue rose 4.4 percent, to $5.69 billion (S)

headline: On the Scent of Natural Remedies
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column explores sites that offer information about aromatherapy and other complementary herbal remedies as well as online products; drawing (M)

headline: Charity Said to Have Paid Terrorists Is Under Investigation by the Saudis
abstract: Al Haramain Charitable Foundation, Saudi charity which has been accused by Western officials of sponsoring terrorism, is now subject of criminal investigation by Saudi Arabia, as is founder Ageel al-Ageel; American intelligence recently gave Saudi officials detailed document outlining terrorism links with International Islamic Relief Orgn, another major Saudi charity (M)

headline: Indian Companies Are Adding Western Flavor
abstract: Indian computer companies are offering extensive training programs to teach new employees how to interact with Western clients; lessons include how to speak during conference call and how to sip wine properly; it is particularly imperative for employees of software companies to appear culturally seamless with Americans; American clients account for more than two-thirds of India's software and services export revenues; training programs offered at Hyderabad, India, offices of Fremont, Calif-based Sierra Atlantic, Wipro Ltd and Infosys Technologies, two of India's largest software and services exporters, discussed; photo (M)

headline: The L.C.D. Screen Wins Color-Obsessed Converts
abstract: Recent improvements in liquid crystal display technology help win over even most discriminating eyes of design professionals and others who prized cathode ray tube for color quality and fluid rendering of motion; series of illustrations shows workings of LCD (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: ICELAND: First Whale Harpooned; CHECHNYA: Russia Invites Observers To Republic'S Vote; SPAIN: Effects Of Oil Spill Will Last 10 Years; IRELAND: Happy Hour Is Past;.

headline: Hong Kong Chief Executive Faces Calls to Step Down
abstract: Hong Kong's chief executive Tung Chee-hwa faces calls for his resignation and for greater democracy following defection of key legislative ally, James Tien; Tung is forced to defer vote on internal security legislation that has been his top priority, but he makes clear that he still believes Hong Kong is required to pass measure; says his top priority would now be economy; pledges to address concerns raised by estimated 500,000 demonstrators at pro-democracy march July 1; how Beijing will react to postponement of bill it supported, and whether struggle will bring greater democracy to Hong Kong, remains to be seen; main opposition party does not call for Tung's departure, fearing that Beijing might then appoint more politically adroit succcessor who could push through proposed new laws banning sedition, subversion, secession and treason; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TIFFANY & CO., New York, the U.S.'s largest luxury jewelry retailer, said it had bought the land and building of its Tokyo flagship store for about $140 million.    NATIONAL EQUIPMENT SERVICES INC., Evanston, Ill., a renter of construction equipment, filed for bankruptcy protection and said it would file a recovery plan in a few weeks.

headline: Is Universal Worth Fighting Over?
abstract: Status of bids for Vivendi Universal discussed; photos (M)

headline: Fancy Goods a Tougher Sell in Japan
abstract: Many Japanese consumers are starting to turn away from excess that luxury goods have come to represent; contradict common belief that Japan's appetite for such goods is bottomless; sales of lxury goods in Japan have declined by more than one third since 1996, to 1.2 trillion yen ($10.8 billion); photo (M)

headline: Tribunals Move From Theory to Reality
abstract: Pres Bush's designation of six prisoners at Guantanamo naval base are eligible for trials before military commissions is incremental but significant step in turning theoretical possiblity into practical reality (S)

headline: 2 of Big 3 Reach Pacts
abstract: Ford Motor said that it had reached tentative agreement on a labor contract with the United Automobile Workers, following the union's deal with the Chrysler Group of DaimlerChrysler. That left General Motors as the only member of the Big Three still negotiating.     Business Day, Page C1.

headline: New Cabinet In Japan Emphasizes Fiscal Reform
abstract: Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi, newly re-elected leader of Japan, puts together new cabinet that strongly suggests he would press ahead with tough economic reforms; photo (M)

headline: Hot Tickets, Hawked Legitimately Online
abstract: Selling tickets to events on secondary market--also known as scalping--has gained legitimacy as it moves online; options abound, with demand driving supply, and variations in delivery options and fees; total sales of movie and event tickets online are expected to reach $3.1 billion in 2003 according to Internet research firm Jupiter Research; Ticketmaster and Tickets.com offer opportunity for season ticketholders of sports team to sell unwanted tickets; broker sites like TicketCity aggregates ticket inventories of brokers worldwide; list of available options; drawing (M)

headline: JARDEN AGREES TO BUY LEHIGH CONSUMER PRODUCTS
abstract: Jarden Corp agrees to buy Lehigh Consumer Products Corp, largest supplier of rope, cord and twine in US, for $155 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: ESPN, Bristol, Conn., expanded its relationship with the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy, naming the agency to handle the account of ESPN Videogames, a new joint venture with a unit of Sega of America. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Wieden & Kennedy handles the account of ESPN, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company and the Hearst Corporation. Sega of America is part of the Sega Corporation.

headline: System Seems Poky?
abstract: Block XP's Animation    Q. The Windows XP interface has nice animated graphics, but the system itself seems somewhat slow. Is there a way to turn off some of these features and speed things up?    A. With artistic touches like soft shadows under alert boxes and animated sliding menus, Windows XP was designed to be attractive on the screen. But all those graphics consume computer resources and may make the machine seem sluggish.

headline: India Tries to Contain Tempest Over Soft Drink Safety
abstract: Soft drink rivals Coca-Cola Co and PepsiCo have join forces to defend safety of their products in India after Center for Science and Environment, respected nongovernmental group, reported that all 12 leading soft drink brands contain unsafe levels of pesticides; they own all 12; Health Ministry deflates furor, which spurred sharp sales drop and demonstrations, by announcing that government tests have not found unsafe pesticide levels; weighs imposing European Union standards on water in soft drinks; photo (M)

headline: Wrestle a Rapper to the Ground, Then Remix
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews games Def Jam Vendetta and Amplitude; photos (M)

headline: P.& G. Chief to Get Public Service Award
abstract: Advertising Council to honor A G Lafley (S)

headline: ARMY IS RELUCTANT TO FLAUNT PHOTOS OF HUSSEIN'S SONS
abstract: United States is reluctant to release photos of Saddam Hussein's two dead sons to skeptical Iraqi public, out of fear military would appear to be gloating; Lt Gen Ricardo S Sanchez, commanding officer, admits release of grisly photos presents predicament; shows photos briefly to small group of reporters; photos show battered, bloodied heads and upper torsos of Uday and Qusay Hussein; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld tells reporters on Capitol Hill that pictures will be released, but declines to say when; ordinary Iraqis remain decidedly unconvinced that Hussein's sons, who were responsible for deaths of hundreds of Iraqis, are themselves gone; United States calls their deaths turning point in postwar occupation for Iraq that could demoralize those loyal to deposed government; any hope of quick improvement in almost daily armed attacks against Americans is short-lived when two American soldiers are killed in latest attacks outside Mosul; Sanchez says four senior members of Hussein government, now in custody, including two of men's uncles, have been shown bodies and confirmed they are Saddam's sons; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Interest Rate Cut
abstract: Bank Indonesia cuts rupiah overnight intervention interest rate to 9 percent from 9.75 percent to help stimulate economic growth (S)

headline: Killed in Iraq
abstract: Dept of Defense confirms deaths of three Americans in Iraq (S)

headline: Few Ways to Limit Farm Aid, Report Says
abstract: US Agriculture Department, on eve of global trade talks, releases report showing that there are few effective payment limits on $20 billion that country spends each year to subsidize farmers; poor and developing nations have complained that subsidized agricultural exports from rich nations destroy livelihood of millions of farmers in Africa, Asia and Latin America; farm subsidies will be subject of talks at World Trade Organization meeting next week in Cancun, Mex; World Bank, in annual report on global economic prospects, urges US and other wealthy nations to reduce subsidies as part of overall plan to lift poor nations out of poverty through trade and investment; World Bank's chief economist Nicholas Stern comments (M)

headline: Blackboard Expands Reach in Deal to Set Up Chinese Colleges With Its Software
abstract: Blackboard Inc, based in Washington, DC, will announce its partnership with Chinese public-private education company Cernet, which provides Internet services to more than 1,000 universities in China, to create software platform that will allow professors to post course materials, conduct discussions and administer tests online; Blackboard will furnish Chinese-language versions of same educational software platforms it has provided to more than 3,000 clients, 600 of them abroad and in five other languages; company anticipates $3 million to $5 million in revenues in first year from China program; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: MEXICO: Death Again Ruled A Suicide; ARGENTINA: First Gay Union;.

headline: Foreign or Domestic? Not All Taxes on Dividends Are Equal
abstract: Mark Hulbert column on strategies used by international stock mutual funds to avoid withholding tax that many foreign governments levy on dividends paid to foreigners; graph (M)

headline: ArvinMeritor Extends Dana Bid But Doesn't Raise Offer Price
abstract: ArvinMeritor Inc extends its bid for rival auto parts maker Dana Corp through Oct 2, but does not raise its offer of $15 per share, or about $4.4 billion, for company; some analysts say that will make it difficult for Dana's shareholders to reconsider their earlier rejection of offer (M)

headline: MARATHON OIL TO CUT 265 JOBS IN REORGANIZATION
abstract: Marathon Oil Corp plans to cut 265 jobs, mostly at its Houston headquarters, and will close its Denver office to save more than $65 million per year (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Seiko Epson Returns To Profit
abstract: The Seiko Epson Corporation, one of Japan's biggest makers of printers, said it had earned 6 billion yen ($50.1 million) in the quarter to June, in part because of the demand for its color printers. The company, which recently completed a large share offering in Tokyo, lost 1 billion yen in the same period a year ago. Seiko Epson cut its full-year sales goal by 4.1 percent.   Ken Belson (NYT)

headline: The Danube Transformed: From River of Blood to River of Hope
abstract: First article of series, Down the Danube, examining past and present of countries along river that touches more lands and people than any other in Europe; most terrible events of 19th and 20th centuries occurred along Danube: two World Wars, Holocaust, imposition of Iron Curtain, transformation of eastern countries into poverty-stricken police states, outbreak of ethnic savagery in former Yugoslavia after collapse of Soviet empire; although countless acts of violence have taken place along its shores, Danube is changing, becoming different sort of symbol, no longer of European division but of tenuous but promising European unity, where wars of past have become inconceivable; photos; map (L)

headline: J. Lo and Affleck Finally Get Some Privacy
abstract: Movie Gigli, which stars Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck, is box-office disappointment, grossing only $3.8 million over opening weekend in face of scathing reviews; photo (M)

headline: A State Pursues WorldCom; Effects Seen On U.S. Case
abstract: Oklahoma charges WorldCom Inc and six of its former executives, including longtime chief executive Bernard J Ebbers, with 15 felony violations of state's securities laws; lawyers and analysts say charges are unlikely to slow WorldCom's efforts to emerge from bankruptcy under name MCI; some say state action threatens to disrupt federal efforts to prosecute crimes committed in $11 billion accounting scandal; charges are first to accuse company and Ebbers of criminal activity; other defendants named include former controller David F Myers, accounting director Buford Yates, and Troy M Normand and Betty L Vinson, who worked in WorldCom's accounting department; those four have already pleaded guilty to federal fraud and conspiracy charges and are cooperating in Justice Department's probe; fifth defendant Scott D Sullivan, former chief financial officer, is facing federal criminal charges but has pleaded not guilty and is set to go to trial; Oklahoma Atty Gen A W Drew Edmondson says state has not questioned any of individuals charged in complaint nor has it coordinated its work with federal investigators; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Grows
abstract: Brazil posts record trade surplus of $2.67 billion in August, pushing total surplus for year so far to more than $15 billion; exports in August were record $6.4 billion, while imports were $3.73 billion; graph (S)

headline: Text of European Competition Commission Statement on Microsoft
abstract: Text of a statement from the European Union's Competition Commission on the Microsoft case.

headline: BIN LADEN IS SEEN WITH AIDE ON TAPE
abstract: Osama bin Laden and his chief lieutenant Ayman al-Zawahiri appear in videotape broadcast by Al Jazeera, and in accompanying audiotape Zawahiri exhorts Iraqi resistance-fighters to 'bury' American troops in Iraq; Al Jazeera says video images were recorded in late Apr or early May; it shows bin Laden and Zawahiri, dressed in Afghan clothing, leisurely walking along rocky trails; bin Laden is shown carrying AK-47 assault rifle; possibility that tapes were made recently underscores concerns expressed by American intelligence officials in recent days about new surge of Islamic militancy in Iraq in response to American-led occupation; statement attributed to Zawahiri in audiotape is aimed directly at insurgents in Iraq; voice attributed to bin Laden refers to 'great damage to the enemy' on Sept 11, and mentions names of five of men who hijacked airliners that day; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says American-led campaign against Al Qaeda has hurt group's ability to recruit new members, raise money and communicate; photo (M)

headline: Martha Stewart Lawyer Seeks An Inquiry on Possible Leaks
abstract: Lawyers for Martha Stewart ask Judge Mi6

headline: TECO ENERGY TO SELL POWER PLANT
abstract: Teco Energy Inc, which is trying to avert credit-rating cut, sells power plant in Florida for $115 million to private equity firm GTCR Golden Rauner and Invenergy; buyers will assume plant's debt, which was $103 million on Dec 31 (S)

headline: BIDDER SWEETENS OFFER FOR ELDER-BEERMAN STORES
abstract: Elder-Beerman Stores Corp receives buyout offer of $81.6 million from Wright Holdings Inc, topping competing proposal from Bon-Ton Stores Inc (S)

headline: At Least 11 Die in Car Bombing at Jordan's Embassy in Baghdad
abstract: The attack, which also wounded more than 60, was the most violent of several incidents in Baghdad in the past 24 hours.

headline: North Korean Standoff Poses 'Greatest Threat,' Carter Says
abstract: Ex-Pres Jimmy Carter, after meeting with Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi, warns current standoff between United States and 'paranoid' North Korea over renewal of nuclear arms program is greatest threat to regional and global peace; notes North Korea has ability to destroy hundreds of thousands of lives and most of Seoul if war should come; urges it to renounce nuclear arms and use of violence in dealing with South Korea; is traveling to promote aid to Africa; says he has no plans to visit North Korea (M)

headline: Pope Struggles While Giving Speech in Slovakia
abstract: Pope John Paul II could not manage to deliver a message on Western Europe's drift from Christianity in his own voice.

headline: People
abstract: Tom Szczepanski is named senior vice president and managing director for Los Angeles operations of MediaVest USA, succeeding Ron Vazzano (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Government To Sell Stake
abstract: Taiwan plans to sell 3 percent stake in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co for as much as $45.9 billion ($1.4 billion); graph (S)

headline: Franco Modigliani, Nobel-Winning Economist, Dies at 85
abstract: Franco Modigliani, economist who received Nobel Prize for his pathbreaking explanations of how people save and role of debt in determining value of corporations, dies at age 85; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer's Profit Falls
abstract: Scottish & Newcastle PLC says full-year profit fell 29 percent; net income for fiscal year ended April 27 fell to 140.1 million pounds ($232 million) from 196.5 million pounds ($325 million) year earlier; operating profit at British beer division fell 8.9 percent; photo (S)

headline: Chinese Leader Cancels Communists' Seaside Retreat
abstract: Hu Jintao, China's newly installed president and Communist Party chief, cancels Chinese leaders' traditional August seaside retreat and orders leaders to sweat out summer at home; move seems equal parts public relations and back-room maneuvering; decision to end secretive meetings is Hu's most formal break with Communist tradition; it is his strongest signal that he intends to manage party affairs differently than his predecessor Jiang Zemin; party officials say Hu and Jiang and those loyal to them have been jockeying for influence in China's political system; Hu now generally gets more prominent mention in state-controlled news media than Jiang, but he is generally considered too cautious to challenge Jiang directly (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Pumatech To Acquire Synchrologic For $60 Million
abstract: Pumatech Inc acquires Synchrologic Inc for about $60 million (S)

headline: I.B.M. Meets Expectations for Quarter
abstract: IBM meets Wall Street's earnings expectations for second quarter; reports net income of $1.73 billion compared to $445 million year earlier; revenues from continuing operations were $21.63 billion, up 10.1 percent from $19.65 billion year ago; software sales rose 6 percent, to $3.5 billion; chief financial officer John R Joyce and chairman-chief executive Samuel J Palmisano comment; photo (M)

headline: Guilty Plea Expected in HealthSouth Case
abstract: HealthSouth Corp former vice president Catherine Fowler pleads guilty as part of $2.5 billion accounting fraud probe; investigation is centering on former chief executive Richard Scrushy, who has not been charged (M)

headline: C.I.A. Thinks bin Laden Made Tape, Though It's Uncertain When
abstract: An analysis has concluded that the voice on a tape represented as that of Osama bin Laden is probably authentic.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Official Hired Killer
abstract: Former Czech Republic Foreign Minister Karel Srba is sentenced to eight years in prison for attempting to kill journalist Sabina Slonkova, who had exposed his participation in financial scam with her articles in Mlada Fronta Dnes daily newspaper; plan was derailed when Karel Rziepel, who was hired to blow up reporter's car, told police of plan (S)

headline: France and Germany Tie Troops for Iraq to a U.N. Mandate
abstract: The issue of broader international military assistance in pacifying and rebuilding Iraq is an awkward one for the Bush administration.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Mudd Jeans names RJ Palmer Media Services to handle media planning and buying on its ad account (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Australia: Another Bank Bidder
abstract: Wesl

headline: Economic Scene; The Supreme Court finds the 'mushball middle' on affirmative action.
abstract: Alan B Krueger Economic Scene column on affirmative action in college admissions; discusses earnings outlook for blacks in light of Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's stand in University of Michigan Law School case that racial preferences will no longer be needed for diversity in 25 years; cites studies that show 40 to 60 percent of gap in earnings between particular individual and average worker is closed from one generation to next; sees no evidence to support Justice Clarence Thomas's stand that attending top colleges harms minority students; photo (M)

headline: Raising Ship a Tricky Job for Dutch Company
abstract: Smit Salvage of Rotterdam is undertaking to salvage Norwegian-registered ship, Tricolor, which sank late last year in English channel with its load of 2,871 BMW's, Volvos and Saabs, worth about $40 million; photos (M)

headline: Illinois Judge Again Orders Philip Morris to Pay $12 Billion Bond
abstract: Illinois Circuit Court Judge Nicholas Byron orders Philip Morris USA to post $12 billion bond while appealing March smoking liability decision; appellate court ruled in July that Byron erred in reducing appeal bond by half and permitting it to be secured with note rather than cash; company to appeal (M)

headline: G.O.P. Senator Criticizes Bush On Liberia Case
abstract: Sen John Warner, Republican chairman of Armed Services Committee, criticizes Bush administration for preparing plans to send US troops to Liberia without making convincing case to Congress, which is in recess; comments on Senate floor after Pentagon abruptly cancels detailed briefing; charges administration is not adhering to doctrine of spelling out risks and national interest involved; remarks by usually staunch Bush ally come as two of three Navy ships carrying 2,300 marines are set to arrive off Liberian coast (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Antiterror Exercises
abstract: Shanghai Cooperation Organization, made up of China, Russia, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan, hold antiterrorism drill involving more than 1,000 troops (S)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: President Quits Party; CHINA: North Korea Refugees Secretly Ousted;.

headline: Case That Crawled Through Courts Returns to Go
abstract: Federal Appeals Court orders new trial to settle 1987 dispute over tons of Colombian coffee that failed to arrive in New York; nullifies 1997 decision in case because presiding Judge Milton Pollack belatedly disclosed that he and his wife and trust that benefited her owned at least $250,000 in stock in Chase Manhattan Bank, one of half dozen banks suing insurer for reimbursement; KMZ Rosenman lawyer Henry L Goodman, who has been working on lawsuit from beginning, first on behalf of Chemical Bank, then for its successor, Chase, part of J P Morgan Chase, says thought of doing this over in case that has been going on for more than 16 years is daunting; case, with legal fees estimated to be at least $20 million so far, could continue for another two or three years; court documents show nearly $100 million worth of coffee was not lost but never existed; export company, owned by prominent Colombian family, issued fraudulent documents indicating coffee was shipped, and banks, thinking deliveries had been made, immediately paid bills; banks say exporter falsified documents for about 200,000 bags of coffee and eventually one member of Colombian family pleaded guilty in Miami to criminal charges of fraud; banks filed suit in 1987; about half of deal had been insured by syndicates or companies at Lloyd's of London and they settled 10 years ago for about $25 million; Affiliated FM Insurance Co continued to fight; Pollack decided case in banks' favor six years ago and awarded them $92 million; insurance companies appealed; court disqualified Pollack three years ago, returned case to him with instructions to adjust amount of money; Pollack reduced award to $70 million; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Prime Minister Puts His Position on the Line
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas challenged the Palestinian parliament today to back his agenda or dissolve his government.

headline: Real cure is based on plant that grows along China's rivers
abstract: GUILIN, China:—  Artesunate may be considered the modern miracle cure for malaria, but the drug has the humble heritage of a traditional herbal extract used to treat fevers in China for more than 2,000 years.

headline: DataBank; Stocks Go Sideways, but Bonds Tumble
abstract: Financial markets' performance in week of July 14-18 noted; tables; graphs (S)

headline: A Shifting Spotlight on Uranium Sales
abstract: News analysis: White House is using curious defense of Pres Bush's State of Union speech regarding reference to intelligence report alleging Saddam Hussein was seeking uranium in Africa; says Bush's top aides acknowledge that Bush cited dubious intelligence and admit that vetting process for his speech failed, while arguing that history may yet prove him right; says it plays to central argument that Bush and aides have used to try to quiet growing political storm: that Hussein posed urgent threat, no matter what was going on about uranium sale (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BG Net Income Increases
abstract: BG Group says its second-quarter net income increased 191 percent, to 160 million pounds ($260 million) (S)
