headline: Mismatched Conditions In the U.S. Economy
abstract: Jason Knapp letter on Sept 14 article blames failure of demand to keep pace with rising productivity on 'offshoring' of large numbers of skilled and service jobs

headline: Fed Chief Gives Bright Outlook; Cuts an Option
abstract: Alan Greenspan tells Congress that Federal Reserve is prepared to hold interest rates low as long as necessary to spur economic growth, discounting speculation that rate cannot be lowered much beyond current 1 percent; offers unexpectedly upbeat forecast that ignites bond market selloff; presents sunny indicators and praises Pres Bush's tax cuts for increasing household income and spending, but assures lawmakers that interest rates will not be raised during 'fragile' recovery; photo; irritated Democrats demand he reconcile outlook with reality of growing unemployment (M)

headline: BARNES & NOBLE BUYS BERTELSMANN STAKE IN DOT-COM
abstract: BarnesandNoble.com Inc shares rise 16 percent after Barnes & Noble Inc agrees to buy Bertelsmann's 37 percent stake in Internet bookseller for about $164 million; Barnes & Noble will own 75 percent of company (S)

headline: MediaTalk; ABC's Revamping of 'This Week' May Start With a Name Change
abstract: Tom Bettag, new executive producer of ABC's Sunday morning public-affairs show This Week, weighs changing program's name and format; program will continue to revolve around interview with major newsmaker; photo (M)

headline: Travel Industry Fears New Rules Could Deter Visits to U.S.
abstract: Travel Industry Assn warns that new security measures intended to prevent terrorists from entering US will likely deter foreign tourists, who will have to submit to interviews and carry computer-readable passports (M)

headline: FPL AGREES TO BUY HALF OF AMERGEN FROM BRITISH ENERGY
abstract: FPL Group acquires British Energy's 50 percent stake in AmerGen Energy for $276.5 million; AmerGen owns Three Mile Island Unit 1 nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania and two other US reactors; plants have capacity to generate 2,480 megawatts; Exelon, which owns other half, has 30 days to match bid (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cuts At Electronics Maker
abstract: Electronics manufacturer Matsushita Electric Industrial plans to shut three factories in Japan by March 2004 as part of cost-cutting effort; production and workers will be shifted to other Japanese factories (S)

headline: Ex-Premier Goes on Trial in Paris on Party Graft Charges
abstract: Alain Juppé, a former prime minister, went on trial today over illegal payments by French companies to employees of President Jacques Chiracs former political party.

headline: Blair Defends Iraq War at Party Meeting
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he had no question that his decision to go to war in Iraq was right.

headline: Tax Policy That Uses Economies Of Scales
abstract: Daniel Altman Economic View column suggests using basic principles of economics to address growing problem of obesity in US; proposes that Americans be assessed lump-sum tax to fund individual cash awards for those registering normal weights throughout year; chart (M)

headline: A Tutor With the Textbook Key Unleashes Your Inner Einstein
abstract: Web site hotmath.com offers grade-specific math tutorials for students; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Help For Lenders
abstract: Thai government is nearing completion of plan to allow commercial banks to write down $17.3 billion in bad debt; banks currently list 21 percent of loans as nonperforming (S)

headline: Israel Rejects Wide Criticism of Its Threat to Exile Arafat
abstract: Israel fends off worldwide criticism of its decision in principle to oust Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, even though it seems unlikely for now to carry out threat; Israeli analysts see threat intended at least in part to address public anger at two suicide bombings; Prime Min Ariel Sharon has strong public support in Israel for removing him; photos (M)0

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Steady
abstract: Number of jobless in Germany remained at 4.4 million, or 10.6 percent of work force, in August, raising hopes for recovery of job market after slightly declining numbers in two previous months (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Deal Said to Be Reached In Inquiry on Failed Insurer  Crédit Lyonnais and a corporation run by the French government have agreed to plead guilty and pay hundreds of millions of dollars to settle a federal investigation into the takeover of a failed California insurance company, people close to the situation said.    The matter stems from the collapse of Executive Life, a California insurance company, in 1991 after its extensive portfolio of junk bonds lost much of their value. Crédit Lyonnais acquired the junk bond portfolio for about $3 billion, and other French investors acquired the insurance business. [Page C4.]

headline: A Chance For Utilities To Clean Up Their Act
abstract: Interview with John C Kohli, manager of Franklin Utilities fund, on his post-blackout views of utility companies; says his fund is sticking with its investment in FirstEnergy, Ohio utility at center of investigations into power failure; photo (M)

headline: Will Anyone Throw Money, Lots of It, at a Glass House?
abstract: Chalan Farm, 35,000-square-foot glass house built by electronics magnate John Boulton on 48 acres in Franklin Township, NJ, is expected to sell after year on market; asking price is $12 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Arrest In Threat To Poison Water Supply
abstract: German police arrest man suspected of planning to poison Einbeck (Germany) water supply with cyanide after tracing two threatening letters to man's home and finding 110 pounds of poison in his basement (S)

headline: Boeing Is Said to Have Won Major Order From AirTran
abstract: AirTran Airways reaches agreement with Boeing Co to buy 50 narrow-body jets with options to purchase 50 more; deal is valued at list price of $4 billion, though planes are almost always sold at discount; most of 50 planes are 737-700's, and some are larger 737-800 models (M)

headline: Trying to Set Up Democracy in a Divided Kurdish Region
abstract: Difficulty of establishing pluralistic political system in Iraq is seen in northern Kurdish region, which is now divided in two, each run by single political party that permits no dissent and uses torture, killings and kidnappings to achieve political goals; faltering experiment with democracy is example of how patronage and tribal allegiances crowd out rule of law; photo of Goran Salih, journalist who says he was reprimanded for writing acticle critical of Kurdish Democratic Party

headline: A Nero Wolfe in C.P.A.'s Clothing
abstract: Alison Leigh Cowan reviews Christopher Reich novel The Devil's Banker; photo (M)

headline: Fired Auditors Questioned SureBeam's Revenue Policy
abstract: SureBeam Corp, which last week fired its audit firm Deloitte & Touche, says Deloitte questioned company's basic method of recognizing revenue as well as two specific transactions (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mine Strike Set
abstract: South Africa's National Union of Mineworkers says more than 160,000 gold and coal workers will strike beginning July 27; talks between union and South African Chamber of Mines broke down over pay, retirement benefits and job grading; AngloGold and coal companies Xstrata, Kangra and AfriOre have made new proposals through Chamber of Mines and are exempted from strike call while union considers their offers (S)

headline: Officials Say U.S. Troops' Role Will Be Small
abstract: Bush administration officials hail arrival of Nigerian peacekeeping forces in Liberia, but caution that conditions are not yet right for US forces to land; add that US military role would be extremely limited in any case, confined to logistics, intelligence and communications for African or UN peacekeepers, and provided rescue could be effected quickly; Sec Donald Rumsfeld explains policy (M)

headline: 3 at Hamilton Bancorp Charged With Fraud
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission charges Hamilton Bancorp officers Eduardo Masferrer, Juan Carlos Bernace and John M R Jacobs with hiding losses at Hamilton Bank unit in order to overstate income in news releases and SEC filings; bank was shut down by regulators in 2002 (S)

headline: Union Given Deadline in Goodyear Talks
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co says that if it does not reach agreement on contract with Steelworkers of America by Aug 15, it will begin announcing plans to lower costs (S)

headline: Kodak Shifts Direction and Slashes Its Dividend
abstract: This is the first time since the company was founded in 1880 that it has cut dividends. It also plans to concentrate the companys future efforts on digital markets.

headline: One-Handed Keyboard Skimps on Space but Not Function
abstract: FrogPad introduces one-handed keyboard that uses keystroke combinations to perform all standard functions delivered by standard key board; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Opposition Gains
abstract: Zanu-PF, Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe's governing political party, loses council seats and mayoral elections to opposition Movement for Democratic Change (S)

headline: Turkey Says U.S. Has Agreed to Free 11 Soldiers Suspected in Plot to Kill Kurdish Aide
abstract: Senior Turkish official, speaking on condition of anonymity, says American forces in Iraq have agreed to release 11 Turkish soldiers held in unusual diplomatic standoff, even as American officials accuse soldiers of plotting to kill American-backed Iraqi official; State Dept official says two sides are trying to arrange speedy release, while beginning what he says would be joint American-Turkish investigation into Turkish troops' activities in Iraq and their detention; although Turkish government declined to take part in American-led invasion of Iraq, it has been sending troops into northern Iraq since end of Persian Gulf war in 1991, largely to pursue Kurdish guerrillas there; Pres Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Vice Pres Dick Cheney reportedly hold telephone conversation on matter; photo (M)

headline: Demystifying Medicine
abstract: Essay by Dr Herbert Pardes, president of New York Presbyterian Hospital, on his early career and training; photo (S)

headline: Business; Coming Soon to a Theater Near You: The Moviemercial
abstract: Some studios, instead of releasing toys and games tied to movie, are starting with product and figuring out film later; are betting that films built around well-known brands will win back customers from video games and Internet; toymakers see such films as needed new realm for advertising; photos (M)

headline: Verizon Reduces Profit Forecast As Demand Falls and Costs Rise
abstract: Verizon Communications Inc reduces its 2003 profit forecast on disappointing demand from business customers and increased costs from new labor agreement (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Carmaker Expects A Loss
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors forecasts first-half loss as result of car loan defaults and slumping sales in North America (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against Japanese yen after industry report shows consumer confidence unexpectedly fell in August; dollar settles at 118.40 yen, down from 119.49 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: OPEC Unfazed by Prospects For Renewed Flow of Iraqi Oil
abstract: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, preparing to meet, Vienna, is expected to do nothing to respond to likely resumption of steady flow of Iraqi oil exports; stance indicates OPEC's relative comfort with and confidence in relatively high price of oil, which has surpassed $25 a barrel for most of year, and its skepticism about whether Iraq can sustain 600,000 to 650,000 barrels a day its officials predict; few analysts expect serious price drop when Iraq returns to market (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Tax Repeal Considered
abstract: Thailand says it might allow overseas investors to buy local bonds and abolish 15 percent withholding tax on interest paid to bondholders, in bid to increase trading in bonds and persuade Asian naitons to buy more of one another's debt (S)
